A meeting of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Committee was held at No. 41 Grove-street last evening, ex-Alderman John W. Jacobus presiding. George B. Deane, Jr., moved that it be "the sense of the committee that John J. O'Brien was not the choice of the committee for Chairman of the County Committee."

RICHMOND, Va., March 3.--Michael Ellick, a dry goods merchant in the lower part of this city, was fatally shot this morning by his son, Moses M. The young man fired four shots at his father, two of which took effect in his...

The evidence given before the Senate Committee on Public Health during the last few days is not encouraging to consumers of butter. There are two wellknown compounds which masquerade as butter; of these, one is called butterine and the other oleomargarine.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3.--The last hope of saving the neck of John McGinnis has been abandoned, and he will be executed in one of the corridors of Moyamensing Prison to-morrow. McGinnis murdered his mother-in-law, Mrs. Reed...
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 3.--The Rev. C.S. Smith, formerly for Pittsburg, but now of Bloomington, Ill., and Chariman of the colored men's State Central Committee in that State, is in the city.

UTICA, N.Y., March 3.--All of the owners of property destroyed by fire on Sunday announce their purpose to rebuild immediately. A proposition under consideration by the landowners to unite in erecting one massive block to...

Property on the line of Lexington-avenue, aggregating in value over $2,000,000, was represented before the Board of Street-opening, which met in the Mayor's office yesterday morning, among the owners of property present being E. Ellery Anderson, George H. Chapman, F. R. Houghton, Julius Lipman, John R. Flanagan,...

BERLIN, March 3.--The German Ministerial organs associate the alliance of Russia, Germany, and Austria with a coming league of the Continental powers against the maritime and commercial preponderance of England.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3.--The report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for 1883 shows the gross earnings of the Pennsylvania Railroad Division, main line and branches, Pittsburg to Philadelphia, to have been $32,017,813...

Last night in hauling in the Times's office flag, which had been floating at half-mast in memory of Gov. Hubbard, the flag was torn from the rope, the end of which flew to the top of the staff, 30 feet from the roof.
President Arthur has made a mess of it in Pennsylvania by the nomination for Pension Agent at Philadelphia of Mr. John M. Vanderslice, the Cameron-Quay candidate for that office.
SUAKIN, March 3.--Gen. Gordon will send the Egyptian troops found at Tokar to join the garrison at Suakin.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 3.--John L. Campbell, of Clarion County, undergoing a two years' sentence in the Allegheny County Workhouse, escaped last night by digging through an 18-inch brick wall.

Postmaster Pearson yesterday issued instructions to the Superintendents and clerks employed in the Money-order Division of the Post Office that in future all persons applying for payment of a money-order must be required...

It is reported that the London police are not very hopeful of finding the authors of the explosion at the Victoria Station. "The clues," they say, "are not very promising." It would be hard to find a case in which criminals had been more profuse and considerate in leaving clues to their own identity in the hands of the police.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 3.--At a meeting in this city to-day the Keystone Base-ball Association, representing clubs at Chester, Lancaster, York, Carlisle, West Chester, and Littlestown, was formed. The playing rules of the American Association were adopted and the President was authorized to sign the National agreement.

At the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening the farcical comedy of "The Member for Slocum" was produced in the place of "Warranted," and Mr. Nat C. Goodwin was again afforded an opportunity of showing how clever and amusing a comedian he is.

Col. Joseph Cushing, one of the oldest circus managers in this country, died on his farm near Dover, N.H., yesterday. He had been suffering severely with rheumatism for a number of years, but was able to be about until a few years ago, when he was confined to his bed. On Sunday he burst a blood-vessel in his head, and from the effects of this he died.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 3.--Specials from Bismarck, Jamestown, and Fargo show that March came in with a blizzard that throws all its predecessors this year into insignificance. There was heavy snow all Saturday night, and yesterday morning the wind began blowing 40 to 50...

The Republican State Committee will meet in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel at noon to-day for the purpose of fixing a date for the State Convention and a place in which to hold the convention. Few members of the committee were in the city last night.
One of the most important sales to bookcollectors that has ever occurred in the country began yesterday in George A. Leavitt Co.'s auction-rooms in Clinton Hall.
LONDON, March 4.--The steam-ship Erl King. (Br.,) Capt. Denham, from New-Orieans Jan. 15, has arrest Liverpool.
At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Church Temperance Society yesterday a petition was adopted urging the passage of the Roosevelt high license bill.
ST. LOUIS, March 3.--The suit of Henry Oberbeck against Christian Von der Ahe was tried in the Circuit Court here to-day. Oberbeck was a member of last year's Allegheny and Peoria Base-ball Clubs.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3.--The Citizens' Committee of One Hundred, who, during the four years past have done good work in purifying the municipal offices in this city, appears to be greatly discouraged by the defeat of all their...

BOSTON, March 3.--A mass-meeting of Harvard students was held this evening in Holden Chapel, Cambridge, to take action upon the recent action of the Harvard Faculty in adopting resolutions restricting athletic sports.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 3.--Mr. Lowe, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture, reiterates the statement made a few days ago as to the worthlessness of Chief Nimm's statistics with regard to the influx of Canadians into the...
After court hours yesterday, Mr. Anthony Comstock, who had a warrant granted by Justice Daffy, made a descent on the publishing house of Mr. Frank Tousey, at No. 3t North Moore-street.
"Put that man out; he's been drinking and makes too much noise," said Justice Patterson yesterday afternoon at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

The Star prints the following: "The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee will meet at the Arlington Hotel to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock to complete its organization. Since the adjournment of the caucus the following additional members have been named:

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 3.--The miners' troubles are gradually being settled, and in the first pool all the mines are at work at the district price, with the exception of the Fawcett and Munhall mine.

The Irving Hall General Committee held its first meeting for 1884 last evening. While the Chairman was informing the delegates that that organization existed solely to benefit the public, and did not banker after patronage, other leaders of the party were distributing among the reporters copies of a set of resolutions denouncing...

There is trouble among the druggists, due to the fact that certain druggists, ` moved possibly by compunctions of conscience, but probably by a desire to attract customers, have begun to sell drugs at prices lower than those of other druggists.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., March 3.--The ship Donald McKay, of Bremerhaven, Capt. Welden, from New-York for Bremen, with a cargo of 15,000 barrels of oil, arrived here on Saturday evening with eight feet of water in the hold and leaking six inches per hour.

That familiar and always agreeable vagabond, Conn the Shaughraun, made his reappearance in this city last evening at the New Park Theatre. Perhaps this play cannot aspire to the distinction of being intrinsically the best that Mr. Boucicault ever wrote, but it certainly...

ALBANY, March 3.--Attorney-General O'Brien this afternoon rendered a decision granting the application of Charles J. Ryan, Charles Peterson, and James R. Young, creditors of the North River Construction Company, that he (the Attorney-General) make a motion in the Supreme Court to remove Ashbel Green, Receiver of...
The value of the Supreme Court lies in the fact that through its decisions questions as to the meaning of the Constitution which it would be dangerous to leave unsettled may be determined.

Furs are about to be put away until the advent of another Winter, but notwithstanding this their price continues to advance, and the trade in them, which at this season is ordinarily dull, is still brisk.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 3.--The courtship of A.F. Seanlon, a young postman, and Eva Underhill, a winsome brunette, almost culminated in a tragedy on Franklin-avenue to-day. Miss Underhill is guarded by her stepfather, Thomas Hetzel. She has had many suitors, but she preferred Scanlon, who has recently been appointed postman.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 3.--The veto of the Prison Commission bill was so generally anticipated that the appearance of Col. Lamont in the Assembly to-night bearing the blue-ribboned document itself created no surprise and but very little attention.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 3.--John McGreevy, sexton of St. Pius's Catholic Church, was found dead in bed at his boarding-house this morning.

On Feb. 24 a dispatch to THE TIMES announced that in pursuance of a plan to capture a Logan Mississippian the President would appoint Col. W.F. Fitzgerald to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court for Arizona.

ELKTON, Penn., March 3.--Finley Small is an employe of the Sugar Run tannery, in this village, and boards with a family named Jordan. Elizabeth Galloway, aged 19, has worked as a servant in the family for several years. Last week Mrs. Jordan's father died, and the family...

At the meeting of the Kings County Democratic General Committee last evening, at Music Hall, Brooklyn, the long faction fight over the Thirteenth and Seventeenth Ward contests was finally decided by dismissing the charges of irregularity preferred...
BERLIN, March 3.--The speech from the throne at the opening of the Reichstag, which will be received on Thursday, will advocate the completion of the measures for social reform.

President Sloan, of the Delaware, Lackawanna and western Railroad, announces in a circular the following appointments: B.A. Hegeman, Traffic Manager; William S. Sloan, General Freight Agent; W.F. Holwill, General Passenger Agent.
BOSTON, March 4.--The Harvard Faculty, at its meeting this afternoon, voted "to instruct the Committee on Athletics to notify the Conference (of colleges) on Inter-collegiate Contests...

ATLANTA, Ga., March 4.--An active canvass to promote the nomination of Mr. Tilden for the Presidency by the Chicago Convention is now going on in the State, and has aroused general enthusiasm. There never was a time since 1876 when any other names could evoke the...

UTICA, N.Y., March 4.--Democratic Utica elects James S. Sherman (Rep.) Mayor by about 1,200 majority over Lewis H. Shattuck. This astonishing result was helped on the one hand by Mr. Sherman's personal popularity and on the other by the cry against Mr. Shattuck, who is a manufacturer, that his firm at one time or another employed Italian cheap labor. The Mayor-elect is a son of Gen. Richard U. Sherman.

SANDUSKY, March 4.--To-night William McMillan, a farmer living near Huron, in this county, murdered George Thompson, aged 20, a neighbor. McMillan was drunk, and had had a quarrel with his wife, who screamed for help.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 4.--At the unveiling of the soldiers' and sailors' monument here on the coming Fourth of July Stewart L. Woodford has been invited to deliver the address. The seventh and Twenty-third New-York Regiments, also companies from Rochester, Utica, Troy, and other places, are expected, and the arrangements for decorating the city and having a gala time will be on a magnificent scale.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 4.--Detectives Crawford and Schnuks made what then regard as an important arrest to-night in the person of Dan Flanagan. They think that he is a wellknown robber who recently escaped from the...
ALBANY, N.Y., March 4.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following decisions were handed down; Morton A. Brown, respondent, vs. William F. Mandeville, appellant: William J. Callahan, Executor, ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 4.--Mr. J. W. Longley, member for Annapolis, has given notice in the house of Assembly that at a future day he will move a resolution to the elect that a union of the Provinces of Nova Scotia, NewBrunswick, and Prince Edward Island into one Province, on a fair basis, would be advantageous to the common interests of all.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 4.--The Winter race meeting was continued to-day. The track was in good condition.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., March 4.--Six months ago merchants of this and neighboring towns began to find among their cash receipts sundry pieces of coin, of every denomination, from 50 cents to 5 cents, which the bankers denounced as counterfeit.

Large fields of heavy ice appeared in the harbor early yesterday morning, and for several hours impeded navigation considerably. The ice was quite thick, and it was extremely difficult for the ferry-boats to force their way through the fields.

Mrs. Kate A. Cunningham, of No. 239 Bleecker-street, was attacked by a footpad yesterday afternoon, who attempted to rob her while she was walking alone on the Boulevard near Sixty-eighth-street. Mrs. Cunningham is a brave woman, and the robber met his match when he attacked her. She is about 35 years of age, robust and muscular.

The committee appointed by the Mott Memorial Hall Conference of Independent Republicans met in the office of Gen. Francis C. Barlow yesterday afternoon, Carl Schurz, Sigismund Kauffman, Joseph W. Harper, Alfred T. White, ...

ST. LOUIS, March 4.--The Globe-Democrat states: "That the Atchinson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad has declared war against the Western trunk line alliance by cutting Colorado rates $1.77 on first class freight, and proportionally on other classes which is 90 cents below Commissioner Vining's late order on first class freight."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 4.--At a late hour Sunday night Carl Steiner, who has heretofore borne an excellent reputation, accompanied Miss Louise Mechel from one of the German theatres to her home on the north side.

Detective Sergeant Thomas Adams returned from Boston yesterday without Matthew Callahan, the book agent, who was arrested in that city for an alleged brutal assault upon Ella Everett, the daughter of a lamp-lighter living in One Hundred and Ninth-street, an account of which has appeared in THE TIMES.

POTTSTOWN, Penn., March 4.--A fire broke out in the gymnasium of Prof. John Meiggs's Young Men's Seminary, near Pottstown, about 3 o'clock this afternoon. The building was a frame structure, situated about 20 feet from the large stone seminary.

ALBANY, March 4.--According to the semi-annual reports of the savings banks of New-York made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department the number of banks in operation in that city is the same as during the preceding year--25--although one of the number (the Equitable) is practically closed, having received no deposits for years. The number of banks in operation in the State...

The present Congress cannot be accused of saving at the spigot and wasting at the bung-hole. On the contrary, it has pulled out the former and opened wide the latter, and is doing its best to empty the Treasury by both orifices.

The Republican State Committee at its meeting yesterday agreed upon Utica as the place and April 23 as the time for holding the State Convention to choose delegates at large to the National Convention. This will give ample time and opportunity for holding separate conventions in the Congressional districts.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 4.--The funeral services over the body of the late Minister Hunt took place to-day at the American Church. The coffin, wrapped in the Stars and Stripes, was conveyed to the church by a hearse drawn by six horses.
DES MOINES, Iowa, March 4.--The results of the city elections in Iowa show no special deviation from previous years, party lines, being always less closely drawn than at the State elections.

DES MOINES, March 4.--Mrs. Florence Miller, Secretary of the Iowa Women's Christian Temperance Union, says that while that organization will hardly resort to the method of the crusade to enforce the new prohibitory law, there will be an active continuous effort to keep it vital.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 4.--The new Board of Directors of the Indianapolis and St. Louis Railroad Company met in this city to-day and organized by the election of J.H. Devereux, President; Stevenson Bark, Vice-President; ...

SCRANTON, Penn., March 1.--The political wire-pullers of this section are actively at work endeavoring to defeat the popular district method of selecting delegates to the Republican National Convention, although the sentiment of the people is overwhelmingly in favor of such a...

BOSTON, March 4.--The report of the United States Local Inspectors, Andrew Burnham and Andrew J. Savage, on the City of Columbus investigation was completed late this afternoon and was forwarded to the Supervising Inspector-General in New-York to-night.

LONDON, March 4.--The Croydon March meeting began to-day. The international hurdle race (handicap) was won by Mr. W. Gregory's 4-year-old ch. g. Chicard. Mr. Cannon's (formerly Mr. Lorillard's) 5-year-old ch. h. Sachem came in second, and Lord Howe's 5-year-old b.h. Frency third. There were 11 starters. Chicard won by four lengths.
OIL CITY, Penn., March 4.--The following circular signed by the highest officials of the National Transit Company and United Pipe Lines will be published to-morrow in the Derrick.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 4.--Four mine accidents, two of which were fatal, occurred at Drifton to-day. August Gosso, an Italian laborer, at No. 2 Slope, was struck by a mine locomotive and fatally injured; George Bud was kicked by a mule in the abdomen and died soon afterward: Michael Cosco, a Hungarian laborer, was seriouly injured as was also Thomas Morgan.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 4.--A current of excitement has flashed over the State to-night in consequence of a red-hot row between Gov. Waller and Judge Birdsall in the Executive Chamber at Hartford to-day, while the Legislature was in session.

ALBANY, Ga., March 4.--Ringing of bells and beating of drums by the drum corps of the Albany Guards called the members of that company to their hall, and rumors were at once circulated of a negro rising throughout the county.

The arrangements for the visit to England, Ireland, and Scotland of a representative team of Philadelphia gentlemen cricketers are nearly completed. The team has now been a month in training under the supervision of Mr. Daniel S. Newhall, of the Young America Cricket Club, who is leaving no stone unturned...

A solemn pontifical mass of requiem was celebrated in the Church of St. Boniface, in Second-avenue, yesterday morning, for the repose of the soul of the Right Rev. Mgr. Louis E. Hostlot, late Rector of the American College at Rome, Italy.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 4.--A curious counterfeiting case was heard before United States Commissioner Bradford to-day. The prisoners, Daniel Feaster and his wife and Charles Arnold and his wife, were held in $1,000 bail each...

A large audience attended the Commencement exercises of the ninth year of the American Veterinary College last night at Chickering Hall. Samuel Marsh, President of the Board of Trustees, conferred the degree of ...
Detroit will have a pool tournament this month. The entries are Frey, Malone, King, Sutton, Lambert, Shaw, Leonard, Dankelman, and a few new players. The prizes will amount to $700.

RICHMOND, Va., March 4.--The resolution recently--introduced in the Virginia Senate by Mr. Kerner, inquiring into the expediency of establishing an experimental colony for colored people, has attracted very general attention.
There seems to be no doubt that the relations between the Faculty and the undergraduates of Princeton have been seriously strained by the recent policy of the governing body.

The opponents to the Rev. Dr. Newman were happy yesterday over the statements of Trustee Nicoll, at the meeting of the Trustees, Monday night, in regard to the finances of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church. Besides the $4,000 due the Ladies' Aid Association, interest...

A deputation of the owners of property on Washington Heights called on Commissioner Thompson, of the Department of Public Works, yesterday, to urge him to use his best efforts to secure improvements to the streets and avenues in that district.

The Mutual Trust Company was organized in 1868 under the title of the Public Exchange, and with extraordinary privileges granted by the Legislature. In the exercise of one of these privileges in 1880, it organized the American Mining Stock Exchange.

Seabury C. Magill applied to Justice Naeher yesterday for a warrant for the arrest of his wife, Minnie Magill. At an examination on Monday Mrs. Magill pleaded not guilty to a charge of abducting her two children, and agreed to appear for examination on Friday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 4.--There is considerable stir in commercial circles over the appointment of Albert Antisdel, of this city, as General Superintendent of the North-western Division of the American Express Company and the announcement that the division head-quarters are to be changed at once from Chicago to Milwaukee.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 4.--The Democrats of the Fourth Legislative District of this county have instructed their delegates to the State Convention to support Eckley B. Coxe for delegate at large to the National Convention, and to support Randall for President. This is the first ball for Randall in a county giving 2,000 Democratic majority.

The Jersey cow Princess II., No. 8,046, owned by S.M. Shoemaker, of Baltimore, has recently completed the largest test of butter for the period of one week that has ever been recorded. The cow gave birth to a calf late in December last, and her milk immediately showed signs of...

Mr. Jackson, the joint agent of the railway lines doing business in Castle Garden, stated yesterday afternoon that the West Shore Railway had entered the immigrant pool. Its share had not been determined.
WASHINGTON, March 4.--The following is a copy of a bill introduced by Senator Sherman to-day granting copyright to newspapers:

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 4.--This forenoon, John Johnson, a Swede, shot and killed his wife and then killed himself with the same revolver. Johnson was of a very jealous turn and recently has his neighbor arrested for attempting...

WASHINGTON, March 4.--First Lieut. Joseph H. Dorst, Fourth Cavalry, has been ordered to report to Col. William B. Royall, Fourth Cavalry, President of the board appointed to meet in this city by special orders of Feb. 9, for duty as Recorder of the board.

BOSTON, March 4.--The latest report about Butler's plans is that the Butler Republicans in this State are talking of having a National Independent Republican Convention, to nominate their leader for the Presidency.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 4.--William Nichols, who was fatally shot by Edwin Botheras at Hazleton on Saturday evening, died of his injuries at 2 o'clock this morning.

The Brooklyn savings bank reports for Jan. 1, 1884, show that the total resources of the savings banks of Kings County were $83,747,503, of which $13,621,618 was invested in bonds and mortgages and $59,540,025 in stocks; $2,040,175 ...
A ball and amateur concert will be given at Delmonico's on March 14 in behalf of Hebrew charities.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 4.--Robert E. Miller committed suicide at Pierce's Sanitarium here to-day from melancholia. From papers found on his person he is supposed to have come from Fort Assiniboine, Montana, and to have been the Quartermaster's clerk: also that his home was Pellville. Ky.

The Inspectors and Captains of Police met with Superintendent Walling, at Police Head-quarters, last night, and spent three hours in discussing the subject of a pension bill, which it is expected the Legislature will pass during the present session.
In the Surrogate's Court, yesterday, exSecretary William M. Evarts spoke from 11 o'clock until 4 in behalf of the proponents in the contest over the codicil to the will of the late James Stokes.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--The Danville riot investigation was resumed to-day. J. J. Verser, (white,) a Deputy--Collector of Internal Revenue, said that about 10 days or two weeks before the election he was passing a store, when Mr. Graves, its proprietor, stopped him and began talking politics.
Victor Hugo has forwarded to the poor relief authorities of Paris the sum of $1,000, to be used in giving aid to persons in arrears with their rent.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--Representatives Reed and Boutelle, of Maine, and Cutcheon, of Michigan, made arguments before the Ways and Means Committee to-day in opposition to the placing of lumber on the free list. Mr. Reed. in behalf of the Maine delegation, presented some figures showing the injury which such an act would cause.
The Bartholdi Statue Committee, with the exception of Mr. Parke Godwin, met at Mr. Joseph W. Drexel's house, No. 103 Madisonavenue, last night, and opened six bids for building the pedestal.
The one hundred and seventh anniversary of the birth of Robert Emmet, the Irish potriot, was celebrated by 3,000 people, under the auspices of the Clan-na-Gael, in Cooper Institute last evening.

At the opening of the meeting last evening of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic of this city, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, the death of Richard C. Morgan, late Commander of ...
OTTAWA, Ontario, March 4.--It is reported that a private letter has been received from a member of the Manitoba Government statin that Premier Norquay has resolved to...

HUDSON, N.Y., March 4.--Henry A. Tilden, who is a brother of the Hon. Samuel J. Tilden and has been confined to this home at New-Lebanon for several weeks by serious illness, is rapidly sinking, and his friends say he can survive only a short time.

SUAKIN, March 4.--Seven hundred men, women, and children have arrived here from Tokar. The rebels mutilated the British dead that fell into their hands. The marines and sailors attached to Gen. Graham's expedition have a returned to Trinkitat and embarked for Suakin.
City Treasurer Smith, of Bayonne, N.J., who has been arrested for stealing the town funds, was last night removed from office by the Common Council of that place.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--On Sunday las John Glascock, a well-known and influential farmer of Fauquier County, Va., living two and a half miles from Delaplane Station, on the Virginia Midland Railroad, murdered his entire family, consisting of a wife and three children, and then committed suicide by shooting himself through the heart in a piece of woods near his house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 4.--The Muldoon-Bauer Graeco-Roman wrestling-match, for $500 a side, took place last night in Mechanics' Pavilion. Bauer won the first fall in 18 minutes. Muldoon won the second in 5 minutes 20 seconds, and the third and match in 12 minutes 10 seconds. Both men were trained down to 185 pounds. A match has been arranged between Whistler and Muldoon for $1,000 a side.

WASHINGTON, March 4, 1884. The House bill making appropriations for the support of the Military Academy for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1885, after an amendment had been adopted promiding that hereafter any cadet dismissed for hazing should not be eligible to reappointment, was passed by the Senate to-day.

Although the Senate cleared its calendar yesterday of bills for the erection of public buildings, and appropriated more than $3,000,000 for that purpose, it is by no means through with that sort of legislation.

The plans for the new buildings it is proposed to erect in Broadway where the St. Nicholas Hotel now stands, as already reported in THE TIMES, were filed yesterday with Inspector Esterbrook, of the Bureau of Buildings, by the...

At a meeting of the Directors of the National Rifle Association yesterday Col. John Ward was elected Secretary for the current year. Five new rifle-matches were proposed by J.H. Brown, to be included in the programme of the next Autumn prize-meeting at Creedmoor.

TRENTON, N.J., March 4.--The many objections which have been urged against the two railroad tax bills now pending in the Legislature led to a conference upon the question last evening, the result of which was the preparation of a new bill. When the House was about to adjourn for dinner, to-day Mr. Armstrong, of Camden, ...

CHICAGO, March 4.--The architects have completed the arrangements for fitting up the Exposition Building for the Musical Festival, and the alterations necessary for that event are believed to be suitable for the National Conventions, to follow.

In the course of the investigations made by District Attorney Ridgway, Brooklyn, into the fraudulent-divorce business conducted by Munro Adams, at No. 234 Broadway, the fact was discovered that Several lawyers in this city were involved with Adams in the frauds.

NASHVILLE, March 4.--Federal and Confederate soldiers are making arrangements to join a large party of Federal soldiers, from the North and assist in the celebration of the twentysecond anniversary of the battle of Shiloh.

If the weather permits, the torchlight parade of the Barnum and London Shows next Saturday evening will be a great affair. Mother Goose has consented to take part, and will risk the lives of her numerous children by exposing them to the evening air.
BOSTON, March 4.--In the House to-day the bill providing for biennial elections was defeated--yeas 139, nays 87, not the necessary twothirds in favor.

At an executive session yesterday of the Committee of Bridge Trustees, appointed to consider the question of tolls, at the bridge office in Sands-street, it was resolved to report in favor of maintaining the present rates.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 4.--P.S. Mulhearn, mail agent on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, fell from the mail car at a point near Chain Dam, Northampton County, to-day, and received fatal injuries.

Commissioner Thomas S. Brennan has been active lately, at meetings of the Board of Charities and Correction, in agitating the subject of affording elementary instruction to the prisoners in the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island.

Between 200 and 300 memebrs of the New-York Historical Society listened with interest, last night, to a proposition to hold in April, 1889, a grand centennial anniversary celebration of the Inauguration of George Washington as the first President of these United States.

The annual meeting of the Directors and stockholders of the Texas and Pacific Railroad took place yesterday, and was adjourned, to be resumed April 15 in Marshall, Texas, as required by the laws of that State, under which it was chartered.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 4.--Insurance Commissioner Spooner is still waging war against the bogus insurance companies in this and adjoining States. He has succeeded in driving a half-dozen companies from the State, and others are now being prosecuted.
BUFFALO, March 4.--The National League of Base-ball Clubs met in this city to-day and unanimously adopted the following schedule of championship games for the coming season:
The old Confederate fortifications around Athens, Ga., are now being leveled.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 4.--At the afternoon games of the pool tournament here to-day the first series was between King and Wharton. The first named player won easily by a score of 11 to 3.

Col. Rodney C. Ward, of the Twentythird Regiment, says that he was not at the meeting held with closed doors on Monday night by the Uniformed Veteran Battalion of his regiment, and that he did not, therefore, apologize for appending his signature to the anti-veteran manifesto.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 4.--Mail advices from Fort Benton, Montana, relate that the ice in the Mississippi River broke up last Monday and spread over a portion of the bottom on which Fort Benton is situated. Many business houses were flooded, and the families on the two streets facing the river were compelled to abandon their homes without saving anything. The damage to property will reach $ 20,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 4.--An association of business men has just been formed here to promote by means of steam-boats commercial, intercourse between this city and NewYork.

EASTON, Penn., March 1.--Benjamin Beatty attempted to chastise his 17-year-old boy Harry this morning, when the latter drew a revolver and shot his father in the breast. While trying to shoot again he was disarmed, but only after a severe struggle. Mr. Beatty is not fatally hurt, though the ball has not yet been extracted. The boy who is a reader of dime novels, received a severe thrashing, after which he made his escape.

UTICA, N.Y., March 4.--The vault of the Utica City National Bank was opened to-day and the contents were found uninjured. The safe of M.B. Delong was raised from the ruins of his...

Mr. Charles Stoughton's perseverance in endeavoring to secure the passage by Congress of the bill authorizing the Secretary of War to contract with him for the improvement of the Harlem River is becoming proverbial.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 4.--The Firemen's Charitable Association celebrated its forty-ninth anniversary to-day by a parade of all the engines and companies composing the organization. Thirty engines were in line and between, 3,000 and 4,000 men.
TORONTO, Ontario, March 4.--The Jarrard extraditon case was finally settled this morning by the judgement of the Court of Appeal remanding the prisoner, Levi D. Jarrard, for extradition.

In the State of Michigan there is a bold and unfortunate reformer, the wife of a dull and conservative man. This reformer is now suffering for the crime of being in advance of her age. She has a new and thoroughly artistic idea in regard to dress, and this idea has cost her the confidence and affection of her husband.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 4.--On account of the brisk westerly winds which have prevailed for several days and the rough water out at sea Jay Gould could not get away from Charleston until to-day.

GALENA, Ill., March 4.--A passenger train on the Illinois Central Pailroad was thrown from the rails this morning near Maryland Station. All the coaches left the track. Two were upset and were badly wrecked. Three persons were injured, but none fatally. The wounded are H.J. Brown, of Galena; J.C. Summerfield, of Chicago, traveling salesman, and a traveler from the East whose name was not ascertained. The wounded were brought to Galena.

The eighteenth annual report of the St. Francis Hospital, Nos. 603 to 611 Fifth-street, under the charge of "the Sisters of the Poor of St. Francis," for 1883, was issued yesterday. The number of patients treated this last year is 1,913,...

WASHINGTON, March 4.--In the KeiferBoynton investigation to-day, D.G. Swaim, Judge-Advocate-General of the Army, was the first witness called. He had met Charles S. Garfield twice, but did not know that he had been promised an office by the President.

The members of the Republican State Committee were prompt in assembling at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday noon. Chairman James D. Warren, Gen. Sharpe, and ex-Senator Birdsall were among the early comers. Collector Robertson, who lives in the hotel during the Winter months, also appeared in the lower corridors some time before the meeting was called.

The sale of the collection of Americana of the late Henry C. Murphy, of Brooklyn, was continued yesterday at the auction-rooms of George A. Leavitt Co., in Clinton Hall. A11 the buyers who were present on Monday from different parts of the country were in attendance when Auctioneer Mery lifted his gavel at 2:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

Mme. de Salazar, a pianist well known among Cuban residents of New-York who are interested in musical affairs, gave a matinee concert in Steinway's smaller hall yesterday.
LONDON, March 4.--Mr. Wilson Barrett, the actor, has finally declined the offer of an engagement for America.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 4.--The Prohibition State Convention held in this city today made the following, nominations: For Governor--The Hon. Elisha H. Palmer, of Montville; Lieutenant-Governor--Franklin H. Sage, Stonington; Secretary of State--Aaron Morehouse,...

PITTSBURG, March 4.--C.A. Smith, colored, an ex-member of the Alabama Legislature and Chairman of the Executive Committee which is arranging for a National Convention of Colored Men, was in the city to-day. The convention is to be held in Pittsburg on May 29 and 30. Representative men will be here from all the States. Its object is to formally ask the Republican Party to make an effort this year to carry...
LONDON, March 4.--Extraordinary precautions are being taken to insure the safety of Buckingham Palace. The movements of all persons who are found lurking about in the neighbood are closely watched.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--Representative Potter's bill to refund the bonded debt of the United States at 2 per cent. interest is now being carefully examined by Secretary--Folger, who has been asked to give an opinion on the measure to the Committee on Ways and Means,...

PHILADELPHIA, March 4.--The comic opera " Falka," by Messrs. Leterrier and Vanloo, music by Francois Chassaigne, was produced for the first time in America, at Haverly's Theatre, here, to-night. The airs of the opera are catchy, and many of the situations exceedingly droll. The house was crowded and the audience was enthusiastic.

ALBANY, March 4.--It was the same old story when the amendment of Mr. Clinton, of Erie, to the Civil Service bill came up in the Assembly to-day. The Democrats offered their usual opposition to reforms sought to be established by conscientious Republicans. By voice and vote they recorded themselves against the bill.
The old Goelet mansion, at the north-east corner of Seventeenth-street and Broadway, is being converted into a business building, and will be occupied by a jewelry firm.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4.--John McGinnis, who wounded his wife and killed her mother, Mrs. Mary Reed, on the evening of Sept. 30, 1881, was hanged for the murder in Moyamensing Prison at 10:35 o'clock this morning. The condemned man spent the first half of the night with his spiritual advisers.

Tables covered with rare flowers stretched across the new Horticultural Hall, in Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday, and throughout the afternoon crowds strolled around them, admiring the March display of the Horticultural Society.

On last Saturday evening there was a fire near Flushing, Long Island, and the Fire Department was called out to extinguish it. Young America Hose Company, NO. 2., was out, and as the streets were muddy the men concluded to take their machine on the sidewalk.

An amendment is to be offered to the Dorsheimer international copy right bill when it comes up again in the House of Representatives, providing that all publications entered for copyrighting in the United States under the act shall be printed and manufactured in this country.

A plan for the erection of a church, Sunday-school, and parsonage, on the north-east corner of the Boulevard and Sixty-eighth-street, was filed yesterday in the Bureau of Buildings by Mr. S.B. Reed, an architect, of No. 245 Broadway, for the Consistory of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, of which the Rev. Carlos Martyn is President.

The Senate Committee on Military Affairs has decided that it is useless to vote condemned cannon and cannon-balls to Grand Army posts, towns, cemetery associations, and other organizations when the supply is already exhausted.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: Mr. George F. Edmunds presented the resolutions adopted at the meeting of the bar of this court, held to pay respect to the memory of the late Philip Phillips, which were received and ordered to be filed.

Ex-Alderman John W. Jacobus answered a ring at his door, at No. 16 Morton-street, on Monday night, and William Rollston, of No.454 Hudson-street, stalked in and said: "I've come to have a wrong righted." He told Mr. Jacobus that they had met in a lodge-room up town.

During the debate in the Senate last Saturday on the resolution directing the Commissioner of the New Capitol to discharge any officer under his authority who had applied political tests in engaging employes, Senator HUSTED quoted with effect Superintendent PERRY'S testimony against the Deputy Superintendent, McINTYRE.

CHICAGO, March 4.--Joseph R. Raycroft, a printer, and the Treasurer of Grace Reformed Episcopal Church, is the latest church official who is being anxiously sought for. Raycroft is behind in his church accounts to the extent of $926. He had promised the church Vestry several times to make good the deficit, but always...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 4.--The whisky trade in Kentucky has been at a stand-still for the past month owing to the agitation and uncertainty of the bonded extension measure. Sellers, confident of the ultimate passage of the bill, have repeatedly refused full market prices...
A dispatch from London yesterday said that the other cable stocks were advancing on reports of a disagreement among the projectors of the Mackey--Bennett cable.

About 200 of the New-York Alumni of the College of New-Jersey, at Princeton, assembled last evening at Delmonico's, to eat their annual dinner and to listen to the ensuing outpour of wit and eloquence. James W. Alexander, President of the Alumni Association, presided.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4.--Of the four Philadelphia appointments made by the President yesterday three are distinctly political and in the interest of the machine side of the party in Pennsylvania. Col. Quay triumphs as to the point over which he made the greatest effort-- the displacement of Gen. Sickel and the appointment of Vanderslice.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 4.--The Marietta and North Georgia Railroad has a hard road to travel. When the last legislative committee found in favor of the road and the General Assembly granted it 2,500 able-bodied convicts for three years, it seemed as if the star of the road was in the ascendant.
SCRANTON, Penn., March 4.--Richard Calden was arrested here to-day on a charge of issuing fraudulent tax receipts in the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards at the recent election.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 4.--In the Supreme Court to-day the Attoney-General of the State ordered an abatement to be entered in the case of M.T. Polk, the defaulting Treasurer, on account of the death of the defendant. This action disposes of the criminal prosecution, and the next steps taken will be proceedings against Polk's estate to recover the amount stolen, and ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 4.--John Albright, the noted jockey and driver of the famous pacer Mattie Hunter, was arrested in this city to-day at the instance of the Pittsburg police authorities, being wanted in the latter place to answer to a charge of perjury. Albright says the charge is trumped up and he is perfectly willing to meet it.

Commissioner Purroy's new tank, which it is proposed to use in the dry goods and tenement-house districts in case of fires when there is a scarcity of water, was tested near the New York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad station, on the north side of the Harlem River, yesterday.

DALTON, Ga., March 4.--A double tragedy occurred on the Western and Atlantic Railroad, at Tilton, this afternoon. Two young men of high standing from Dalton, Henry Flowers and William H. Ward, went to Tilton, and while there became intoxicated.

PRINCETON, March 4.--After chapel this morning the Princeton College students tramped through the snow-drifts on the campus to get their mail from the little Post Office in Nassaustreet. In each man's box was a fawn-colored, Government-stamped envelope, unsealed.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee met at the Arlington Hotel, in this city, this evening, and organized for the coming campaign. Senator Pendleton, Chairman of the Democratic joint caucus, presided, and Representative Post, Secretary of the joint caucus, acted as Secretary of the meeting.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 4.--The Yale Glee Club have had manufactured a valuable tankard, suitably inscribed, to present to Col. John Macon Brown, a member of the Yale Class...

The eighth annual bench show of dogs given by the Westminster Kennel Club will begin in Madison-Square Garden on Tuesday, May 6, and close on the following Friday night. It is expected that the exhibition will excel all others previously given by the club.

PITTSBURG, March 4.--The exact extent of the reduction offered by the steel firm of Singer, Nimick Co. to their employes was ascertained to-day. Melters are asked to accept $1 per ton less than the present rate.

In the Queens County Court of Sessions yesterday morning the Grand Jury took up the case of Charles H. Rugg, the negro charged with the murder of the Maybee women and the assaults on the Spragues and the Townsends. Over 60 witnesses had been subpoenaed, and the courtroom ...

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, March 5.--A snowplow on the St. Paul Railroad struck a sleigh containing a farmer named Sisk, his son, age 19 years, a married daughter, and two small children, at Sibley to-day. The son was instantly killed and the father was fatally injured. The others received slight injuries.

Written statements concerning the disposition of the body of Henry Devlin, who died of Bright's disease and phthisis in the Charity Hospital Feb. 23, were sent yesterday to the Commissioners of Charities and Correction by Dr. L.L. Seaman, chief of staff of the Charity Hospital ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--After many weeks of inquiry into the affairs of Marshals Mr. Springer's Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice has at last reached the beginning of its examination into the conduct of the star route prosecutions, and to-day heard ex-Postmater-General James as the first witness in that branch of its investigations.

A deputation of the Hack-owners' Association called on the Mayor yesterday and urged that he should sign the amendment to the city ordinance affecting them, passed by the Board of Aldermen at the last meeting, without delay, so that it might be enforced at the Purim ball ...

CHICAGO, March 5.--The Chicago and North-western Railroad having failed in a State court in its attempt to prevent the Chicago and Evanston Road from getting an entrance to the city by building a bridge over the North ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The withdrawal of Col. Keogh's nomination as Marshal for the Western District of North Carolina is a frank confession of serious defeat by the Administration. North Carolina is almost the only debatable Southern State, as matters now stand, in a Presidential election.
HAVANA, March 5.--There was a run on the Banco Industrial to-day. The bank met all demands, being assisted by the Spanish bank and a private banker. The bank paid out until 8 o'clock to-night.
The citizens of the State of South Carolina are tired of hearing the discharge of pistols by the Cash family and listening to the groans of their victims.

EASTON, Penn., March 5.--The Prison Inspectors, at a meeting this afternoon, appointed watchmen over Sabato Alexander, the murderer, because an instrument with which the prisoner, it is supposed, expected to use in taking his own life was found in his cell.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 5.--A report submitted by Superintendent Maxwell to the Chamber of Commerce to-day shows the whole number of hogs packed here during the past Winter to have been 365,451 a decrease of 59,949 as compared with the previous year.

PANAMA, Feb. 24.--Several cases of yellow fever have occurred here during the past week, and the new arrivals are consequently somewhat frightened. One month ago M. Dingler, the chief of works of the canal company, lost his daughter from this disease, and yesterday his son died of the fever.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 5.--At a meeting held here to-night to commemorate the anniversary of Robert Emmet an address was delivered by the Rev. George W. Pepper, of Ohio, after which Mayor Powderly, Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, offered a resolution which was adopted unanimously, disapproving the action of the Government in accepting from the British Government the ship Alert for service in the arctic.

American graziers may congratulate themselves that the official investigation into the sanitary condition of the American pig has not only had its effect toward rehabilitating that beast, but has been useful also in the collateral case of the American cow.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 5.--The sale of reserved seats for Henry Irving's performance in this city will begin Friday morning at 10 o'clock. All day long there has been more than a dozen messenger boys standing in line in front of the store at which the reserved seats are to be sold.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--I.C. Fowler, (white,) late of Bristol, Va., Chairman of his county Readjuster Committee and now clerk of the United States court at Abingdon, Va., was called by the Danville investigating committee to-day. He identified a circular which was current in his neighborhood previous to the election.

Hush C. Miller, son of the Rev. Alexander Miller, was taken to the Tombs Police Court yesterday, before Justice Duffy, by Sergt. Cahill on a charge of abandonment preferred by his wife, Caroline M. Miller, a handsome brunette, who was fashionably attired. A white plume danced on her hat and diamonds sparkled in her ears.
WASHINGTON, March 5, 1884. The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher and Mr. Henry Irving were among the President's visitors this afternoon.

LOWELL, March 5.--George F. Hunt, the Treasurer of the Odd-fellows' Building Association, was arrested this afternoon charged with the embezzlement of funds of the association to the amount of $2,700. Hunt acknowledged his guilt on Jan. 1, but was given an opportunity to make restitution. The money belonged to the proprietors of Odd-fellows' Block.

ALBANY, March 5.--The Assembly bill taking from the New-York Board of Aldermen the power of confirming the Mayor's nominees came up as the special order in the Senate this morning, and, after an hour and a half's discussion, was ordered to a third reading and passed, by a vote of 24 to 7, as follows--[Republicans in roman, Democrats in italics:]

OLEAN, N.Y., March 5.--At the conference meeting held here to-day for the Thirtyfourth Congressional District, attended by five representatives each from Allegany, Cattaraugus, and Chautauqua Counties, embraced in this new district, it was decided to hold the district convention for selecting delegates to Chicago at Olean on April 16, and that the convention shall consist of 50 delegates from each county.

At the offices of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad it was stated, yesterday, that the Emigrant Passenger pool had agreed to give the West Shore 13 per cent. of the business. The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western gets the same percentage.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., March 5.--An old guide from the Lake Pleasant country brings the intelligence to this village that the past few days have been marked in that section by the capture alive of three white deer.
DES MOINES, Iowa, March 5.--The Republican State Convention has been called to meet here on April 30.

WOOD'S HOLL, Mass., March 5.--The Wood's Holl Wrecking Company's steamer Hunter has arrived with the last lighter-load of cargo from the steamer City of Columbus. The ship has nearly gone to pieces, and there is no more cargo of any value in her. She is sanding up fast, and will probably in a short time be laid flat by the heavy sea and covered with sand.

BOSTON, March 5.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Union Pacific here today was attended by so large a number that an adjournment was taken immediately after the opening to enable a committee to hunt up a larger hall than the Directors' room, the place originally chosen.

At about 10:30 A.M., Babu Keshub Chunder Sen expired at his residence at Lily Cot tage, and immediately after his remains were laid out on a new sandalwood bedstead, which was covered with marigolds, jessamine, and roses.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 5.--An elopement that occurred last Saturday night came to light to-day. Mr. R.J. Butz is a rising young architect of Allegheny. Miss Annie Carson is a handsome and accomplished daughter of Mr. Robert Carson, a wealthy and well-known business man.

WESTBORO, Mass., March 5.--A sensation has been created here by the absence from town of L.K. Travis, a wellknown lawyer in Worcester County. It is reported that a young lady of this town has departed with him.

BOSTON, March 5.--The shoe factory occupied by Melvin Leach at Brockton, Mass., was closed this morning. An attachment for $15,000 has been placed upon the stock and machinery by Lucius Leach and a keeper put in charge.

Two of the members of the "Whyo" gang, recently committed by Justice Duffy for six months as vagrants, made their escape Saturday night from Hart's Island.

OSWEGO, N.Y., March 5.--The charter election yesterday resulted in the election of James Dowelle, Democrat, Mayor, by 155 majority over R.J. Oliphant, Republican. The Democrats elected their Aldermen in three wards and the Republicans in five.

One hundred milkmen of Brooklyn, Eastern District, met at the Masonic Temple, in Broadway, yesterday afternoon, and were told by Prof. E.H. Bartley, of the Long Island Hospital, the methods by which they could detect impure milk.

CAIRO, March 5.--Gen. Graham has arrived at Suakin. The troops are embarking at Trinkitat for Suakin. The cavalry, before leaving Tokar, discovered that Osman Digna is stationed 10 miles from Suakin.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 5.--Edwards, the champion Australian pedestrian, has accepted the challenge of Vaughn, the English champion, for a six days' match, and has put up a forfeit of $250.

EMERSON, Manitoba, March 5.--The International Railway Convention is still in session. Col. WASHINGTON, March 5.--The PostmasterGeneral has succeeded in making arrangements for a special fast mail train between New-York and Chicago, which will prove a great convenience to those cities and a large extent of country.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 5.--Cornell University added another Japanese student to-day to its rolls in the person of S. Arakawa, who was the official representative of Japan at the Boston Exposition of Foreign Products during the past year. The Woodford prize competition, which promises to be quite sharp, has been postponed until Friday, next week, on account of President White's absence from town.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 5.--Nine months ago a social sensation was created here by the romantic marriage of Willie O. Berndorfer, an Israelite, to Miss Colista Hopwood, daughter of a prominent member of the Episcopal Church. When her father asked her to become a candidate for confirmation she said that she could not, as she intended to become a Jewess.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 5.--The NewHaven Bicycle Club has decided to hold its races on May 28 at Hamilton Park. Among the interesting events will be a race between Harvard and Yale.

LONDON, March 5.--The efforts of the police to discover the authors of the recent dynamite outrages continue with unabated zeal. It appears to be certain that they are upon the right trail. It has been learned that three men landed at Southampton on Feb. 20, from the steamer Donau, which left New-York on Feb. 9.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, March 5.--Great excitement prevails in Huron County over the discovery this afternoon that Martin O. Van Fleet, County Treasurer, is a defaulter to the amount of $60,000 of the county's money and several thousand dollars held in trust for private individuals and the Presbyterian church of which he was Treasurer.

The long-mooted question of the management of the Metropolitan Opera-house will in all probability be settled to-day, although the public is not likely to know anything about it before to-morrow. TRENTON, March 5.--The Newark Plank road claimed the attention of the House for a long time this morning. It was a general act reducing tolls on the railroads, and was finally lost by a vote of 28 to 34.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 5.--The charge that bribery was resorted to in securing for the Hon. J.C.S. Blackburn the Senatorial nomination for Kentucky, has resulted in the determination on the part of the Legislature to set on foot immediately an investigation.

August Prince, Joseph Levine, William Rooth, and Charles Dahn, striking members of the Cigar-makers' Progressive Union, were arrested near Straiton Storm's factory, in East Twenty-seventh-street, yesterday.

CINCINNATI, March 5.--Two pretentious projects in the way of new theatres are announced to-day. One of them is in connection with the proposed second Dramatic Festival. Finding that Booth and Irving would want $15,000 each should they make an engagement to appear, their figures are regarded by the Board of Directors as too high.

In October last James J. Gerow, of Fordham, was given a contract to repair the roofs of the State armories at Oswego and Auburn. The work was supposed to be done under the direction of Martin C. Deegan, of this city, Superintendent of Armories.

BALTIMORE March 5.--The Manufact urers' Record will to-morrow publish the statement of two months' progress in manufactures in the South, showing the amount of capital invested in Southern manufacturing and mining enterprises during January and February.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 4.--The strike of the 1,500 coal miners in the third pool against a reduction of cent collapsed to-day, and the men returned to work at the wages offered by the operators.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5.--A solid sheet of new ice has formed on the river from here to Sing Sing. It is five inches thick and is fast to either shore. People are crossing the river with teams at West Point.

MIDDLETOWN, March 5.--Last Summer the wife of Benjamin Smith, of Hancock, Delaware County, was so badly injured by a runaway horse that she died in a few hours. After her death Smith and his son James, aged 16, continued to live in Hancock.

"How late in the year do people buy diaries?" a book-seller was asked. "All the year round and into the next year," was the reply. "I've sold last year's diaries this week, and, for all I know, I may sell them for the next six months. What do folks do with last year's diaries? Well, you see, diaries are not what they used to be.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 5.--After the mass-meeting last night there were excited assemblages of the students to discuss the resolutions. The streets were unusually quiet, and knowing ones thought it a calm preceding a storm.

BOSTON, March 5.--The Produce Exchange in this city adopted the following to-day: Whereas, The continuance of the coinage of silver dollars as required by the law of Congress must inevitably result in displacing gold, unsettling values of all kinds, and bring disaster upon the Nation; therefore be it.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 5.--The Citizens' Association to-night nominated Dr. John Swinburne for Mayor, Anthony Gould for Recorder, W.S. Hevenor and Myer Nusbaum for Police Justices, and James H. Carroll and F.N. Busler for Police Commissioners. An independent faction of the organization has nominated Alexander Gregory for Mayor.

"Larry" McCarty, the dance-house keeper; was found dead yesterday morning in his cell in the Jefferson Market prison, by Keeper Henry Van Holland. He appeared to have died suddenly in a uraemic convulsion.
Gordon Percival, 84 years of age, has just emigrated from Maine to Washington Territory.

CORNING, Ohio, March 5.--Four persons were arrested here to-day charged with murder in the first degree in having lynched Richard Hickey two weeks ago.

The disagreeable snow-storm which visited this city yesterday was the same one which formed in Colorado on Tuesday morning and began its march to the eastward. The storm centre yesterday morning was in Arkansas. To the north of Virginia, along the coast, the storm took the form of snow, and it was a part of this which New-York City experienced.

In accordance with the recent decision of the Court of Appeals, Theodore Hoffman, who was found guilty of murder in the first degree for killing the Hebrew peddler Zife Marks with an axe, at Port Chester, a year ago, was arraigned at White Plains yesterday afternoon to be sentenced.

RICHMOND, Va., March 5.--No event has occurred for some time that has attracted so much interest as Mr. John S. Wise's posing before Sherman's committee. The colored people are very much dissatisfied with Mr. Wise's reference to them.

CLEVELAND, March 5.--William McMillan, a farmer living near Huron, who shot and killed George Thompson yesterday, subsequently attempted to shoot himself, but the shot struck his watch and glanced off. He was found in bed by the officers at a late hour last night and taken to jail. This morning McMillan was found dead in his cell. It was supposed that he committed suicide by taking poison.

The Purim Association's annual masquerade ball, which is always one of the most brilliant of the season, took place last evening at the Metropolitan Opera-house. Long before 10 o'clock a line of carriages extended down Broadway to below Thirty-third-street. Their occupants were discharged as rapidly as possible. Inside the opera-house the scene was one of real brilliancy.

BOSTON, March 5.--The Boston Art Club has adopted a resolution denouncing the recent legislation of the Forty-seventh Congress which discriminated against works of art by foreign artists, and uniting with other art associations of the country in urging the speedy repeal of the legislation to which reference is made.

The great stakes of the American Jockey Club and the Monmouth Park Association, which closed on March 1, show a very pronounced increase in the number of entries as compared with last year. This is especially the case in the stakes of the Jockey Club to be run during the Spring meeting.

UTICA, N.Y., March 5.--The State Liquordealers' Association met at 1 o'clock to-day in the City Opera-house. P.J. Fitzgerald, of Troy, was elected Chairman, and J.M. Downing, of Albany, and william Hall, of New-York, Secretaries.

ERIE, Penn.. March 5.--Three seamen, C.J. Keegan, J. Wachter, and Thomas Wilson, of the United States steamer Michigan, at this port, were accepted to-day as volunteers for the Greely arctic relief expedition. Capt. Reed, commander of the Michigan, volunteered to command a vessel, but was rejected on account of defective eyesight. He denies that his eyesight is bad, and has asked for an examination.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 5.--The Republicans have stood ready up to the last moment to ratify any ticket which the Independents or anti-ring Democrats might put in the field, pledging them the entire party vote unconditionally.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 5.--The Canadian Pacific Railway Loan bill passed its third reading in the Senate this afternoon, and shortly afterward Sir William Ritchie, Deputy GovernorGeneral, came down to the Senate Chamber and in her Majesty's name assented to the passage of the bill.
On the 30th of April last Judge Torrance awarded $400 damages to Mr. Edmond Lareau, an advocate who had brought a charge of libel against La Minerve.
The formation in Germany of registered credit associations, or people's banks, has proved to be a great success, and from a very unpretending commencement a most prosperous system has been developed.

Henry Weitfuller was arrested in Newark on Thursday last for an atrocious assault on Joseph Hoersdoeffer. He told Judge Hood that he had a case of small-pox in his family, and was at once released on his own recognizance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 5.--In July, 1883, George R. Madison, while employed as a brakeman by the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad Company, lost his leg while on duty. He brought suit against the Erie Company, lessee of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio, for damages, and to-day the jury in the United States District Court awarded him $7,000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 5.--Robert E. Miller, of Bellville, Hancock County, Ky., committed suicide by shooting himself in the head yesterday at Dr. R.V. Pierce's Sanitarium. He came here a month ago suffering from nervous prostration, and at times was very despondent ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 108-- Seth H. Kellogg, appellant, vs. The United States.--Appeal from the Court of Claims. Order dismissing under sixteenth rule vacated, and case dismissed on motion of T.W. Bartley for the appellant.
Eighty-four men, eleven women, and a precocious boy shouted at a voluble auctioneer for five hours, yesterday, in the Manhattan Market, Thirty-fourth-street and Eleventh-avenue.
Since Jan. 1 470 orders to erect fire-escapes on buildings in this city have been issued by Inspector Esterbrook.
HUDSON, N.Y., March 5.--Henry A. Tilden, although no better, appears to hold his own,and an immediate fatal result is not anticipated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 5.--The Winter athletic meeting of Yale College began today. The Seniors defeated the Sophomores in the tug-of-war. F.R. Smith, '83, and Mitchell, '85, Sheffield Scientific School, were the best rope climbers.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 5.--The Republican State Central Committee will hold a meeting in the Plankington House parlors at noon tomorrow.

READING, Penn., March 5.--A passenger train consisting of three coaches on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was thrown from the track to-night, near Bridgeport, by a broken axle, causing a delay of nearly two hours. Timber on a passing freight train crashed through the sleeping car, and one train was set on fire. There was great excitement among the passengers, but none of them was injured.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., March 5.--The jury investigating the death of Michael Cadden who was killed on the Reading Road, has found the company responsible on account of the gross negligence and hasty action of its employe, Conductor Charles Kocher.
A fire broke out at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the basement of the four-story building at No.59 Beekman-street and running through to No.89 Ann-street.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 5.--The United States Brewers' Association has just issued a circular to all firms members of the association here, requesting them to make out a list of all the voters in their employ, and also all of those who have neglected to take out naturalization papers.

MORRISTOWN, Tenn., March 5.-Two children of Mr. Joe Guthrie's family, who were poisoned by eating canned blackberries, at Rogersville Junction, died to-day, making three in all who have died. Mrs. Guthrie, mother of the children, is unconscious and is thought to be dying.

CHICAGO, March 5.--A remarkable case of conspiracy and imposition was developed in the Superior Court to-day, when Elizabeth Rieney began a suit against Fernando Wistamil, the proprietor of the Denver House, for $5,000 damages for trespass.
BOSTON, March 5.--One of the burglars arrested in Lawrence on Monday has made his identity known as Johnny Irving, the notorious burglar and bank robber, hailing from NewYork.

Seals have seldom been so plentiful in the harbor as they were yesterday. This fact incited a number of enterprising Staten Islanders to engage in the unusual sport of hunting them. Two large seals, fully 5 feet long, which were on an ice-floe that was driven near shore at South Beach, were fired at by two brothers named Rollinson.

Warden Brush's night school at Sing Sing Prison is proving a success, and so great has become the interest in it among the convicts that the number of pupils has increased from 76 to 94, and another class, making the third, will have to be formed.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--Secretary Folger has written a letter to Mr. Morrison, Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means, acknowledging the receipt of a resolution adopted by that committee requesting the Secretary of the Treasury to examine the Potter bill and report ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--Ex-Speaker Keifer and Gen. Boynton were both on the witness stand to-day before the Keifer-Boynton Investigating Committee. Mr. Keifer testified that up to Feb. 2, 1883, there had been no suggestion of impropriety made to him by Gen. Boynton.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 5.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the following business was transacted: No. 312--Lewis Cuddeback, appellant, vs. Oscar F. Sherman et al., respondents; argued by W.H Cuddeback ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--An order was issued from the War Department to-day directing Col. John Newton, Engineer Corps, to assume the duties of Chief of Engineers to-morrow, when the retirement of Gen. H.G. Wright takes effect. His nomination for that office will probably be sent to the Senate to-morrow. He was ordered by telegraph yesterday to proceed at once from New-York to Washington, and he arrived here to-day.

The report of the United States Local Inspectors who investigated the loss of the City of Columbus has been made. It places the whole blame of the disaster upon Capt. WRIGHT. The latter had a pilot's license, and assumed, in addition to the ordinary duties of a ship-master, the duties of a pilot.

Since his retirement from the office of Postmaster-General, in January, 1882, Mr. THOMAS L. JAMES has maintained, under great provocation, a discreet and dignified silence regarding the events that marked his brief but momentous administration of the Post Office Department.

A large number of crows were foraging for food yesterday quite close to the house of a farmer residing in another town, near the Hartford boundary.
ATLANTA, March 5.--The trouble at Allapapa, in which the aid of the military was invoked, grew out of the arrest of a noted desperado, Dan Turner, a white man, who has been guilty of many atrocities.

A suit for the rescission of the lease of a part of the premises known as the Hotel Brunswick is on trial, before Judge Van Brunt, in the Supreme Court, Special Term. The plaintiff is Augustus Gerald Hull, as Trustee, and the defendants are Francis Kinzler and Rebecca Mitchell, Executrix, composing the firm of Mitchell Kinsler.
The President gave a state banquet to 37 gentlemen at the White House this evening that was quite unique in the annals of official banquets.

Collector Robertson has received a letter from the Treasury Department stating that the propriety of prohibiting the importation of neat cattle from Great Britain is under consideration. It is officia11y stated that a dangerous foot and mouth disease now prevails among neat cattle in England, and that it has already been introduced into the cattle quarantine grounds at Portland, Me.

The funeral services of Dr. Maurice Vergnes were held yesterday morning at his residence, No. 64 Clinton-place. Though in full sympathy with Christianity, he was so opposed to all dogmas and creeds that his friends determined to conduct the services without the observance of any religious rites.

Michael Mullone, publisher of the Jersey City Argus, was arrested last night on a charge of criminal libel, preferred by Police Commissioner Otto W. Meyer. The charge is based upon an article published in the Argus on Feb. 23, associating the name of the plaintiff with that of the wife of a well-known cigar-dealer.

The Hoffman Fire Insurance Company ceased to do business in November last, and has paid all its liabilities except a few which represent $4,000, being based on policies that it has been unable to cancel because their holders could not be found.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 5.--The funding of the State debt at 53, under a law passed at the last session of the Legislature, is progressing slowly. Up to the present time the board has funded bonds of all series, aggregating $3,500,000.

LONDON, March 5.--The House of Commons to-day rejected Mr. Parnell's bill amending the Irish land act by a vote of 325 to 72.

CHICAGO, March 5.--The cases of Dr. Geiger and William Guetschow, the alleged promoters of a "graveyard" insurance scheme to defraud the Home Life Insurance Company of New-York, were called before Judge Hawes this morning. Guetschow pleaded guilty, and his case went over indefinitely. Dr. Geiger was not present, and his bond, signed by M. Brand, was declared forfeited.

ALBANY, March 5.--Bank Superintendent Paine has issued a certificate authorizing the Nineteenth Ward Bank to transact business as a banking association under the State laws, with a capital of $100,000. The bank will be situated at Fifty-seventh-street and Third-avenue, NewYork City, and will be opened for business March 10.

Emma Louise Trautz, a young widow, of Newark, aged 22 years, attempted to commit suicide last evening by taking strychnine. It is said that unrequited affection on the part of a married man named Anthony Burkhardt was the cause of her act.

The sale of the library of American of the late Henry C. Murphy, of Brooklyn, continued with its usual animation yesterday afternoon and evening, all the local and foreign bidders being in their seats promptly when Auctioneer Mery lifted his gavel.

LAWRENCE, Mass., March 6.--The boiler in J.T. Trees's dyeing establishment exploded this forenoon, killing John Trees, Jr., the engineer, and fatally injuring William Moreland and Michael Cronin, two employes. So great was the force of the explosion that the three buildings were shattered into splinters. Pieces of the boiler and debris were thrown 400 feet, crashing through roofs of dwellings, but fortunately injured no one. Cronin has since died.

Young Mr. LANGSTON, the colored man who has just killed two other colored men in Washington, seems to fancy that it is character and not color that makes "the nigger." One of his victims, the colored man WILLIAMS, was engaged in the humane and Christian task of trying to separate two men who were fighting.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 6.--About 30 representatives of the barbed wire manufacturers of New-York, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Iowa, and Missouri held a meeting here to-day. They had had a long consultation regarding their interests. The meeting was secret, but it was learned from a trustworthy source that it was decided to advance the price of barbed wire cent per pound.
The St. Nicholas Society, at a quarterly meeting at Dolmouico's last evening, passed a resolution thanking Mr. Hamilton Fish for the original draft of its constitution and by-laws...

SHREVEPORT, La., March 6.--Wash Wilson shot and killed a man named Taylor at Rocky Mount, Bossier Parish, Tuesday evening during a Democratic primary election. Wilson says that he acted in self defense.

A fire occurred early yesterday in the six-story apartment-house No. 68 Madisonavenue, known as the Columbia Flats, which, though slight in its nature, for a time imperiled the many occupants of the house. The Columbia is a handsome brown-stone structure, inhabited by 12 families.

READING, Penn., March 6.--Early this morning two unknown young men, one of whom was dead and the other dying, were found near the furnace boilers of the Henry Clay furnaces, on the outskirts of this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 6.--At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce here this afternoon resolutions were adopted protesting against the proposed action of the Government to confiscate all duty-paid merchandise that has remained in a bonded warehouse for over three years. A memorial has been telegraphed to the Secretary of the Treasury requesting a delay of 90 days.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., March 6.--The trial of Mickey Smith, a policeman of Prospect Borough, for the killing of John Monahan by shooting him with a pistol in a saloon last August, ended last evening, the jury bringing in a verdict of murder in the first degree.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 6.--Further investigation of the affairs of M.O. Van Fleet, defaulting Treasurer of Huron County, shows that he had followed in the wake of many who have preceded him, in using other people's money to speculate with.

A. Zeter, a milk-dealer, owns a large and valuable Newfoundland dog. Last Wednesday the animal sprang upon him and slightly scratched the little finger of his left hand with its teeth. There has been considerable talk in the neighborhood regarding the recent deaths caused by hydrophobia.

The strike of the silk ribbon-weavers of Paterson has been considered about over for a week or two past, as the principal mills are fully supplied with hands and are daily turning away new applicants.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 6.--A fire occurred in a building situated on Main-street, two blocks west of the Post Office, this morning. The building is owned by William G. Hall, and was occupied by W.E. Robbins, a grocer. The fire began in the cellar, and was started by the explosion of a kerosene lamp which had been left there. The loss is $1,000, which is covered by insurance.

John Jameston, of No. 116 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street, had a narrow escape from a horrible death on the elevated railroad last night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6.--In the case of Dr. William S. McBride, charged with embracery in connection with the Malone homicide cases. Judge Yerkes to-day delivered an opinion remanding the defendant for trial.

A discovery of immense importance to evolutionists and of incalculable interest to the human race has just been made by an English scientific person. It is not only an evidence of the truth of the theory of evolution, but it beautifully confirms the nebular hypothesis. It is the discovery of the grand and startling fact that man is ultimately to become rotary.

Mme. Modjeska made her last appearance in New-York during this season at the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon. She performed the character of Adrienne Lecouvreur in Mr. H. Herman's rearrangement of the French piece. It was in this character that Modjeska introduced herself several years ago to our public.

Twelve ushers busied themselves for an hour last night in filling up the seats in Chickering Hall and conveying beautiful flowers to the graduating class of the New-York College of Dentistry.

Last evening there was a beautiful pink after-glow in the west, against which loomed the peak of Mount Davidson. At a short distance above the peak, in the midst of the roseate glow, stood the new moon, and above the moon a solitary star.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6.--The blue ribbons dangling from the hair of Lizzie Diamond as she moved about her work this morning in L.W. Leihers's silk manufactory, on Gardenstreet, caught in a loom as she passed.
