A young immigrant woman name Jennie Leschermann was recently discharged from the Ward's Island Hospital. While there her hair was cut off by the direction of the physician.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 6.--To-day being the fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the city, church bells were rung from 11 to 12 o'clock, and at noon a salute of 50 guns was fired by the Toronto Field Battery.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 6.--Charles O. Scull, Assistant General Passenger Agent of the Pennsylvania Company, says that the stories of dissatisfaction on account of the inspection of the berths in the sleeping cars must have been invented by some sleeping car conductor, as no complaints of any kind have been received at head-quarters.

The celebrated "mule case" was decided in Princess Anne, Md., last week, and the people of Somerset County now breathe more freely. Squire Warwick rendered the decision in the presence of everybody who could squeeze into his office.

The New-York Druggists' Union met yesterday to consider the agreement sought to be entered into with the wholesale druggists whereby the present demoralization of the trade may be remedied. Mr. A.J. Ditman presided.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 6.--Rachel Campfield was to-day adjudged an indigent lunatic, and was sent as a county charge to the Middletown Asylum. Her father was the inventor of much of the broom machinery now in use in this part of the State.

William Doh, a German stone-cutter, who had been out of work for three months, committed suicide last evening by hanging himself to the bed-post in his room at the boardinghouse No. 517 West Twenty-sixth-street. He had been depressed owing to his inability to procure remunerative employment.

JACKSON, Mich., March 6.--Porter's saw mill at Onondaga, 18 miles north of here, was last night destroyed by the explosion of the boiler in the mill. William Ward and John Porter were killed and William Younger was fatally injured. The accident was caused by low water in the boiler. The loss on the mill is $3,000.

Giuseppe Guidice was convicted last night, in the Kings County Court of Sessions, of murder in the first degree. The verdict was somewhat of a surprise, as the evidence in the early part of the trial pointed to a quarrel between the murderer and his victim just before the shooting. Guidice and Maggiorini Daghiero were bakers and worked in the bakeshop of Mary Dassori,...

BANGOR, Me., March 6.--Judge Samuel F. Humphreys was to-night nominated as candidate for Mayor by the Republicans. He is in the same set of law offices as that of ex-Chief-Justice Appleton, and is considered a strong candidate. Ex-United States Senator Hannibal Hamlin...

RRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 6.--Capt. Annie Dixon, Annie Mather, Addie Richards and Lucie Reed, and Mme. Neilson, members of the Salvation Army, arrested yesterday for violating the city ordinance by parading the streets, were to-day each fined $7 and costs or 15 days in jail. They refused to pay the fine and were committed.
PITTSBURG, March 6.--Jury Commissioner Andrew Moreland slipped on an iron grating in Diamond-street, in this city, this morning, and, striking his head against the curbstone, was instantly killed.

MILWAUKEE, March 6.--L.N. Packard, 22 years of age, late of this city, committed suicide at Ashland, Wis, last night, by shooting himself through the head. There was no cause for the act. He was a stenographer, and was in good circumstances.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--Ex-AttorneyGeneral MacVeagh continued his testimony today before Mr. Springer's committee relative to his connection with the star route cases. Those cases, he said, would present themselves to anybody's mind as having very grave political complications. One of the gentlemen accused (S.W. Dorsey) had been a United States...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 6.--The regular monthly land excursion on the Gould system to Arkansas and Texas left here last night on a special train over the Iron Mountain Road.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, March 6.--A decree foreclosing certain deeds of trust on the property of the Steubenville Furnace and Iron Company has been granted. There is an unpaid balance of bonded indebtedness amounting to $45,000.
Accounts from the Oporto wine-growing district state that the phylloxera is causing such devastation there as to threaten the very existence of the vineyards.

Vernon H. Brown Co., the agents of the Cunard Line, received a dispatch yesterday announcing that the steam-ship Aurania had just completed a successful trial trip.

LONDON, March 6.--The Inman Line steam-ship City of Chicago, Capt. Leitch, from New-York Feb. 26, for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at 7 o'clock this evening.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6.--There is a big strike of coal miners in the Hocking Valley, caused by the refusal of the coal operators to concede the demands of the haulers. TRENTON, N.J., March 6.--Both houses of the Legislature adjourned to-day for the week. At noon the Democrats held a joint caucus for the selection of a candidate for State Controller.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 6.--The Union-Leader, ex-Chairman Bogert's paper, and the Leading Democratic daily in North-eastern Pennsylvania, to-night, in a leading editorial, nominates Randall as Pennsylvania's choice for the Presidency.

The Denver (Col.) News says that for some time past a hundred or more of the residents of Huerfano County, Col., have been annoyed by notices received from the Pueblo Land Office requiring them immediately to vacate the lands pre-empted under the laws by them as agricultural land, because they have been more recently discovered to be coal lands.
SAVANNAH, March 6.--At noon to-day Coroner Sheftall put in his appearance at a colored funeral which was in progress five miles beyond the city limits. He was accompanied by the constable.

Mr. Henry S. Wood, whose office is at No. 61 Broadway, is the projector of a scheme for connecting the Harlem and Hudson Rivers by means of a straight canal 300 feet wide, crossing the island at about One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 6.--Although invitations to attend the sessions of the Southern Immigration Association in this city next week have been sent ex-Senators Blaine and Thurman, they have not yet replied.

TROY, N.Y., March 6.--At an early hour this morning three men fired pistol shots at a non-union boarding-house near the Malleable Iron-works. Policemen followed the men over the hills, firing at them. By the aid of lanterns blood was found on the snow where one of the men fell. The wounded man was carried off by his companions in a sleigh.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--In the Ways and Means Committee to-day Mr. Morrison pressed to a vote his revised bill to reduce the present tariff 20 percent., and it was ordered to be favorably reported by a vote of 7 to 5.
WASHINGTON, March 6, 1884. The House to-day paused the Naval Appropria tion bill by a vote of 259 to 1, the nagative vote being cast by Mr. White, of Kentucky.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 6.--Arrangements have been perfected for the consolidation of the Pratt Coal and Iron Company, the Alice Furnace Company, and the Linn Iron Company, all in or near Birmingham, into one organization, with a capital of $3,000,000.
Three steam drills were busy punching holes into the rock back of the Dakota Flats yesterday, and three derricks were hauling out the huge hunks of rock that had been blasted out.

Holbert, the catcher of the Metropolitan Club, has arrived in Havana, Cuba, where he is filling the catcher's position for the Havana Club. He hurt his leg while boarding a car previous to his departure South, and it was feared the "Mets" would lose for a time the services of this plucky back-stop.

"Storm Beaten" will be revived in this city next week at Niblo's Garden. Mr. George Riddle will read Mr. Carleton's tragic play, " Memnon." at the University Club Theatre to-morrow morning.

LONDON, March 6.--Organized action between England and the Continental powers against anarchists and dynamiters has been agreed upon without any special treaty. The Police Departments of the powers have been instructed to co-operate with one another under this compact.

PEORIA, Ill., March 6.--This is evidently Peoria's year. The Democrats of Illinois will camp here on July 2, on a spot which will then have been deserted nearly three months before by their Republican adversaries. Peoria, like Chicago, will have its "No. 2."
QUEBEC, March 6.--Mme. Balgaretti, sister of the Rev. Father Conneau and sister-inlaw of ex-Speaker Blanehett, was run over and killed by a runaway horse on the sidewalk last night.

Edward Leahy, a dirver of one of George K. Otis's rickety mail wagons, was arrested on Feb. 29, by Officer George H. Lambert, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, for driving a horse which had a cracked hoof.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 6.--The Winter race meeting was continued to-day. The weather was clear and pleasant, and the track was in good condition.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 6.--James R. Chrysler, a well-to-do farmer of Jackson County, several years ago wooed and won Miss Josephine Webb, the daughter of a neighbor. For a while they lived in the neighborhood in which they were married, but later came to Atlanta and for two years lived happily.

Nicolo Tuzzo, an aged and decrepit Italian, was yesterday on trial for assault in Part II. of the General Sessions in attempting to shoot James McGivney, son of a policeman, and the evidence as to his guilt was very conclusive.

ALBANY, March 6.--The bill appropriating $1,000,000 for the New Capitol came up for a third reading in the Senate, when Mr. Thacher moved to recommit and substitute his bill appropriating $1,400,000. This was lost. Mr. Davidson moved to reduce the appropriation to $500,000.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 6.--Information of a homicide committed at Baker's Station, seven miles from Nashville, last night, was received here to-day. Jack Hirsch killed his sister, Rosa Hirsch, while the two were engaged in a quarrel.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 6.--Last May, the Twenty-eighth New-York volunteers entertained at Niagara Falls the Fifth Virginia (Confederate) Veterans. This year the New-York men are to be entertained at Staunton by the Virginia veterans on a day yet to be agreed upon.
THE TIMES has received $5 from "C.M. A." for the flood sufferers, which will be sent to the proper relief committee.

MORROW, Ohio, March 6.--Jacob Faulkner, age 19, shot and instantly killed Patrick T. Kennedy, a foreman on the Cincinnati and Muskingum Valley Railroad, in a sudden quarrel. They had previously been good friends, but had high words over some hard names Faulkner had called Kennedy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6.--In the case of James Crawford, an ex-railroad conductor charged by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company with embezzling tickets, the jury agreed shortly before 12 o'clock last night. The verdict was guilty. This morning Crawford renewed his bail in the sum of $2,500 pending argument for a new trial.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 6.--It is nearly two weeks since W.B. Cash shot down two men in the streets of Cheraw, S.C., in broad daylight and without the slightest provocation. One of his victims is dead; the other can hardly recover.

MORGANTON, N.C., March 6.--Lucky Joe Wilson, the chief of a band of horse-thieves and outlaws, escaped from the jail of Wataugn County to-day by a sharp ruse. Wilson was sentenced to the State prison for 10 years for his outlawry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 6.--During a quarrel at San Leandro last night William Scollard drew a revolver and shot Aleck Dietrichsen, a saloon-keeper, dead. When Scollard's father was told of his son's act he exclaimed: "My God, can this be." and fell dead.

CHERAW, S.C., March 7.--Bogan Cash is still at large, and the excitement here is gradually dying out. No attempt was made to arrest him to-day, and until the State moves in the matter nothing will be done. Absolutely no confidence can be placed in the local authorities.

BOSTON, March 7.--A hearing took place before Judge Devens, of the Supreme Court, to-day, on a bill in equity brought by the Globe National Bank against Ferdinand A. Wyman, Assignee of the Shaw Brothers.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 7.--A sensational elopement is reported from Annandale, a small hamlet in Butler County. The principals are Edward Beatty and a 13-year-old daughter of S.H. Kelly.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 7.--The Ellenville ladies who threatened to boycott the business men who did not vote the temperance ticket are jubilant, as a "no license" Excise Commissioner was elected by over 100 majority. Ten towns in this (Ulster) county voted for no license.

EMPORIA, Kan., March 7.--Much concern is felt among stock men in this section of Kansas over a disease which has made its appearance in several herds of cattle in Woodson County, near Neosho Falls. Yesterday Gov. Glick, State Veterinary Inspector Holcomb, and Williams Simms, Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture, visited the infected district.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 7.--The decision of Judge Shipman in the matter of the Receivership of the New-York and New-England Railroad; read this afternoon, reviewed in detail the circumstances precedent to, and existing at, the time of the application for a Receivership, and held that they justified the appointment of a Receiver. The motion to dissolve the Receivership was denied.

A conference of Pastors of many of the Protestant churches of Brooklyn was held at the Central Baptist Church, in that city, yesterday afternoon, to consider a plan for observing Lent, or at least some portion of that part of Lent remaining.

The Democratic majority in the Newark Common Council was checkmated again last night by Judge Fort. Mayor Haynes signed the police ordinance late in the afternoon, and it was confidently expected that about 40 Republicans would be removed from the police force and a like number of Democrats appointed to fill their places, but early in the evening Judge Fort served a mandamus on the City Council, which prevents appointments being made until June.

The question has arisen how the percentages of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad in the West-bound trunk line pool is to be figured. The Lackawanna was awarded 14 per cent. by the arbitrators.

TROY, N.Y., March 7.--Hugh G. Hughes, proprietor of the Eureka Slate Quarry at Poultney, Vt., was instantly killed yesterday afternoon in the quarry by the fall of a large stone being hoisted from the pit. A workman was also seriously injured.

It is reported by cable that one of the journalistic reflectors of opinions of Prince BISMARCK in Berlin is collating and republishing unfriendly comments on Minister SARGENT'S appointment made when his name was first sent to the Senate by the President.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 7.--The Stantou House, bui1t 10 years ago by the Hon. J.C. Stanton, of New-York, at a cost of $250,000, was to-day sold under a mortgage foreclosure of $100,000 held by Otto Plock, of New-York. The hotel was one of the finest in the South, and was owned of late by Frederick Wolffe. At the sale it brought only $41,000. Major M.H. Clift was the purchaser.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 7.--An attachment was last night placed on the property of the stranded Webber Opera Company, in this city.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 7.--There is no change whatever in the condition of affairs in the Hocking and Sunday Creek Valleys, where the miners are on a strike, or rather the haulers are, because of a reduction in the price of hauling.

When the case of Mrs. Minnie Magill, charged with abducting her boy, Tyndall, from his home, at South Fourth and Eighth streets, Brooklyn, was called by Justice Naeher yesterday the defendant did not appear. Her husband, Seabury C. Magill, who made the complaint, was in court.

The New-York Base-ball Club has secured the services of James L. Price for manager. He is a lawyer of good practice, and is well known in military circles, being Captain of Company H of the Seventh Regiment.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 7.--The proceedings of the Farmers' Convention have been delayed by the difficulty of the committee to obtain an interview with the officials of the local Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--John Kalor, the chief of the boy desperadoes of the Thaddeus Stevens and Lincoln Public School, marched into Magistrate Brown's office this morning at the head of his band of six Philadelphia cowboys.

Private dispatches from Chicago yesterday reported the cutting of passenger rates eastbound. One said; "Rates cut. New-York selling $15 and $16. Cain killed Abel." The low differential rate from New-York to Chicago is $18 50. Additional information was that the rates were offered by the scalpers, who were supposed to have secured concessions of some sort. LEWISTON, Me., March 7.--The boiler of the Boston Mill, at Bryant's Pond, exploded today, killing four men, while another was badly injured. Three of the killed were boiler-makers from Boston, who had just repaired the boiler which burst while they were gathering up their tools.
PARIS, March 7.--The police have discovered that a man employed as a shorthand writer by a firm of engineers here is an emissary of Patrick Ford, of the Irish World.

BERLIN, March 7.--In the Reichstag today, after the President had been re-elected, that functionary announced the death of Herr Lasker and of other members who had died during the recess. The Deputies remained standing, as a mark of respect, while this announcement was being made.

A concert given at Steinway Hall last evening made known to the public a young violinist of great ability and still greater promise. Mr. George Lehman, who studied violin playing in Leipsic, is about 18 or 19 years of age.

The Board of Street-opening and Improvement listened to some more talk yesterday on the petition of several Lexington-avenue property-owners to remove the eleveated railroad shops at Ninety-eighth and Ninety-ninth streets. R.H. Gallaway, Vice-President of the Manhattan Railway Company, submitted plans for running the street under the shops 14 feet below the preent grade.

HAVANA, March 7.--Advices from St. Thomas of Feb. 26 report that two very severe earthquake shocks were felt on that island recently. The American corvette Alliance left St. Thomas on Feb 24 for St. Kitts.
SAUKIN, March 7.--Oaman Digna, the rebel leader, refuses to negotiate and ignores the flag of truce sent out from the Suakin forts. Gen. Graham is already beginning the advance against him.

Francois Lobert, an aged and blind mendicant, who plays a violin, is led about the city by a dog, and he exhibits a sign, setting forth that he is alone in the world. He was committed yesterday by Justice White on a charge of mendicancy.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7.--A student standing before the Post Office here to-day said to a TIMES reporter: "Yes, most of us are eating very humble pie to-day;" and so it is. No massmeeting was held last night to afford opportunity for the presentation of MacMullin's letter to the students before its appearance in print. This fact caused some doubt in the minds of the students to-day as to their exact position.

NORFOLK, Va., March 7.--In the Corporation Court, to-night, Charles L. Whitehurst was convicted of the murder of Junius A. Rogers. The jury brought in a verdict of murder in the second degree and fixed his imprisonment at 12 years in the penitentiary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 7.--Anna Smith, the wife of George Smith, of Birmingham, who, with her husband and Theodore Forest, are accused of making and attempting to pass counterfeit coin, was tried in this city today before United States Commissioner Johnson T. Platt.

The Queens County Grand Jury concluded the examination of witnesses in the Townsend, Sprague and May bee cases yesterday morning. They then began to examine witnesses in regard to the poisoning of the Collyers at Laurel Hill.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 7.--This forenoon all the officers of the St. Paul Railroad received a printed circular, issued by Manager S. S. Merrill, announcing the appointment of Roswell Miller as Assistant General Manager of the road.

The special Assembly committee of which Mr. Roosevelt is Chairman devoted nearly six hours yesterday to the Surrogate's office. All the members of the committee were present. William J. Trimble, the probate clerk, who has a salary of $2,000 a year, said that when attorneys asked him to draw up an order he expected to be paid for it.
OMAHA, Neb., March 7.--Bishop Clarkson lies at the point of death. It a probable he will not live till morning.

Gen. and Mrs. Grant passed through here at 6 o'clock this morning, en route to Old Point Comfort, Va. Gen. and Mrs. Beale and their daughter, who were to have joined Gen. Grant's party here, postponed their departure on account of the inclement weather and Mrs. Beale's delicate health.

A jury in the Supreme Court yesterday practically upheld the will of Cynthia Hesdra, a wealthy colored woman, who died in 1879. The relatives of Mrs. Hesdra contended that the will was a forgery prepared for the benefit of Edward D. Hesdra, her husband.
WICHITA, KAN., March 7.--A man said to be Tiller, the St. Louis express robber, was arrested here this afternoon and turned over to the Sheriff.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 7.--On the night of Aug. 29, 1881, William McGregor, an ex-engineer of the Great Western Railway, was found on the Hamilton and North-western track at Hamilton, just under the Great Western Railway bridge, his body fearfully mangled.
CINCINNATI, March 7.--The first dog show, of any considerable pretentions, in Cincinnati, closed to-night. The management seems to have been pleased with the result.

While carrying a can of kerosene last evening Mary Murray, aged 10, of Newark, fell and spilled it over her clothing. On arriving at her home she attempted to dry her dress before the stove, when it took fire, and in an instant she was enveloped in flames. Before they could be extinguished she was burned in a shocking manner, and was conveyed to the hospital in a dying condition.

ROANOKE CITY, Va., March 7.--Information has been received here that a revenue informer was hanged last Saturday night in Floyd County by moonshiners. The name of the person said to have been hanged is not given. Floyd is a remote south-western county, far away from railroads and telegraph offices.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 7.--Superintendent Maxwell, of the Chamber of Commerce, to-day made public interesting comparative figures with reference to the hog product here for the past Winter.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 7.--Officer James Walsh, an old member of the police force, was dismissed to-day after an investigation of charges made against him.

SCHENECTADY, March 7.--A meeting of the Twentieth Congressional District Republicans to elect delegates to Chicago has been called to meet at Schenectady April 16.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 7.--While James Higgins, of No. 63 Ferry-street, Fair Haven, was erecting an electric clock in the factory of the Electrical Supply Company, in Ansonia, this afternoon, he was caught by a revolving shaft making 125 revolutions a minute. All his clothing was torn off, and nearly every bone in his body broken. He was immediately brought to the hospital in this city. He cannot recover.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 7.--Frey and Wharton were the contestants in the first series at the afternoon session of the pool tournament. The champion played unusually well, and won the series by a score of 10 to 6.

OWEGO, March 7.--The Twenty-sixth Congressional District is one of the strong Republican districts which will be relied upon to roll up a heavy vote for the next Presidential candidate. It is permeated with Garfield sentiment. Madison County gave the dead President 2,110 majority; Chenango, 1,210; Broome, 1,723, and Tioga, 1,123.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 7.--A very important decision was rendered yesterday by Judge Deady in the United States District Court. The case involves the authority of the State of Oregon to collect a tax on mortgages held by foreign corporations, which is a matter of vital importance to Portland and the State generally.

DES MOINES, March 1.--The Republican politicians of Iowa say that the State's delegates will go to the Republican National Convention without pledges or instructions. "We have no candidate now." said one of the most active and influential of these gentlemen, "and there shall not be any if I can help it.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--The extension of leave of absence granted First Lieut. Charles G. Ayres, Tenth Cavalry, in special orders of Dec. 10, 1883, has been further extended one month, and the extension of leave of absence on Sergeon's certificate of disability granted Second Lieut. Alfred McC. Ogle, Nineteenth Infantry, in special orders of Aug. 31, 1883, is further extended six months on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

LONDON, March 8.--The steam-ship Brookffield, (Br.,) Capt. Reynolds, from New-York Feb. 21, has arr. at Newcastle.

PARIS, March 7.--The Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks, of Indiana, has returned to Paris from his trip in Southern Europe. He was not pleased with his trip. He considers Italy unhealthful for Americans to visit at this time of year.

A project has been set on foot for the founding of a hospital and clinic for the treatment of cancer cases exclusively. Mr. John E. Parsons is the President of the organization in charge of the matter and Mr. Joseph W. Drexel is the Treasurer.

The "Italian bandit," Giuseppe Panizza, who, with Cesare Picone, is accused of inducing vincenzo Dragone, a musician of the Casino orchestra, to accompany him to a house in East Twenty-fifth-street on March 7, 1883, and there, at the point of the knife, compelling him to sign a note for $1,000, was yesterday placed on trial before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions.

LABANON, Penn., March 7.--The will of the late Manus G. Friel, probated to-day, makes the following bequests: To the Orphans' Home of St. Mary's Catholic Church of this place, $10,000; the Catholic parochial school, $7,000; the Catholic theological seminary, at Harrisburg, $2,000; the St. Lawrence Catholic Church, at Harrisburg, $1,000, and for the erection of a Catholic church at Cornwall, $1,500.
BOSTON, March 7.--The leading lawyers here are interesting themselves in the appointment of a successor to Judge Lowell, who has just resigned his place as Circuit Judge for this circuit.

MANCHESTER, March 7.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "There is but small change in the market, although in some quarters prices are a hade firmer, owing to large purchases of cotton at Liverpool."

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 7.--The schooner Tidal Wave, from the Georges, which arrived this morning, reports cutting away 150 fathoms of cable on March 5 to escape a collision with the abandoned schooner Stephen J. Fooks. The Fooks is a collier belonging to Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--The Signal Corps Station at Chincoteague, Va., reports at 6:35 P.M. that a dense fog prevailed and that an unknown steamer was ashore three miles south-east of Assateague, Va. The life-saving crew had gone to her assistance.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 7.--John H. Stone, nominated by the Republicans for Attorney-General, has declined, saying that he is a Democrat and will support the Democratic nominees.

A Greene-street stable sustains and shelters a thorough-bred goat of the male species. Yesterday afternoon, through the open door, a young darky could be seen astride the animal's horns, trying to ride it around the stable. "Get off from that goat," yelled the driver of a passing street car. "Get off from that goat!" howled the conductor.

The public rehearsal prefatory to the fifth concert given this season by the Symphony Society of New-York took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon in presence of a very numerous audience. The New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company has recently put in some of its locomotives a new patent "smokeburner." The engineer controls this by a small lever near the air brake appliance. One of these locomotives--No. 512--was passing through Croton on its way up the river, when this lever blew out.
WASHINGTON, March 7, 1884. At the evening session of the House 19 pen sion bills were passed, among them one granting a pension to the widow of Gen. Judson Kilpatrick.

Augustin Daly is already making preparations for the customary Summer tour of his company, and its travels during the coming Summer promise to be varied and extensive. On Thursday Mr. Daly concluded arrangements by which his entire comedy organization will appear in London in July in several of the comedies in which it has been so successful here.

Burt, of this city, and Mr. C.B. Angle, the secretary, of Albany, met yesterday at the New-York Hotel. Their object was to make arrangements for the general examination of applicants for the State civil service.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 7.--William Buchner, Collector of Customs at Fort Erie, Ontario, has been suspended from his office. It is understood that he has embezzled $5,000 of the funds intrusted io him. An investigation is being made by Inspector T.C. Muburn, of Hamilton.

SCHENECTADY, March 7.--S.R. James, a leading wholesale and retail crockey dealer in this section, transferred his stock and trade to his father-in-law to cover indebtedness to the latter of $60,000. James was a partner in the crockery establishment in Milwaukee, and debts of the latter concern inolved him to such an extent that a bill of sale was necessary for his protection.

The deaths in Brooklyn during last week were but 199, being 39 less than the previous week, and 80 less than the corresponding week of 1883.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., March 7.--Two burglars are under arrest here and are held until word can be obtained from the New-York authorities what to do with them.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 7.--David McLain, who enticed W.S. Saxton to his gate on Feb. 5, 1879, and shot him dead in the presence of his family, was publicly hanged at Trader's Hill at noon to-day. McLain raved like a mamac. His death was not painful.

Abel Easton, a lawyer and the keeper of a Turkish bath in East Forty-sixth-street, was before the Senate Investigating Committee yesterday to tell what he knew about the Public Works Department. Through the questioning of Mr. Whittridge, counsel for the committee, Mr. Easton was induced to tell all about the formation of the company owning the bath.

For a quiet town the Bloomfield (N.J.) Republicans had a lively caucus last night. In a Presidential year the Republicans can always count on over 400 majority out of a total vote of 1,100. The local officers are all Republican, and some of them have held their places undisturbed for years. For nearly a year there has been some dissatisfaction among the young men of the party ...

A mild mannered man of middle age, who is in the wholesale oil business on Cedarstreet, got off a Jersey City ferry-boat yesterday afternoon and walked briskly along Libertystreet toward Broadway. Just as he crossed Church-street he was approached by a respectably dressed young man of suave manner and pleasing address.

OTTAWA, March 7.--Mr. Lowe, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture, has, it is reported, got himself into trouble over the exodus matter.
The seats in the Stock Exchange of the late Julius Hallgarten and George N. Kennedy have been sold for about $25,000 each.

A row of straps attached to the bell-cord hangs along the sides of the street cars on a west side line. Yesterday afternoon a fat woman, desiring to have the car stop, threw her weight on one of the straps. A tall man standing on the rear platform with his back to the car, clapped his hand to his ear and ejaculated. "Holy Moses!" The conductor grinned and rang the bell.
Judge Allison's wife was severely injured by a remarkable accident on Tuesday afternoon. About 4 o'clock she alighted from a Walnut-street car at the Forty-second-street station.

CHICAGO, March 7.--The new fast mail train between New-York and Chicago is not looked upon very favorably by the people of the railway mail service here.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 7.--The Yale College Faculty have notified Ayers and Coule, two applicants for places on the lacrosse team which is going abroad, that if they leave before Commencement they must receive their degrees with the Class of '85.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--A well-dressed woman went into a fashionable Chestnut-street clothing house yesterday and asked to be measured for a pair of trousers. After she had been served an attendant said to a reporter: "We make men's suits for ladies right along.

Mr. Charles Stuart Welles, of this city, lectured before the Liberal Club, in East Fifteenth-street, near Third-avenue, last night, on "The New Marriage; or, Uniform Marriage Laws." Mr. Welles treated of the legal aspect of his subject in a previous lecture. His argument last night was mainly devoted to the religious view of the subject of marriage.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 7.--It is reported that the question as to whether the powers granted to the Canadian Pacific Railway Company enabled that company to do general telegraph business has been discussed by the Ministers.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 7.--Edwin Botheras, who fatally shot William Nichols at Hazleton on Saturday, was given a hearing this morning before Alderman Parsons.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 7.--The Faculty of Hamilton College has reconsidered its rejection of the compromise with the bolting Seniors suggested by Theodore W. Dwight, of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 7.--Nine Italians of the crew of the Italian bark Tonio refused to sail with their vessel the other day on the ground that she was bound for a South American port ...
TITUSVILLE, Penn., March 7.--Dispatches have been received from thoroughly trustworthy sources, which if correct betoken the opening of another oil field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 7.--Fifteen thousand persons assembled in the Pavilion last evening to witness the Sullivan-Robinson match, and it is estimated that as many more were turned away. The receipts from the sale of tickets were nearly $20,000. Tickets were sold at $5 advance. The arrangements, which were under the management of Hugh Goyle, were perfect.
All outside offices for the sale of emigrant tickets are now closed and the sale confined to Castle Garden. The Lehigh Valley is there represented in the office of the Pennsylvania Road.

DANVILLE, Va., March 7.--William S. Palmer, living near Reidsville, N.C., indicted for the murder of a negro, Martin Yaney, on Jan. 30 last, was acquitted to-day in the Hustings Court after a trial of nearly three days' duration.

LONG BRANCH, March 7.--William E. Robbins, the proprietor of the grocery store on Main-street, in the cellar of which the fire on Thursday morning originated, has been arrested charged with arson. When the flames were subdued a committee of citizens and firemen examined the cellar to ascertain their cause.
The House should promptly concur in Mr. SEWELL'S new Militia Appropriation bill, which passed the Senate almost without question and without a division.

UTICA, N.Y., March 7.--The call for the Congressional District Convention, Twenty-third District, to be issued to-morrow, specifies as one of the duties of the convention the choice of a Presidential Elector for the district. The convention will meet April 17 at Booneville.
The report of a committee on revision of the rates of brokers' commissions was considered by the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Major H.V. King presided.

Mr. Burt D. Bishop, the member of the Relief Committee of the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce who was chosen to make a trip along the lower river towns and distribute money among those who had sustained loss by the flood, has completed the work, having visited 43 towns and villages.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 7.--Issac M. Burr, of this city, was arrested last night for forgeries aggregating $1,500. He secured the amount from Mrs. Jane A. Sherman, of Danbury. He was held in $4,000.

LONDON, March 8.--The exhibition of the Royal Hibernian Academy at Dublin is a great success. The best English artists contribute. John Everett Millais, Sir Frederick Leighton, Val Princep, and others send their best new work. Among the Irish artists, Coles, Watkins, Alfred Grey, Bingham, and McGuiness are conspicuous. The exhibition is already leading to many orders to Irish artists for work.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8.--Mrs. Carrie B. Kilgore, who has long been waging a gallant fight for admission to practice as a lawyer at the Bar of the Common Pleas Courts in this city, was again rebuffed to-day by an adverse decision in Court No.1, rendered by Judges Allison and Biddle.

At dinner, it is hardly necessary to say, the obtain a due proportion of the fats and oils in very varied forms. It is true we do not emulate the nutritive existence of the Esquimaux, whose dietary of blubber and fats constitutes the summum, bonum of a life spent amid perpetual snow.

CHICAGO, March 8.--While skating on the lake off Racine, Wis., to-day, Alexander Jones, 14 years old, disappeared throuch an air-hole. His companions rushed to his assistance and saw him through the clear ice 20 feet from the airhole, whence he was swept by the undercurrent. They tried to break through the ice with their skates while the unfortunate lad endeavored to assist by bumping his head against it, but failed, and the boy was drowned.
The President gave a dinner at the White House to-night in honor of Mr. Henry Irving and Miss Terry, to which a few intimate friends were invited.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 8.--Two months ago Maurice Agulski, a Russian Jew, came to Toronto, leaving a wife and child in New-York. His wife came here yesterday, having ascertained that her husband had married Miss Hyman under the name of Goldstein. She obtained a warrant for his arrest this morning, but Agulski, hearing of it, left the city, and has not yet been captured.

WASHINGTON, March 8.--A.M. Gibson was examined by Mr. Springer's committee to-day relative to his connection with the star route investigation. He said that he had received $5,000 for his services as counsel, and he proposed to show that he had earned that amount, and that it was small compensation in comparison with the amount paid to other parties for services.

Four dingy-looking fast mail cars, a, weather-beaten express car, and a bright yellow Directors' car stood in the yard at the Grand Central Station at 8:45 o'clock last evening. Soveral muscular men tossed mail-pouches into the postal cars from several mail-vans, others ran confusedly up and down the station, and the engineer, the calmest man within speaking distance, held down the safety-valve a of his engine to save the steam.

Delia, Moran, of No. 13 Roosevelt-street, was walking down Fulton-street to her work yesterday, when she was knocked down by August Welland, age 25, an ex-convict, who was under the influence of liquor, and kicked in the stomach. Officer Shaeffer, of the First Precinct, arrested Welland, and in the Tombs Police Court, while the girl was telling her story to Justice Duffy, the prisoner attempted to strike her.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 8.--C.D. Sharp was last August found guilty of outraging Amanda and Emma Clark, aged respectively 16 and 12 years. The penalty in the first case is 50 years in the penitentiary, and in the other death. He has been sentenced to be hanged at Gainesmille on April 25.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 8.--Mrs. Julia Ann Worst, of New-Holland, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging herself with a rope in the garret of her residence. She had been suffering from melancholia for several months past and no doubt took her own life while under its influence, as there is no known cause for the rash act.
BOSTON, March 8.--The Rev. J.S. Cantwell, D.D., Pastor of the Universalist Church in North Attleboro, has resigned his charge to accept the position of editor of the Universalist, of Chicago.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 8.--The water in front of this city rose 5 inches to-day, and now marks 8 inches under the high-water mark, which is the top of the levees. Two days more of a rise like that of to-day and the water will pour over the bank and into the streets of the city. The water is already percolating through the embankment in the lower part of the city.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 8.--This morning at the Supreme Court, Chambers, Messrs. Harris and Ecclesine, counsel for William McDonald, the witness who last week was punished by the Senate for contempt, applied to Judge Learned for a writ of habeas corpus to review the action of the Senate.

RICHMOND, Va., March 8.--The Democrats to-day introduced a bill in the Virginia Senate which proposes to make radical changes in the present system of public schools in the State. The measure contemplates creating the office of Director of Schools in all the counties in the Commonwealth. The colored people are to have their own Directors and the whites theirs.

CINCINNATI, March 8.--Mrs. Cummings, a somnambulist, visiting her brother, Mr. Vanderwort, at Loveland, Ohio, was quartered for the night in a room on the second floor. Shortly after 10 o'clock she arose in her sleep, imagining that murderers were in the house, put on her slippers, got out on the roof of a veranda, slipped ...

Christian Rothgerber, a German, 33 years of age, who kept a bakery at No. 1,154 First-avenue, committed suicide last evening by shooting himself in the right temple with a revolver. He lived with his family, consisting of his wife, three children, 7, 5, and 3 years old, and an infant 6 months old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. March 8.--George Holt, formerly a soldier at Fort Adams, and later a civil constable of Newport, deserted his wife and was married six months ago. In a letter received by his wife to-day Holt says that she is the fourth woman he has married, and that he had to go or he would soon be behind the bars.

HAVANA, March 8.--The various boards representing commerce, agriculture, and different industries throughout the island, and other corporations of a similar nature, were desirous of holding a mass-meeting in Havana. Their objet was to effect a union with one another and to ask directly from the home Government for ...

LONDON, March 8.--The dynamite scare is subsiding, but the papers still continue to harp upon the duty of America to suppress conspiracy. The Saturday Review says: "The new form of Irish warfare is as dangerous to Americans as to Englishmen. It a portmanteau belonging to au Irish conspirator who is about to quit ...

A considerable number of persons assembled in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon when Mr. Baillie Hamilton, a young Englishman, exhibited his new musical instrument, the "vocation." This instrument is designed to fill the place of the large pipe organ in any church where economy of space and money must be considered.

The moon was not shining with a silvery radiance in the clear blue heavens. The heavens were not clear nor blue. Tne gentle zephyrs were not crooning through the pine trees with a soft murmur like that of as Eolian harp. The shrill voice of the cicada was not heard amid the umbrageous foliage, nor was the whisper of lovers' voices wafted sweetly upward by the evening air.
QUBEC, March 8.--Sergt. Harpe, of the provincial police, has gone to New-York. taking with him a man named Brown, who mysteriously left his family some time ago.

Last week witnessed the completion of one and the commencement of another important addition to the Indian railway system. The Central Bengal Line, begun about three years ago, has now been opened from Calcutta to Khoolna, while at Poonah, on Wednesday, the Governor of Bombay performed the ceremony ...

Gen. Winslow stated yesterday that the special committee designated to arbitrate the accounts between the West Shore Railway and the North River Construction Company had prepared the draft of its report. He denied that the report had been signed, and said that its provisions would not be made public at present.

The Alliance Israelite Universelle has issued a circular calling attention to the Purim collection in aid of the schools under its charge for training the children of Hebrews in Oriental lands "where, by reason of mediaeval laws or a bigoted and ignorant public sentiment, the work of emancipation is still difficult."

PARKERSBURG, West Va., March 8.--Considerable interest is felt in Burning Springs, near this city, over the result of the deep oil tests now being made in that once famous territory. The experimental well on Capt. Joe Simpson's land is now at a depth of 1,480 feet, with a flow ...

At the usual weekly meeting of the Mayor's Cabinet yesterday a resolution was adopted suggesting that the Park Commissioners should have a bill prepared for presentation to the Legislature providing for the changing of the name of Reservoir-square to Bryant Park.

The steam-ship Gloucester, Capt. Peters, of the Great Western Line, arrived yesterday from Bristol and Swansea after a voyage of nearly a month. Her bows bore evidences of her having been caught among ice-fields. She brought the crew of the British bark George Peabody, which was lost in the ice which now covers the Banks of Newfoundland. The bark left this port for Dunkirk with a cargo of oil on Feb. 9.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., March 8.--When Mrs. George Smith, whom United States Commissioner Johnson T. Platt refused to hold in New-Haven yesterday on the charge of uttering counterfeit money, arrived at her home, in this place, last evening, the indignant local officials ...

ATLANTIC CITY, March 8.--The steamer Clydesdale, of Glasgow, Scotland, from Kingston, Jamaica, for New-York, with a general cargo, eight passenger, and a crew of nineteen men, struck on Brigantine Shoals last evening, at 5 o'clock, during a heavy fog.
LONDON, March 8.--Advices from Hong Kong state that Admiral Lespes has assumed command of the French fleet in Tonquin.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 8.--The United States Veterinary Surgeon at Fort Leavenworth, Dr. Holcomb, detailed to investigate the cattle disease in Woodson County, reports that the foot and mouth disease exists in a severe form, and not the dreaded anthrax, or black leg, as at first supposed, which is much more fatal, ...

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, March 8.--A special from Fresnillo, State of Zacatecas, says: "The final spike in the Mexican Central Railroad was driven to-day on a broad plain six miles from Fresnillo, at 4:50 in the afternoon, in the presence of a distinguished assemblage. There is now an unbroken railroad from Mexico City to the Rio Grande.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 8.--After a long and bitter debate the Democratic members of the General assembly in caucus voted last night on the graded tax substitute for the Scott liquor law and it was lost, receiving five votes less than a majority of all the members. It was, however, reconsidered and will come up again at caucus next week, when an attempt will be made to have present 38 members who were absent last night.

BUFFALO, March 8.--The resignation of John C. Graves as Brigadier-General of the Eighth Brigade has been accepted by Adjt.-Gen. Farnsworth. Gen. Graves was to-day handed a letter by Col. A.E. Rockwood, Assistant Adjutant-General on Major-Gen. Rogers's staff, accepting the resignation. Adjt.-Gen. Farnsworth compliments Gen. Graves, and the letter is also signed by Gov. Cleveland.

Police Commissioner Partridge and Health Commissioner Raymond, of Brooklyn, have prepared, with the approval of Mayor Low, a series of regulations for the government of candidates seeking positions in the departments of which they have charge. Both departments are specially exempted from the operation of the civil service law. The regulations for the Police Department apply only to those ...

The Commissioners appointed by the Court of Appeals to determine what damages should be awarded to Rufus Story for the depreciation of the value of his property in Frontstreet by the structure of the elevated railroad examined the premises yesterday morning and then met at the office of ex-Judge Russell to hear testmony.

CHICAGO, March 8.--Albert Wilson, aged 21, resided with his brother David, at No. 66 Chicago-avenue, and became too intimate with David's wife. David traced the guilty pair to a hotel. Late last night the wife knocked at his house for admission. It was refused her. This morning she came again.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 8.--Gov. Waller was interviewed this afternoon regarding the late unpleasantness between himself and Judge Birdsall. The Governor expressed himself very forcibly on the matter. He said that he considered a newspaper that would print the privaite correspondence of any man a low, mean sheet.

At midnight on Friday Annie Maher rushed out of her house at No.1,134 First-avenue and told Officer O'Rorke that her husband had just tried to shoot her. Her husband, who is a liquor-dealer, and who was charged a short time ago with beating her and with engaging in dogfighting, was locked up in the Twenty-eighth precinct Police Station.

NEW-HAVEN, March 8.--Mrs. Elizabeth H. Lewis, 50 years old, and her daughter, 16 years old, were found dead in one bed at their home, No. 13 Asylum-street, this afternoon. About three weeks ago the husband, of Mrs. Lewis, John E. Lewis, one of the two bank watchmen ...

No information concerning the whereabouts of John McMahon, the missing Collector of Hoboken, has as yet been received. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the Aldermen's investigating committee took possession of the Collector's office.
Twelve candidates for the position of Superintendent of Police Telegraph underwent a competitive examination at the Brooklyn Police Central Office last evening.

CHICAGO, March 8.--Toward midnight last night Capt. James Dalton, the pugilist, who is booked for a sparring match at Hershey Hall to-morrow night, was standing before the bar of the Park Theatre with a number of boon companions.

CHICAGO, March 8.--Regarding the alleged break in east-bound freight rates, while there has been no open cut, there seems to be every reason to believe that large contracts have been made here to-day on a basis of 15 cents on grain to New-York, and this fact has been telegraphed to other points by certain shippers from this city.

A proverb is a useful piece of literature, but is there no exception to the rule that in the mouth of the gift horse one must not look? In some cases duty admonishes us not to look only but to sound every tooth, and wisely form conclusions, even to the return of the gift horse with thanks.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 8.--Newport, Ky., was so wrecked by the flood that when the question of how to apply the relief so generously sent by the people of the United States came up for settlement it was found that assistance in putting poor people back in their homes was of the greatest importance.

Carlton at Watertown last Summer, and held in confinement so long on insufficient evidence before his final discharge, has petitioned through counsel for compensation, and his case was heard by a legislative committee yesterday. Read and Dr. Gustave Sussdorf, to recover $50,000 for the loss of her daughter Clara's services. DUNCAN, Shipping Commissioner for the Port of New-York and Superintendent of the Sunday-school of the Tompkins-Avenue Congregational Church in Brooklyn, has lately been engaged in an attempt to get $100,000 damages from THE TIMES. MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 8.--A severe snow-storm has prevailed in this city for 24 hours past, and there is no immediate prospects of a cessation of the storm. At the Signal Service Office the information is given out that the storm is general over the North-west, and in many places the fall is the heaviest of the season. In the extreme North-west the weather has turned ...

William N. Loew, the lawyer who agreed to collect $40 from Louis Scheier, a young jeweler, of No. 52 Suffolk-street, in payment to Charles Vitreol and his wife, for arranging an engagement of marriage between Scheier and Rosie Goodman, was in the Tombs Police Court yesterday in answer to a summons.

The fifth concert given this season by the Symphony Society of New-York took place at the Academy of Music last evening. The programme was the same as offered at the Friday afternoon rehearsal and already reviewed at some length in these columns. The interpretation was all that could be desired, and the impression produced was of the very best kind.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 8.--The contests in the Yale athletic meeting to-day were unusually exciting and well attended. In the tug of war between representatives of the Class of '84 of the academic department and Sheffield Scientific School the Scientific giants won by 6 inches. The team from the Class of '87, aggregating over 800 pounds, were defeated by the 600-pound team of '85 by 6 inches.

Gen. Egbert L. Viele presented his report of the practical workings of the cable railway in Chicago to the Commissioners of Rapid Transit yesterday afternoon. The number of horses, ha said, used in the 152 miles of surface railway in Chicago was 1,700.

"Oh, will yez go away?" howled a gigantic policeman, bracing his back against the Madison-Square Garden at the Fourth-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street corner at 8 o'clock last evening. "Yez" didn't stir. "Yez" had been walking around and around the garden all day, trying to get a peep at Barnum's circus which was inside.

Mrs. C. Vanderbilt, widow of Commodore Vanderbilt, gave a luncheon party to 24 young ladies and gentlemen yesterday at her residence, No. 10 Washington-place. An elaborate luncheon was served by Clark. There were music and dancing after the repast.

There was a meeting of veterans last evening in Miller's Hotel, No. 52 Union-square, in the interest of the Union Veteran Army bill now pending before Congress. The bill was introduced in the House of Representatives on Jan. 7, and is an act granting land warrants to soldiers and sailors in the Federal service in the war of the rebellion, and to their widows and orphans, ...

LONDON, March 8.--An informal meeting of the Cabinet was held on Friday. As a result of the deliberations, definite instructions have been sent to Sir Evelyn Baring, British Minister at Cairo, and to Gen. Stephenson, the commander of the British forces in Egypt, in regard to the Government's policy in Egypt. Sir Evelyn Baring's scheme for financial reform is virtually rejected, though the Government says it is held for the present in suspension.

WASHINGTON, March 8.--Capt. Joseph H. Willard, Corps of Engineers, has been relieved from duty as a member of the general court-martial convened at Willett's Point, New-York Harbor, by special orders Jan. 3, 1884.

And here, fortunately, there are no misty traditions which the sun of criticism ruthlessly dispels, no tombstones at variance with the registers of births and deaths, and no entries about one sister.

Mr. Stetson yesterday received an ominous-looking box, on the upper left hand corner of which was written: "With the compliments of Lilly Langtry. My honest debts." In the box reposed two dozen extremely fine silk handkerchiefs, the reception of which was explained by Mr. Stetson on the ground that he had made a bet with Mrs. Langtry on the relative returns of her engements here and in Boston.

The Wall-street ferry-boat America had just left her slip on the New-York side on her 4 o'clock trip to Brooklyn, when a cry of "man overboard" was raised, and a few seconds later a young man W.K. Butts, who had been standing near the chains on the forward part of the steamer, was seen struggling in the water. The ferry-boat then had got some distance into the stream.

CHICAGO, March 8.--The first primaries in the State were held to-day in Douglass County, and resulted in giving Congressman Cannon, the present Representative from the Fifteenth District, the county delegation, thus practically assuring his renomination. He was elected in 1882 by a plurality of 1,217,and can undoubtedly carry the district again.

Numbers of people who had been spending the evening out and returned to their homes during the early hours of yesterday morning were to be seen clinging hopelessly to the iron fences and holding on for grim death. The streets were covered with a thin coasting of ice, which rendered walking a precarious and almost impossible operation.

FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, March 8.-- Gen. Grant held a reception in his parlor at 11 o'clock this morning. Gen. Tidball, commandant, and the officers of the garrison, and other army and navy officers at the hotel called. A national salute was fired from the fort at noon is honor of Gen. Grant's arrival.

For several years an intrigue, mainly fostered by Caroline Jagemann, had been forming with a view of compelling Goethe to resign his post, the Duke's affection for the latter having long excited the jealousy of the favorite, between whom and the Superintendent no very amicable feeling existed.

FARGO, Dakota, March 8.--It is stated that an agent of the Dominion Government here claims to have discovered that a meeting was held last night over the Gold Mine saloon, by secessionist agitators, and that fiery speeches were made by M.J. McGuire, of Chicago, and Harry O'Neil, of Fargo.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8.--A cloud-burst near Caliente at 11:30 o'clock last night covered in an instant the track of the Southern Pacific Railroad for a distance of several hundred feet with two feet of sand and water. Buildings near by were covered to a depth of 18 inches.

"Uncle Rufus" Hatch ceased to be a member of the Stock Exchange some years ago, but he has kept up business relations with some of its members ever since. He visited the subscribers' room yesterday and was invited be the Chairman to take a sent on the rostrum in the board-room.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 8.--A dispatch from Clifton, Arizona, dated yesterday, says: The heavy rains for the past 48 hours have swelled the San Francisco River to such an extent that the iron suspension bridge of the Arizona and New-Mexico Railway has been carried away, causing a loss of $25,000.
Speaker Carlisle has accepted the invitation of the New-York Free Trade Club to be present at its annual dinner at Delmonico's on March 15.
OMAHA, Neb., March 8.--Bishop Clarkson is still alive. His Great vitality and splendid constitution have sustained him beyond the expectation of his physician.

BUFFALO, March 8.--All the union printers in the employ of the Courier struck to-day, doing out when time was called. The union men comprised about half the Courier force. The non-union men continued at work. Two years ago there was a general strike of printers in Buffalo for an advance from 32 to 35 cents per 1,000 cms.

Collector Robertson sent to the Treasury Department yesterday an answer to the recent letter of Assistant secretary FrencH calling for information relative to the effect of stopping the importation from Great Britain of neat cattle, in consequence of the prevalence of a contagious hoof and mouth disease.

Capt. James W. Brainsted, of the ferryboat Westfield, was arrested Friday night in East Thirty--eighth-street as a suspicious person by Central Office detectives. In the Tombs Police Court yesterday the detectives asked Justice Duffy to discharge the Captain, asthey had made a mistake.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 8.--The Cotton Exchange this afternoon unanimously passed resolutions urging Texas Congressmen to oppose the further coinage of silver dollars upon the present basis of valuations.

Elwell, President of the Maritime Exchange, testified before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation yesterday relative to the manner in which the Harbor-masters have performed their duties since last May. Senators Fassett, Robb, and Coggeshall were the only members of the committee present.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 8.--Prominent labor leaders in this city met to-night and formed the Supreme Council of the National Homestead Association by electing the following officers: President--A.C. Rankin; Vice-President--D.B. Sturgeon, M.D.; Secretary--Matthew W. Smith; Treasurer--John Jarrett; Attorney--J.H. Stevenson. The object of the association is to assist the laboring classes to secure homes and to cultivate the spirit of economy. Branched will be organized as rapidly as possible in the principal cities of the country.

Mr. Matthew Arnold sailed for Liverpool yesterday afternoon on the Cunard steam-ship Servia. Among those who took leave of Mr. Arnold on the Servia were Mrs. R.M. Stuart, Mr. W.T. Hatch, Mr. Charles Butler and Miss Butler, and Mr. and Mrs. Coddington and daughter.

BIRMINGHAM, March 8.--William J. Cornell, who for the past 15 years has been preparing himself to cuter the Jesuit order, returned a few weeks ago from the novitiate of the order at Woodstock, Md., to his home in this place, worn out by severe study. Last night he became violently insance, and attempted to kill all the members of his family.

The special committee of the Assembly which is investigating the business methods of the different departments of this city devoted most of its time yesterday to the Surrogate's office. Some attention was also paid to the Tax Office and Park Commissioners.

PITTSBURG, March. 8.--The Delegate Convention, representing the Pittsburg district of the Amalgamated Association, was held in this city to-day to discuss the scale of wages which the iron-workers will present to the manufacturers at the annual conference on June 1.

According to the affidavit of Annie Ellis, wife of a gun-smith, Martha Severn, wife of a cook, attacked her at No. 54 Barrow-street, where they live, "with a calf's limb," and blackened her eye on Thursday. Yesterday Mrs. Severn was arrested, and she told a very different story.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 8.--A number of the window glass blowers who were idle during the strike here, and went to Belgium to work, where they were promised large wages, have returned to this city, and report that matters are not so rosy in the glass-making trade in that country, since the men have a returned to work in the United States.

KEOKUK, Iowa., March 8.--The Mackley Block, at Memphis, Mo., was burned yesterday. The loss on the building is $20,000, and on stock and furniture, $16,000. Laomi Mott, Philip Payne, and Samuel Dobyns were buried beneath the falling walls, and Perry Tucker, Lee Davis, Hallett Sanford, and Mrs. McDale were seriously injured. The body of Payne has been recovered, and the search is being continued for the others.

EBENSBURG, Penn., March 8.--Michael Murray, whose trial began here on Thursday last, was found guilty this morning of murder in the first degree. Murray lost a leg 17 years ago. For the last four years he has been a vagrant. He is 51 years old and was never married. His victim, John W. Hancuff, was 29 years old and had a wife and child.

WASHINGTON, March 8, 1884. The Postmaster-General has appointed N.G. Summerfield Assistant Superintendent of Railway Mail Service in connection with his position of chief clerk of that service.

BOSTON, Mass., March 8.--The Directors of the Union Market National Bank of Watertown, closed by the defalcation of Treasurer Abbott, have received authority from Washington to resume business. Ample provision has been made to pay any and all depositors who may desire to withdraw their deposits.

NEW-HAVEN, March 8.--The Sunday Register will publish a report of a movement to form an organization of independent revenue reformers the object being to hold the balance of power and cast the votes of the members with the party planting itself nearest to its platforms. David A. Wells and Prof. Sumner are in the movement.

BOSTON, March 8.--One of the boldest cases of shop-breaking in this city for some time occurred to-day at the pawn shop of Isaac Myer. At noon Myer locked the store door and went to dinner. On his return, at 1 o'clock, he found that his store had bean entered by thieves and a large amount of his foods taken.

The steamer Belgenland, of the Red Star Line, arrived at her wharf at the foot of Grandstreet, Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. Instead of turning into the wharf on her way up stream, she steamed north, and, turning, rode down to the dock on the ebb tide.

The Board of Managers of the Produce Exchange has adopted a new rule which will be submitted to a vote of the members. It provides that when a member fails his contracts shall be settled on the same day or on one of the two days following, at the option of the holder or holders of his contracts.

CHICAGO, March 8.--The Consolidated Paper Company, manufacturing coarse wrapping paper, has made an assignment. The liabilities are $97,000 and the assets $125,000. The assets consist of bills receivable and open accounts to the amount of $25,000, and wrapping paper stock valued at $100,000.

In 1618 one Dud Dudley first used coal for smelting iron. A hundred years afterward Henry Cort paddled iron. These two men laid the foundation of England's metallurgic supremacy, and yet both of them starved for their pains. It can hardly be said, however, that to-day great inventors, like poets and philosophers, go without their rewards.

Niles, and a warrant has been issued for Niles's arrest on the charge of manslaughter.

BUFFALO, March 8.--Eight or ten sporting men, who attended a cock-fight near this city a few nights since, were arrested to-day, at the instigation of the Society for the Prevention of Gueity to Animals, and warrants are out for many others. Those arrested were taken to Hamburg, to be examined before the County Justice in whose jurisdiction the main occurred.

John J. O'Brien, the temporary Chairman of the Republican County Committee, said yesterday that he was confident of his election as permanent Chairman. He was satisfied that he would have not only enough votes to elect him, but that he would perhaps have 50 votes to spare.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 8.--When darkness came over this place on Friday night the storm was a pouring rain and the mercury dropping below the freezing point. This morning everything out of doors was coated with ice. Telegraph wires and tree branches were covered with ice half an inch thick and icicles wore hanging from them. In Mill and Cannon streets heavy limbs, broken by the weight, were continually falling.

The Spring racing meeting of the Rockaway Hunting Club will take place at Far Rockaway over a natural grass country on Saturday. May 10, at 2 P.M. The first race will be a hunters' flat race, open to half-bred qualified hunters, distance about half a mile. Second Race--Sweepstakes, open to polo ponies; distance about half a mile.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 8.--The Winter race meeting was continued here to-day. The weather was clear and warm. The track was in good condition.

Singapore and Malacca are already far behind us, and on our port bow lies outstretched along the horizon far as the eye can reach the vast, shadowy, dark-blue mountain wall of Northern Sumatra.

A gentleman in Oconee, Ga., is digging a cyclone pit under his house, fixed with a trapdoor. It is large enough to accommodate all his family, and whenever a cloud arises they take refuge therein. Storm pits are also going down by the hundred in other parts of the State.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 9.--Under special instructions from Gov. Thompson to capture at all hazards the escaped murderer Bogan Cash, State Constable R.N. Richbourg, with 12 picked men, armed with Springfield rifles, left Columbia at midnight last night and arrived at Florence at 3:30 A.M.

ALBANY, March 9.--Intimate friends of Gov. Cleveland predict that he will veto the Roosevelt Alderman bill. They base their statement on the fact that tremendous political pressure is being brought to bear to persuade him to this course. Those who have always regarded his executive acts as little likely to be influenced by political considerations are awaiting developments with a great deal of curiosity.

The Union Home and School for Soldiers' and Sailors' Children will close its doors on March 31. The principal reason for this is want of support from the various counties of the State which have children of their old veterans in the home.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--The Washington Post and Typographical Union No. 101 have satisfactorily settled the difficulties between them. The Union men went to work in the establishment to-day, and the order to "boycott" the Post, issued by the Trades Assembly, has been withdrawn.
Clement's Inn, in London, was sold a fortnight ago. It fetched $315,000. The understanding is that the Bank of England will occupy the old hall.

SUAKIN, March 9.--Osman Digna has finally refused to surrender to Gen. Graham. He is determined to fight. He has two cannon and 1,000 rifles.

Among the passengers who arrived by the Britannic from Liverpool yesterday were Senator and Mrs. J. Donald Cameron, Col. H. Mattson, Mr. A.M. Naylor, Mr. George Osborne, the Hon. Lyulph Ogilvy, Mr. J. Swarsenski, and Mr. J. Duff Wallace.

The statement is made that George L. Lorillard will retire from the turf and sell his country seat, Westbrook, with his training stables, track, and through-breds at Islip, Long Island. He is now at St. Augustine, Fla., whither he went in the Fall to spend the Winter.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 9.--To-night Charles Campbell, member of Parliament for Victoria, Nova Scotia, while under the influence of liquor made a savage onslaught on the Hon. David Mills, who, with others, was engaged in attending to his correspondence in the House of Commons Chamber. He endeavored to strike Mr. Mills with a stick, but was prevented by the gentlement present. The matter will be brought up in the House to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 9.--Labor officials are circulating a petition here to be presented to Congress, asking for an appropriation of $10,000,000 of the surplus in the Treasury for colonization purposes. This amount would allow 20,000 families $500 each to locate an entry...

The lovers of base-ball of New-York and Brooklyn will have ample opportunities offered them to witness a large number of games in this neighborhood the coming season by the New-York, Brooklyn, and Metropolitan Clubs. There are 166 championship games to be played-- 56 by the New-Yorks, 55 by the Metropolitans, and 55 by the Brooklyn Club.

FORTRESS MONROE, March 9.--Gen. Grant is not much pleased with the weather here, and say if the rain continues he will soon return to New-York. He is looking well, but is a little despondent.
WHEELING, West Va., March 9.--Cassville, Wayne County, was visited by a destructive incendiary fire on Saturday night, several business houses being, consumed with their contents.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--In the House of Representatives to-morrow, after the usual call of States for the introduction of bills, the Committee on the District of Columbia will be entitled to the floor. The committee, however, has no bills of general importance ready for action. The consideration of the Post Office Appropriation bill will then probably be continued.
Joseph Hatton, of London, is at the Clarendon Hotel. Henry Irving and Brain Stoker, of England, are at the Brevooit House.

MALDEN, Mass., March 9.--Mrs. Kate E. Jones, wife of John T. Jones, of this city, who died suddenly last Wednesday, as supposed from injuries received from falling down stairs, is now thought to have been the victim of foul play.

Patrolman Moncrieff, of the Twentyeighth Precinct, while on post on Avenue A at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, saw a man lying in an open lot between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth streets. He went into the lot to rouse the sleeper, as he supposed, but to his surprise found that the man was dead.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 9.--A special from Toledo published here explains the unique and expensive method adopted by General Passenger and Ticket Agent Sanderson, of the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad, to prevent conductors from pocketing fares.

The council of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church will be called to order tomorrow morning in Association Hall, at Fourthavenue and Twenty-third-street. Twenty-four churches have been invited to send their Pastors and a delegate each to take part in the proceedings of the council.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 9.--Incendiaries have been at work in the vicinity of Bellaire for several days, several barns having been burned. The last one belonged to Samuel F. Freidikler and was of great value. Three men have been arrested and held on suspicion.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 9.--Much excitement has been created in Williams College by cane rushes between the Freshmen and Sophomores. On Friday night the Freshmen took the cane into the chapel, and in the presence of the Faculty began to display it.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 9.--Louis Buse, a saloon-keeper, was arrested to-day charged with shooting his daughter. Buse, after filling himself up with liquor, assaulted his wife, knocking her down. On being remonstrated with by his son, he picked up a small rifle and, aiming it at the boy, missed his mark, the ball striking the daughter on the top of her head, fortunately inflicting only a scalp-wound.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 8.--As the city, of Scranton is only five hours' ride from NewYork, and has a population of about 60,000, including many play-going persons, we are frequently favored with some of the best Metropolitan "talent." The Red Star and Netherland Steam-ship Companies have adjoining piers from the railroad company.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 10.--Train No. 35, on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railway, struck and killed an Indian named James Jacobs, at a point near Steamburg. Jacobs was drunk and asleep on the track.

B. Sener, to reappointment, leaves no doubt in the minds of the practical politicians here that Arthur is still one of their kind.

The proposed issue of $500,000 bonds of the Pittsburg, Wheeling, and Kentucky Railway Company will be guaranteed by the Pennsylvania Company, to which the first named road is leased. These bonds are to be issued to pay for the construction of the road from Wheeling to Benwood, a distance of six miles.

CHICAGO, March 10.--A largely attended meeting of stock-dealers was held at the Transit House to-day and resulted in the organization of the Chicago Live Stock Exchange. With but a few exceptions, every commission firm doing business at the stock yards was represented.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 10.--News has reached here of a difficulty between a Mrs. Hughes and her sister, Miss Harwell, in Coffee County, in which the latter killed the former. Mrs. Hughes and her husband separated some died a few months ago and the widow took possession of what little property he left. The sister went after some cattle, and the trouble arose in which Mrs. Hughes was fatally stabbed.

Franklin B. Gowen said yesterday, in the suit to set aside the lease of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, that he was going away. Roscoe Conkling wanted to call him before the testimony was closed. Mr. Gowen said he was going to Fortress Monroe to stay about two weeks. He would be back in time.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 10.--In the pool contest to-day the afternoon series was played between Sutton and Leonard. Sutton played carefully, as usual, and made a number of combination shots which elicited much applause.

Barnum's parade went through the town last night in a blaze of glory, and carried all the juvenile population before it. The glittering procession outdid itself again this year, as it has done for every previous year to which the mind of man goeth back, for Barnum is the only man who can out-Barnum himself.

At the meeting of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees, yesterday, President Kingsley explained that the withdrawal of the injunction secured by the Manhattan Railway Company preventing the Bridge Trustees from taking down City Hall station left the matter open to the Trustees to proceed as they had originally intended to do.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 10.--Herbert E. Smith, manufacturer of the finer grades of boots and shoes in this city, made an assignment to John Anderson, of this city, to-day. The assignment was unexpected, as Smith was heretofore thought financially sound. His liabilities are $20,000; his assets are not yet known.

COLUMBUS, March 10.--The County Jail is full of people that have been held for complicity in the Hickey lynching, at Rendville, on Feb. 2. In the Common Pleas Court the Grand Jury was called and charged. The Judge in his charge dwelt on the Clifford murder and the subsequent ...
SCHNECTADY, N.Y., March 10.--The Schenectady locomotive shops, employing 1,000 hands, which has been closed some weeks, has resumed with about 400 men.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 10.--The Sharon-Hill divorce trial began here to-day. After the opening statements of counsel on both sides, Martha Wilson (colored,) a dress-maker, was called. She testified that the marriage contract produced in court was the one Miss Hill has shown her in 1880.

Mr. Samuel Grau, business agent for John A. McCaull, Edward Aronson, Mr. Dorval, who has charge of the Casino cafe, and two other gentlemen, were standing just inside the front door of the Casino last evening, when a small district telegraph messenger entered.

BOSTON, March 10.--George H. Hosmer, of Boston, and Alfred Hamm, now of New-Bedford, met in Boston to-day and signed articles to row a three-mile race for $500, the course, date, and referee to be decided upon at another meeting, to be held on May 12. The articles call for a race not later than June 20. Both men deposited $100 forfeit.

Police Commissioner Partridge, of Brooklyn, yesterday appointed Frank C. Mason, a telegraph operator who has been in the employ of the American Rapid Telegraph Company for some time, to the position of Superintendent of Police Telegraph.

CHICAGO, March 10.--At the meeting today of the Fourth District Republican Congressional Committee, the Logan and anti-Logan men were still at a dead-lock, four on each side.
