The Common Council of Hoboken met last night to consider the situation as regards the missing Tax Collector, Mr. John McMahon. The investigating committee was directed to meet daily, or to have one member in attendance at the examination of the accounts and the safe.

A man entered Sweet's restaurant, at No. 4 Fulton-street, about 9 o'clock yesterday morning, sat down at a table and ordered his breakfast. While waiting his head dropped down to the table. Two waiters, thinking that he was intoxicated, lifted him up and carried him to the door for fresh air.

CHICAGO, March 10.--A sparring exhibition, in which several local bruisers were to have taken part, at Hershey Hall to-night, was prevented by means of an injunction sued out by Mrs. James Walsh, the owner of the building.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 10.--Cornell students are much excited and indignant over the dispatches which were published in certain NewYork papers last Saturday. These dispatches falsely relate that the Sophomores last Friday night attempted to break up the Freshman supper by various low and undignified devices.
BUFFALO, March 10.--Louis Buse, age 55, proprietor of a grocery store and saloon in this city, was arraigned in the Police Court this morning for shooting and severely wounding his daughter.

Alderman O'Neil, Chairman of the Committee on Salaries and Offices, yesterday presented to the Board of Aldermen a long report on the veto by the Mayor of the resolution forbidding the Controller to pay salaries or compensation to non-resident office-holders.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 10.--The Assembly wrangled until midnight over the Adirondack Park bill, about which it got into such a tangle last week. The members of the northern tier had enlisted a large force from the interior counties on the plea that the rural tax-payers would never condone such an offense as that of supporting the bill.

Giuseppe Panizza, the alleged Italian bandit from Sicily, faced his accuser again in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, and sat patiently in front of the box while the numerous witnesses testified.

COBLESKILL, N.Y., March 10.--The steam boiler in the Middleburg Paper Mills burst early this morning, nearly wreeking the building. Scott Fox, a workman, was fatally scalded. He was married only last week, and his young wife had just left his side and the building when the explosion occurred.

UTICA, N.Y., March 10.--George Cragin, who, with John Humphrey Noyes,founded the Oneida Community, in 1848, was found dead in bed yesterday at the community. He was 75 years old, and had long been subject to heart disease.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday, after a very brief discussion of the resolution to stop the pay of non-resident clerks and employes, lately vetoed by the Mayor, voted to pass the resolution, the Mayor's veto to the contrary notwithstanding.

HAVANA, March 5.--It is reported that the Caja do Ahorros, when it reopens in May, will probably return the deposits. Its reported difficulties arose from its liberality in discounting notes and advancing money on dubious securities. The courts are investigating its affairs.

SUAKIN, March 10.--Gen. Graham's advance has been postponed until Wednesday, owing to the necessity of forming water stations on the route to Tamanieb. Several battalions of infantry to-day marched to Zeriba, where they formed a small intrenched camp to store water.

OMAHA, Neb., March 10.--James Nugent, brother of the proprietor of the Theatre Comique in this city, was shot and killed in the bar-room adjoining the theatre at a late hour last night. A time, was shot in the jaw, but was not fatally injured. Several arrests have been made, but the guilty parties and the cause of the shooting are not yet certainly known.
LANCASTER, Penn., March 10.--Jacob M. Harnish, son of David W. Harnish, of West Lampeter Township, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 18.--The Southern Immigration Association will meet at noon to-morrow in the State Capitol and continue in session probably three days. The interior of the building has been handsomely decorated, and a large number of visitors from various States have arrived.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 10.--A large meeting of the Louisville distillers and whiskydealers was held this afternoon at the Whisky Exchange. Some indignation was expressed at the delay of Congress in taking up the whisky bill, but there was a very decided expression of opinion that the bill would finally pass.

CHICAGO, March 10.--Peter Schmitz, who strangled his wife to death last week, to-day strangled himself to death in his cell in the County Jail. He had suffered greatly from remorse since the murder of his wife. A piece of curtain cord was drawn about his neck with his own hands and held there until he died. Schmitz was worth about $30,000.

NORFOLK, Va., March 10.--A representative of THE TIMES had a chat with Gen. Grant at the Hygeia Hotel on Sunday. The General said he had been so closely confined to his room for some time past that he had but little opportunity to look into the political situation, but from what he could gather it seemed to him that the Republicans would nominate either Mr. Blaine or Mr. Arthur.

BATAVIA, N.Y., March 10.--The report of Frank S. Wood, the Referee appointed by the Supreme Court to hear and determine claims against the Western New-York Life Insurance Company, of Batavia, now in the hands of Receivers, has just been filed.

NYACK, March 10.--A strong war against the liquor-dealers is being started in Nyack and adjacent villages. Clergymen of all denominations and many of the most prominent citizens are engaged in the movement.

The Hon. "Mike" Dady, of Brooklyn, is not pleased with the result of a brief call made by him to-day upon the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Dady takes, like a number of other visitors from Brooklyn, some interest in the selection of the site for the proposed public building in his city.

All the articles lost on the elevated railways in two years and remaining unclaimed are for sale. Col. F.K. Hain, the General Manager, has invited bids for the lot from junk-dealers. The property is in a room in the Manhattan Railway Company's Building, No. 4 Front-street.

A post-mortem examination yesterday in the case of Mary Bassler, daughter of a tailor of No. 73 Cannon-street, established the fact that malpractice had caused blood-poisoning. At present her betrayer and the person guilty of the crime are not known. The story that she was assaulted at No. 161 Rivington-street is discredited.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 10.--There is great popular interest in the trial of the twentythousand-dollar libel suit brought by Sheriff A. B.R. Sprague, of this county, against Horace H. Bigelow, a prominent capitalist and Butler politician, now in progress in the Superior Court.

TORONTO, March 10.--One hundred and twenty-five boys and men employed by McPherson Co., boot and shoe manufacturers, of Hamilton, have gone on a strike. The female operatives of the same firm have been out on strike for several weeks against out on strike for several weeks will cause a large reduction in their wages, and the men and boys have now decided to support the women.

A reception was given by the ladies of the Central Congregational Church at Madisonavenue and Forty-seventh-street, last night, in honor of the sixth anniversary of its foundation. Among the guests were the Rev. Robert Collyer. Dr. Newman, and Dr. Hayden, Secretary of the Home Mission.

TRENTON, March 10.--The South Jersey Republicans have decided to press Senator John J. Gardner, of Atlantic, for delegate at large to the Republican National Convention. He is a man of large ability, and is also talked of conspicuously as a candidate for Congress next Fall.
PARIS, March 10.--It is rumored that serious news has been received regarding the French advance upon Bac-Ninh. The Government's silence upon the subject causes great irritation.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 10.--The Elmira, Cortland and Northern Railroad was incorporated to-day. It is to run from Elmira to Canastota, in Madison County, a distance of about 120 miles.

BANGOR, Me., March 10.--This city elected a Mayor to-day. The vote stood: For Humphrey, Republican, 1.621; Cummings, Democrat, 1,536, and for Woodbury, Prohibitionist, 109. The City Council is Republican.

BUFFALO, March 10.--Many Democrats here profess great confidence in Gov. Cleveland's nomination for President by the Democratic National Convention in Chicago if the Tilden move does not prevent it. To help Cleveland's chances it is proposed to send a large delegation from Buffalo in his favor.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 10.--AttorneyGeneral O'Brien is very sick at his home here with quinsy. He was taken ill on Friday night after his arrival home.
CHICAGO, March 10.--A Tribune special from Mount Pulaski, Ill., says: "William Hoagland was to-day arrested on a charge of complicity in the triple murder mystery of two years ago.

BOSTON, March 10.--Edward G. Nickerson, a respected business man having an establishment on Long Wharf, has been missing for four weeks, and all efforts to discover this whereabouts thus far have been futile. An examination of his books shows nothing pointing to the slighest irregularity. His liabilities are about $5,000, and the assets will pay 30 per cent. Nickerson had only a few dollars with him when he disappeared.

SCHNECTADY, N.Y., March 10.--Local carpenters and masons who did repairs on the State armory here, which is now being investigated by a legislative committee, report that the whole amount of work done here cost about $40, but that the State paid about $400 for it to contractors.

When Louis C. Hamersley, a wealthy citizen of New-York, died last May, it was found that all his property had been given to his widow on condition that when she died it should go to the male issue of his cousin, J.H. Hooker Hamersley.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 10.--It appears now that Oliver Dyer, Jr., member of the Sophomore Class at Yale College, who was taken away senseless from the sparring bout in the college athletic games Saturday afternoon, cannot recover.

That wheat from India is, in a future not very remote, to be a formidable competitor with American wheat in the world's markets does not admit of doubt. Fertile land, a teeming population, cheap labor--these elements of production exist to an extent hitherto but dimly recognized.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 10.--The Faculty of Union College have tabled a proposition of Harvard that the Athletic Association of Union unite with Harvard and other athletic societies to the State College Base-ball Association, of which the Union team is a member. They have agreed to name 12 professional players, who may be engaged by the respective teams. This will allow two professionals to each club.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 10.--Last Spring a man named Underwood, agent for a New-York Catholic Society, brought about 100 foundlings from that city to Milwaukee, and found homes for the entire lot.

There is no good reason why the Legislature should not complete its work and adjourn by the 1st of May. Some interruption and delay will, no doubt, be caused by political episodes connected with the choosing of delegates to the National Conventions, but six weeks ought to be sufficient time in which to finish all the legislation, that is called for.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--No decisions of general importance were rendered by the Supreme Court to-day. The court, however, denied a motion to advance a number of cases known as the driven well cases, which involve the validity of the driven well patent, and are of interest to several hundred thousand owners of driven wells in the Western States. WASHINGTON, March 10.--That the decision of the United States Supreme Court as to the power of Congress to give legal tender quality to Government notes has not been heard with indifference by the members of Congress is evident from the measures introduced to-day in the Senate and House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--Col. W.E. Sims, whose speech at Danville, it is alleged, contributed to the excitement out of which came the riot of Nov. 3, was examined by the Danville sub-committee this morning. Witness was canvasser for the State at large for the Coalition Party, and up to the last month of the canvass was absent most of the time from Pittsylvania County making speeches in other parts of the State.

None of the telegraph companies sustained damage from Sunday's storm except the Western Union. Its lines on both sides of the Hudson River between Poughkeepsie and Albany were broken in many places. The damage was chiefly caused by falling trees.
Ex-Senator Simon Cameron celebrated on Saturday in Florida his eighty-fifth birthday. There are 219 students at the Texas State University, 30 of them young women, who are classed with the men.
LONDON, March 10.--The race between George Bubear, the English oarsman, and Wallace Ross, the sculler of New-Brunswick, took place this morning in accordance with previous announcements.

CHICAGO, March 10.--The new fast mail service has developed with great promptness. Before the end of the day on which the party from New-York arrived by the NewYork Central and Lake Shore train arrangements had been made for expediting the service from Chicago to Omaha.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.--Police Captain Howell and Lieut. Markoe, who lately visited Chicago to make an inspection of the police patrol of that city with a view of its introduction here, submitted their report to Mayor King this afternoon. They approve the system, and say that under its operation a saving of nearly 50 per cent. can be made.
The cable announces the death of William Blanchard Jerrold, well known as a journalist, playwright, and author. He was born in London in 1826, and was the eldest son of Douglas Jerrold.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.--This afternoon the residence of Mrs. Elizabeth Keating. No. 310 south sixteenth-street, was damaged by fire to the extent of $250. In attempting to extinguish the flames, Mrs. Keating, who was 80 years of age, was so badly burned that she died this evening.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 10.--An application for a charter was made this morning by the New-York and Philadelphia Coal and Iron Company, with a capital of $5,000,000. Its business is to be carried on in Somerset and Cambria Counties, in this State. The Directors are Samuel Bonnell, Jr., of Elizabeth, N.J., who is President; J.C. Short and F.A. White, of New-York William Gualyer, G.B. Bonnell, and C. Sturtevant, of Philadelphia, and Jacob Zimmerman, of Johnstown.

The Athletic Associations of Columbia College held n meeting last evening, at the suggestion of the Faculty, to express an opinion upon the resolutions to govern college athletics that were drawn up by the committee composed of college Faculties.

TRENTON, March 10.--Another advance was made this evening in the solution of the railroad question. The tax bill which Mr. Armstrong, of Camden, substituted for the joint committee's bill was taken up and passed in the House by a vote of 49 for it to Mr. North against it.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 10.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the following business was transacted: No. 116--Winifred Cooper, Administrator, respondent, vs. the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company, appellant. Argued by William C. De Witt for appellant, Charles J. Patterson for respondent.
It was with feelings of considerable relief that the members of the Fourth Company, Seventh Regiment, at the end of their meeting last night, found that everything had apparently terminated happily.

BOSTON, March 10.--The case of Matthew Callahan, the New-York commercial traveler who was-arrested here at the request of the New-York authorities for the alleged abduction of a young woman named Ella Everett, came up by continuance in the Municipal Court this morning, and the prisoner was discharged, a dispatch having been received announcing that the New-York authorities were unable to secure a requisition.
Dock Commissioner Voorhis testified before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation, yesterday, relative to the performance of the duties of Harbor-masters since the 24th of last May.
MONTREAL, March 10.--The snow-storm which has swept over the country the past two days has again blocked up several of the leading railways, and railway travel is almost at a standstill.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, March 10.-- Fears exist here for the safety of 10 men who went to Rathdrum 13 days ago to locate a trail to the Coeur d'Alene gold mining district. They left a point 25 miles from Rathdrum with four days' rations and left other provisions in charge ...

PORT ROYAL, S.C., March 11.--On Saturday last, in a dense fog, about eight miles oft Delaware Light, the steamer San Antonio, of the Mallory Line, from New-York, ran into and sank the brig Addie Todd, Capt. Crowley, of Calais, Me., from Cuba, with sugar and molasses for New-York. The brig sank in 30 minutes. Her crew was saved and taken by the San Antonia to Fernaudina, whence they will proceed to New-York.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 11.--The semiannual convention of the railroad and river coal miners of the Pittsburg district met here to-day. Thirty-four delegates, representing 15,000 men, and nearly every mine in the districts were present.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--The litigation between the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Schuylkill River East Side Railroad Company, which owns the charter and franchises by means of which the Baltimore and Ohio expects to get into this city and make connection with the Reading system, was given a now twist to-day.

It had been the intention of his friends to have given him a reception on his return to this country, but he sent word that he did not wish anything of the kind.

A heavy New-York stockholder of the Mexican Central Railroad stated yesterday that that road would certainly be opened for traffic to the City of Mexico by March 20. Arrangements have been made by which Pullman cars will run from St. Louis to Mexico with only one change, and that at El Paso.

LOUIS, March 11.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company was held to-day at the offices in the Equitable Building, and the following Directors were elected for the year beginning to-day: Jay Gould, Russell Sage, F.L. POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 11.--Navigation was reopened to-night by the steamer Daniel S. Miller's starting for New-York. The John L. Hasbrouck is expected to arrive here from New-York to-morrow morning. .

Husted camped on the field last night, and, having rallied his forces, this morning he was in readiness to meet the men of the North when, led by the St. Lawrence giant, they swooped down upon the Adirondack bill. BOSTON, March 11. -- Mr. Frederick H. Prince and Miss Abbie N. Norman were married to-day. The groom is the son of ex-Mayor Prince, Secretary of the Democratic National Committee, and the bride is the daughter of George H. Norman, the water-works contractor, who has a fine house at Newport, and is well known in Boston and New-York.

A brigantine, built at an expense of $18,351, was launched Nov. 12, 1856, for the work of the American Board of Missions in the Micronsian Islands. After 10 years' service she was sold. The second vessel in the same service was wrecked on the Island of Kusail Oct. 18, 1869. A third vessel, a brig of 181 tons, is still in use: Each of the three was named the Morning Star.

BALTIMORE, March 11.--Under a call for a mass-meeting of property-owners and others opposed to the passage of the bill now before the Legislature authorizing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to build an elevated railroad through the city to connect with their Philadelphia branch road, several hundred persons assembled at Raines Hall to-night.

WILKESBARRE, Penn, March 11.--About two weeks ago a company composed of three individuals, calling themselves the Globe Tea and Coffee Company, rented a room in this city and began selling tea and coffee in caps a present being given to each purchaser of a can of coffee or tea. They did a thriving business and reaped quite a harvest.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., March 11.--The excitement noted last week as raging in the oil region surrounding this city has spread to Washington County, Ohio, just across the river, and people are swarming in from all directions, eager to buy up lands and put down wells.

A miscellaneous lot of goods which hare remained unclaimed in the United States public stores in this city for more than a year were sold at auction by direction of Collector Robertson yesterday. WASHINGTON, March 11, 1884. The following nominations were sent to the Senate to-day J.E. Irish, of Wisconsin, to be Consul at Cognac; Abram J. Gifford, of New york, to be Agent for the Indians of the Fort Berthold Agency in Dakota; Elliott S.N. Morgan of Wyoming, to be Secretary of the Territory of Wyoming.

The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby started for the weekly meeting of the Greek Club, Friday night, with a volume of Euripides under his arm. He failed to notice that it was raining and freezing at the time, and he had no sooner closed the door behind him than he shot like a flash down 11 stone steps and into the gutter.

Figures showing the cash receipts at the Fulton Ferry since the opening of the bridge were given out yesterday by Matthew Bunker, Secretary of the Union Ferry Company. From $35,940 in last June and $37,186 in July the receipts have decreased to $27,151.50 in February, the total receipts for the nine months being $335,150.50. TORONTO, Ontario, March 11.--Counsel for Harry L. Lee, the Cincinnati forger, has decided not to appeal to the Court of Appeals. Lee will he sent across the line when the necessary requisition is received.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 11.--AttorneyGeneral O'Brien has not been so well to-day.

CHICAGO, March 11.--A rumor was current on the Board of Trade to-day that the eastern trunk line pool had gone to pieces. Commissioner Moore pronounced the rumor false, and said that there was no prospect of a rupture of the pool. His advices from Commissioner Fink were to the effect that there was no rate-cutting anywhere.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 11.--Congressman Kellogg left here for Washington this morning, having accomplished the purpose of his visit to this city. The disaffected elements in the Republican Party were soothed into harmonious relations and a delegation elected to the Chicago Convention unpledged and uncommitted...

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 11.--A suit was brought to-day against Chief of Police W. E. Marsh, of this city, for $12,000 damages for having caused the arrest and imprisonment of Capt. James Hunter, of the Salvation Army, in January last. The payers were served late this afternoon. Other similar suits against the city will follow soon.

The hearing in the suit to set aside the lease of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey to the Philadelphia and Reading did not go on yesterday on account of the inability of counsel for the plaintiff to be present.

Mr. Nat C. Goodwin was last night again unable to appear at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre, owing to his severe illness, and it is extremely unlikely that he will be seen before tomorrow night. Mr. Goodwin is suffering from a series of carbuncles on the neck and inflammation of the stomach.

SILVER CITY, Arizona, March 11.--The train robbers who were imprisoned here broke jail last night. They were pursued and overtaken by a Sheriff's posse. The robbers resisted arrest and two of them were killed and another was wounded.

Stokes, the exclusive information that, although Mayor Edson had vetoed an Aldermanic permit for its erection over the sidewalk, sufficient influence might be used to overcome the objections...

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The Senate in Executive session to-day reversed its action of Jan. 18 and ratified the Mexican treaty, with the amendment providing that the treaty shall not become operative until Congress shall have passed laws to carry it into effect. The Senators talked on the subject for three hours before reaching a vote.

WHEELING, West Va., March 11.--Yesterday and to-day there was quite a run of depositors, mostly by people having but small balances to their credit, on the Bank of Wheeling, one of the soundest banks of the city. The trouble was originated yesterday morning by a German woman presenting a check not properly indorsed by her husband.

PARIS, March 11.--Advices from Tonquin report that the French column, advancing upon Bac-Ninh from Hardzuong, has had a successful engagement with the enemy. Admiral Courbet has taken an iron-clad to Quinhon and declared that port blockaded.

DENVER, Col., March 11.--At 6 O'clock last night a snow-slide descended on the little snowbound station of Woodstock, on the branch of the South Park Railroad 75 miles south-west of Leadville, carrying away every building in the town, including the railroad station. The news was brought to Pitkin, nine miles distant, by a section hand on snow-shoes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was held to-day in Musical Fund Hall. Col. Louden Snowdon presided. The annual report was read and discussed, page by page, and much time was consumed in questions and speeches by Messrs. Parker and Lockwood.

A movement is on foot to establish somewhere within a short distance of New-York a sea-side home exclusively for nursing mothers and their infants. The need for such an institution is made apparent by an examination of the mortality statistics in the office of the Board of Health.

Martin upon taking the chair, "that we shall hold until the Legislature decides that we are to retain our uniforms and rank or that we have no right...

Referee Theodore W. Dwight read a long and elaborate address to the expectant counsel on both sides of the Marie-Garrison yesterday, in which he stated that he had traveled diligently over the long road pointed out by the counsel for the defense, and that he had failed to find any ground on which he could dismiss the complaint.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--Dr. K.P. Stritmatter to-day slapped his hand on a desk in the Coroner's office, saying: "I'll dissect that body if I have to steal it from the grave." He referred to the body of little Peter Mohr, who died on Sunday night. Mohr had been known for years among the neighbors as the "blue child."

WHEELING, West Va., March 11.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Wheeling and Harrisburg Railroad Company, and of the Elm Grove and State Line Railroad Company was held here this afternoon, at which the two companies were incorporated and consolidated under the name of the Wheeling and Harrisburg...

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 11.--The party of 10 men who were reported to have been lost in the Coeur d'Alene Mountains have arrived at Trout Creek, after 13 days' woeful experience in the deep snow and dense forest. They are utterly worn out.

DOVER, N.H., March 11.--A lively contest is promised between Father Murphy, the pastor of St. Mary's Catholic Church, and the Emmet Associates, Father Murphy having by authority from the Bishop informed the members of the organization that they must disband or suffer excommunication.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 11.--The Southern Emigration Association assembled in the Hall of the House of Representatives at noon to-day, and was called to order by Col. A.J. McWhirter, of Tennessee.

ERIE, Penn., March 11.--George D. Sidman, special examiner in the United States Pension Bureau, charged Nathan Turner with hav ing retained more than the lawful fee for prosecuting pension claims. Turner was arrested in Corry to-night, and Commissioner Grant committed him to jail.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11.--A Patti panic is raging here. Over 300 people stood in line all night to be first at the box-office this morning. Tickets had been on sale only a short time when the management announced that all had been sold. The long line of people howled like madmen. Some paid $12 for their places in the line.

TROY, N.Y., March 11.--Thomas J. Tiffany, who has been Postmaster at Bennington, Vt., for 13 years, absconded Dionday. It is believed he has $2,500 with him. The Government Inspector, F.N. Bassett, arrived Monday, and Tiffany told him he had sent the department a draft for the last quarter's returns.

The merchants doing business in the building at No. 46 East Fourteenth-street yesterday sent to Mayor Edson, to the Police Commissioners, and to the Captain of the Fifteenth Police Precinct a petition asking for an abatement of the nuisance created by the presence of vendors of paper and small wares in and about the building.

The Aqueduct Commissioners, including the Mayor, Controller Grant, and Commissioner Thompson, of the Department of Public Works, left the city yesterday afternoon by the Pennsylvania Railroad for Baltimore and Washington, for the purpose of inspecting the water systems of those cities.
BALTIMORE, March 11.--Marchant Co., of this city, shippers of flour, have made an assignment for the benefit of creditors. The liabilities are stated to be $30,000, and the nominal assets $45,000.

ODELL, Ill., March 11.--Gailus Eggenberger, a leading citizen, was found dead on the railroad with two bullet-holes in his head. The murderers are unknown. The citizens offer a reward of $500 for their capture.

William H. McMahon, the son of the missing Tax Collector of Hoboken, and his assistant, yesterday resumed his duties the office under the supervision of the Committee on Finance. He will also render such service in examining his father's books and accounts as the committee and Expert Sackett may desire. The safe was opened at 10 o'clock and in it was found...

WASHINGTON, Penn., March 11.--A young man named Harry Livison was arrested here last night charged with house-breaking and larceny of about $1,000 worth of jewelry from the residence of Sarah Frank, at Sharon,Mercer County, Penn.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 11.--On the Fourth of July, 1871, the students and Faculty of Yale College were surprised to hear of the marriage of Gilbert S. Deans, a Yale student and son of Judge Deans, of New-York City, to a 14-yearold girl named Julia H. Sperry, a resident of Westville, one of the suburbs of New-Haven. Deans lived with his young wife but a few weeks.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 11.--Judge Kenyon, of this city, has made an important decision affecting the rights of widow's in moneys received from insurance upon the lives of their deceased husbands. In 1871 Crosby Co., wholesale hardware dealers, recovered judgments in the Supreme Court against Sarah Stephan, the wife of a prominent hotel man, aggregating...

BUFFALO, March 11.--The Right Rev. John Ireland, Roman Catholic Bishop of St. Paul, lectured at the Music Hall in this city last evening on " Intemperance and Law." The meeting had been widely advertised, and the Hon. William P. Letchworth presided.
BOSTON, March 11.--The House this afternoon passed a bill providing that wife-beaters shall be logged by the keeper of the House of Correction in the county where the offense occurs.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 11.--At a meeting to-day of the Presidents of seven cotton factories in and near this city, it was resolved that Cotton mill owners throughout the South and West be invited to meet in Augusta on April 3, to consider some plan looking to a decrease in the production of cotton goods.

The New-York State Veteriary Society. held its eighth annual meeting at the Ashland House last evening. Prof. A.F. Leautard, of this city, presided. The draft of a bill regulating the practice of veterinary surgery and medicine in this State was read and discussed, and...
NEW-ORLEANS, March 11.--The weather to-day was clear and windy and the track dry.

TROY, N.Y., March 11.--Two men drove up to the house of Burris Duncombe and sister, rear Hoosick, yesterday, and forced Duncombe to drink some liquor. They then assaulted the sister. Her brother, while attempting to defend her, was severely beaten.
William M. Bunn, of Philadelphia, is at the Grand Hotel. Prof. Hiram Corson, of Cornell University, is at the St. Denis Hotel.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 11.--The Republican Congressional Committee for the Twentyfifth (Onondaga and Cortland) District to-day issued a call for a convention, to be held at the City Hall in Syracuse on Wednesday, April 16, for the selection of two district delegates and two alternates to the Republican National Convention to be held at Chicago June 3.

CINCINNATI, March 11.--Judges Baxter and Sage, of the United States Court, were today asked to set aside the recent decree for $110,000 in favor of the contractors who furnished locomotives to the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railway, which is now in a Receiver's hands.

RELEIGH, N.C., March 11.--The funeral services of the Hon. Kenneth Rayner, late solicitor of the Treasury, were held here to-day. The State Superior Court adjourned as a mark of respect. Chief-Justice W.W.H. Smith and Associate Justice Augustus S. Merriman were among the pall-bearers, and the Bench and Bar of the State were well represented. Many members of the family from the far South were also present.

The recent disclosures of the manner in which bogus divorce decrees were obtained by the wholesale only emphasize what was pretty well known before. The conditions which permit this kind of rascality would not be possible if it had ever been made anybody's special business to look up and punish the frauds.

TRENTON, March 11.--The Senate Committee on Railroads met in the Senate Chamber this evening to hear arguments for and against Assembly bill No. 253, otherwise known as Gov. Abbett's Corporation Taxation bill. The Governor was an attentive listener. Col. Edward T. Green and Barker Gummere represented...

The British troops in Egypt are said to be "aggravated" by the expression of OsMAN DIGNA's ferocious intention of drinking the blood of the Turks and their allies, and also to be depressed by the lack of facilities for the formation of a square in the broken ground which is likely to be the scene of the next battle.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11.--The opening of Mr. Mapleson's season of Italian opera in San Francisco last night was attended with remarkable success. The Grand Opera-house, in which the performances are given, is the largest theatre in the city, and it was overcrowded. Mme. Gerster was the Principal sinker, and "Lucia" was the opera.

TORONTO, March 11.--Late last night Capt. W. Steacey, of the London Salvation Army, stated in the meeting at Kingston that while at Orillia he heard that a woman who had been sick for 15 years, during the latter two of which she was confined to her bed, was coming to that town to see the army. He went to the station to meet her.

Ashley C. Baker, a veteran of the war of 1812, died at the home of his son, Charles R. Baker, in Flushing, Long Island, on Monday. He was well known to the people of that village, of which he was one of the oldest citizens. He was born in England in 1795, and was brought to this country by his parents when about 7 years old.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 11.--The accounts of W.G. Morgan., manager of the Hartford branch and member of the firm of Putnam, Earle Co., New-York, have been under investigation by the firm for the past two days. Morgan is confined to the house by a, serious attack of neuralgia of the heart. It is said that the accounts are found confused, but nothing serious is reported, and no loss to banks or customers . will ensue.

When the Villard excursion in its Western progress reached Dakota in September last, its arrival and the presence of the many notable men of both hemispheres who participated in it were taken advantage of for the laying of the cornerstone of the Capitol building of the new Territory.

ALBANY, March 11.--Mr. William J. McDonald, the contumacious witness, will remain in the custody of the Sheriff of Albany County for another week. This morning return was made to the writ of habeas corpus in his case before Judge Westbrook. The Hons. Hamilton Harris and T.C. Ecclesine appeared for Mr. McDonald and Mr. F.W. Whitridge for the Senate...

Detective James K. Price, of the Twentyninth Precinct, saw John Smith and Frank O'Hara acting suspiciously about the stoop of Mrs. Caroline Boyd's residence, No. 114 Madison avenue, O'Hara went up the stoop and was working at the lock, while Smith stood on guard on the sidewalk.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 1,240F.L. Ames et al., , plaintiff in error, vs. The State of Kansas ex rel. W.A. Johnson. Attoney-General; and No. 1,241--The Kansas Pacific Railway Company, plaintiff in error, vs. The State of Kansas, ex rel. W. A. Johnson, Attorney-General. Argument concluded. No. 910--The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company,

The Academy of Music was crowded to overflowing last evening with the friends and relatives of the graduating class of the Medical Department of the University of New-York. The stage was bordered in front with potted plants in bloom and at the sides and rear with evergreens.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 11.--Andrew J. Weaver, a brother of Congressman Weaver, of Indiana, committed suicide this morning at Greenville, a small station on the line of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road, about six miles south of Scranton. Mr. Weaver was about 43 years old. He was aroused at 7 o'clock by his daughter.

CINCINNATI, March 11.--One of the large stockholders of the Kentucky Central Railroad refuses to pay the 10 per cent. assessment recently voted in New-York. As a consequence, the plan of paying off the floating debt of the road and completing the Stanford extension by an assessment upon...

The annual meeting of the New-York Athletic Club was held last evening in the club's rooms, at No. 115 West Twenty-thirdstreet, There was considerable wire-pulling done in the electioneering for the Governing Committee. The re-election of Thomas R. Keator and B.C. Williams was opposed by a large element.

At the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday resolutions were adopted that the New-York Cable Railroad Company be obliged to run a sufficient number of trains to "actually accommodate all public need in that behalf," and that the Directors of the company shall be nine in number.

NEW-HAVEN, March 11.--Allan Sawyer, of Mount Carmel, a well-known farmer, his wife, Mrs. Sawyer, and Jennie Billsbrough, a servant in the house of Mr. C.W. Keeler, of this city, were arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Grand Juror Tuttle, of Hamden, on a charge of being concerned in a case of malpractice, the victim...

CHICAGO, March 11.--The Rock Island Road to-day made an additional cut in the freight rate from Chicago to the Black Hills, by way of St Paul, of 25 cents per 100 pounds when the North-western, St. Paul and Western Trunk Association immediately met the cut. Black Hills rates have been reduced from time to time from $4 to $2.75, the present rate.

Jonas Silk, a native of Hungary, who lives with his parents at No. 607 Eighth-avenue, attempted to commit suicide yesterday by shooting himself five times in the head and face with a small revolver. He worked in a clothing and furnishing goods store kept by his father, at No. 441 Eighth-avenue, and was in the habit of sleeping in the place.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--In the KeiferBoynton investigation to-day U.H. Pointer, a Journalist, gave a description of the meeting of correspondents, at which resolutions of censure upon Speaker Keifer were adopted, staring that his effort to have the matter of the opening of the press gallery investigated before the adoption of the resolutions, was opposed by Mr. Boynton.

Association Hall, at Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue, was about half filled with ladies and gentlemen when the council called to settle the differences between the Rev. Dr. J.P. Newman and the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church was called to order at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The members of the council occupied the front seats on the floor of the hall.

WASHINGTON. March 11.--Mr. Dingley, from the Shipping Committee, reported favorably to the House to-day his pilotage bill. It authorizes the examination of masters or metes of American vessels by United States local inspectors, and the granting to them, if found competent, of licenses to pilot their vessels.
LONDON, March 11.--Another bill has passed the Parliament of Queensland restricting Chinese immigration.
A meeting of the members of the Mercantile Exchange was held yesterday at Reade and West streets. There was a large attendance and President George B. Douglas was in the chair.

All the articles that have been left unclaimed with the American Express Company were sold at auction yesterday at No. 55 Cedarstreet. The sale was "on sight or unseen," and consequently had ull the uncertainty of a lottery. About 650 articles from all parts of the world, consisting of carpet-sachels, trunks, chests, hat-boxes, stoves, bedsteads, and paper...

TRENTON, March 11.--Both houses held a single short session to-day. The fact that the town elections were in progress all over the State took members out of their seats. Of three vetoes received from the Governor two are of small bills on the ground that they are special and local.

The programme interpreted by the NewYork Philharmonic Club at Chickering Hal last evening, when the fifth concert by that meritorious organization was given, included compositions by Beethoven, Mozart, and Brahms. The soloist of the occasion was Mme. Cora Giese, and Mr. Richard Hoffman was at the piano. Mozart's F major quartet opened the concert. Its four movements, all in quick time, and all brimming...

GOLD MINE, Lebanon County, Penn., March 11.--A shooting affray occurred near this village to-day, which resulted in fatal injuries to two men and the serious wounding of another. The affair was caused by the elopement of Mary Chusterman, daughter of Capt. John W. Chusterman, a well-known farmer, with a laborer named Ezekiel Henry.
About 300 employes of E. Ridley Sons have signed the following preamble and resolutions:

WORCESTER, Mass., March 11.--The will of the late Hon. L.J. Knowles, the well-known inventor and manufacturer of the Knowles steam pump and the Knowles loom, was filed to-day. It gives his wife his residence and $100,000, also the interest of $50,000 during her life, and at her death the principal is to be divided as follows:

If the Democratic and Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives fairly represent the position of their respective parties on the tariff question, an issue is squarely made in the two reports on the Morrison bill.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 11.--Train No. 10 on the Michigan Central Railroad, due here at 7:30 A.M., struck a broken rail about 100 miles from here which completely overturned the sleeping car Garogan. There were 15 passengers aboard, including Carrie Swain, the actress, and D.A. Gaylord of the Elmira Advertiser. Nearly all were badly bruised, but not seriously insured.

OTTUMUR, Iowa, March 11.--The trial train of the new fast mail system between Chicago and Omaha reached this city at 10 o'clock, seven hours. The train overtook at this city the regular train which left Chicago at 10 o'clock in the evening.

SOMERS POINT, N.J. March ll.--An unknown steamer, apparently a fishing vessel, is ashore on the Great Egg Harbor Bar, and is signaling for assistance. She is pounding badly, and the seas are making a clean sweep over her. The life-saving crews from South Atlantic City and Ocean City are attempting to board her. A high southerly wind prevails.

Louis Rapp keeps a beer saloon at No. 158 West Eighteenth-street. He lives and keeps boarders on the upper floors of the house. His wife, Mrs. Annie Rapp, was in charge of the saloon on Monday, and at 4 o'clock in the afternoon she sent her daughter Lizzie, age 14, to the apartments above on an errand.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The Secretary of the Interier transmitted to the Senate to-day a communication from the Commissioner of Railroads in response to a Senate resolution of Feb. 25 calling upon the Secretary for Information as to whether...

"Wanted, a Partner," was played at Paterson on Monday night by a company under the management of Mestayer Barton. As it turned out they had one partner more than they wanted. This was Carlo Mauran, known on the stage as Harry Bloodgood, who formerly took the part of the manager in the drama.

RALEIGH N.C., March 11.--Gov. Jarvis received a dispatch this afternoon announcing that E. Ray and W.A. Anderson, the revenue officer who recently killed three men in Mitchell County, had surrendered and were in jail at Asheville. The State rewards offered for their capture amount to $800, and the private rewards to $4,000.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The Post Office Appropriation bill was taken up in the House to-day, and was first addressed by Mr. Bingham, of Pennsylvania. He said he came to the consideration of the subject with a view to a careful and efficient administration of the Postal Service.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 11.--Just before dark to-night a disastrous fire visited East St. Louis. It originated in a barber's shop on the levee, spread from there to a lot of other frame dwellings and then crossed the tracks of the Chicago and Alton Company until the flames reached the Advance Elevator A.

Mr. James C. Carter took his seat as President of the Bar Association last evening. He made a neat little speech of thanks for his election, saying that he considered his new place one of the most distinguished to which a lawyer could aspire. Mr. H.M. Olcott presented to the association a resolution directing the Committee on the Amendment of the haw to examine the bill...
BATAVIA, N.Y., March 11.--John Brider, a German, aged 39 years, was instantly killed in a neighboring farmer's woods this morning by a falling limb.

Early in the session Mr. Burleigh, of New-York, introduced in the House of Representatives a bill to abolish tonnage duties on tugs, tow-boats, and vessels not propelled by steam, built within the United States and trading between contiguous foreign territory and this country.
BOSTON, March 11.--At the annual meeting of the Boston Commercial Exchange to-day the following officers were elected: PresidentHenry F. Woods; Secretary-Herman L. Buss; Treasurer-Fred N. Cheney.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 11.--Col. Edward S. Wheat, ex-United States Marshal for the middle district or Tennessee, and one of the most prominent citizens of the State, was shot and killed at Church and College streets at 8:30 o'clock this morning by his father-inlaw, Col. William Spence, who was his...

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. William H.W. James, Twentyfourth Infantry, in special orders of Jan. 2, has been extended three months. Leave of absence until Aug, 28 has, on account of ill-health, been granted Cadet John A. Legen, Jr., Fourth Class, Military Academy.
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 11.--This morning Harry, the 12-year-old son of Edward H. Turner, becoming angry at a reproof by his mother, snatched up a revolver and shot himself through the heart.

BUFFALO, March 11.-Mrs. Jessie Reed, the giantess in Bunnell's Museum here, died this morning of fever. She was 19 years old, weighed 400 pounds, and was 6 feet 4 inches in height, She was born in New-Rochelle, her maiden name being Waldron.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11.--The Hon. J.M. McKleroy will publish an open letter in the Advertiser to-morrow. withdrawing from the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor. This leaves Gov. O'Neal without opposition, unless some one else enters the field.

The greatest show on earth began its exhibitions before the people of New-York in Madison-Square Garden yesterday, and about 15,000 of the population witnessd the two performances in the afternoon and evening. There were three rings and a stage to be observed, and the only fault the Spectators found was that there...

The "boys" succeeded in organizing the Republican County Committee last evening, and John J.O'Brien, in spite of the caucusing which has been done for the last two weeks and the careful plans which had been laid to defeat him, was elected to be permanent President of the...

TOPEKA, Kan., March 11.--Gov. Glick has received numerous requests to call a special session of the Legislature to take action toward suppressing the cattle disease, which prevails in a part of the State. He has written a letter say-- ing he does not think it would be the best course to pursue.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 11.--At the charter election held here to-day there was a complete overthrow politically, the Republicans making a clean sweep and electing Trustees in all four wards by large majorities. Capt. James N. Pronk, for President, has 277 Majority. Last year the Democrats carried everything, the Board of Trustees standing seven Democrats to one Republican.

It is expected that Mrs. Judson Kilpatrick will return to this country before many months for the purpose of educating her daughters here, and it is desired that she shall find her home and that of the lamented General at Deckerstown unincumbered when she arrives.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 11.--The Republican County Committee of Lackawanna, at a meeting held here to-day, adopted the report of the conference committee of Luzerne and Lackawanna which met recently to devise a plan of electing delegates from the Twelfth Congressional District to the Chicago Convention.

Miss Maggie Harvey, the young woman who was attacked by the negro Jesso Williams on Saturday in her bedroom in the Sloane flats, No. 49 West Thirty--second-street, and left bound and gagged on the floor, is in a very precarious condition from the shock and fright, and it is greatly feared that she will die.

JACKSON, Miss., March 11.--A dispatch from Starkeville says a cyclone struck the Agricultural College this afternoon. Capt. Lucas was slightly injured and all the buildings were more or less damaged. The stock suffered greatly. Farm implements, fences, and grain were blown away.

When next the boys of Princeton come to the conclusion that they are suffering intolerable wrongs and that their treatment is, on the whole, worse than that of the victims of the Spanish inquisition, they will do well to refrain from premature publication of the fact.

Four men sat around a table in Military Hall, No. 192 Bowery, last night, and resolved to organize a Society of 1812 of New-York City. The names of the four were J. Gould Warner, C.B. Riker, James Riker, and Christopher R. Forbes, all descendants of soldiers who fought in the war of 1812.

SUAKIN, March 11.--Firing was heard today in the direction of Zariba. Gen. Graham, Col. Stewart, and the whole force went thither. The firing was owing to an attempt by the rebels to cut off a British convoy. The attempt was not successful. The British savalry quickly dispersed the rebels, who numbered 300. A number of Egyptian camel drivers bolted during the attack upon the convoy.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The majority and minority reports of the Ways and Means Committee on the Morrison Tariff bill were submitted to the House to-day. The division in committee was upon strict party lines. Mr. Morrison was asked when he proposed to call the bill up for action. He said he did not know. Other members of the committee expressed the...

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 11.--The Republican Convention for the Seventh District last evening nominated Robert Small (colored) for Congress to succeed Edmund W.M. Mackey, deceased. There was litt a opposition to small, and his nomination is considered equivalent to an election, the majority of negro voters in the district being overwhelming.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11.--Information from Shawnee, Straitsville, Corning, Nelsonville, and other points shows that the strike in the coal mining region of the Hocking Valley has been made general and will continue. The last man went out to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--William A. Cook was examined to-day by Mr. Springer's committee. He said when the announcement was made that he was to represent the Government in the star route cases Col. William P. Wood offered him a retainer of $25,000 if he would defend those who might be indicted.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 11.--In the Louisville Jockey Club races over a week ago Carson was defeated in a mile and a quarter race by Athlone, the former being the favorite. Mike Welsh. Carson's trainer, claimed that the horse had been poisoned, and made charges against a colored man, Dick Parks, who disappeared the day after the race.
OAKLAND, Cal., March 11.--In the city elections yesterday the Republicans had from 200 to 800 majority.

Surrogate Daniel G. Rollins yesterday removed from office Probate Clerk William J. Trimble and Assistant Probate Clerk Robert E. Cleary. No reasons for the removals were given, but it is generally understood that the step was taken on account of the disclosures recently made in the legislative investigation.
HAVANA, March 11.--The yacht Atalanta his arrived in this port, having Mr. Jay Gould and family on board. It will remain here for some time and then visit other parts of the island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 11.--In the Sharon divorce trial to-day, Nellie Brackett, an intimate friend and companion of Miss Hill, testified that she thought the latter was Senator Sharon's mistress. When she became acquainted with Miss Hill the latter told her so. Witness was then shown the marriage contracts and afterward heard Senator Sharon acknowledge...

WASHINGTON, Penn, March 11.--A little child of M. Sprawls, of Burnsville, was burned to death yesterday by its clothes coming in contact with the fire in the stove. The flesh all over the child's body was burned almost to a crisp.
C.B. Richard Co. have lately recived $115.35 additional subscriptions to their fund for the relief of the sufferers from the Western floods. The total receipts have been $756.90.

Complaints have been made by the Captains of several steam-ships that there was some obstacle on the inner bar of Gedney's Channel. Yesterday the Pilot Commissioners received a communication from the Coast Survey office, in which it was stated that the schooner Drift had made a thorough survey--of the channel and...

BOSTON, March 11.--There are reported to be indications of a well-planned Blaine movement in this State to secure delegates in the district. conventions favorable to his nomination, if not as a, first move as a second. But the ablest Republican leaders take no stock in it, and it is not likely to meet with much encouragement. The best indications point to a hearry, if not a solid Edmunds delegation from Massachusetts.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Miss., March 11--Mr. Upchurch endeavored to cross Red Island Creek, which was deep and swift. He had his wife and four children with him. Almost as soon as he had reached the edge of the water the swift current shifted his horse's head down the creek.

TORONTO, March 11.-- A sensation has been caused here by the precautions rendered necessary by the threats of Feniana to injure the public buildings. About a week ago secret information was given the Provincial Government that an attempt was to be made shortly to blow up the Provincial Parliament buildings and Government House by dynamite.

Association Hall was well filled last evening on the occasion of the anniversary of the Bible and Fruit Mission and the lodging and coffee house connected with it. The Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby presided. The resume of work for the year by Mrs. E.O. Conger showed that 79,925 persons had been served with meals; of whom 7,975 were sick in the hospital.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y. March 11.--Mrs. Emma Wilbur, of Upper Lisle, Broome County, had her feet crushed Nov. 3, 1883, at Suspension Bridge. She sued the Now-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, and they settled the suit by paying her $3,500.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 11.--In the pool tournament this afternoon Sutton played Eggleston and Wharton, defeating them both. the first one by a score of 11 to 6 and the second by 11 to 5. These games excited little interest, as none of the contestants have any chance to win a prize.

MONTREAL, March 11,--The police found three women dying of starvation in a house on St. Antoine-street last night. Their names are C.M. Pitt and E.A. Jones, sister, who are over 50 years of age, and a daughter of the latter named Alice. They came here a few months ago from Toronto and tried to get work at dress-making, but failed...

A fire, probably caused by the careless use of a match, broKe out in the attic of No.52 Vesey-street early yesterday morning. Ann Sullivan, the bedridden wife of a 'longshoreman, who was at work at the Old Dominion Steam-ship pier at the time, was suffocated.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 12.--Edward Ray and Waightstill Anderson, who killed three men on the 15th of last month in Mitchell County, surrendered themselves yesterday, and are now in jail in Ashville. The Governor had offered $800 reward for their apprehension and the citizens had offered $3,500 more so that from 100 to 300 men were on their trail all the time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 12.--The dam at Fresno, Cal., has broken away, and the town is inundated. The railroad bridge has been rendered unsafe, and passengers have to be transferred. Reports from the interior state that the weather is clear, and that the roads are drying up. A dispatch from Los Angeles says it will be a week before trains can run east, and two weeks before repairs can be completed to this point.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12.--The Roosevelt investigating committee held a secret meeting to-night for the purpose of considering and agreeing upon a report of their labor in New-York. The report, accompanied with eight bills, will be completed in season to present to the Assembly on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 12.--Barrister R. Massugema, a Japanese of high rank, who was sent to Europe by his Government to study law, and was admitted to the Bar in England, was introduced to Judges Allison and Biddle in court to-day. He is about five feet two inches in height, but has an uncommonly large head and a high, broad forehead.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 12.--The Tennessee River Convention has been in session all day, Gov. O'Neal, of Alabama, presiding. About 500 delegates are present from Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, and other States interested in improving Southern rivers.

Fire spread rapidly last night through the three upper floors of No. 105 Walker-street, a four-story building, owned by J.T. Dill and occupied by Albert Komp, dealer in neckwear supplies and necktie printer. Four-fifths of the contents of the building were destroyed, but the damage to the structure is not more than $1,200 will repair.

NEENAH, Wis., March 12.--The largest sale of pine lands ever made in this city took place to-day. Six thousand acres of land and 100,000,000 feet of lumber, purchased four years ago by W.H. Upham for $11,000 was sold to George C. Wilcox, of Chicago, for $100,000.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 12.--Ben Thompson and Ning Fisher were shot dead in the Vaudeville Theatre last night. Joe Foster was shot in the leg, and will probably die of hemorrhage. Thompson and Fisher had been drinking together, and entered the theatre in company. They met Foster in the dress circle, and some words were exchanged, and shortly after shots were exchanged.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 12.--The convention of the sugar-planters in this city today was the most important in the results that may follow of any like assemblage since the war. Every parish and almost every plantation in the State was represented by its best men, and the reports of the delegates to Washington were received.

Judge Van Brunt, holding Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, dismissed the complaint of the Germania Fire Insurance Company against the Hanover Fire Insurance Company and Alexander Stoddart, Manager of the New-York Underwriters' Agency. The plaintiff and defendant companies did business together ...
WASHINGTON, March 12.--The following circular has been sent to all United States Attorneys and Marshals: ...

BOSTON, March 12.--The schooner Joshua S. Bragdon, which arrived here to-day, brought the Captain and crew of the schooner F.D. Hodgkins, (new,) from Jacmel, Hayti, for the Delaware Breakwater, for orders, with 160 tons of logwood. Capt. Bonsey reports that on March 9, when about 20 miles from Fenwick Island, the ...
The Attorney-General has sent to all the District Attorneys and Marshals of the United States a circular which will be found in our columns this morning.

There was an entertaining and not wholly uninstructive debate in the House yesterday on the proposition to limit the salaries of Postmasters to a reduced figure. As matters now stand, the salaries of several Postmasters in the larger cities are included in the lump sum annually appropriated by Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 12.--John O. Shook, a drug clerk, to-day stabbed to death Michael Sullivan, a railroad clerk. After the stabbing Shook went to his place of employment, where he was arrested. They were boarders together in the house No. 1,112 Locust-street, and the trouble which culminated in Sullivan's death commenced with a quarrel at the supper table. Shook says:

BALTIMORE, Md., March 12.--The Republican State Central Committee met in this city at noon to-day. The meeting was harmonious. The State Convention for the election of delegates at large to the Presidential nominating convention was appointed for May 1 at Hagerstown.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12.--Ever since he entered upon the duties of his office three years ago Mayor King has been in great demand to tie the nuptial knot. To-day, the third anniversary of his first wedding ceremony, the bachelor Mayor married his two hundredth couple.

Among the curiosities that attracted the attention of the thousands at the great moral show at Madison-Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening were several members of Sitting Bull's tribe of Sioux Indians, from the Black Hills of Dakota, who arrived here yesterday morning.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., March 12.--The hooppole cutters and bark-peelers in different parts of this county are commencing early to talk of the presence of bears in unusual numbers in the mountains. Shandaken, Henley, Woodstock, and Hardenbergh Townships seem to be the chosen fields of these animals this Spring.

Once in the course of every season Mr. Augustin Daly produces same trifle lighter than the light comedies which he usually presents to the public. Such a one he brought forth last night under the title of "Red Letter Nights; or, Catching a Croesus." The plot of this piece is of the simplest possible character, although an abundance of farcical incidents are spread over it.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 12.--Much excitement has been caused by the arrest of Attorney-General G.P.M. Turner, of this county, at 3 o'clock this morning. He went to a house of bad character in an intoxicated condition. He said he was the Attorney-General, the bravest of the brave; that he made all the laws and intended to break up all such places in the city, and that one in particular.

CHICAGO, March 12.--Chicago live stock dealers seriously question the trustworthiness of the reports of great ravages by the foot and mouth disease in the South-west. Some of them pronounce the cattle plague a myth, existing only in the fertile brains of scheming politicians, who are denounced for resorting to a plague scare as a means of helping their scheme to create a bureau of animal industry.

OMAHA, Neb., March 12.--A very largely attended meeting was held at Boyd's Operahouse this evening to give expression, on behalf of the citizens of Omaha, of their sense of the great loss society has sustained in the death of Bishop Clarkson, and to attest their profound respect for his memory.

PITTSBURG, March 12.--The conference of the Independent Republicans opposed to the County Executive Committee's method of electing delegates to the National Convention at Chicago this afternoon was attended by about 40 prominent citizens, including manufacturers, merchants, and professional men. S.S.D. Thompson. President of the Armenia Insurance Company, presided.

ALBANY, March 12.--A final effort to procure for future Mayors of Brooklyn the power of absolute removal of their departmental appointments was made in the Assembly, to-day, but without success. The bill for that purpose had been reported adversely by the Cities' Committee, the Chairman and three Republican members being recorded in favor of favorable action.

GREENSBURG, Ky., March 12.--At Marcum's mill yesterday, Asa Cantrell was shot by John Marcum. The two had an altercation, but were separted by their friends. Subsequently Cantrell, baring his breast, dared Marcum to shoot, which he did, killing Cantrell instantly. Marcum is but 17 years old. Cantrell was 45 and a desperate character.

On the afternoon of Jan. 14 Daniel F. Gearon was ejected from a saloon at No. 319 East Thirty-ninth-street for disorderly conduct. At the request of the bar-tender, Joseph Raynor went for a policeman.

Officer John Waddell, of the Long Island City Police, was startled about 3 o'clock yesterday morning by the cries of three little children, who were running down Ferry-street screaming, "Murder! help!". The officer rushed up to the children and the oldest managed to say, "Oh, Mister, run, two men are killing Mrs. Brannigan."

WORCESTER, Mass., March 12.--On Tuesday, Feb. 26, Mrs. Ozel Stockwell, of Fitchburg, Mass., gave birth to a daughter, and on Wednesday, March 5, one week and one day later, another daughter was born to her. The question which agitates Fitchburg is. "Are they twins?"

HAVANA, March 12.--Gen. Badeau, the United States Consul-General at this port, to-day presented Mr. Jay Gould to Capt.-Gen. Castillo. The latter, with his wife, afterward paid a visit to Mr. Gould's yacht. To-morrow Mr. Gould will give a breakfast on board the yacht, to which have been invited Gen. Badeau, his secretary, Senor Corsa, and Mr. Todd and wife.

LONDON, Ontario, March 12.--Mrs. Jane Brooks, the wealthy widow of New-York who was arrested in Chicago in a suit against her late husband's estate, and who left that city unexpectedly, is in this city.

BRANFORD, Conn., March 12.--Three weeks ago Charles H. Derby, a man of clerical garb and speech, and about 32 years of age, came here and boarded at the residence of Horatio Culver, a young and well-to-do sailor. Derby represented himself to be a Congregational minister, retired because of ill health.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 12.--Hiw Edward Haley, of Bridgeport, Conn., who was found fatally injured along the Reading and Columbia Railroad on Friday, and who died in the County Hospital on Saturday, met his death is yet unknown.

The township elections in Passaic County on Tuesday were uniformly favorable to the Republicans. In Pompton and West Milford the contest was unusually severe, and both townships gave extraordinary Republican majorities. In Manchester the Republican majority was two or three times as large as usual. In Little Falls and Acquackanonk union tickets were elected, on which Republicans predominated.

Among the fraudulent divorce decrees secured by Munro Adams was one in which Sidney H. Stuart appeared as attorney for the plaintiff, George Thornton. John G. Law, the ex-Deputy Clerk of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, who was indicted in connection with the fraudulent divorce business some time ago, appeared...
LONDON, March 12.--A dispatch from Melbourne states that the Australian cricketers have started for England.

GRAFTON, West Va., March 12.--The result of the meeting of the Republican State Executive Committee at this place to-day was a political victory for the machine. There was an undoubted preponderance of sentiment for Blaine, but the pressure exerted by the Federal officials outweighed the individual preferences of ...

WILKESBARRE, March 12.--The new airshaft of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company, near the Avondale shaft, was the scene of a terrible accident this afternoon, by which one man was killed and five others injured. The shaft is now about 200 feet deep, and a gang of ...

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, March 12.--Geronimi, with his Apaches, in charge of Lieut. Britton Davis, returned from Sonora, bringing 125 cattle and 100 horses and mules with Mexican brands. They started them last Saturday. Mr. Hewland, the General Inspector of Customs, attempted to seize the stock as smuggled property. Lieut.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--William A. Cook continued his testimony to-day before Mr. Springer's committee. He corrected a statement he made yesterday, and said that Col. Wood offered him a retainer of $20,000, instead of $25,000, if he would defend those against whom indictments might have been found. Mr. Cook read a letter sent by him to Mr. Bliss, in which ...

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 12.--William Hamer, a resident of High Spire, near this city, was bitten by a pet dog about six weeks ago, and on Saturday last he was attacked with hydrophobia. His sufferings were terrible, and in his struggles it required six men to hold him. He died last night.

There were a number of small fires Tuesday night and yesterday morning. Shortly before midnight a fire at No. 172 Fulton-street did $800 damage to the property of W.A. Force, a maker of stencil plates. An hour later there was a slight fire at No. 104 Bayard-street, which ...

A large crowd assembled in Sweeney's Racquet Court, at No. 159 East Thirty-fifthstreet, yesterday afternoon, to witness a fourhanded game of hand-ball. The contestants were Philip Casey, the champion, who took for his partner P.H. Smith, the champion of St. Louis.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 12.--The jury in the case of Gottschalk Lederman against the North British and Mercantile Insurance Company, which has been on trial during the past three weeks, returned a sealed verdict last evening, which was opened when the court met this morning.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 12.--At a special meeting of the Milwaukee Merchants' Association this afternoon the following resolution was adopted, and ordered sent to the Wisconsin Senators and Representatives at Washington:

In the hearing in the suit to set aside the lease of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey in the office of Blatchford, Seward, Griswold Da Costa yesterday, Stephen M. Williams, who has charge of the Jersey Central accounts, resumed his testimony.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 12.--The trial of John B. Griffin, charged with murdering Samuel Groener, of Pawling, by throwing a dynamite cartridge into the house where he lived on Oct. 5 last, was commenced and finished to-day. The evidence for the prosecution was in the main given by the occupants of the house where Groener lived, and the ante-mortem statement of Samuel Groener was also introduced.

ALBANY, March 12.--The Adirondack Forest Preservation bills engrossed the attention of the Assembly Committee on Public Lands. Some urged a postponement of the whole subject till next week, but a majority favored immediate action.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 12.--Col. William Spence, who yesterday shot and killed his son-in-law, Col. Edward S. Wheat, on account of business troubles, was to-day indicted by the Grand Jury. He is as passive as ever and repeatedly tells his friends who call on him at the jail that he took Wheat's life in order to save his own. Spence will be arraigned in the Criminal Court on Saturday.

The Republicans in the House are making a vigorous fight against the unreasonable stinginess of the Democrats in the appropriations for the postal service, which they believe will cripple the ordinary business of the service and certainly prevent the Postmaster-General from carrying out projected plans for extending its benefits and improving its efficiency.

HANCOCK, N.Y., March 12.--But for the ill-health of Matthias Mergridge, of Union Settlement, Wayne County, Penn., five miles from this village, his 64 children, grand children, and great-grand children would have celebrated at the homestead on Monday the sixty-fourth anniversary of his settlement on the spot, where he has lived ever since. Mr. Mergridge recently passed his eighty-sixth year.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 12.--The Odd-fellows Grand Lodge in California has sent word to members of the fraternity in this section that Benjamin Eggleston died at Dodgeville, leaving a fortune estimated from $100,000 to $1,000,000, and no heirs. He was said to have come from the Mohawk Valley.

A gentleman in evening dress hastened out of a room at Pinard's, in East Fifteenthstreet, last evening, and as he donned his overcoat and hat, was heard to say: "I've had quite enough of that meeting!" He had just left a small assemblage of Twenty-second Regiment veterans. Lieut.-Col. Brown presided over a "strictly private" meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12.--George Ryley, Andrew P. Sell, W.H. Conn, together with Superintendent W.B. Gill, all of the Western Union Telegraph Company, were this afternoon held in $800 bail to answer in court to the charge of conspiracy and detainer. The case is one of the many growing out of the recent controversy between the Baltimore and Ohio and Western Union Telegraph Companies over the tenancy of a branch office in a Third-street banking-house.

An odd-looking circular was posted on the bulletin board in the Cotton Exchange by Frederick Zerega yesterday morning. Across the top was written in English: "Private and Confidential." There was a general rush on the part of the cotton brokers to see what the document contained.

The State Board of Health met yesterday afternoon to receive the report of the sub-committee appointed to inquire as to the poisonous nature of water-gas. Among those present were E.M. Moore, of Rochester; President of the Board Erastus Brooks, J.T. Gardiner and Dr. J. S. Delavan, of Albany, and four public analysts, Profs. E.G. Love, of this city; S.A. Lattimore, of Rochester; W.G. Tucker, of Albany, and G.C. Caldwell, ...

It was resolved by the Board of Trade and Transportation, yesterday, that immediate steps should be taken by the State to put the canals in thorough repair for the coming season of navigation, and that the further improvement of them should be prosecuted without delay.

READING, Penn., March 12.--A premature explosion in a stone quarry of the Leesport Iron Company yesterday hurled a man named Aaron Clay 20 feet into the air. His face was crushed to jelly and an arm and both legs were broken. He lived but a few hours.

At a meeting of the Young Men's Republican Club, at No. 21 West Twenty-seventh-street, last night, the committee appointed by the club, consisting of G.R. Hawes, Joseph Pool, and M. N. Budlong, was continued, with power to take necessary action in calling separate Congressional District Conventions to elect delegates to the National Convention, in case the some are not called by the County Committee.
The following stocks and bonds were sold at auction by Adrian H. Muller Son, in the Exchange Sales-room, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday noon:

CHICAGO, March 12.--When George F. Slosson, the billiard-player, was informed to-day of the challenge of William Sexton he said: "I'm sorry it comes just at this time, for I'm so busy getting my billiard hall ready for opening that I can't possibly give my attention to match-making for a few days. This hall is my business, my livelihood, and I can't slight it for anything else.

At a meeting of Brooklyn ministers yesterday afternoon in the First Baptist Church, in Pierrepont-street, it was arranged to hold a series of union evangelical services in Historical Hall on the afternoons of next week. The services will begin at 4 P.M. and last one hour.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 12.--The Assembly Prison Committee by a vote of 6 to 3 has agreed to report favorably to-morrow the Howe Commission bill.

DETROIT, March 12.--William McDowell died at Traverse City, this State, yesterday, aged 104. He was the oldest Mason in the world. This was settled beyond dispute several years since. He was made a Mason in Lodge 298, Balleymaney, County Antrim, Ireland, June 23, 1807.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 250-- Louis McMurray et al., appellants, vs. Dwight D. Mallory et al.; argument concluded. No. 251--J.D. Taylor et al., Executors, , appellants, vs. Albert Bowker; argument begun.

CHICAGO, March 12.--Promptly on their return from the trial trip of the new fast train to Omaha., Postmaster-General Gresham and First Assistant Hatton proceeded to make arrangements for similar improvements to the north-west of Chicago. The postal party went to Milwaukee to-day, and after a conference ...

RALEIGH, N.C., March 12.--George Harrington, owner of large livery and sale stables in Fayetteville, has failed, with liabilities to the amount of $25,000. David Rosenthal, dealer in ready-made clothing in Raleigh, has made an assignment.

The sub-committee appointed by the Executive Committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association to investigate the charge made against L.E. Myers, of the Manhattan Athletic Club, by James Watson, that he is a professional, met last evening in the Knickerbocker Cottage.

BOSTON, Mass. March 12.--The Yale Alumni of Boston and vicinity, to the number of 75, held their annual dinner at the Parker House to-night. Arthur Hemmenway, '65, presided. President Noah Porter and Prof. Wheeler were guests, and among the Alumni present were Gen. Francis A. Walker, the Hon. Elizur Wright, the Rev. H.M. Dexter, and Linus M. Child.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 12.--John Frank Ford, the noted horse-thief and jailbreaker, is again in custody. He has broken out of a dozen jails in Pennsylvania and Maryland, his last feat being performed in October last,...

President Kirk sat in the Mayor's office yesterday and performed the duties of the Chief Magistrate in Mr. Edson's absence with the same dignity which marks his bearing in the Aldermanic Chamber. He had many callers, who congratulated him on the occasion, among the ...

DENVER, Col., March 12.--A large number of delegates were present this morning at the opening of the Wool-growers' Convention, representing Colorado, Kansas, Minnesota, NewMexico, Utah, Wyoming, Idaho, and Nebraska, To-day's session was consumed in speech-making and in effecting an organization.

The thirtieth annual meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn was held last evening in the hall of the association, at Gallatin-place and Fulton-street. President Edwin Packard occupied the chair. After some pleasant musical exercises the annual reports were read. All of the debt of the association, with the exception of $3,000, has been cleared off.

JACKSON, Mich., March 12.--The examination of Crouch and Holcomb, charged with murder, was continued this morning and created much excitement. Detective Harris testified that Holcomb admitted that he had had a 38calibre revolver, but said that he had lost it in a lake up north.

James McCluskey, of No. 420 West Thirty-second-street, made a curious charge against Dr. L.E. Holt, of No. 200 West Fifty-secondstreet, at Police Head-quarters last night. According to McCluskey, his child, who had been attended for pneumonia by Dr. Holt, died Tuesday night.
