The dead-lock in the Democratic Water Board of Newark, that has existed since Jan. 1 owing to the persistent refusal of Mayor Haynes to attend the meeting, was broken last night. Three Democratic and two Republican members were present, and a combination was formed by ...

The boats of the Poughkeepsie Transportation Line began their regular trips between Poughkeepsie and this city, touching at intermediate points, on Tuesday. The Daniel S. Miller, under command of Capt. Edward D. Carpenter, left Poughkeepsie at 2 o'clock Tuesday and ...

TRENTON, March 12.--Mr. Armitage, of Essex, recently introduced a civil rights bill very similar to that introduced into the Senate by Mr. Youngblood. The House loaded both down with amendments that made them ridiculous. Mr. Armitage succeeded in putting his bill through the committee mill again, and it came out regenerated and rejuvenated.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 12.--In a long deposition filed to-day in the office of the Prothonotary of Common Pleas, Charles H. Day, Adam Forepaugh's agent, confirmed the suspicion that the so-called offer of a prize of $10,000 by Circus Manager Forepaugh to the handsomest woman in America was an advertising dodge.

A gang of men was at work about 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the Ninth-street station of the Third-avenue elevated road hoisting ties from the street below for use in constructing a platform along the track. They used a derrick and tackle attached to a movable platform near the north end of the down-town station.
Chileon Thompson, of East Troy, N.Y., committed suicide in Hoboken yesterday by taking a dose of laudanum.

Seven boys were captured in Jersey City yesterday morning. Two were from Trenton and were armed with revolvers and cartridges. Their parents had already telegraphed to the police concerning them, and they were sent home.

Mrs. Richard Neville is lying in the NewYork Hospital in a critical condition from a selfinflicted wound in the left breast. She is a daughter of M.C. Shaw, of Port Chester, and about 22 years old. Last week she returned to this city from Port Chester, and, at her boardingplace...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 12.--The arrival of Walter Evans, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, in this city, his home, is causing much political conjecture. Mr. Evans declares that his visit has no connection with the interests of Arthur in the State delegation to the National ...

Steps have been taken to cancel the lease of the Oregon and California Railroad Company to the Oregon and Transcontinental Company. It is stated that the desired result will be brought about by mutual consent. The Oregon and Transcontinental has stopped the work of construction, thus breaking its contract with the ...

At a meeting of the registered drug clerks last evening for organization, in the lecture-room of the College of Pharmacy, No. 200 East Twenty-third-street, Charles H. Roberts said the object of the gathering was to aid in the enforcement of the pharmacy law, to provide that no clerk should put up perscriptions who was not licensed to do so.

Three phlegmatic and perspiring young Germans, whose knowledge of American customs seemed confined to a three-weeks' study of varied life on the Bowery, appeared at the Post Office with painstaking regularity several times yesterday and Tuesday to claim ownership in a money order for $1 from Columbia, Penn., payable to John Koppler, of this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12.--Information has been received here that Attorney-General O'Brien, who has been seriously ill at his home, in Watertown, for some time, is much improved. His speedy recovery is now looked for.

A telegram from Hartford reports that the accounts of W.S. Morgan, manager of the Hartford branch of the banking house of Putnam Earle, No. 5 Wall-street, this city, and a member of the firm, have been found to be very much confused. N.D. Putnam, the senior member of the firm, said: "Mr. Morgan's books do not agree with the books of the house here, and we know that our books have been correctly kept.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The annual meeting of the Illinois Central stockholders was held today. The following new Directors were elected by a unanimous vote: Walther Luttgren, of A. Belmont Co., New-York, to serve a until 1885; Sidney Webster, Robert Goelet, and S. Van Rensselear Conger, of New-York, to serve until 1888.

COLUMBUS, S.C., March 12.--Col. E.B. Cash will be taken before Chief-Justice Simpson at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning upon a writ of habeas corpus, when his "illegal arrest and detention in custody," as his counsel put it, will be inquired into. Eminent counsel will argue the case on both sides, and an interesting legal battle is anticipated.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 12.--The Railroad Commissioners to-day heard and approved the petition of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company to issue preferred stock to the amount of $5,000,000, each share to be paid either ...

ALBANY, N.Y., March 12.--Gov. Cleveland received in the Executive Chamber at the Capitol this afternoon a delegation from the Woman's Suffrage State Convention now in session here. Regardless of the leap year possibilities of such a visitation to a bachelor, he gave them a most cordial welcome, making a favorable impression by his affability and courtesy.

STARKVILLE, Miss., March 12.--A terribly destructive storm passed through this county last evening doing great damage. The course of the storm was from south-west to north-east, along the line of the Canton, Aberdeen and Nashville Railroad, about 12 miles west of here. It followed the railroad closely for about eight miles, destroying timber and blowing down houses, barns,

CINCINNATI, March 12.--A strong delegation of citizens was before the Board of Public works to-day to urge the ceding of a strip of land 125 feet wide from the west side of Lincoln Park for the use of the Southern Railroad.

BENNINGTON, Vt., March 12.--It is now learned that Postmaster Tiffany, who was Clerk of the Board of Trustees of Bennington Uraded School District, and managed the financial affairs of the district, has taken with him in his flight the order book. It is feared that heavy deficiencies will be found in addition to those in the Post Office funds.

A pet dog belonging to Mrs. S. de Sirenilh, a wealthy French lady residing in Stuyvesant-place, New-Brighton, Staten Island, got badly mangled by another dog a few days ago, and as the animal appeared to suffer greatly, its mistress decided to end its misery.

Anton Huber, a young German, 24 years of age, who lived with his father at No. 104 East Eighty-eight-street, was found hanging to a beam in Simonson Sons' lumber-yard, in East Seventy-ninth-street, yesterday morning. A note-book found near by was full of rambling sentences in German, from which it was gathered ...

A detailed review of Johann Sebastian Bach's "Passion Music" according to St. Matthew, if at all proportioned to the magnitude of the work, would be quite out of place in the columns of a daily newspaper. The task of enumerating the manifold beauties of the score has been fulfilled long since by commentators whose labors have left little or nothing to discover or to honor, and dry description of ...

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange discussed various proposed amendments to the by-laws yesterday and listed a few additional railroad bonds. The application of the New-York, Lackawanna and Western Railway Company to have $5,000,000 of its guaranteed construction mortgage bonds placed on the regular list was granted.

The atmosphere in Dr. Newman's corrugated iron church was chill and smoky, yesterday, when the doors were opened to admit the advisory council. Deacon James P. Foster beamed effulgently upon the shivering multitude in the 400 pews. "Didn't I tell you," he said, "that the place was cold as Greenland and could not be warmed? Sell it? Well, I should say so."

Schedules in the matter of the assignment of Jacob P. Billups, Alexander Burgess, and John M. Billups, Jr., composing the firm of J.P. Billups Co., cotton brokers, were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday. They show that the liabilities of the insolvent creditors are $680,187.27; their nominal assets, $732,375.49; and their actual assets, $1,650.

The bark J.R. Lopez, Capt. Mountford, which arrived yesterday, brought as passengers the Captain and several members of the crew of the brigantine F.H. Todd, which was wrecked at Mona Island on Feb. 13. Capt. George W. Clark, of the lost vessel, says that she was at anchor in the harbor of Mona Island on Feb. 13, when a violent south-easterly gale set in.

UTICA, N.Y., March 12.--The heavy rains and rising temperature of yesterday and last night have swollen the creeks through the Mohawk Valley to rivers and flooded the flats for miles. At Whitesboro, four miles west of Utica, the water of the Sauquoit Creek flooded the New York Central Railway tracks to the depth of six inches to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12.--In the Sharon divorce case to-day Frank Rodney, cousin of the plaintiff, testified that on the evening before Sharon's arrest, in September last, he accompanied Miss. Hill to the Palace Hotel. He heard her say to Sharon: "You know, senator, I am your lawful wedded wife although you have told some of the best people in the city that I am only your mistress."

SUAKIN, March 12.--The British forces reached Baker Pasha's position at Sereiba on Tuesday at midnight and went into camp. Abyssinian scouts reported that Osman Digna was in position and surrounded by a large force of rebels.

NEW-HAVEN, March 12.--To-day was ladies' day at Yale, and the athletic games were well attended. The tug of war between '75, Yale and Sheffield Scientific School, was won by the former by 4 feet 6 inches. The other winners were as follows:
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 12.--Christopher Hammond has sued the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company for $50,000 damages for loss of both arms by being run over while in the employ of the company.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 12.--In December last Mr. T.D. May, who had been engaged in business here for a year past, was married to the daughter of Pinkney Chamberlain, of Mariettastreet. The young couple were welcomed into social circles, and seemed to have a happy life before them.

William H. Fogg, George S. Coe, and Solon Humphreys, a special sub-committee representing the Chamber of Commerce, have prepared a circular for distribution among the several commercial bodies of this country. The circular states the desire of the Chamber that the coinage of silver dollars shall be suspended for a ...

A young Englishman, who has only been in this country two or three days, strolled into the brown-stone building in City Hall Park yesterday in search of the Register's office. By some means he was switched into the stream of prisoners going into Part I., of the Court of General Sessions, and carried into the prisoner's pen.

President Norvin Green submitted to the Executive Committee of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday a financial statement (estimated) for the quarter ending March 31, 1884. According to this statement there was a surplus on the 1st of last January of $3,970,931.78.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 12.--The Board of Public Works yesterday elected James I. Waddell, who resides in Annapolis, Commander of the steamer Leila, one of the vessels of the oyster police force. Capt. Waddel commanded the famous Confederate cruiser Shenandoah.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The Tribune has reports from a large number of points in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, and Ohio relative to the damage done to the Winter wheat crop by the hard freeze following the warm rain of Tuesday. As a rule, the crop has not been damaged greatly yet, but fears are entertained of serious consequences of a further freeze-night. In many localities the weather was growing colder very fast.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 12.--The woman's suffrage question came up before the Senate yesterday, and was met with telling speeches. Senator Bills was vehement in denouncing the cause, saying women, as a class, do not care to vote, as they did not take the opportunity given them in Boston to vote on the school law, only 700 taking advantage of the chance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 12.--The Sacramento municipal election resulted in the election of the entire Republican ticket with the exception of Mayor, to which office J.Q. Brown, Democrat, was elected.
WASHINGTON, March 12.--The following is a synopsis of the decisions rendered by the Treasury Department in Customs cases during the past week:

ROCHESTER, March 12.--Gillette played Sutton in the first series at the pool tournament this afternoon. He won the first six games by some of the finest playing during the tournament. At the beginning of the seventh game Sutton's luck improved, and at the commencement of the twenty-first game it was a tie. Then Gillette made a series of splendid combination shots, which secured the series for him.

Six dirty, unkempt lads, whose ages range from 9 to 12 years, members of a gang of young thieves who have been a source of constant annoyance and loss to the grocerymen on Tenth and Eleventh avenues, from Twenty-fifth to Twenty-eighth street, stood in a row in front of Justice Patterson, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday to answer a charge of burglary.
ALBANY, March 12.--The return of Mr. Daniel Manning from Bermuda has been quickly followed by a development of the Democratic programme in this State.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--A court of inquiry has been appointed to meet at Fort Reno, Indian Territory, on Tuesday, March 25, to investigate the past and present management of affairs at that post, particularly with reference to the creation and expenditure of a "slush fund," and the establishment and conduct of the Quartermaster's borrow and loan account with the post trader.

OSWEGO, N.Y., March 12.--Miss Helen L. Sloan, only daughter of ex-Speaker George B. Sloan, was married to-day to Lieut. John W. Danenhower, United States Army, and who has been brought into prominence by his connection with the Jeannette arctic expedition. While filling an engagement to lecture in this city about 18 months ago Lieut.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--As it had been announced that the Fitz John Porter bill was to be called up in the Senate to-day, most of the visitors to the Capitol turned their steps toward the Senate wing and crowded into the galleries, until not even standing-room was left. The only vacant seats were in the diplomatic gallery, which was occupied by eight ladies and gentlemen, double the number it has held before during this session.

The election of JOHN J. O'BRIEN as Chairman of the Republican County Committee completes the rehabilitation of the old machine under the plan of reorganization, and confirms the view that the plan was a sham throughout.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12.--Frank, alias "Bat" Harold, who was formerly a police officer, and who was recently arrested for planning a great number of robberies which were committed under his direction, was convicted to-day.

WEYANWEGA, Wis., March 12.--This community was shocked this morning by the announcement that Frederic Vierks, an old German resident of the town of Lind, had been murdered during the night. His body was found by his wife just outside of the barn about 1 o'clock this morning.

A meeting of the Western Anthracite Coal Association will take place at the Gilsey House to-day. The organization regulates the rates of transportation and the price of coal west of Syracuse and in Canada. It has nothing to do with prices east of that point. The contract now in force dates from April 1, 1883. The parties to it are producers and shippers of coal.
WASHINGTON, March 12, 1884. Representative Willis says that another effort to pass the bill extending the bonded whisky period will be made after the passage of the Post Office Appropriation bill.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 12.--The Democratic members of the General Assembly held their third coucus to-night for the purpose of coming to a conclusion in regard to what shall be done with the Scott law.

LONDON, March 13.--An explosion occurred last night in a hotel at Fulham, a suburb of London. It is believed to be another Fenian dynamite outrage. A box containing four packages, apparently cartridges, was found on the premises. One man was blown to pieces.

Another gentleman is not pleased with the selection of the Johnson-street site for the new Post Office Building in Brooklyn, and, like Mr. "Mike" Dady, has laid his grievances, first before the Secretary of the Treasury, and then before the President. The complainant this time is Mr. William H. Grace, a Brooklyn real estate agent, who has been here several ...
An English scientific person has made a careful examination of the weight of the English nobility for the last three generations.

The President gave another State dinner party to Senators and Representatives at the White House this evening. A company of 54 sat down at the table. The decorations of the East Room were unusually handsome. The great apartment was converted into a tropical bower by 2,000 plants, set in beds of moss, in the angles and window recesses.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 12.--Details of a terrible crime and of swift and terrible retribution come from Robertson County. Tenn. Twenty-five miles from Springfield, near the Kentucky line, lived John Martin, his wife, and three children, two of them grown young women, the other a boy of 12. Martin was in his seventieth year and has lived in the neighborhood nearly his entire life.

ALBANY, March 12.--The Assembly Railroad Committee listened to arguments this evening on the bill extending the time of the Rapid Transit Commission. Charles P. Shaw was the leading speaker, and made an exhaustive and forcible argument in favor of the bill.

Wilhelm Messner, a German cabinetmaker, 23 years of age, was arrested yesterday, charged with having on Sunday morning attempted to set fire to the planing and molding mill at Nos. 306, 308, and 310 Eleventh-avenue. The mill is a four-story brick structure, owned by Albert Horn.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 12.--The indications to-night are favorable to a resumption of work by all the coal miners in the Hocking Valley to-morrow morning. Mr. McBride, President of the Miners' Union, visited New-Straitsville to-day, and after learning the true situation of affairs informed the men that they were clearly in the wrong.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--The Secretary of the Navy has received a communication from Capt. G.S. Nares, Royal Navy, embodying his views and those of Major H.W. Fielden, her Majesty's Army, and Capt. A.H. Markham, Royal Navy, in response to the invitation received from the Secretary of State for such suggestions as they might make for the conduct of the expedition to be sent for the relief of the Greely party.
ALBANY, March 12.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: No. 127-- The Mayor, , of New-York, appellants, vs. Henry Hart and William Remsen, respondents.

The Hahnemannian Society of the NewYork Homeopathic Medical College held its twelfth annual Commencement last evening in the college amphitheatre, at Twenty-third-street and Third-avenue, and the exercises were listened to by a large audience.
Giuseppe Panizza, the Italian "bandit," was yesterday sentenced by Recorder Smyth to four years and six months in the State prison.
Miss. Maggie Harvey, who was assaulted in the Sloane flats, in West Thirty-second-street, on Saturday night by the negro Williams, rallied yesterday considerably. Last night she was so ...

The examination into the charge of abandonment preferred by Mrs. Caroline M. Miller, against her husband, Hugh C. Miller, a salesman in the lace department of Arnold, Constable Co., and the son of the Rev. Alexander Miller, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Dunellen, N.J., was set down for yesterday, in the Tombs Police Court.

Gas which had leaked from a defective pipe in a shed of the Delavergne Mixer Refrigerating Company's works, No. 153 Bankstreet, exploded yesterday afternoon and started a fire, but the shock broke a carboy of liquid ammonia and a gauge on an ammonia gas tank, and when the firemen arrived the ammoniacal vapor had put out the fire. The damage done amounts to about $300.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 12.--Chris tian and John Siegel, merchants of this city, and brothers, were buried in one grave to-day. Both died of typhoid fever within 24 hours. Two other brothers are ill. The fever was caused by drinking water from a well into which a cesspool drained.

The foreman of the jury trying the suit of Elisa Alkalay for a limited divorce from Joseph Alkalay is a gentleman who is determined that matters with which he has to do shall not go wrong. Yesterday he indignantly interrupted the flow of Counselor Wehle's speech, who was opening the case for the defendant, by protesting against some of the lawyer's statements as being not warranted by the testimony.

BOSTON, March 12.--The will of Elisha V. Ashton, in which are contained many munificent bequests to local charitable institutions, was allowed in the Probate Court to-day despite the objections made by the heirs on the ground of undue influence, and that the testator was of unsound mind. Unless a compromise is effected it is understood that an appeal to the Supreme Court will be taken and the will contested.

As we have said before, the wonder to foreign observers of British politics is not that bills for the extension of the franchise should be introduced into Parliament, but that they should not be much more sweeping than they are.

No American steamer has ever gone through the Suez Canal with a cargo. The San Pablo, of the Pacific Improvement Company, however, will sail this morning for China by way of Gibraltar and the Suez Canal. Several hundred cases, containing American agricultural implements, cotton, and woolen goods, go by this steamer to be exhibited at the Corean exhibition, which is to be held in Seoul, the capital of Corea.

PETERSBURG, Ill., March 13.--Fannie Dukes, sister of Zora Burns, went on the stand this morning and testified as follows: Zora went to work at Carpenter's in January, 1883, and a short time afterward wore silk dresses and fine shoes.

That the accumulation of wealth in business neither dulls nor entirely absorbs the intelligence nor relaxes public spirit is shown by the intimate connection of manufacturing and commercial firms with recent political history, and the immense sums spent on the institutions of the great towns of the North and Midlands. Mr. Gladstone, as every Englishman knows, is the ...
NORFOLK, Va., March 13.--Pea-nut buyers and sellers of this city have been at loggerheads for some time past, and almost all transactions in their trade are suspended.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 13.--The last Congressional apportionment made a new district of Niagara, and the Fourth and Fifth Assembly Districts of Erie. Niagara County has never before been associated with any part of Eric in a Congressional district, and this present association has, at the outset, precipitated a serious and an awkward difficulty in the matter ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 13.--The Legislature to-day appropriated $1,200, and authorized the Governor to appoint a suitable person to go to Florence, Italy, and remove the body of Joel T. Hart, the sculptor, to this State. Hart was a resident of Clark County, Ky., where he began his life in the humblest circumstances. The body will be buried in Frankfort Cemetery, where repose the bodies of many of the greatest men of the State.

It was hardly necessary for Gov. CLEVELAND to give a hearing to the opponents of the Roosevelt Anti-Confirmation bill if his wish was merely to know what they could say against it. It had been said over and over again.

FARGO, Dakota, March 13.--A largely attended meeting of Fenians was held here yesterday, with Capt. B. Hazen in the chair. A report was made that three cases of arms were stored at some accessible point, and that should there be ...

CHICAGO, March 13.--Controller Gurney will leave here for New-York next Saturday to bring action in the United States court against the Stewart estate for the recovery of taxes due this city and county, amounting to $12,000. He will take with him as evidence of the claim depositions from this city. The Stewart estate, it is understood, will contest the suit.
The performanace of Bach's "Passion Music." which was publicly rehearsed at the Acacemy of Music on Wednesday after noon, was repeated last evening in presence of an overflowing audience.

Acting Mayor Kirk was the victim of a practical joke at the hands of Alderman Grant yesterday which for a time disturbed the usual serene atmosphere of the Mayor's office. Mr. Kirk had just administered the oath of office to James Lapham as a city surveyor, and had resumed his work of signing warrants, when he was interrupted...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 13.--The lower two classes at Williams College, Williamstown, held meetings to-day to consider the best means of preventing future disorderly coflicts between the Freshmen and Sophomores. The following resolution was carried by a majority of the Sophomores and unanimously by the Freshmen: "Resolved, in view of recent disorders in the college occasioned by a limitation of personal rights, that we as a class, are in favor of removing all such limitations."

OMAHA, March 13.--The funeral of Bishop Clarkson this afternoon was the most imposing ceremonial ever witnessed in Omaha. Bishop Vail, of Kansas, officiated, and 50 clergymen participated in the services, which were held in the cathedral. The edifice was crowded long before the hour appointed for the services. The public schools were closed, and many banks and businees houses were also closed during the funeral.

CHICAGO, March 13.--A bill was filed today in the United States Circuit Court by the New-York publishing house of Harper Brothers against John A. Enander and Gustaf A. Bahman, publishers of the Swedish paper, Gamla of copyright.

A contractor is about to build some private dwellings for G.S. Lespinasse at One Hundred and Sixty-fifth-street and Tenth-avenue. Yesterday Michael Barry was foreman of a gang of blasters who were excavating for the foundations of one of the houses.

LOUISVILLE, March 13.--The CourierJournal this morning publislied a report of an alleged murder and lynching at Springfield, Tenn., and a summary of the case was telegraphed to THE TIMES last night. The Courier-Journal will print a statement to-morrow admitting that it was imposed upon and that the story was a senseless hoax. The scene of the reported tragedy was so remote that it was not possible to verify the facts until to-day.

It is earnestly to be hoped that some proper recognition will be made of the services in the cause of popular education rendered by Capt. WALSH, of the gang of infant desperadoes just arrested by the police of this city.

Year by year the colleges devoted to the education of girls are approaching more closely in all respects to the colleges designed for the other sex. The girl undergraduates already study Latin and Greek; celebrate their class days, and plant their class ivies.
Ex-Senator D.B. St. John, of Newburg, is at the Hotel Brunswick. Ex-Gov. William Claffin, of Massachusetts, is at the Gilsey House.

In the forthcoming number of the Revue Historique M. Joseph Reinach will give a considerably number of unpublished dispatches, addressed by Gambetta from Tours to Jules Favre and Gen. Tiochu during the siege of Paris. They are a valuable complement to the dispatches published at the time, or by the National Assembly, and all breathe as ardent patriotism and a ...

ALBANY, March 13.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: No.133-- Mary Story, respondent, vs. The Williamsburg Masonic Mutual Benefit Association, appellant. Argued by C.L. Lyon for appellant. J. Stewart Ross for respondent. No. 135--George Clarke appellant, vs. Ira Davenport as Controller of the State of New-York, respondent.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 13.--Prentiss Tiller, money clerk of the Pacific Express Company at St. Louis, who disappeared from the office of the company in that city on Sunday, March 2, taking with him two valises full of money packages, valued at about $75,000, was arrested in Milwaukee this morning. The arrest is one of the most important ever made in the history of the city.
PARIS, March 13.--The French occupied Bac-Ninh yesterday. The Chinese fled in the direction of Thainghuien. The French had 70 wounded.
OMAHA, Neb., March 13.--The Third Nebraska Representative District Republican Convention has been called to meet at Norfolk on April 29. to elect delegates to the National Republican Convention.

NORWALK, Ohio, March 13.--Mrs. Blinzley was arrested here yesterday and sent to jail to await trial on a charge of cruelty toward Mag gie Montgomery, a girl 8 years of age, whom she had adopted from a Cleveland charitable institution.

LUMPKIN, Ga., March 13.--The crooked paths pursued by the Rev. J.W. Fackler, such as having married two wives, the frequent use of intoxicants, and other conduct unbecoming a minister, a full account of which has been published, have been investigated by the church of which he is a member.

JOLIET, Ill., March 13.--The Omaha express on the Rock Island Road, due here at 12:50 to-day, struck a broken rail three miles from the city and seven coaches left the track and overturned, but no one was seriously injured. The train was badly wrecked.
LONDON, March 13.--The funeral of William Blanchard Jerrold took place to-day. Messrs. Morwood, Sala, and Yates were present.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--By the aid of five Republicans and one Readjuster the friends of Fitz John Porter succeeded to-day in getting the bill for the relief of Porter passed by the Senate. It is a long time since the dignified Senators have had so large, an audience as was packed into the galleries this afternoon.

The Rev. Warren C. Hubbard, Pastor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, at Clinton and Carroll streets, Brooklyn, has been sued by his wife, Genevieve J. Hubbard, for limited divorce on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment.

UTICA, March 13.--Dr. J.H. Douglass, one of the oldest practitioners in Central NewYork, died to-day, age 75. He was born in NewYork City, but was during the greater part of his life a resident of Utica.

ALBANY, March 13.--The Democrats in the House had their usual bout with the prison labor question to-day, and for some little time amused themselves by posing as friends of the working men and of the tax-payers. The absurdity of the farce which they were playing was felt to be so great that they with difficulty repressed their laughter. The Prison Committee had favorably reported the Howe commission bill.
C.W.J.--The article was not published in THE TIMES. Old Sea Captain.--The Grand Duke Alexis, who visited this country, is still alive. He is a brother of the present Emperor.

One hundred and forty-nine new doctors were turned loose upon a suffering community last evening at Steinway Hall, where the twentythird annual Commencement of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College was celebrated. Prof. Isaac E. Taylor, the President of the Faculty, conducted the exercises, and upon the stage were tho Trustees and Faculty of the college, ...

We were pleased to learn yesterday that the success of the colony of silk-culturists recently planted in Moore County is assured. The colonists already settled are entirely satisfied with their prospects, and many more are expected soon to follow them.

Still another new rapid transit project has been broached in Brooklyn. There are now more than half a dozen schemes, some of them originating as far back as 12 years ago, in various stages of development, but rapid transit, in the opinion of the much-enduring victims of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, seems as far odd as ever.

Prince BISMARCK'S appearance in the Reichstag and the speech which he made there do not seem to indicate his desire to stand well with the United States so much as his consciousness that his ungracious refusal to forward the Lasker resolution has put him at a disadvantage in German politics.

The fifty-seventh annual report of the Board of Trustees of the Northern Dispensary for 1883, which has been published, shows that of the 12,227 patients treated for different diseases during the year, 11,409 were cured or relieved and only 97 died.

TROY, N.Y., March 13.--By the efforts of the Tax-papers' Association the Sheriff's bills, the payment of which the association protested against, have been reduced more than $4,000. The Sheriff has also agreed to reduce the number of his deputies.

In spite of the jubilant dispatches, the defeat of OSMAN DIGNA can scarcely be supposed to he conclusive. In military language an engagement in which the total loss of one side is little more than a hundred would not be classified as a battle at all, but only an affair.

Joseph Carter, an Orderly Sergeant, 40 years old, of Company K, Fifth United States Artillery, now attached to the garrison at Fort Schuyler, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning was found dead in his room at the Van Dyke House, No. 28. Bowery.
The meeting of the Presidents of the trunk lines and the managers of their Western connections, which was called the fore part of the week, took place yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 13.--Hop Sing, a pensive Chinaman, sleeps in a room behind his laundry at No. 203 Dekater-street. At 2 o'clock this morning he was awakened by a terrific racket among his ironing boards. He rushed out and found a man in the laundry who sent a string of oaths and two pistol bullets at his head.

ALBANY, Ga., March 13.--For two days Mr. S.D. Irvin, of the firm of Cook Irvin, warehousemen, had not been seen, and his whereabouts became a matter of inquiry. Telegrams were sent to different cities where it was supposed he might go, but without avail.

At the University Club Theatre last evening Miss Cassely, a dramatic reader, introduced herself to the metropolitan pubic. Miss Cassely recites rather than reads, and so secures such force as may be gained by that method.

Dr. Feodor Mierson, of Mount Kisco, white walking across the tracks of the Harlem Railroad at that place yesterday morning, was struck by the locomotive of the Chatham express and so badly injured that he died threequarters of an hour afterward.

A bride in Essex Centre, Ontario, at the very last moment repented of her promise and caused the utmost consternation among her friends and all, present by replying to the momentous question of the officiating clergyman, ...

A correspondent of an Adelaide paper whose judgment, the editor says, is entitled to respect, calculates that the wheat harvest in South Australia will give an average yield of about 11 bushels per acre.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 13.--There were only two series played at the pool tournament to-day, and both were in the evening. In the first series Heman played Gillette. Heman made several difficult combination shots, and won by 11 to 7. Then came the long-looked-for series in which Frey and Ressunger were the contestants ...

WASHINGTON, March 13.--"While I remarked yesterday that Mr. Bliss's appointment as counsel in the Star route cases was a political one," said William A. Cook at the beginning of his examination to-day by Mr. Springer's committee, "I do not mean there was no reference to the fact that he was a lawyer. While he was a lawyer, he never would have been selected but for partisan reasons.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--Leave of absence until Aug. 28 has, on account of ill-health, been granted Cadet John F. Miller, Fourth Class, military Academy. The extension of leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability, granted First Lieut. Jalius E. Quentin, Fourteenth Infantry, in special orders of ...

TAUNTON, Mass., March 13.--The trial of the fast of a series of interesting graveyard insurance cases was begun this morning. James Kirby, of Fall River, was charged with conspiracy in connection with Dr. Henneasy and William Driscoll, both of whom are now missing. They attempted to defraud the United States Benefit Association of Boston of $5,000, the amount of a policy on the life of Charles Russell.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 13.--The Voluntary Trade Tribunal, composed of railroad coal operators and miners, met to-day to arrange a price for mining after April 1. The operators demanded the acceptance of a reduction from the present rate--3 cents per bushel.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 13.--A destructive cyclone passed near Guntersville, Ala., last night. H.S. Hess and Mrs. John Tidmore were killed and John Tidmore and Mrs. Frank Farmer were severely injured. About 30 houses in the path of the storm were blown to atoms. The storm left the earth after moving nearly six miles.

The fraudulent issue of 2,000 shares of the stock of the Manhattan Beach Railway Company by J.H. Fullerton, one of the company's clerks, raises a very interesting question as to who shall bear the loss. Fullerton has been in the employ of the company about four years.
A meeting of the College Base-ball Association will be held in Springfield, Mass., to-day, when efforts will be made to have Dartmouth reinstated and Columbia join the association.
J. Champlin Morris, of No. 7 Exchangecourt, has sold his seat in the Stock Exchange in consequence, as he says, of the dullness in the stock market.

It is the intention of the friends of Mr. Morrison's Tariff Reduction bill to make a stubborn fight for that measure, and to compel the Democrats who follow Mr. Randall to assume all the responsibility that belongs to them if the bill is defeated.

The six boy burglars, an account of whose exploits was given in THE TIMES yesterday, were again before Justice Patterson at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. Their confinement in prison did net appear to have dampened their spirits.

Probably the most annoying and impatient journey ever made in Caledonia County was made on Thursday by George Richardson, in his second trip from Danville to Upper Waterford. George had engaged to enter into a copartnership of marriage with a Danville young lady.
The affairs of Loop, Hopkins , Co., of williamstown, which was the firm name of the company which Dr. Chadbourne and Keyes Danforth controlled, have been practically settled.

John Russell, a printer, died in one of the city hospitals in May last. It was discovered that he had been a miser, and had left about $40,000. In the Union Dime Savings Institution he had deposited $2,500 to the credit of one Sarah Russell. An Englishwoman of that name who claims to be Russell's sister is suing the Public.

A long legal opinion has been procured by some of the creditors of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company. It holds that the stockholders are liable for the debts of the company to the amount of the 16 2/6 per cent. unpaid on the original subscription.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 13.--The Immigration Association this morning adopted bylaws establishing the territory of the association to embrace the 14 Southern States. The objects of the association are to establish immigrant homes when necessary, encourage foreign and domestic immigration, publish ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 13.--Frederick Warde, the tradegian, left here for New-York to-night. Before his departure he caused to be sered upon Mr. Collins, his late manager, a summons in a suit brought to annual the contract existing between them.

Agent F. Le Boulanger, of the Bordeaux Line, received a dispatch yesterday announcing that the new steam-ship Chateau Margaux was spoken, with her rudder broken, on March 8, in latitude 44 and longitude 43 , by the Guion ...

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 13.--The boiler of a freight engine exploded this morning as it was leaving the yard. The fireman, Charles Cooper, age 27, was badly injured, and, it is feared, will lose his sight.

James F. Campbell, an Indian, known in the Eighth Ward as the "Red Man," went last night to Henry Boscher, who keeps a furnishedroom house at No. 27 Sullivan-street, and told him that Capt. McDonnell had sent him to warn him to close up his place, as a raid would be made at 10 o'clock.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 13.--It has been a matter of surprise that the woman suffrage resolution has occupied so much time and has called forth so much oratory. The friends of the measure may well congratulate themselves that the subject has been respectfully treated and not ...

ILION, N.Y., March 13.--The Ilion Citizen printed its entire edition to-night by electricity, using an electric motor, deriving the current from a 10-light dynamo 15 rods away. It is the first newspaper in the country thus printed.

Steam-ships Nereus Coleman, Boston, H.F. Dimock; Thornhill, (Br.,) Wetherill, Cardenas, Beloni Co.; Ptolemy, (Br.,) Ballantine, Liverpool, Busk Jevons; Cienfuegos, Faircloth, St. Jago and Cienfuegos, James E. Ward Co.; City of Montreal, Lewis, Liverpool via Queenstown, Inman Steam-ship Co.; Roanoke, Couch, Norfolk, City Point, and Richmond, Old Dominion Steam-ship Co.; British Empire, (Br.,) Fawcett, Havana, and Mexican ports, F. Alexandre Sons; Mynberg, (Ger.,) Jaeger, Baltimore, Oelrichs Co.
"Confusion" will be revived here next Monday night at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre. Miss Sarah Cowell began a series of four readings yesterday afternoon at the University Club Theatre.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 13.--The Assembly Committee on Cities heard Mr. Matthew P. Breen, of New-York, in opposition to the bill providing for the enlargement of the Grand Central Station in New-York.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 13.--The action of Chief-Justice Simpson, of the State Supreme Court, to-day in admitting Col. E.B.C. Cash to ball in the sum of $2,500 is not calculated to inspire any deep confidence in the administration of justice in South Carolina. The Colonel is charged with being accessory after the fact to the murder of Town Marshal Richards, of Cheraw, by his son, W.B. Cash.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 13.--The Directors of the Laclede National Bank, while summing up business to-day, found Frederick J. Dieterichs, their Paying Teller, short in his accounts $30,000.

When the Hon. Albion W. Tourgee started for the lecture-room of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, to deliver an address before the Young Men's Philomathean Society, he had not fully decided what he should talk about.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 13.--In the Sharon divorce case to-day the celebrated marriage contract was offered in evidence to prove the defendant and plaintiff to be man and wife. H.L. Welis, of Santa Cruz, testified that he heard Senator Sharon in August, 1881, introduce the plaintiff to a friend of the witness as "Mrs. Sharon."
The award for the erection at Charleston of a sarcophagus to John C. Calhoun, for which the last Legislature appropriated $3,000, was given to a design presented by Col. James G. Gibbes, of Columbia.

The Western Anthracite Association continued its session at the Gilsey House all day yesterday. After a prolonged discussion, in which much friction was developed, the association decided to endeavor to make an arrangement with ...

The abolition movement in Ceara has thus far accomplished the liberation of all the slaves held in 25 municipalities, and has so reduced the number held in the other municipalities that the complete emancipation of the province is anticipated before the close of June next. Should this expectation be realized, the province of Ceara will have accomplished a work which is without parallel in the history of the world.

Terry Co., of No. 5 Pine-street, have been commissioned by the Trustees of the Brooklyn bridge to fit up and let for storage purposes six of the large arches under the bridge in Frankfortstreet, between Vandewater and Rose streets.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 13.--The water in front of this city rose six inches to-day, reaching the high-water mark of 1874. This is the second time since that date the water has reached this height, but it is the first time on record when it has occurred so early in the season.

The funeral services of Col. Frank Wrisley, proprietor of the Victoria Hotel, will be held at the Church of the Measiah at 9:30 o'clock this morning. The body will be taken to Boston on the 11 o'clock train from the Grand Central Station. After services in Boston it will be taken to Belmont, Mass., for interment. Flags were at half-mast on most of the principal hotels in this city yesterday in honor of the deceased.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13.--Senator Pruden's bill amending the jury law so as to make men who have read newspaper accounts of cases and have formed an opinion eligible to serve as jurors came to the House by message yesterday afternoon and provoked a long discussion this morning.
A young woman, whose left wrist was broken and bandaged, accosted an officer of the First Precinct on Wednesday afternoon and asked where a destitute but respectable woman could find shelter.

ERIE, Penn., March 13.--City Treasurer Boyle was formally pronounced a defaulter by the Council to-night, and Capt. Jarecki, one of his bondsmen, was appointed temporary Treasurer. Boyle has been seen in Buffalo, presumably enroute for Canada. At the Council meeting to-night resolutions offering a reward for his capture were passed by the select branch, but were negatived in the Common Council.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 13.--The annual report of the Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western Railway for 1883, issued to-day, shows: Earnings, $1,058,663.40; other receipts, $4,942.38; operating expenses and taxes, $670,524.94; leaving net receipts, $393,080.84; interest on funded debt, $252,849; leaving a surplus of $140,231; interest on income bonds, $30,000, paid out of surplus, leaving a clear profit of $110,231.49.

A young Paterson factory girl, whose name is withheld by the police of that city, has been the victim, according to her story, of a misplaced confidence twice repeated. Some time ago she became acquainted with William Shorter, a young man employed in a sewingmachine agency in Paterson.
TOPEKA, Kan., March 13.--There has been no official information received by the State Board of Agriculture as to the condition of Winter wheat.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 13.--This afternoon, as a young man named Simon Barnett, of No.1 Alphonse-street, was crossing the Centralavenue bridge, he saw a man sitting outside of the railing on the edge of planks on the north side of the bridge.

There was an unusually large attendance at the meeting of the Military Service Institution, at Governor's Island, yesterday. Gen. Hancock presided, and among those present were Gen. Theodore F. Rodenbough, Judge-AdvocateGeneral Horatio C. King, Gen. T.L. Crittenden, Gen. Thomas B. Fry, Gen. W.D. Whipple, Gen. T.W. Sweeny, Gen. I. Vogdes, Gen. T.V.D. Reeve,...
CITY OF MEXICO, March 13.--Yellow fever is raging at Tehuponepec City. John Meyers, an American railroad contractor, died of the disease this morning. Many people are leaving the city.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--The dispatch reporting the speech of Price Bismarck was shown this afternoon to members of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House and to other members. Ex-Gov. Curtin, Chairman of the Foreign Afdairs Committee and ex-Mininter to Russia, said:

LANCASTER, Penn., March 13.--The Carlisle authorities were wrong in their statement that the prisoner in their custody was John Frank Ford, the noted horse-thief and jail-breaker. When the Lancaster authorities reached Carlisle last night they found that the prisoner bore not the least resemblance to the noted convict, with the single exception that he had only one eye.
Michael Loesch, an organist, who lives at No. 76 East Fourth-street, attended the performance at the union-Square Theatre on wednesday night. He placed his overcoat on an unoccupied seat beside him.

Mrs. Jane Verdon, of No. 231 East Seventy-seventh-street, caused the arrest yesterday of Michael Ryan, a former attendant at the Court of Special Sessions, whom she accused of personating an officer and abducting her nephew from her house. According to the statement of the woman, made to Justice Patterson at the ...

RICHMOND, Va., March 13.--A meeting of the Atlantic States Nail Association was held here to-day. Reports show that the stocks of nails are light and the demand large. The price was fixed at $2.60 per keg, the base thus conforming to the price recently established by the Western Nail Association.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 13.--Col. A.M. Swope, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Seventh District of Kentucky, has resigned. No reason for his resignation has been assigned. His resignation is dated Feb. 25, and is to take effect March 31. The Collector expresses a wish for the re-election of President Arthur, and pledges his help to that end.

When the members of the advisory council were admitted to Dr. Newman's cold church yesterday morning they found Trustee Hopkins Standing on guard at the vestry door. "The committee are inside, finishing up their report,," he said. "They will notify the council when they are ready."

TROY, N.Y., March 13.--The ice in the Hudson broke up last night and gorged at the iron-works. The wharves at the lower end of the city are flooded, and the coffer dam at the new railroad bridge was carried away.

BENNINGTON, Vt., March 13.--Late last night George Piffany, a son of Bennington's absconding Postmaster, who has been employed in the Post Office, was arrested, charged with stealing the Government's money.

In the Court of Special Sessions, yesterday, the Rev. Griffith H. Humphrey, Pastor of the Welsh Presbyterian Church in East Thirteenth-street, was charged by Laura A. Jones with being the father of her 2-months-old child. Miss Jones and Owen Owens, with whom she lived in Seventeenth-street, were members ...

It was scarcely 1 o'clock yesterday morning when John McNally, the night watchman at Trinity Cemetery, on Washington Heights, saw two figures coming from the river-front toward the wall of the cemetery, at One Hundred and Fifty-fourth-street.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13.--Mrs. Emma D. Coolidge was arrested to-day upon the charge of attempting to abduct her 10-year-old son Alfred, and with conspiring with two other persons to accomplish her purpose. The woman is separated from her husband, George E. Collidge, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 13.--Shortly after 7 o'clock this evening gas in the furnace of B. Edgar Thompson's steel-works, at Braddock, Penn., exploded, instantly killing William McCall and seriously injuring James Murray and Christopher Toole.

William Ranals, of No. 346 West Fiftysecond-street, a collector, and John S. Forgan, of No. 159 Varick-street, book-keepor, in the employ of George Raynor, at No. 160 South Fifthavenue, were arrested yesterday on complaint of Raynor, who charged them with embezzlement. It is charged that Ranals collected a number of bills, and Forgan marked them on the books as paid, but the money was not turned in. The accused were held for examination.
TROY, N.Y., March 13.--Fred R. Ames, a son of the late Austin Ames, the millionaire, of Whitehall, dropped dead in a saloon here this morning after a debauch.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13.--Alredy a fight has opened in the Athens district for the Congressional nomination. The present incumbent, the Hon. J.W. McCormick, is now serving his first term and has given satisfaction to his constituents. Mr. McCormick, according to party usage, is clearly entitled to a second term, and will be a candidate for renomination before the convention.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 13.--The Commercial Gazette will publish to-morrow interviews with prominent Republican manufacturers, merchants, and bankers on their Presidential favorites. Blaine is a strong favorite, with Edmunds second and Arthur third.

BOSTON, March 13.--The House to-day defeated the bill extending municipal suffrage to female citizens by a vote of 144 to 50, with 11 pairs.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13.--At to-day's session of the Philadelphia annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, the members of the second year's class were admitted to full connection.

The New--York Druggists' Union held a meeting yesterday to take action upon the price list that has been prepared lately.

TRENTON, March 13.--A movement for a final adjournment of the Legislature has been made and defeated. In view of the pressure for the passage of an act imposing a share of the public burdens upon the railroads, the movement was not without its significance. BOSTON, Mass., March 13.--Taban Pratt and other creditors of the Midland Improvement Company, of North Carolina, applied to Judge Devens, of the Supreme Court, to-day for the appointment of a Receiver. On behalf of Lewis Coleman, another creditor, a, postponement was had for a week, the question of jurisdiction to be determined in the meantime.

WASHINGTON, March 13, 1884. The Treasury Department, having received in formation that 25 Cuban bandits had sailed from Juan de Los Remedios in the brig Screamer, destined for Boston, has ordered the Collector of Customs at that port to prevent their landing if possible.
The second harp and organ concert of the series of entertainment now occurring, under the auspices of Mr. George W. Morgan and Miss Maud Morgan, at Chickering Hall, was given yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, March 13.--The big Gazellan on Feb. 14, in latitude 23 5', logitude 64 15', passed the wreck of a wooden steamer apparently not long in that condition. She was copper-bottomed and was about 800 tons burden.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 13.--The leading inventors of the country have issued a call for a convention to take action to prevent pernicious legislation by Congress. It will be held in Music Hall, this city, on March 25 and 27. Responses from all parts of the United States and Territories already received show that an attendance of 3,000 may be expected. All inventors are eligible as delegates.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 13.--D.K. Mason, tobacco merchant, who made an assignment this afternoon, was arrested to-night on a warrant sworn out by the President of the Board of Trade charging him with felony. Mason is accused of having hyothecated warehouse receipts at the banks to the value of $50,000, when he had no tobacco in warehouse. He was formerly engaged in business at Paducah, Ky., where he also failed.

A warm discussion is going on in Vienna newspapers in connection with the case of an officer recently dismissed from the army for refusing to fight a duel. Two young men named Hintner and Morl, both Lieutenants in the Reserves, and both attending lecture in the University of Gratz, met last October at a railway station.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 13.--Joseph H. Young, dry goods merchant of Concord, N.C., has made an assignment. His liabilities are $26,000, and the assets are about $20,000.

BALTIMORE, March 13.--Ex-United States senator Henry G. Davis and wife, of West Virginia, gave a reception and dinner to the Hon. James G. Blaine and Mrs. Blaine, of Maine, this evening, in the Mount Vernon Hotel here.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 13.--North Mansfield, nine miles west of the city, was the scene of a murderous affray last night. Early in the evening Edward Sumners visited William Daily's saloon and got into a dispute with Daily.

JACKSON, Mich., March 13.--The Crouch murder examination was continued to-day. Galen E. Brown, who was shot on Feb. 8, testified to conversations he had had with Foy, who said that the Crouch estate owed him $2,000. He would not tell what the money was owing to him for, but said that it was not for work on the farm.
HAVANA, March 13.--Mr. Jay Gould changed his plans to-day and sailed this afternoon for St. Augustine, Fla.

Mr. McCullough's engagement at the Star Theatre has lasted nearly two weeks; the two weeks will end to-morrow. This engagement is, altogether, a peculiar one in the brilliant career of Mr. McCullough. For many years his engagements have been, in our city, noteworthy and popular. Popularity, it must be said, did not spoil him.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 13.--Ferdinand Schueffler and a lad named William Denoyer were burned to depth in the fire here yesterday morning, they having been cut off from escape in the sixth story of the carpet-sweeper factory. Their remains are supposed to be deeply buried in the debris. Schueffler was a married man and the father of several children.
A brilliant assemblage filled Chickering Hall from top to bottom last night at the annual Commencement exercises of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 13.--The Republican Convention for the election of delegates at large to Chicago will meet at Montpelier April 30, and the two districts will hold separate conventions--the First at Rutland at some date not more than 15 days after April 30, and the Second at Montpelier on April 26.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13.--Mayor-elect Smith to-day announced several appointments, among them that of Gen. James Stewart to be Chief of Police.
A man was busily engaged in pasting patent medicine advertisements on the posts supporting the awnings in front of a block of stores in Eighth-avenue at 1 o'clock the other morning.

CHICAGO, March 13.--The Tribune's dispatches to-night regarding the cattle disease show the situation to be in the highest degree alarming and indicate that the live stock men at the Union Stock-yards whose views were given yesterday have either ignorantly or interntionally belittled the case.

ALTOONA, Penn., March 13.--The Right Rev. John Tuigg, Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburg and Administrator of the Allegheny Diocese, had another attack of paralysis last evening, and is now in a critical condition.

RANDOLPH, N.Y., March 13.--The third annual meeting of the Western New-York Agricultural Association began here to-day. The Hon. A.G. Dow, of Randolph, made an address, and J.C. Sibley, of Franklin, Penn., spoke on his model dairy farm, where 130 head of thoroughbred ...

LONDON, March 13.--Dispatches from Suakin say that the rebels opened fire on Gen. Graham's forces at 1 o'clock this morning. The British forces were formed to repel a charge, but no attack came. The men were thereupon ordered to lie down again. The fire of the rebels continued all night, but the British did not reply. An officer and two men were wounded and one man was killed.

Charles H. Rugg, the negro who was indicted for the Maybee murders and the Townsend assaults, was taken into the queens County Court of Sessions, at Long Island City, yesterday, Judge Armstrong presiding, but he was not arraigned on any of the indictments.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 13.--John B. Dutcher, D. H. Sherman, and several other Eastern capitalists, who own the old beef-canning establishment in East St. Louis, arrived here yesterday and arranged to turn their property into a large slaughtering concern, from which they will soon send great quantities of dressed beef to New-York and other Eastern points in refrigerator cars.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 13.--The dividend of the Enterprise Factory, in Augusta, of 2 per cent., to be followed by a like dividend quarterly, is payable April 1. It is in striking contrast with other mills.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 13.--The trial of Seneca B. Miller, the second of three Pawling dynamite murderers, was commenced this morning before Judge Bernard. Nearly all of the witnesses who testified yesterday against John B. Griffin were recalled, and the evidence elicited was fully as damaging.

Montreal, March 13.--Exchange on London for 1,000,000 has been purchased from the Bank of Montreal by the Government.

An affidavit was filed yesterday in support of a motion for a new trial in the case of H.M. Stone against Charles L. Hunt, in which a judgment was rendered for the plaintig as compensation for damages to a collection of museum curiosities. Charles Maxwell, the affiant, said he was an old showman, and for several years occupied the position of lecturer in Stone's and other museums.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 13.--A bill was quietly introduced in the Legislature recently, at the suggestion of citizens of the town of Glenville, Schenectady County, the purpose of which was to prevent the New-York Central Railroad from exercising tho right, given by an old State law, to abandon a part of the Mohawk turnpike, between Glenville and Hoffman's Ferry.

Among the numerous matters which the Randall Appropriations Committee has industriously neglected is the appropriation for the continuance of the Civil Service Commission. ALBANY, N. Y., March 13.--Gov. Cleveland gave a hearing on the Roosevelt Aldermanic bill this afternoon. Assemblymen Haggerty, Donnelly, and Clarke, John F. Strahan, W. Bourke Cockran, Gen. John Cochrane, Aaron J. Vanderpoel, Alderman O'Neil, Maurice F. Holahan, James J. Donovan, Civil Justice Michael Norton, and other New-York gentlemen were present to oppose the bill.
The other day we remarked that "no one cared about Merv" now but Mr. Charles Marvin and Mr. Ashmead Bartlett. As the statement has been controverted, we may appeal to Mr. Marvin himself as a witness.

POCAHONTAS, Va., March 13.--An explosion occurred in the Laurel Creek coal mines at this place this morning at 1 o'clock. The mines are owned by the South-west Improvement Company, and have been in successful operation for several years.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--The House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day considered the action of Prince Bismarck upon the Lasker resolution. Mr. Phelps proposed that a report should be submitted to the House declaring in effect that the wise course of the Secretary of State relieved the House from the necessity of any further action.

Miss Clara Louis Kellogg gave a musicale at the Clarendon Hotel last evening. The large rooms on the ground floor of the hotel were thrown open, beautifully decorated with smilax and a profusion of natural flowers, and brilliantly lighted, and about 200 guests enjoyed the interaretation of a musical programme of unusual merit and liberality.

ST. PAUL., Minn., March 13.--The fast mail train reached here at 3:25 o'clock this afternoon, five minutes ahead of time. It was met at the station by a number of leading citizens and a delegation from the St. Paul Board of Trade.

BOSTON, March 14.--The swine plague, or hog cholera, is reported to be prevalent in Arlington and neighboring towns in this State. One farmer who has between 500 and 600 hogs has lost nearly 200, and with others the loss has been very large, in some cases calf of the droves having died. The disease is identical with the swine plague which was so prevalent in the West a few years ago.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 14.--Mr. Roosevelt, of New-York, Chairman of the Assembly special committee which has been engaged in investigating various departments of the local Government of the city of New-York, made the following unanimous report to the Assembly this afternoon:

Mlle. Louise Lablache, one of the contralti of the Metropolitan Opera-house company has had the fortune, or misfortune, to make a serious impression upon the heart of a Frenchman residing in this city. Early in the season he began to lay at the feet of the young songstress, especially when she sang at the Sunday evening concerts, floral offerings of enormous size.

Some additional testimony was taken by the Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation, at the Maritime Exchange, yesterday, regarding the performance of the Harbor-masters' duties since last Spring. L.J.N. Stark, President of the Dock Commission, said that the Commissioners had not undertaken to perform any duties pertaining to the berthing of vessels until such duties were forced upon them.
WASHINGTON, March 14, 1884. Treasurer Wyman to-day mailed checks aggre gating $2,544,208, in payment of bonds of the one hundred and twenty-fifth cull, maturing on March 15.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 14.--The North ern Pacific will put on a through Portland train to connect with the Milwaukee fast mail train. It will leave here at 4 o'clock, taking the Northwestern mail delivered from the East at 3:30 o'clock. The North-western is also expected to make connection with Eastern passenger trains. The time from St. Paul to Portland will be 90 hours, and to Tacoma 100 hours.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 14.--The river is now several inches higher than it has been at any time during the Winter. Much suffering is being endured by the poor people whose homes are in low places. The public rehearsal prefacing the fifth philharmonic concert of the present season took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The programme was one of the most pleasing offered for many months; it was interesting, neither too heavy nor too light, and of suifficient brevity to occupy two hours, and no more. It also enlisted the services of that rara avis in the Philharmonic world--a soloist, in the person of Mr. Rafael Joseffy.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14.--The Chinese cigar-makers' strike is ended, and the men will return to work on Monday.

BOSTON, Mass., March 14.--George S. Woodbridge, wholesale and retail producedealer, Lincoln-street, has failed. His liabilities are unknown.

SANDWICH, Mass., March 14.--The laborers on the Cape Cod ship canal refused to go to work this morning, and say that they will not return until better food is furnished to them. Some intend to leave, while others will await the result of their strike. They say that it is hard to tell who is to blame, the cook or the food contractor.

Speaking at the Vale dinner in Boston, the Rev. Dr. Daniel Butler said he couldn't remember that the good old college at New-Haven had ever graduated a demagogue. He had in his mind's eye, he said, a recent chief magistrate of Massachusetts. "You could no more grow such a man in Yale College than you could raise alligators in Eden."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 14.--Congressman Skinner, Chairman of the Republican County Committee of Jefferson County, has forwarded a call to the committee of St. Lawrence County for a district convention, to be held at Gouverneur on April 15.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 14.--Mrs. Lawrence, of Chicago, mother of the late T.G. Lawrence, Class of '84, has given Yale College $50,000 for a dormitory.

BRYN MAWR, Penn., March 14.--Dr. James E. Rhoades, of Philadelphia, was to-day elected by the Trustees President of the Bryn Mawr College, and Martha Carey Thomas, of Baltimore, Dean of the Faculty and Professor of English. The institution will be opened to students in the Autumn of 1885.

TITUSVILLE, March 14.--About five miles up the Allegheny River from Warren is a small oil field known as Wardwell Pool. A little over a mile west of this Chambers and other producers are drilling a well. On Friday last sand was unexpectedly reached. The well was shut down, and it is thought a wooden plug inserted in the hole. The well made one flow, sufficient to convince the owners they had valuable property.

LONDON, March 14.--Further details of the battle between Gen. Graham's forces and the rebels, near the Tamai Wells, continue to arrive. During the confusion which followed the wild rush of the Arabs upon the British and caused them to retreat the newspaper correspondents and other non-combatants took part in the fray and used their revolvers freely and with deadly effect.

PETERSBURG, Va., March 14.--The steamer Little Helen, owned at Richmond, lying off a wharf at this city, has been seized by Deputy United States Marshal Gallaghan for indebtedness here. The Little Helen is a passenger and freight boot.

Mr.. Joseph Allen, of the firm of Joseph Allen Co., flour and commission merchants, at No. 11 South-street, died Thursday afternoon at his residence, No. 171 Macdougal-street. Mr. Allen, who came from an old New-England family, was born in Andover, Windsor County, Vt., in 1803.

Lady John Manners has been presented by the Master and members of the Shipwrights' Company with a marble bust of her husband. Two years ago Lord John Manners was the Master of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13.--The University of Edinburgh, Scotland, has invited Dr. Samuel D. Gross, Emeritus Professor of Surgery in Jefferson College, to accept the honorary degree of LL.D. at the tercentenary of its foundation on April 17.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 14.--Oliver Dyer, Jr., of Mount Vernon, N.Y., a member of the Sophomore Class of Yale College, died at noon to-day from injuries received in a spairing match at the college, in the athletic games on Saturday afternoon. At no time since the accident has he been conscious.

Yesterday the Fire Commissioners directed Inspector W.P. Esterbrook to make a personal examination of Madison-Square Garden, to determine as to the sufficiency of its exits and what may be necessary to secure the safety of audiences. Peter Seery, Inspector of Combustibles, was directed to see that the provisions of the law with reference to the storage of combustible materials, fire-extinguishing apparatus, and fire-alarm telegraph connection were properly observed.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 14.--William H. Field, of Greenwich, who shot his brother about a month ago, and who has since been confined on the charge of intent to murder, has been adjudged hopelessly insane by the commission appointed to examine him, and he has been sent to an asylum.

ISLAND SHOALS, Ga., March 14.--Samuel McDaniel, a young farmer, was yesterday in one of his fields plowing. The plow caught in some obstruction. Urging the mule, he found that the plow had caught in the handle of a five-gallon jug which he pulled out of the ground.
HANCOCK, N.Y., March 14.--Dennison Fisk, a prominent citizen of this village, and his on were thrown from a sleigh yesterday afternoon, the former being killed and the latter having an arm broken.

BALTIMORE, March 14.--In the Baltimore Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South to-day, Bishop Wilson presiding, the annual report of the Wesleyan Female Institute, at Staunton, Va., was presented. The report shows the institute to be in a prosperous condition, with a well organized board of teachers, and a roll of 142 pupils from 17 States in the Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14.--Mme. Gerster's second appearance at the Grand Operahouse in this city was witnessed on Wednesday night by a large audience. Tickets, as on Monday, were sold at a high premium.

Chief of Police Harrigan, of St. Louis, arrested, on Feb. 29, a man who gave the name of George A. Vincent, for attempting to carry out an extensive scheme of forgery. Vincent had opened accounts with several prominent St. Louis banks, and had tried to swindle them by means of forged drafts on this city for large sums.

CHICAGO, March 14.--Chief Veterinarian Salmon, of the Department of Agriculture, Washington, passed through Chicago to-day on his way to Kansas, where he has been ordered by the Government to examine the cattle disease reported in that State as the foot and mouth malady. Secretary John H. Rauch, of the Illinois State Board of Health, accompanied him as far as Chicago.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 14.--The Twentyeighth New-York Veterans, who are to make their return visit to the Fifth Virginia Regiment of Confederate Veterans at Staunton, Va., this year, decided to-day to leave Lockport about May 20 on a special train. DENVER, Col., March 14.--The Aspen stale, which arrived at Leadville at midnight last night, brought news of a fatal snow-slide which occurred on the Aspen Mountain Monday night. Instead, he passed the night at the Lindell Hotel, where he made a patient endeavor to rectify the express company's accounts, which were so badly deranged by the youth's exploit.

LONDON, March 15.--The Bullionist asserts that negotiations are proceeding with the Government at Washington for the lease of Samana Bay from San Domingo. CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 15.--An eastbound passenger train on the Western North Carolina Railroad was wrecked to-day one mile east of Marion, the engine and two cars being thrown down an embankment. Engineer Knox was killed and the fireman was badly bruised. No other persons were seriously hurt.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 15.--Early this morning, while freight train was backing out of a siding near High Park, the scene of a terribly accident on the 2d of January last, another freight train ran into it. The engineer and fireman of the latter train, seeing it was impossible to prevent a collision, jumped from the engine, and were seriously, if not fatally, injured. The damage to the rolling stock is estimated at $25,000.

BUFFALO, March 16.--Mr. J.N. Scatchard has resigned his office of Water Commissioner of this city on account of ill health. He has been the foremost member of the board, and to him it owes its efficiency in the past few years.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 16.--Last night the employes of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad Company relaid the switches, frogs, , torn up in the afternoon by the Pittsburg, Cleveland and Toledo Railway Company's men where the roads cross at Hazelton, near here.

BALTIMORE, March 16.--Franz Struat, a worker in terra cotta who came to this city two years ago from Austria, committed suicide today in this city by strangling himself with a skate-strap. The cause assigned was temporary aberration of mind from overwork.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 16.--The Rev. John Lyon, of the Church of the Redeemer in this city, went to Hartford on Wednesday for a short visit among friends. He left there Thursday afternoon, since which time nothing has been heard from him. There is no cause for his absence.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 16.--From a canvass of the State made by the Constitution it is found that the demand for the nomination of Mr. Tilden is unprecedented for its unanimity, and the responses come from representative business men and politicians in every county and town in the State.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 16.--A Seneca County farmer living near Fostoria, named George Brough, went into a restaurant at Pemberville while intoxicated and ordered supper. He attempted to bolt an ounce and a half of beefsteak without chewing it and it lodged in his throat. He fell to the floor and before assistance could arrive had choked to death. He was 45 years of age.

LONDON, March 16.--It is rumored that the Government, desiring to test the opinion of the country in regard to the Egyptian policy, and fearing that obstruction in the present Parliament will thwart the Franchise bill, has decided to dissolve Parliament, and informed the Queen of this decision through Mr. Chamberlain, who dined at Windsor Castle last evening.

CHICAGO, March 13.--The case of John Cohesy and John Weaver, accused of stealing $4,000 from Michael Powers, was tried before a jury in Judge Gardner's court yesterday, and the defendants discharged. Powers and his wife were an aged and penurious couple.

A meeting of the Board of Directors of the American College at Rome was held in this city last week. The President, Archbishop James Gibbons, of Baltimore; the Secretary, Archbishop John J. Williams, of Boston, and the Cardinal, represented by Coadjutor Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan, were present.
WASHINGTON, March 16.--In the House of Representatives to-morrow, under suspension of rules, a number of committees will ask for the passage of measures upon which favorable reports have been made.

CHICAGO, March 16.--Deputy Sheriffs took possession of the box-office of Hooley's Theatre here last night on the strength of a claim for $1,200 which Anna Dickinson makes against Fannie Davenport, the actress, now appearing in that theatre. The thirteenth anniversary of the Paris Commune was celebrated last night at the Germania Assembly Rooms by the German Socialistic Labor Party. There were about one thousand people present, and the scene was decidedly lively.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 16.--A woman named Sarah J. Gibson, living two miles out of Deposit, N.Y., came to this city yesterday from Delhi with a check for $700 and $100 in cash. Having cashed the check at a bank here she started home by way of the Erie Railway.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 16.--A murder mystery of 17 years ago has been cleared up today by the dying confession of Charles Kett. On Jan. 11, 1867, Christine Kett, a beautiful young lady 18 years old, was found at her home in Oakstreet lying at the entrance to the cellar with her brains oozing from a ghastly wound in her head. She was dead, and no clue was left to the murderer.

The Veteran Association of the One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Regiment held a special meeting yesterday afternoon at Royal Arcanum Hall, No. 52 Union-square. Several letters were received from relatives of dead comrades asking for assistance in obtaining evidence for pension claims.

There were some sins, he said, which were committed in words. Profanity gas one of these. "It will do no good," said Dr. Newman, "for me to say that no gentleman will use profane language. In Europe more than in America have pastels and their kindred, colored crayons, labored under the contempt of artists and amateurs. In this country the art may be considered not to exist; in Europe it has been the stock in trade of inferior male and female workers in portrait.

CLEVELAND, March 16.--A colored desperado named Jesse Lawrence, who was recently freed from the penitentiary and went to his home in Cadiz, engaged in a fight last night with a white man named Hilligas. Policeman John Stebbens ordered the men to quit, when Lawrence pulled a revolver and threatened to shoot the officer. Stebbens was too quick for him and shot the rough through the heart. Death resulted immediately.
The annual parade of the Irish societies in honor of St. Patrick will take place this afternoon. The Sixty-ninth Regiment will attend high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 16.--Arthur Croft, known throughout the professional base-ball world, died here to-day of pneumonia. In 1878 Croft led the country in fielding, his home position being at first base. That season he was a member of the Indianapolis Club, which won the championship of the National Association. He played professionally with the original St. Louis Browns, with the Browns of 1881, and with the old Troy Club.

His road was not sufficiently interested to have it considered a Lackawanna line.

WASHINGTON, Penn., March 17.--The remains of Miss C.B. Tilton, who died at the residence of her brother, in Philadelphia, of consumption, a few days since, were incinerated here this afternoon. ATLANTA, Ga., March 18.--Two policemen saw an object hanging from a telegraph pole which looked like a man. The concluded it was a case of suicide and sent for the Coroner who ordered the body to be cut down, when it was found than it was a figure stuffed to represent a man. The inquest was postponed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18.--Mrs. Damon Y. Kilgore's ambition to become a lawyer was crushed again to-day. Judges Ludlow and Yerks, a majority of the Common Pleas Court, No. 3, followed in the footsteps of Courts Nos. 1 and 2 and overruled the motion for her admission to practice.
