ST. JOSEPH, Mo., March 21.--J.B. Johnson has been detected in stealing quinine, morphine and other valuable drugs from the wholesale drug-house of Saul I. Smith Co. of this city. Johnson was formerly clerk in the house, but has now two drug stores of his own.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 21.--Col. Mapleson, of Her Majesty's Opera Troupe, was found guilty here to-day of violation of the city fire ordinance in blocking the aisles of the Grand Opera-house. The impresario will be sentenced to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, March 21.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: Nos. 270 and 271--George Hagar, appellant, vs. Reclamation District No. 108. Argument concluded. No. 272--The Adamantine Brick Company et al., appellants, vs. L.C. ...
Two alleged white elephants, said to come from Siam, where it is reported that white elephants are worshiped by the natives, are currently believed to be about to be exhibited in our city.

DOVER, Me., March 21.--At the time of the Barron murder, strong suspicions were entertained against a traveling phrenologist named Allen, who had been in Dexter and vicinity traveling from house to house. Detectives were sent out at the time to find him but failed to do so.
DUBOIS, Penn., March 21.--Ever since Dubois was made a borough money has been quietly, yet persistently, leaking out of its treasury.

The German ship Wilhelm, which arrived here yesterday from Bremen, had a narrow escape from being lost in the ice on the Banks of Newfoundland. Ice was sighted as soon as the Banks were reached, and fields of it were constantly passed until latitude 41 20' and longitude 54 67' was reached.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 21.--The Rate Committee of the Southern Pool Associatian has adjourned, leaving rates in a more muddled condition than ever before known. When the Rate Committee met last Tuesday the members did not seem to disguise the fact that the situation was critical and the outlook was brightened by no signs of promise.

ALBANY, March 21.--The General Surface Railroad bill, which was discussed in the Senate on Tuesday and made a special order again for next Tuesday, is likely to meet with more determined opposition than was at first anticipated. Nearly 200 graduates and undergraduates of Columbia College sat down to the annual dinner of the Alumni Association in Delmonico's last evening. Every man present, except one, bore that relation to the college. The stranger was President Porter, of Yale.

WASHINGTON, March 21.--The House Committee on Banking and Currency began an investigation to-day of charges made in a memorial recently laid before the House, setting forth that Government officials had been guilty of fraud and misconduct in combination with the Directors of the Pacific National Bank, by which the shareholders of that bank had suffered considerable losses.

Within the last week no less than four gangs of small-boys have been broken up by either mothers or policemen. All of these gangs consisted of students of dime literature, and their object in every instance was robbery, if nothing worse.

The kirmess, which was so successful last year, will be repeated after Easter for the benefit of the Skin and Cancer Hospital, and, remembering the uncomfortable crowding at Delmonico's, a much larger hall has been selected.

George Fuller, one of the most prominent of American portrait and landscape painters, died at his home in Boston yesterday of Bright's disease of the kidneys. Mr. Fuller was in the sixtysecond year of his age, and until within a few days past was apparently hale and hearty, so that his sudden death came like a shock to his friends.

Ellen O'Neil, a pretty young girl of 14, and Dennis J.O'Keefe, a rough-looking man in a red shirt, a sparrer and bar-tender by trade, were arraigned yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court, the former for being wayward and running away from home and the latter for abducting the girl.

POMEROY, Ohio, March 21.--A constable of Lebanon Township brought to jai1 Don S. De wolf, charged with fatally shooting Abraham Webster, a farmer, age 66. The two quarreled while riding home from Racine.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 21.--A man who bas swindled the veteran soldiers of the country out of $10,000 was released from the Lancaster Jail yesterday. He was immediately rearrested, and was to-day brought to the city and again imprisoned by United States Commissioner Phillips in default of bail.

CINCINNATI, March 22.--The County Treasurer to-day stopped payment of warrants drawn by the Auditor for the reason that the county fund has been overdrawn $160,000. With a jail full of murderers awaiting trial this action will stop all proceedings in the criminal courts for an indefinite period.

LONDON, March 22.--The feeling of disquiet in regard to Gen. Gordon has been lessened, but not extinguished, by the news to March 15. His position is regarded as extremely precarious. WASHINGTON, March 22.--The investigation of the appointment of House employes was conducted by a sub-committee, of which Representative Dockery was Chairman. Mr. C. W. Tyson, of the stenographers of the House, who resigned March 3, 1883, stated under oath that his resignation was demanded by Gen. Keifer without cause.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 22.--The defeat of the Democratic Party of Rhode Island at the coming State election is already assured. The boasted strength of the party is fast being disproved and the leaders are beginning to see that with all their efforts to secure a large registration last November and December they are still hopelessly in the minority.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 22.--Prof. W. H. Clarke, the well-known organist and musical author, lately of Boston, now of Toronto, will return to this city for residence in May.

Mr. Millner Gibson was indebted for not a little of his popularity and prestige to the social gifts, the innate kindliness and geniality, as well as dexterity, of his wife. Few are the cases in which an Englishwoman lies achieved such a success in her capacity of hostess on both sides of the Channel as this admirable lady.

After spending the whole afternoon in debate upon the Whisky bill the House of Representatives adjourned at 5 o'clock without having made any headway with the measure. The bill now goes over until Tuesday, as Monday is the day for the introduction of bills, and what spare time there may be after that business is closed will be filled up with other matters.

The other day we noticed Mr. Browning's energetic applause of Salvini's magnificent impersonation of Othello. We are glad to find that the society of which Mr. Browning is President--the New Shakespeare Society--on the proposal of its founder, Mr. Furnival, unanimously elected Signor Salvini to be one of its Vice-Presidents. The honor is well deserved, and the society has done itself credit by paying this tribute to Signor Salvini's genius.

The invasion of women, which is the chief event in recent university history, advanced another step at Oxford last week, when Congregation agreed, by 100 votes against 46, to admit women to several university examinations.

The scarcity of legal-tender notes of the denominations of one and two dollars is leading to a rapid increase in the circulation of the standard silver dollars. Since the fact has become generally known that the printing of one and two dollar notes has been stopped, in consequence of the exhaustion of the appropriation for that purpose, bankers in this city have been carefully husbanding their supplies of small bills.

Daniel B. Hopkins, a journalist and theatrical agent, died of Bright's disease, at Tampa, Fla., yesterday. He went there about six weeks ago for his health. He was a boy in a Rochester printing office, and became a reporter. During his life he was agent for Barnum, Abbey, Haverly, John A. Stevens, and others. His body will be brought to Brooklyn for burial.

The latter hastened to explain that, unlike the ordinary Judge, he had no objections to receiving hearsay evidence. Thus encouraged, the pilot proceeded to spin his yarn:

SHAMOKIN, Penn., March 22.--Later advices state that two men were killed and a third seriously injured by the explosion of sulphur yesterday in the Carson colliery, near this place. Zacharias Henninge and Cavel Gatenbouskey, Hungarians, were working side by side in a narrow chamber only four feet high.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 22.--The remains of Mme. Anna Bishop reached Barrytown at 11:25 o'clock this morning, whence they were conveyed to Red Hook and interred in the Lutheran Cemetery, beside those of her son. The Episcopal burial service was read, the Rev. John W. Moore officiating. The only persons present were a few relatives and friends.

Jacob P. Billups's seat in the Cotton Exchange was to have been sold at auction yesterday, but an injunction, issued by Judge Truax, on the application of Mr. Billups's attorney, prevented. The rules of the Exchange provide that when a member's seat is sold by order of the Board of Managers, it must be sold by the Superintendent.

The Court of Appeals has sustained the will of the late Gen. Alfred Duffie, formerly United States Consul at Cadiz, Spain. The will was made in Spain, in accordance with formalities prescribed by the laws of that country for the making of what is known as an "open will." The contestants alleged that the instrument was nothing more in effect than a notarial certificate.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 22.--At 2:30 o'clock this afternoon the ice moved in the Coon River at Van Meter, tearing out the dam and breaking up the mill-race. The water then undermined the mill and it toppled into the stream a complete wreck. There was 1,000 bushels of wheat in the mill.

At any early hour this morning fire was discovered in one of the vaults used for storing old paper below the Senate folding-room. The blaze was easily extinguished. To prevent a recurrence of this danger it was to-day decided to store all the waste paper on the Senate side in the vaults outside the Capitol, underneath the terrace. The fire was spontaneous this morning.

LANSING, March 21.--Although the Republicans of Michigan are to choose delegates to the National Convention four weeks from Thursday next, not one of their leaders ventures at this day to predict the course which the delegation will take, or to name the man for whom a majority of the delegates will vote.

Mr. Augustus Schell is seriously ill at his residence, No. 9 West Thirty-fourth-street. He has been a sufferer from a complication of diseases, of which Bright's disease is prominent, for several months.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 22.--At 7:30 o'clock to-night Helen Ransier, a married woman, and the mother of three children, shot and killed Adam Sutler, on Green-street. The woman claimed that Sutler had been persecuting her for some time, and that she did not intend to kill him.

Mr. JOHN ROACH published a pathetic wail in the Tribune of Saturday over the possible passage by Congress of a free ship bill. Such a bill, authorizing Americans to buy foreign-built ships, would, Mr. ROACH assures us, at once close all the existing American ship-yards, and would leave us wholly dependent upon foreigners for ships for our navy should a sudden outbreak of war compel us to create a navy.

OLEAN, N. Y., March 21.--The traveler on the Erie Railroad soon after passing Elmira comes upon striking indications of oil in huge colonies of tanks at Wellsville and at this place. This, 395 miles from New-York, is a lively town of something more than 3,000 inhabitants.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 22.--Capt. Perley, of the New-Brunswick Engineers, has been offered the command of this year's Wimbledon team. The position of second in command has been offered to Capt. Bosse, of the Sixty-fifth Regiment of Montreal.

BUFFALO, March 22.--The newspaper owned by James D. Warren, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, publishes to-day the calls for four of the Assembly District Conventions of Erie County to elect delegates to the State Convention. They will be held on April 8 and 10. It also publishes a leading editorial entitled, "Shall Republicans Win or Lose?" which is evidently intended to have great significance.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22.--Three thousand people attended the performance of "Faust" at the Grand Opera-house this afternoon, and many more were turned away at the doors. Some of the spectators were allowed to go upon the stage, and the wings were crowded throughout the representation. Mme. Gerster was the Margherita, and her impersonation was received with many evidences of satisfaction. She was cheered to the echo between the acts and bore away armfuls of flowers.

A postal from Mrs. Hunter to a lady in this city says that Mr. Hunter is recovering from an attack of cold and erysipelas, and that he is convalescent. With the exception of nervous prostration, he was at no time seriously ill.

Judge Lawrence decided yesterday that the case of Savvillar Downing, who claims that the boy Carlos Wilson is her child and not that of Emma Wilson, should be heard before Mr. Thomas P. Wickes as Referee. The reference will proceed on two days' notice.

The steam-ship Pontiac, from the Mediterranean, was towed into this port in a disabled condition yesterday morning by the Anchor steam-ship Bolivia, which fell in with her on Friday, about 30 miles south of Shinnecock Light. Capt. Martin, of the Pontiac, said that he passed Gibraltar on Feb. 28.

BOSTON, Mass., March 22.--The Rev. Henry Morgan, one of the notables of Boston, died to-night of pneumonia, aged 59 years. For 25 years, from platform and pulpit, he has waged a relentless war upon gambling and the social evil. He was Pastor of the First Independent Methodist Church, on Shawmut-avenue. Mr. Morgan came originally from Newtown, Conn.

The violin performances of Miss Jeanne Franko and the piano-playing of Miss Margulies were the most interesting incidents of the entertainment.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 22.--While attempting to drive across the track of the Georgia Railroad this afternoon in the outskirts of Augusta Capt. John Carnagan, a prominent citizen, was killed by an passing train.

BANGOR, Me., March 22.--The Hon. Samuel F. Humphrey was to-day elected Mayor of this city by a majority vote of 155. On last week Monday there was no choice, Humphrey having 1,621 votes, and to-day having 1,929. The Republicans are considerably elated over the result of the election.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 22.--John Schofield, an old man employed in the spinningroom of the Chase Mill, who was assaulted by unknown persons on Tuesday night, died this morning from his injuries. The police are endeavoring to find his assailants.

The Committee of Investigation appointed by the Colorado Coal and Iron Company stockholders began its work yesterday. It expects to have a report ready about the 1st of next month.

The first opportunity for seeing the portrait of Pope Leo XIII., which he sent as a present to the American Bishops, was afforded at the Appraiser's stores yesterday afternoon. The case containing the picture, which is about 9 feet by 12, was opened in the presence of a number of persons and under the direction of John A. McSorley, a Custom-house broker, who for years has had charge of religious works.

NEW-LONDON, March 22.--A queer little body passed out of existence here late last evening in the death of Mrs. Sophia Bentley Hall, better known as "Granny" Hall. She was 102 years old, and the oldest person in Connecticut. She was very benevolent. She came from Baltimore some 80 years ago, and was living with the fourth generation of her family. She will be buried on Monday.

The works of the Electric Candle Company and the lard refinery of William H. Popham Co. were destroyed by fire last evening. The two establishments were both in the same building, a brick structure on the south-east corner of Thirteenth-avenue and Fourteenth-street.

Mrs. Dalmayne (of Abergowrie) was a very clever, handsome, and charming woman. She was possessed of a fair-sized house in Queen Anne's Gate; "one of those dear, comfortable old roof-trees," she would say, "that are so entirely livable in;" and so she seemed to find it, for she was there all the year round, except in August and September, when her address was "Abergowrie, N.B."

John Kay, a horse-trainer, whose name is known from Maine to Texas, and through the West to California, died yesterday, on his fiftyeighth birthday, at Sheepshead Bay, from disease of the kidneys. He was born in Fayette County, Ky., and passed his early days on a farm, where he first acquired his knowledge of horses.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The House Committee on Appropriations to-day completed consideration of the Pension Appropriation bill. The measure appropriates $20,684,400, and provides that any balance of the appropriation for the current fiscal year that may remain unexpended June 30, 1884, shall be reappropriated.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22.--At a meeting of the striking weavers of Dobson's Carpet Mills this morning, one of the speakers asked: "Does Mr. Dobson give us the same protection that we give him supporting the tariff?" Every one of the strikers present, of whom 15 were women, answered in a chorus: "No."

Michael Reilly, of Long Island City, and Joseph Lynch, of Greenpoint, were each arrested yesterday. Reilly and his wife kept a grocery and groggery in Sherman-street. Their married life has not been happy, and of late the quarrels between them have been violent.

NEW-HAVEN, March 22.--The New-Haven Organ Company failed to-day. Judge Luzon B. Morris will close up the estate. One hundred hands are thrown out of work. The concern is 15 years old, and at one time made more reed instruments than any other in this country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 22.--Sixteen of the new men who recently took the places of the striking compositors on the Courier left their cases to-day at noon. Mr. McCune, the proprietor, was out of town. Other compositors have been telegraphed for, and no great inconvenience is anticipated, as a fair number remained.

Lizzie Sheehan, a spinster, 25 years old, who lives with Mrs. Mary O'Neill at No. 318 Pearl-street, took the kerosene can from its accustomed place early last evening, and, descending to the courtyard in the rear of the house, poured its contents over her head and shoulders.
ALBANY, March 23.--The principle has always been considered sound that the fewer the laws passed by a Legislature the better the welfare of the whole State is guarded.

Welcome news to those sensitive gentlemen who are always fearing that they are being taken for waiters what times they don the garb of ceremony. The guild of Paris luisants have revolted against the black claw-hammer coat, and the fashion for evening dress for this season is a blue coat with gilt buttons and pearl-gray extensions, the whole costume being something akin to that in which the young Werther ended his sorrows.

Hereafter trains on the Sixth-avenue elevated railway will only run to Fifty-eighthstreet during commission hours. At other times all trains will run through to Harlem, and ashuttle car will take passengers from Forty-secondstreet, not stopping at Fiftieth, to Fifty-eighth. The car will run down to Forty-second-street, because there is no "cross-over" at Fiftieth. The change was made yesterday.

BOSTON, March 23.--The funeral services over the body of George Fuller, the artist, were held at 4 o'clock this afternoon at his late residence in Brookline. The services were conducted by the Rev. Mr. Brown, of the Unitarian church.

The Milan courts have had an interesting copyright case before them. Manzoni's heirs brought an action against Signor Carrara for publishing Manzoni's letters. The two questions to decide were the right of authorship in letters, and whether the right belonged to the writer or receiver.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 23.--The funeral of Gen. Godfrey Weitzel, at Spring Grove, today, was largely attended. The military were present, but did not are a salute over the grave.

The second of the series of composers' nights at the Casino last evening was devoted to the presentation of some of the lighter compositions of Charles Gounod. PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 23.--George W. Danielson, editor of the Journal, while driving with his family this afternoon, received a paralytic shock, which effected his right arm and leg, but did not render him unconscious. His condition this evening is comfortable.

We wish and predict for ex-Gov. Blackburn's private hospital for the treatment of lunatics and inebriates the fullest success. There is no such institution in Kentucky or any of the old slave States, and one is needed.

READING, Penn., March 23.--A body of plasterers held a meeting last evening, and determined to demand $2.50 per day after April 1. All the plasterers in the city will be given notice to make a stand for an advance at that time.

BRADFORD, Penn., March 23.--A white man named John McGerald got into a row in a low quarter of the city with a colored woman named "Lib" Washington. The latter struck McGerald with a poker fracturing his skull. It is thought that he will die.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 23.--Dwight Place Congregational Church, with one of the wealthiest and most fashionable congregations in this city, is in a somewhat perturbed state. The Rev. Thomas Rutherford Bacon, son of the famous Leonard Bacon, who has been Pastor of the Dwight-Place Church for three years, astonished his hearers by suddenly resigning.

A number of butchers in this city, already united in a protective association, have recently formed a central union, and have decided to oppose the introduction of dressed beef from the West.

SING SING, N.Y., March 23.--The Democrats of the town of Ossining made their nominations last night for town officers and selected the following: For Supervisor--John Hoag; Town Clerk--David H. Benedict; Collector--Richard Terhune; Justice of the Peace--John Gibney; Assessor--William Auser.

The first game of base-ball between professional clubs in this city this season will be played on the Polo Grounds on Saturday next. On Wednesday night a young man registered at Brown's Hotel from Chicago. Another young man registered from Kansas City. They were strangers to each other, apparently, and to the city, in fact. The hotel was crowded, and they were asked to room together. They agreed, but before going to bed one of them asked Mr. Brown when the banks opened next morning.

CHICAGO, March 23.--At a mass-meeting of painters to-day it was resolved that on April 1 a demand should be made for $3 a day or 30 cents an hour, instead of 15 to 20 cents an hour, the prevailing rates.

Jacob Miller, a Night watchman, of No. 7,170 Second-avenue, died yesterday at the Presbyterian Hospital from internal hemorrhage, the result of falling from a ladder during a fire at midnight on Saturday. Miller was employed to watch the buildings at Sixty-second-street and First-avenue.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 23.--A report has gained credence all through the State that W. Bogan Cash, the outlaw, for whose apprehension the Governor has offered a large reward, is roaming about the country disguised as a negro.

Church, M.A. Boston: Ginn, Heath Co. 1884.--The stories of the Argo, of Thebes, of Troy, of Ulysses and his wanderings, and of AEneas and his seafaring are told by the Rev. Mr. Church in severely simple English, which is well enough in its way despite a touch of affectation.

A lively discussion was heard last night in one of the Bowery saloons on the subject of cheap hacks for New-York. Two philosophers, whose love of logic was only excelled by their enthusiasm for lager beer, had been indulging in the wildest bursts of rhetoric, much to the amusement of all present and to the satisfaction of the saloon-keeper.

Julius Lang, a Hungarian tailor, 47 years of age, committed suicide yesterday by taking carbolic acid at his house, No. 238 East Thirdstreet. He had been married 10 years, and leaves a wife and two children. Of late he had been dissipated.
Cornelius Vreeland, who was struck on the head with a billiard cue on Saturday night in a Paterson saloon by Henry Henkel, is lying in a precarious condition at the Ladies' Hospital in that city.

The W. and J. Sloane Glee Club will give a concert in aid of the Porters' relief fund at Chickering Hall to-morrow evening. The soloists will be Mlle. Ulie de Lussan, soprano; Edward Gilbert, baritone, and F.W. Taft, organist.

Bishop John B. Salpointe, of Dorila, and Vicar-Apostolic of Arizona, Province of Santa Fe, said mass at 8 o'clock yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Fifth-avenue. The Bishop arrived from Europe last Friday, and was in Rome during the convocations of the American Archbishops. He is the guest of the Cardinal.

MARCO, Ind., March 23.--At Pleasant Valley, Ind., yesterday, Ves Meeks entered the house of a man named Goodman and shot him in the back, the ball passing through the body and lodging under the skin in front. Goodman threw Meeks down, wrested the pistol from him, and shot him twice in the forehead and once in the chest, killing him. Goodman will probably recover. Meeks alleged that his sister had been dishonored by Goodman.

One of the largest and strongest safety vaults ever constructed in this city has been put in the basement of the new Exchange building, at Whitehall and Stone streets, for the NewYory Produce Exchange Safe Deposit and Storage Company.

When the Rev. Dr. Newman said in his opening prayer, yesterday morning, "May greater victories, Oh Lord, be ours," he did not allude to the outcome of the existing church trouble, but an ominous cloud shadowed the faces of the listening leaders of the opposition.

CLINTON, March 23.--The card which appeared in THE TIMES of March 16, signed by Prof. Hopkins, purporting to be an official statement on the part of the Faculty of Hamilton College of the terms on which the Senior Class returned to duty, excited much surprise here among the students and Faculty.

BERLIN, March 24.--Prince Bismarck gave a dinner to the diplomatic corps on Saturday in honor of Emperor William's birthday. Mr. Sargent, the United States Minister, was present. Lord Ampthill, the British Ambassador, proposed the health of Emperor William.

At any rate, it requires the longest time to be read satisfactorily through, and if there be any better test than that will some one please name it? The promised City Hall article makes its appearance, and is very prompt in doing so.

READING, Penn., March 23.--A mechanic named George Reider, engaged in some work on tracks outside of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company's shops yesterday afternoon, seeing a pusher engine coming toward him, endeavored to jump across the tracks in front of the engine. His foot caught in a frog and before he could extract it the engine passed over him at the hip, leaving a mere shred of flesh to hold it to his body.

The steam whaler Thetis, which will be used as the flag-ship of the Greely relief expedition, arrived yesterday from Dundee, and was moored at one of the piers in the navy-yard. The Thetis was purchased by the Government at a cost of about $140,000. She is admirably suited for an arctic expedition.

The spirit of Louise Michel brooded over the Germania Assembly Rooms last night. Over a thousand people who had met to celebrate the thirteenth anniversary of the Paris Commune applauded tumultuously at each frequent mention of her name, and some groaned audibly when Mr. Victor Drury alluded to the unavoidable absence ...

Four complaints for larceny and receiving stolen goods were made before Justice White, at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, against James J. Rooney, alias "Old Jack;" his son John, and his driver, Andrew McNamara, who were arrested on Friday for trading in stolen ...

CLEVELAND, March 23.--George A. Baker, a well-known young business man of Cleveland, agent of the Union Distilling Company, of Cincinnati, who also operated as a whisky broker, has left for parts unknown after appropriating $3,000 belonging to the Union Distilling Company and borrowing an equal amount from friends in this city. A convivial disposition and moving in society that required a style beyond his income are said to have been the causes of his downfall.

ALBANY, March 23.--A dispatch from New-Baltimore this afternoon states that the ice is moving out at that point. This unquestionably removes the last obstruction to the navigation of the Hudson River of its entire length.
Mr. D'Alton McCarthy, member of Parliament, and Col. William Moore were among the passengers who arrived from Liverpool yesterday on the White Star steam-ship Celtic.
CONSTANTINOPLE, March 23.--It is understood that the Grand Vizier has complained to the United States Government of Minister Wallace's recent conduct.
Wheat continues in need of friends. The exports from this country during the eight months ending Feb. 29 were only 49,000,000 bushels, against 88,000,000 for the like period of the previous year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 23.--The money stolen yesterday from a clerk of the Commercial Bank was found this afternoon in an out house of a house of bad character in this city. A clergyman on the train overheard a conversation between the persons arrested. One said to the other:

CHICAGO, March 23.--A special to the Daily News from Petersburg, Ill., says: "Last night Charles Houiden, a farmer living some miles south of here, quarreled with his wife, knocked her down with an axe, cut her throat ...

CHICAGO, March 23.--J.H. Sanders, proprietor of the Breeders' Gazette and a member of the United States Treasury Commission, will reply to the argument of Emory A. Storrs against the Pleuro-pneumonia bill, now pending in the Senate.
Henry Irving is at the Brevoort House. Col. D.C. Houston, United States Army, is at the Everett House.

DENVER, Col., March 23.--Wilson Edmundson, for several years a conductor on the Central Pacific Railroad, committed suicide here at midnight Friday night by taking morphine. Ill-health is said to have been the cause of the act. Edmundson's relatives live at Galesburg, Ill.

The funeral services of Daniel K. Cosgrove, who died on Friday last, took place yesterday afternoon from his late residence, at No. 274 Pearl-street, about 1:30 o'clock. Mr. Cosgrove was born in Brooklyn.

William Hulse, a dealer in fruit and vegetables, left his home in Meeker-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District, Saturday morning, with a wagon-load of provisions. Hulse was accompanied br Edward Knapp, a son of a widow living ...

"Most people think," said the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher yesterday morning, "that the Sermon on the Mount is very simple. As a matter of fact it is as far from simplicity as anything can be. A literal absolute following out of the sermon would destroy law and order and human nature itself.

CHICAGO, March 13.--The public was invited to witness a four-round glove contest at a resort known as the Buckingham, in Fourthavenue, last night, between two local boxers named Tom Anderson and James H. Dalton, and ...

BUFFALO, March 23.--The Humane Society of this city is collecting a large fund by the prosecution of persons who attended a cockfight near this city a short time ago. The new Penal Code gives the informer all the proceeds from fines imposed on this class of offenders ...

The British steam-ship Minerva, Capt. Murton, which arrived at this port yesterday, sailed from Newcastle on Feb. 1. After passing the English Channel she was caught in a hurricane in which she sustained serious injuries. The enormous waves which struck the vessel ...

The Rev. Henry Kimball did not seem in the least disturbed as he stood on the City Hall steps and preached to the crowd yesterday by the knowledge that his former landlady, Mrs. Hattie A. Palmer, of Brooklyn, had sued him for a board bill of $148, and that the fact had been published in all the newspapers. He preached as earnestly as ever and sang with as much power.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 23.--The peculiar will of James Moraghan, of Dunmore, who died about three weeks ago, is attracting a good deal of attention here and promises to develop a lively lawsuit. Moraghan's property, in the shape of real estate, cash, bank stock, and judgments, amounted to $7,000.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the Committee on Labor Bills submitted a bill for an eight-hour law, which was approved and will be introduced into the State Senate in a few days. It provides that any employer who shall require the services of any working man for a longer term than eight hours ...

The prosecution of persons who sell liquor illegally in Westchester County is being steadily pressed by the Law and Order Society. Last November verdicts were obtained at South Salem against G.F. Sarles for $200, and G.W. Briggs for $150, for illegal liquor-selling, and in other suits atainst G.W. Briggs, G.M. Brundage, ...

A fire broke out in the hat store of Earnest Meyer, No. 222 Bowery, soon after 1 o'clock this morning. His aged mother, wife, and six children were asleep on the second floor immediately over the fire.

A North Carolina husband has brought a suit for divorce against his wife, claiming that she has been guilty of cruel and inhuman conduct toward him. He specially sets forth in his complaint that on one occasion she seized an axe and compelled him to climb a tree.

BUFFALO, March 23.--James Sloan, a carpenter, of this city, 55 years old, died early this morning from injuries received by being run over by a street car last evening. He was attempting to board the car at the front end, when he was thrown under it. A wheel passed over his leg just above the ankle, almost completely severing it.

WHEELING, West Va., March 23.--A special to the Intelligencer, from Gallipolis, says: "United States Marshal Atkinson came down from Point Pleasant this afternoon and reports that he and four deputies arrested, before daylight this morning, 20 employer of the Keystone Bridge Company, among them ...

CINCINNATI, March 23.--A special to the Volksfreund, from Columbus, says: "Mrs. Helen Hankinson, an inmate of the Central Insane Asylum, squeezed herself through the bars of her window last night and fell a distance of 70 feet. She was instantly killed."

What the members of the Joe Brady Emergency Club lacked in numbers at their meeting at Hessler's, on Pearl-street, above Chatham-street, yesterday afternoon, they made up in enthusiasm of a peculiarly cyclonic nature. Streams of British blood, blocks of exploding British buildings, and acres of burning British ...

There was little change in the condition of Augustus Schell yesterday. His vital forces still remain strong, although there is a gradual weakening of them. His physician said last evening that his patient would certainly live through ...

ST. LOUIS, March 23.--This Sunday night there was a sad scene at the Morgue. The body of Mary Weilde, a bright German girl of 17, lay there. A few weeks ago she lived happily at home with her parents, who own a large grocery store at No. 819 South Second-street.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--The new Coast survey steamer Carlisle P. Patterson, which was launched in February at New-York, will go in commission on April 1. She will be commanded by Lieut. Richardson Clover, of the navy, and will start for her station, ...

LONDON, March 23.--Suakin is unhealthy. It is proposed to leave 400 British soldiers at Suakin, to be relieved every fortnight, and to station the remainder of the troops at healthier points in the interior.
GALVESTON, Texas, March 23.--A dispatch to the News from Dallas says it is rumored there that a serious accident occurred to-day on the Texas Pacific Railway near Big Springs.

Dedicatory services were held yesterday at the new Park-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church in the morning, afternoon, and evening. A large and fashionable congregation filled the building on each occasion. The church is handsome in every respect. The building is at the corner of Fourth-avenue and Eighty-sixth-street, ...

The property-owners along the line of Broadway are making strenuous efforts to counteract the work of the lobby at Albany and prevent the passage of the Arcade Railroad bill, which threatens,if it becomes a law, to do so much damage to the leading thoroughfare of this city.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 23.--The body of an unknown man was found at the Second-street railroad crossing last night horribly mangled. The man is supposed to have been foully dealt with and then laid on the track.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 23.--The selection of a minister by the Mennonites, who worship at Weaverland, East Earl Township, this county, a few days ago, was an occasion that excited much interest in the neighborhood, and as early as daybreak the roads leading to the ...

Patrolman Thoden, of the Fourteenth Precinct, while passing last night the six-story double building at Nos. 602 and 604 Broadway, noticed a glare of light reflected on the ceiling of one of the upper floors, occupied by Lewison ...

WASHINGTON, March 23.--In the House of Representatives to-morrow is set apart for District of Columbia business. The District Committee, however, will have nothing of general interest to bring forward. Should the minor matters that it will present be disposed of early in the day, the discussion of the Bonded Whisky bill will be continued. The friends of this measure expect to reach a vote Tuesday.

Three young highwaymen, John Gorrevan, William Dunn, and Charles Miller, ll years old each, were before Justice White, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with having robbed Sherwood McCollom, the 11year-old son of a dentist living at No.52 Bedfordstreet.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23.--A special to the Chronicle from Tacoma, Washington Territory, says: "A fire is raging in the Newcastle coal mine, the most valuable of those belonging to the Oregon Improvement Company. The mine has been on fire 18 months. The fact that the fire had obtained the mastery over the management had been concealed. It is believed that it will now be necessary to shut down and flood the mine."

LIMA, March 23, via Glaveston.--The resignation of Senor Larrbure y Unanue has been accepted. He will be temporarily replaced by Senor Zaldivar. Don Belisario Salinas, Bolivian Minister to Chili, has been transferred to Peru. It is rumored that ex-President Pierola will start for Europe on March 27.

In the basement of a substantial fourstory brick building in Murray-street a TIMES reporter was shown the other day a great heap of what seemed to be broken pieces of putty. Barrels and boxes around the room were filled with the substance. "That," said the proprietor of the establishment, "is chicle.

Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning fire broke out in Alexander Spalding's brush factory, at Nos. 38 and 40 Beacon-avenue, Jersey City Heights. By the time the alarm had been sounded the buildings were wrapped in flames. Firemen responded promptly, but their apparatuses were mired on the way, and a ...

BATON ROUGE, La., March 23.--Since daylight this morning it has rained continuously. The river is now at the high-water mark of 1882. The Mulatto Point crevasse has been abandoned and no further effort will be made to close the opening. The force at that point will be distributed among ...

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Senator Vance, in a minority report from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, submitted to-day, expresses the opinion that Germany has a right to exclude American hog products, on the ground that they are unwholesome, if she deems it proper, and that this Government is not justified in impeaching her motives.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Gen. David S. Stanley will be appointed Brigadier-General, vice Brig.Gen. Mackenzie. The following named officers of the Corps of Engineers have been ordered to report for examination for promotion when directed to do so by the senior member of the Board of Officers constituted by ...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 24.--William Berner, who has been on trial for the murder of William H. Kirk, was this morning found guilty of manslaughter. The verdict was declared privately by the Judge who tried the case to be an outrage, and the jury, after leaving the courtroom, ...

PETROLIA, Penn., March 24.--The Bowser and Barnhart factions, who are contesting an oil lease, had a terrible melee Saturday night, near Iron City, in which Bowser and an innocent party named Andre were probably fatally cut. Three of the Barnhart faction attacked Bowser, one of them using a razor, and kicked and slashed him horribly.

Early Sunday morning Emil Meyer, a silk weaver, attempted to stab John Egtar, who keeps a boarding-house at No. 448 West Fortyfirst-street, but a note-book and a wallet in the breast pocket of Egtar's cardigan jacket saved his life by stopping the blade.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--A pretty woman of small figure approached Officer Stark at Eighth and Chestnut streets to-night and said: "I am very tired; take me to some place where I can sit down." She was dressed in black and spoke English with a Spanish accent.

The following letter has been sent to the President by Mr. John A. Walsh, the gentleman about whose appearance as a witness against the Hon. William Pitt Kellogg the Department of Justice has at various times manifested some anxiety:
BERLIN, March 24.--The German papers reproach Queen Victoria with parsimony because of her intention to attend the marriage of her granddaughter, the Princess of Hesse, privately.

MILLERSBURG, Penn., March 24.--Henry Emholtz, aged 16, was arrested at Liverpool, this county, on a charge of highway robbery preferred by Henry Hornholder, a peddler, who stated that last night as he was driving from Schuylkill County he was halted about 12 miles ...
After their regular monthly dinner at Clark's last night, the members of the Congregational Club discussed the "Pulpit as Seen from the Pews." Roswell Smith made the opening address.

A writer in the North American Review, Dr. FELIX L. OSWALD, traces the effect upon the climate and physical condition of many lands produced by the destruction of forests. Asia minor, he says, has become "the epitome of a dying continent." In Spain the agricultural value of the lowlands, ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 24.--The statement published to-day that Gen. Sherman was strongly inclined toward the Democratic Party, and that he might decline a Presidential nomination from the Republicans and accept the ...

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 24.--Charles Butler, the wife-murderer who escaped from the Columbia City (Ind.) Jail a week ago, was arrested yesterday near Woodburn, 15 miles east of here on the Wabash Railway. On Friday Butler went to Antwerp, Ohio, and drank and played cards in a saloon.

Mr. Edwin Booth began a series of 12 performances, in the Fourteenth-Street Theatre, last evening, presenting his impersonation of Hamlet to an audience which completely filled the house and acknowledged the familiar points ...

LAWRENCE, Mass., March 24.--In the Superior Court this afternoon, before Judge Bacon, the first of the Augustinian society suits was called--that of Ellen Lahey against the Augustinian Society and the Archbishop of the Diocese of Boston to recover $1,500 for money loaned by plaintiff to defendants in divers sums and at sundry times.
PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--The National Reform Convention, which began its sessions here to-day, organized by the election of John Alexander as President and a long list of VicePresidents.

The Republicans of Hoboken held their City Convention last night and nominated exMayor E.V.S. Besson for Mayor and John R. Wiggins for Assessor. The Democrats renominated Mayor Timken and City Treasurer Bente. Richard Bowes was named for Tax Collector and James Dollard for Assessor.
BALTIMORE, March 24.--The Elevated Railroad bill passed the State Senate to-night with only two votes against it.
HAVANA, March 24.--A branch railroad from Marianao to the sea coast was opened yesterday.

Yesterday afternoon intense excitement was caused at Junction-road, Upper Holloway, when it became known that two elephants had got down a cellar under the following circumstances: It appears that Messrs. Sanger have arranged to give a circus performance at Gospel Oak, and among other animals, , they consigned by the Midland Railway Company four ...

At 3:07 o'clock Saturday morning a curious shock of earthquake occurred in San Francisco. The peculiarity of it was that, although it was slight, it was preceded by a remarkably loud, rumbling noise, louder than has been heard here for some years. The shock itself was merely a quick move from east to west.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 24.--As the result of the efforts of Mr. Aaron Lloyd, of the NewYork Free Trade Club, who has been in Buffalo a week, a well-attended meeting in the interest of free trade was held in this city this evening.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 24.--Frederick Miller, a New-York thief, was arrested yesterday by Detective Scanlan for robbing Summer residences in the highlands, and was held to await the action of the Grand Jury. A satin opera cloak and cape and other goods were found is his possession.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 24.--Epizootic prevails here to a remarkable extent among horses, and is reported as being worse than ever before.

Sir Joseph Fayrer, President of the Medical Society, and the first authority in the world about snake poison, has come forward in a new capacity, with an infallible receipt for soothing fretful children to sleep.

An interesting case was before ViceChancellor Van Fleet, at Newark, yesterday. About 10 years ago, when Northern Pacific bonds were not very valuable, Charles M. Hassler, a New-York broker, proposed to a number of bondholders that they should turn their bonds over to him.
BOSTON, March 24.--D. Heald Son, dealers in provisions, No. 25 North Market-street, have suspended. Their assets consist largely of claims in Hayti for goods lately shipped thither.

The parochial school kept by the Sisters attached to St. James's Church, in James-street, was dismissed at 11:45 o'clock yesterday morning. As the children swarmed over the adjacent sidewalks two wagons laden with beer kegs belonging to the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company rolled slowly up the hill.
Mr. and Mrs. James C. Townsend, who were brutally assaulted and robbed at their home in the village of Oyster Bay on the evening of the 8th of January last, have entirely recovered.

All the athletic and pugilistic talent of the city and surrounding country gathered in Clarendon Hall last evening, where they smoked the atmosphere blue, to witness the long-discussed wrestling-match between Capt. James C. Daly, known as the "champion Irish athlete," ...

NEW-HAVEN, March 24.--Ex-Gov. James E. English has come out plumply with the avowal that the Democratic Party has placed itself in a position where it must declare in favor of the principles of the Morrison Tariff bill and upon the doctrines of that bill depend for its issue in the coming Presidential campaign.

A branch of the Madison-Square Theatre Company presented "The Rajah" last evening at the Third-Avenue Theatre, with Mr. H.M. Pitt as Harold Wyncot and Miss Rillie Deaves as the Rajah's high-spirited ward. Mr. E.M. Holland made an amusing Jekyll and Mr. Dominick Murray gave a vigorous interpretation of the character of Cragin.

George F. Slosson proposes to challenge Jacob Schaefer for a contest for the balk-line championship, which the latter won at the tournament played in Chicago last Spring. Slosson's double challenge to Sexton and Schaefer does not meet with their favor.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 24.--The Committee on Privileges and Elections met this morning. The draft of the report submitted on Saturday recommending to the House that the bribery cases be referred to a commission composed of Judges was adopted, and the committee adjourned.

A curious controversy was settled in the French Senate yesterday, when it was decided that there should henceforth be two keys to every church belfry in the country, one to be held by the Mayor and the other by the priest.

SUAKIN, March 25.--Osman Digna has assumed the dress of a dervish. His followers, estimated at from 1,000 to 5,000, are exhorting him to fight a third time with promises of success. It is expected that a battle will be fought to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--A few days ago President Judge Hare, of Common Pleas No. 2, reported to the police that his watch, worth $200, had been stolen, as he thought at the theatre or on a street car going home from the theatre. Detective Weyl undertook to recover the time-piece.

DES MOINES, March 24.--Odell Reed, publisher of the newspaper at Eagle Grove, Wright County, died here to-day from the effects of low fever and ulceration of the throat. He was about 30 years of age. Mr. Reed last Spring married Nellie Dickey, daughter of a prominent citizen. Her death is also expected, the result of puerperal fever.

A well-dressed boy occupied a corner seat in a Fourth-avenue street car a few nights ago. Beside him sat a wide-awake Skye terrier. The car contained other passengers and was moving slowly up Centre-street.

The Guion steam-ship Oregon arrived from Liverpool yesterday, after a quick passage, considering the stormy weather which she experienced. Her actual time from Queenstown to Sandy Hook was 7 days 15 hours and 12 minutes.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 24.--Information has reached here that yellow fever has broken out on the United States steamer Iroquois, now on her way to Alaska.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 24.--An accident occurred at the Hillman Vein Coal Company's breaker this morning. John Garry, a youth of 9 years, was employed as a breaker boy in the breaker, and while in the act of pushing some pieces of coal into the iron rollers with his foot the heel of his boot was caught by the revolving machinery, and in an instant he was drawn in and crushed to death.

Mr. Abram Hewitt has lost nearly all hope of Democratic success at the Presidential election, and lugubriously says that the only chance is to "nominate the old ticket and bring Tilden and Hendricks to the White House on stretchers."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 24.--The great wrestling-match between Col. J.H. McLaughlin, of Detroit, and Duncan C. Ross, of this city, for a two-thousand-dollar purse and door receipts, took place at the Euclid-Avenue Opera-house to-night and was witnessed by a crowded house. At 8:30 o'clock the men appeared on the stage and were introduced by Mr. Edward Gillman, of ...

POINT PLEASANT, West Va., March 24.-- The Western Union linemen who were engaged yesterday in putting wire on the Keystone Bridge Company's bridge were arrested this morning on warrants charging them with trespass, but were released on bail.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 24.--At about daybreak this morning a cyclone passed over this county, three miles north-west of this place, doing considerable damage to farm property. Eyewitnesses describe the storm as approaching with ...

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 24.--The exporting merchants here are greatly excited over the news that the Parliament of Newfoundland has passed a law imposing a duty of 100 per cent. on all packages containing goods imported into the colony. This is said to be a retaliatory measure against Canada for passing the law for the inspection of Newfoundland herrings.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Democrats of the Carlisle-Morrison tariff reform school are talking with apparently increased confidence of the action to be taken at the Democratic caucus to-morrow evening. To the outside observer, however, the situation seems to be unchanged. Advocates of each of the different schemes ...
CHICAGO, March 24.--Several Republican County Conventions were held in Illinois today. In Sangamon County Milton Hay and Bluford Wilson were among the delegates chosen to the State Convention.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 24.--The forenoon session of the House was spent in taking final action upon bills. The report of the conference committee on the quarantine bills was concurred in. The bill accepting the provisions of any Federal legislation on the subject of contagious ...

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The House Committee on Banking and Currency will decide to-morrow whether or not an investigation shall be made of the charges against Government officials made by the stockholders of the Pacific National Bank.

The large audience which greeted Mr. John McCullough at the Star Theatre last evening was not only appreciative, but discriminating as well, and restrained itself, furthermore, in giving way to applause until the proper pauses came. Mr. McCullough's personation of the title role in John Howard Payne's tragedy of "Brutus," which was the play presented, ...

SCRANTON, Penn., March 24.--During the past few months a gang of burglars has been robbing the country stores and Post Offices of North-eastern Pennsylvania, and breaking into the houses of the farmers of Wayne, Wyoming, and Susquehanna Counties, causing a regular rein of terror among the country districts north ...

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--Relative to the appointment of Lieut. Gorringe of the Receiver of the American Ship-building Company, the Lieutenant himself says that so far as he can see the assets of the company are abundant to ...

RALEIGH, N.C., March 24.--A son of Capt. James Graham, at Graham, N.C., while hunting, was killed by the accidental discharge of his gun. The deceased man was a grandson of the Hon. William A. Graham, formerly Secretary of the Navy.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 24.--The Republican State Convention will meet April 9. A majority of the delegates to that body has already been chosen in about equal proportions of whites and blacks.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., March 24.--An accident occurred here to-day resulting in the killing of two men and in slight injuries to two others. On the brow of the Sharp Mountain, just outside of the town, is a small coal mine, known as Kirk's mine.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24.--The condition of George W. Danielson, editor of the Providence Journal, who was stricken with paralysis Sunday afternoon, is unchanged. He has spoken but once to-day--a single sentence addressed to his wife. He has taken nourishment all day and seems to understand what is said to him. The announcement of his sudden illness caused almost as much of a sensation and feeling of deep regret as did that of Senator Anthony.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in the municipal bond case of the County of Dixon, Nebraska, plaintiff in error, against Marshall Field. This was a suit upon the past-due coupons of certain bonds issued by the County of Dixon to the Covington, Columbus and Black Hills Railroad Company.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24.--Mr. Campbell's project for a park in the Seventh Ward came up on its third reading this evening and was opposed by Mr. Robb, who said the locality was the most unfit and the least appropriate place for a public park that he ever saw, and he had been to look at it in company with Mr. Campbell.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 24.--The coal trade tribunal appointed to fix the mining rate in the railroad mines for the next six months met again to-day. A consideration of the question was resumed and up to noon it looked as if the board would adjourn without accomplishing anything.

Senator Blair's hopes for the passage of his bill giving national aid to common schools have been strengthened to-day by the course of the debate in the Senate. Last week the opponents of the measure had it all their own way, but to-day strong speeches in its favor were made by ...

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Signal Corps station at Block Island, R.I., reports that the brig Augusta, Capt. Buck, from New-York, bound to Newfoundland, came ashore in a dense fog on the south-west part of the island at 6:30 A.M. She has a general cargo. The crew were saved.

With the reform of the municipal government and the relief of property from burdensome taxation in view, about 80 citizens of Jersey City met in Booreum Hall last evening to put in nomination candidates for the municipal offices to be filled at the charter election on April 8.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 24.--The capture of the two sharpers who robbed Book-keeper Crock, of the Commercial Bank, of $2,500 on Saturday, was followed by a vigorous search for the lost money on a clue furnished by Conductor Jenkins, of the Port Royal Railway, who first ...

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--In the taking of testimony in the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's injunction suit to restrain the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey from annulling the contract with the former corporation ...

Mrs. Jennie Turner, a woman about 40 years of age, and her daughter May, 8 years old, are guests of Matron Webb, at Police Headquarters. The woman is entirely destitute of means. She resided in Buffalo, and her husband was employed in a sofa manufactory in that city. He left there in December, ostensibly to seek a better position.

QUAKERTOWN, March 24.--William Hager, age 51 years, a retired hardware merchant, living on his farm in Rock Hill Township, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself. He leaves a wife and sight children in good circumstances.

Augustus Schell spent a comparatively easy day yesterday, and, although he did not rally, his condition was not worse, and in the evening Dr. Guernsey expressed the opinion that he would live through another day.

William A. Marvin, 60 years old, of Port Jervis, was one of the passengers on an Erie Railway train, which reached the Jersey City tunnel at 10 o'clock Sunday morning. Thinking the train had reached the station at the ferry, Mr. Marvin stepped from the car.

WASHINGTON, Penn., March 24.--Representatives of the Standard Oil Company are prospecting in this county for the purpose of sinking a test well. They will probably begin operations on the Hon. Jonathan Allison's farm, near this town.

A man of middle age, in a, slouch hat and pilot-cloth Inverness overcoat, stood on the steps of the Park National Bank all day yesterday and thrust 10,000 pages of the Bible into the hands of the passing throng. He showered them alike upon merchant, mechanic, mendicant, and messenger boy. Busy men stopped, frowned, and cast the leaves unheeded upon the sidewalk; ...

ROME, Ga., March 24.--The corner-stone of a new Catholic church was laid here a few weeks ago, and many valuable articles and rare relics were deposited therein. Last night the corner-stone was robbed by unknown persons.

Surrogate Coffin, of Westchester County, yesterday rendered his decision in the matter of the dispute over the accounting of the Executors of the estate of the late David Jones, of New-Rochelle, who left property worth about $8,000,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 24.--Senator Edmunds has been in Charleston for several days, coming on to meet Mrs. Edmunds, who recently arrived here on the Yantic, from Bermuda. He has been seeing the sights, and to-day went down the harbor to inspect the jetties.
One of the chief millionaires of Glasgow died recently in the person of James White, who, it is said, was always ready to give up his substance for worthy causes.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24.--The Democratic State Central Committee has filled the vacancies left in the State ticket by the resignations of Amasa Sprague and C.C. Gorman by the nomination of Elisha Mathewson, of Burrillville, for Lieutenant-Governor, and Francis L.O. Reilly, of Woonsocket, for Attorney-General.
LONDON, March 24.--Mr. David Blair, a wealthy Scotchman, has joined the Benedictine monks at Inverness and made over to them an annual income of 6,000.

A long line of carriages was drawn up nearly all day yesterday along Fifth-avenue, near No. 307, where the first floral display of the season was made by C.F. Klunder. It was said to be the finest private display ever made in the city. The room was beautifully decorated. Christopher Brennan, 9 years old, upset a kerosene lamp last night at No. 544 West Thirty-third-street. His father, James, and his mother, Mary, were fatally burned in endeavoring to put out the fire which it caused. The boy was not hurt.

Steps are being taken by some of the members of the Produce Exchange to form a down-town social club. It is proposed to limit the membership to 100.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 24.--A family of French Canadians, consisting of seven persons, who dined on pork yesterday, became seriously ill an hour afterward and vomited blood. Six of them have partially recovered, but the seventh is in a critical condition.

MILES CITY, Montana, March 24.--A Deputy Sheriff arrived here to-day from Rosebud with 13 Cheyenne Indians supposed to have been implicated in tho burning of Anderson's house.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 24.--Capt. F. W. Dawson, the South Carolina member of the National Democratic Committee, in conversation with a TIMES correspondent to-day, gave his views on the tariff question in connection with the tariff bill and the Democratic caucus.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24.--Gov. Abbett has frequently piqued Senatorial curiosity since the opening of the session by sending in envelopes containing nominations. When they were opened in executive session they were found to be only of Notaries Public and Commissioners of Deeds.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24.--John F. Smyth has been burrowing deeply ever since his three henchmen, Draper, Luby, and Bentley, tipped him over last August, and to-day he reappeared upon the surface, twisted the necks of the trio, and took a fresh political start.
BOSTON, March 24.--The House to-day defeated the bill providing that wife-beaters shall be publicly whipped.

It is very hard to tell when a political folly is really dead in the United States. It will apparently be condemned by all reasonable men and abandoned by all politicians with a range of vision beyond their own door-yard, when suddenly it will spring again into prominence.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 24.--An officer this morning arrested Charles Abbott, of Providence, on a charge of stealing a watch from an Amherst farmer. The prisoner turned out to be a deserter from the regular army, and was turned over to the United States authorities. He will be returned to his regiment in the West.

The annual elections for town officers in the 22 towns of Westchester County take place to-day. The following additional nominations have been made: In White Plains the Democrats and Republicans have united on the name of Lewis C. Platt for Supervisor and on H.A. Maynard ...

Mary Louise Corbett was arrested yesterday at the instance of Charles E. McBride, a manufacturer, of No. 2 Franklin-square. Mr. McBride said that the woman was ejected from her apartments, opposite his place of business, July 5, 1883.
It has been shown again and again that many of the most extravagant pension bills which have been introduced and supported in Congress were born in the offices of Washington claim agents.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 24.--Louis C. Wetter, convicted last week in the United States District Court of perjury in having sworn falsely in the case of the Rumford Chemical Company against him, was to-day sentenced to six months' imprisonment at hard labor and to pay a fine of $100.

MILFORD, Penn., March 24.--Argument on the motion for a new trial in the case of John F. Greening, convicted of the murder of Ammi C. Cheever, has been postponed until April 16. Lewis Benjamin, upon whose testimony the prosecution depended to a great extent for establishing ...

Mr. Herbert Spencer having been asked to allow his name to be submitted to the Liberal Association at Leicester as a candidate for Mr. Peter Taylor's seat, has written declining the invitation on the ground of ill-health. Moreover, he does not feel that he should be doing right in abandoning his present work for a political career.

"A stout man--looks like Bill Hasson," was the description given a year ago of a person who wheedled or extorted money out of tradesmen in the upper districts under the pretense of being an Excise Inspector. Hasson is Inspector Dilks's aid in the Third and Fourth Inspection Districts.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 24.--The Lower Mississippi Valley is enshrouded in gloom. The water is higher than the highest water mark, and is still rising inch by inch. Twenty levees have given way. A more disastrous state of affairs the State has not known since the war.

A curious piece of embroidery, bearing evident signs of antiquity and framed in black wood, is to be seen at Mrs. L.D. Shears's studio, No. 16 East Twenty-third-street. Of course, the piece of work has a history. As the product of the modern needle it would be considered far from beautiful.

GLOUCESTER, March 24.--Grave fears are entertained for the safety of the schooner Magic, which sailed from this port for the Georges Banks four weeks ago to-day. She has a crew of 13 men.

William C.D. Rawson was acquitted yesterday, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, of a charge of manslaughter in causing the fatal accident in the Fourth-avenue tunnel on Sept. 22, 1882. Rawson was telegraph-operator and signal man for the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company at Ninety-sixthstreet and Fourth-avenue.

A trim little schooner from Boston made fast to the pier in Fulton Market slip before dawn yesterday morning. So soon as it was light enough to read the early rising fish-dealers saw tacked to the mast: "Eighty Thousand Mackerel For Sale." In less than an hour 30 commission-dealers had bid for the load.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 24.--Within the next 10 days municipal elections will be held in six towns in South Carolina. In only two or three cases, however, will there be any special question involved beyond the ever-present issue of keeping everything solid for the Democracy.
MONTREAL, March 24.--A further reduction in freights from Chicago to Montreal has been made by the Grand Trunk and Canadian Pacific Railways.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 24.--The steamer Chateaux Margaux, from Bordeaux Feb. 28 for New-York, with her rudder gone, has been towed to the mouth of the harbor by the Anchor Line steamer Caledonia, which left her in care of a tug and entered the port. The disabled steamer has not yet arrived up.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24.--The condition of Mr. George W. Danielson, editor of the Journal, who yesterday experienced a paralytic Stroke, is to-day without change.

Among the bills introduced in the House of Representatives to-day was one presented by Representative Lacy, of Michigan, which proposes to make it unlawful for the Secretary of the Treasury to issue Treasury notes of denominations less than five dollars.

Richard Crowley, of New-York, has been subpoenaed to appear before Mr. Springer's committee tomorrow.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 24.--The following was received at the Record office to-day: "Is it true that the Reading Company is issuing acceptances to its miners in your region?"

The Rev. W.R. Alger, of Boston, is at the St. James Hotel. Gen. E.C. Walthall, of Mississippi, is at the New-York Hotel.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 24.--Riley Horde was arrested here to-day at the instance of the Sheriff of Green County, Tenn., on the charge of murdering Mrs. Hunter on Feb. 14, in that county, by firing gun-shot through a window. Horde is very nervous, and evidently knows something about the murder. His brother, Alfred Horde, was arrested in Green County on the same charge and bound over to the Circuit Court last week.

M. PASTEUR is tireless in his search after the germs that produce diseases. Every few months he announces the discovery of a new germ, and simultaneously assures us that we can protect ourselves against the specific disease to which the germ gives rise by inoculating ourselves with it.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 24.--Representative Vanderpoel to-day received dispatches announcing the loss of his woolen factory at West Mitchell by ice and flood. The factory cost $70,000, and the wool and cloth on hand was worth about $20,000 more.

The outer end of the pier of the White Star Steam-ship Company, at the foot of West Tenth-street, has of late become very weak, and a diver found that the ship worm or toredo had been busily at work, and had thoroughly honeycombed the piles that supported 70 feet of the length of the pier.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--A boy in West Philadelphia who had made up his mind that a human being could fly as well as a bird, if it was gone about in the right way, and who thought he knew the way, put his theories into practice to-day.

BLAIRSVILLE, Ga., March 24.--Farmers of Gum Log District, in Union County, while performing road duty, were to-day witnesses of a murder. Among those present were Jefferson Anderson and James Cook, two young men not yet 20 years of age. For a year past they had been on bad terms, owing to some rivalry, ...

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 24.--While four men were crossing New River near Cripple Creek, Wythe County, on Saturday, their boat was swept against a tree by the swift current and overturned. William Lackey (colored) was drowned, and the others barely escaped. T.D. Sexton, paymaster for the contractors of the Cripple Creek Railroad, was one of the accupants of the boat, and lost $600 in the river.

The vote stood 50 to 45 for postponement, and it is alleged that four of the five absentees ...

Some excited meetings were held in the school districts of Passaic County, N.J., Monday. In one district in the upper end of West Milford Township the meeting broke up in a fight, and several arrests are expected. In the Midvale district of Pompton Township there was a sharp contest over the question of building a new school-house.

ATLANTA, March 25.--For four years there has been an estrangement between the white and colored wings of the Republican Party in Georgia growing out of the election of a negro-- W.A. Pledger--to the Chairmanship of the State Central Committee.

The Park Commissioners have decided to sink their aversion to the equestrian statue of Gen. Bolivar as a work of art, and, on the recommendation of John Taylor Johnston, President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Daniel Huntington, President of the Academy of Design, they have designated a place for its erection.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--The Press will print the following to-morrow: The contract for building the New-York, Norfolk and Charleston Railroad, and for the entire equipment, including rolling stock, has been let to the Carolina Construction Company.

ALBANY, March 25.--The General Surface Railroad bill was the special order in the Senate again this morning, but, as the third reading of bills takes precedence over special orders, the surface bill was not reached till nearly 1 P.M.
Two patient cribbage players in Boston have played 23,000 games, and at latest accounts one was only one game ahead of the other.

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 25.--The Grand Trunk Railway authorities have accepted tenders from Pennsylvania and Ohio coal-owners for a supply of 500,000 tons for the current year. The saving to the company by the lower rates will be $250,000, as compared with last year.

In reply to the application of his wife, Edith, for alimony, pending her suit for a limited divorce from him, Vanderbilt Allen has made a remarkable affidavit that was presented to Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, by his counsel, Robert Sewell.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 25.--Jay Gould arrived here to-day in his yacht Atalanta. He spent some time ashore examining the large grain elevator and coal and merchandise piers of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company. He expressed great surprise at their magnitude and completeness.

The Mackinnon Pen Company, manufacturers of fountain and stylographic pens, late of No. 192 Broadway, has been placed in the hands of William H. Ricketts, as Receiver, on the application of S.A. Whitney, a judgment creditor for $2,493.

ANAMOSA, Iowa, March 25.--Warner Williams, formerly of this city, died at Anita, Iowa, on Sunday morning. Though only 6 years of age, his weight was 200 pounds, and he had been on exhibition for some time. His parents refused an offer from Mr. P.T. Barnum of $100 permonth and expenses for the family last Summer. He made a tour through the Western States last year under the title of "The Baby Giant."

The Democrats of Flushing held their town convention yesterday afternoon and nominated Joseph Dykes for the third time for Supervisor and Luke J. Connerty for Town Clerk. Thomas J. McKenna and John J. Gleason were nominated for Justices of the Peace. The present Board of Town Trustees was renominated. The Republicans of Flushing will not make any nomination for Supervisor.

BOSTON, March 25.--A significant premonition of the entrance of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company into New-England was given to-day in a hearing before a committee of the Massachusetts Legislature upon an order to authorize telegraph companies, under proper restrictions, to erect structures upon railroad locations throughout the State.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 25.--The officers of the disabled steam-ship Chateau Margaux, which arrived here yesterday in tow of the Caledonia, tell an interesting story of their tedious and dangerous voyage. The Chateau Margaux sailed from Bordeaux on Feb. 26, with ...

A communication was received by the Board of Health yesterday from the Department of State, forwarding a request from the Duke of Buckingham that the Health Department of this city should be represented at the International Health Exhibition in the city of London, in May, ...
The General Surface Railroad bill was ordered to a third reading in the Senate yesterday with a number of amendments which improve its character.

The sub-committee of the committee to take measures for preserving the Adirondack forests met yesterday afternoon at the office of Henry Clews, at No. 346 Broadway, Dr. Ferdinand Seeger in the chair. The Finance Committee reported that $235 had been subscribed to defray the expenses of the mass-meeting.

BOSTON, Mass., March 25.--The United States Grand Jury reported this afternoon that indictments alleging conspiracy against the Government to obtain pensions by fraud had been found against Azel Ames, Jr., Charles ...

TRENTON, March 25.--The long-delayed report on the tax bills was presented to the Senate to-day. The bill for the taxation of railroads and canals was a disappointment to those who have been foremost in urging reform in that matter.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 25.--At 7:30 o'clock this morning rain began falling heavily, accompanied by severe lightning and heavy thunder, and continued uninterruptedly for three hours. Hail-stones varying from the size of peas to an inch in diameter fell for two minutes, fairly whitening the ground.

John A. Grow, a lawyer, who was charged by Walter A. Mayhew, an Englishman, with obtaining money from him under false pretenses, was placed on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions. The Englishman was charged with stealing a pair of opera-glasses and a revolver, and Grow succeeded in getting him acquitted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 25.--The day was cloudy and the track heavy. The first race, six furlongs, with selling allowances, was won by the favorite, Queen Esther, Beaconsfield second and Claude Brannon third, beating Lillie Dale, Campanini, Nat Trimble, and Riddle. Time--1:21.

PETERSBURG, Ill., March 25.--The State militia on duty around the jail to prevent the lynching of Houlden, the wife-murderer, have been relieved, and the jail is without a guard. The Sheriff anticipates trouble if the weather is not stormy to-night, and will be on the alert. Public feeling against Houlden is running very high.
