PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--The identity of the young woman who attempted suicide by taking laudanum on Chestnut-street last night is still unknown. She is still in the Jefferson College Hospital; and this morning declared that her name was Lisa Mortier, and later in the day she said it was Marie Boutiet.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 25.--A special dispatch to the Picayune from Baton Rouge says: "Gov. McEnery telegraphed to-day from Natchitoches, La., instructing his private secretary to wire the Secretary of War and the Louisiana Congressmen that the laboring population ...

WASHINGTON, March 25, 1884 Mr. Emery Storrs, representing the principal pork-packers of Chicago and St. Louis, addressed the House Committee on Commerce to-day in opposition to the policy of retaliation against countries which impose restrictions on the importation of American pork products. He also advocated the judicious inspection of American meats.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 25.--Winnie Thompson and Lucy Sackers, both colored, residing in an alley between Summer and High streets, left their two children at home to-night with a lamp sitting near a bed. Shortly afterward flames were discovered issuing from the house, and before the neighbors could rescue the children both were burned to death. The cries of the bereaved mothers were agonizing as they ran frantically to and fro bemoaning their loss.

COLUMBUS, Ga., March 25.--The Sun, of this city, published the marriage notice of Mr. Philip Dunlap, of Atlanta, and Miss Sallie Howard, a well-known society belle at Hamilton. The notice created great interest among the relatives of the young couple in this city, who were not aware of the existence of any tender feeling ...

On the application of Messrs. Schell Delehunty, as attorneys for Mr. George Le Boutillier, of Le Boutillier Brothers, Judge Lawrence has granted an order directing the Board of Aldermen to show cause on Monday next, in Supreme Court, Chambers, why a mandamus should not issue to compel the removal from the sidewalks on Fourteenth-street, between Broadway ...

The American bark National Eagle, which was stranded last Saturday on the coast of Istria, in the Adriatic, is, according to advices received by Herman Koop Co., her owners, probably a total wreck. Her crew all escaped uninjured.

MONTREAL, March 25.--There is every indication that the arrangements of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company to carry on a public telegraph business in competition with the Great North-western Company, which has now the monopoly, will soon be completed and made known.

Early on Monday morning Roundsman McCarty, of the Second Precinct, Brooklyn, arrested a young man about 30 years of age at the Pulton ferry, who was apparently very much under the influence of liquor.

Mlle. Zelie de Lussan's concert, which took place at Steck Hall last evening, was not of a character calling for extended criticism. Its most attractive feature was, in fact, the appearance of Mlle. de Lussan, who is seldom heard in public, and whose friends evidently derived great pleasure from her performances last night.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 25.--J.D. Boyle, of the Connellsville Coke Producers' Association, says that a combination effected a few days ago will advance the price of coke from 95 cents to $1.15 by April 1, and that in the near future the price will be advanced still further, until a fair rate has been established.

A four-story brick and brown-stone flat is erecting at No. 230 East Forty-fifth-street, and a steam-hod has been employed there to hoist bricks to the third floor. It consists of an endless chain ladder passing round a drum. On the rungs of the ladder hods filled with bricks ...

The Democratic primaries for the selection of delegates to the Mayoralty and district conventions were held in Jersey City last night. It was expected that they would be warmly contested, but at the last moment Mayor Taussig made an entirely unlooked-for change of front, and withdrew from the race.

RICHMOND, Va., March 25.--The Secretary of the straight-out Republican State Committee is sending out circulars giving information in relation to the convention to be held here by that party on April 30 to select delegates to the Chicago Convention. The delegates to be chosen by the Virginia anti-Mahone Republicans will pledge themselves to support the Republican nominations made at Chicago.

The Hoboken Common Council held a meeting last night, at which a further report was received from Expert Sackett in relation to his investigation of the accounts of the missing Tax Collector, John McMahon.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 25.--It is reported here to-night that the village of Colemansville, in Harrison County, 40 miles from here, was almost entirely destroyed by a cyclone which swept over it at 5 o'clock this afternoon. It is said that 10 persons were killed by flying debris and 15 or 20 injured. Nothing definite is known.

The Pacific Mail Steam-ship Acapulco, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, brought as a passenger James Pratt, a seaman, who is the sole survivor of the brigantine A.G. Jewett, which left Philadelphia for Matanzas on Feb. 19. Pratt was found in an exhausted condition in an open boat at sea on Feb. 25, and was rescued by the barkentine Edward Cushing, Capt. Bickmore, after having been in the boat 54 hours.
WASHINGTON, March 25.--The caucus of Democratic members of the House of Representatives on the Tariff bill was in session at the Capitol this evening from 8 o'clock until nearly midnight.

Eight lawyers sat in a row behind a long table before the tribunal of Surrogate Rollins most of the day yesterday, in continuation of the proceedings begun by Miss Mary Irene Hoyt to open the probate of the will of her father, Jesse Hoyt.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 25.--The reappointment of Major Daniels as Collector at Ogdensburg by President Arthur is creating feeling in St. Lawrence County, notwithstanding the efforts of the press to suppress it. Ex-District Attorney Russell championed Daniels, while exSenator Lynde brought forward a candidate in the Hon. William A. Dart, of Pottsdam. From the fact of Russell's success in Daniels's case, the ...

Articles of incorporation were filed in the County Clerk's office, yesterday, of the United States Cable Road and Subway Company, with a capital stock of $250,000, in 10,000 shares of $25 each. The objects of the company are stated to be "the securing, development, adaptation, ...

As one of the Third-avenue elevated railroad trains arrived at Hanover-square station at 12:25 Monday night Engineer C. Hopton informed the gateman that the train had passed over something which he thought must have been a cat.
CONSTANTINOPLE, March 25.--The Sultan is seriously ill. It is feared that his ailment will end in madness.

CHICAGO, March 25.--At the meeting today at Belleville, Ill., of the Republican County Committee, an effort to secure the indorsement of Logan for President did not meet with favor, and the motion was withdrawn.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--The Directors of the Keely Motor Company, who emerged this evening from Secretary Schuellermann's office, after a full meeting of the board, were a very hopeful-looking body of men. "The vibratory engine is finished," they said; "the work of adjusting and focalizing is progressing rapidly, ...
OMAHA, Neb., March 25.--The Democratic State Central Committee met last night and fixed May 22 as the time and Lincoln as the place for holding the State Convention.

LONDON, March 26.--The inaugural banquet of the City Conservative Club was given last night. Many Conservative members of the House of Commons and other prominent Conservatives were present. Viscount Cranbrook, in a speech, said that since the late Government had been driven from office there had been no peace.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 25.--A Republican convention was held in this county today, and delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions were elected. A vote was taken in the convention as to the preferences for President. Logan, Blaine, Lincoln, and Arthur were the leading ones, although all the prominent candidates had supporters. The convention expressed itself as satisfied with any nomination the party might make.
FONDA, N.Y., March 25.--Last night floating ice in the Mohawk formed a gorge just east of Fonda, and early this morning people were aroused from their beds by the sound of running water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--The annual election of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was held to-day. There was no opposition to the regular ticket, composed of all the members of the present board. A vote of 604,919 shares of stock was cast.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 25.--Mrs. Langtry appeared here last night in "Pygmalion and Galatea," arriving here on Sunday morning in her palace car. The morning being delightful and the air exhilarating, the Lily could not resist the temptation to leave the seclusion of her car, and bantered her manager for a walk.

LAWRENCE, Mass., March 25.--In the Augustinian trials to-day it was announced that 10 of the cases which were against St. Mary's Church had been abandoned, and that the plaintiffs would rely on the three cases against the Immaculate Conception Church.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--Brigadier-Gen. Ranald S. Mackenzie, having been found by an Army Retiring Board incapacitated for active service, on account of disability incident to the service, has, by direction of the President, been retired from active service, in conformity with section 1,251, Revised Statutes.
Some of the Brooklyn politicians are talking of electing the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher a delegate to the National Republican Convention. Mr. Beecher has not expressed any desire to be a delegate.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., march 25.--An ugly complication has broken out in Wayne County over the candidacy of Col. Dudley for Governor. Mr. W.T. Noble, Clerk of the County, is a candidate for Auditor of the State.
DUBLIN, March 25.--Patrick Keily, who has been engaged in organizing a convention of the National League in Waterford, has been arrested for delivering an intimidating speech.

MOBILE, March 25.--The agricultual situation in Alabama and Mississippi is not encouraging, and, should the weather continue as at present, the crops will be very much set back. The Winter has been unusually severe and the cold weather protracted at least three weeks beyond the ordinary time, and now there has been ...

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--A special from Columbia to the Times says: "This afternoon during a parade by Col. Edwards's Warm Spring Indian Company, which has been exhibiting here, the Indians became offended at the derisive yells of a party of white men.

CINCINNATI, March 25.--The Democratic City Convention to-day nominated a ticket that had been made up in advance by John R. McLean and his Payne followers. That wing of the party has obtained complete control in Cincinnati, and since the defeat of Pendleton has not been opposed.

Malachi F. Byrne is a brick-layer, of No. 209 West Twentieth-street, who once wanted to spar with John L. Sullivan. Yesterday, while passing the restaurant of Louis Kirchhoff, at No. 297 Ninth-avenue, he took a handful of oysters from a basket on the sidewalk.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 25.--This morning George A. Riley, having steadied his nerves by copious libations, entered the yard in front of No. 2,204 Morgan-street, walked around to the kitchen, and opening the door, smiled lovingly on his wife, who was at work there.
SPOTSWOOD, N.J., March 25.--T. Brady's hotel, at this place, was burned to the ground this morning. All the guests escaped except Stone Mahony, of Freeport, who was burned to death.

The steamer Lydian Monarch, which is expected to arrive here to-day, has on board the sacred white elephant intended for the Barnum, Bailey Hutchinson show. The elephant is accompanied by 15 Burmese musicians and priests, a sacred white monkey, and a choice assortment of idols.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 25.--Amelia D. Raconska, who calls herself a Hungarian Countess, and who gained some notoriety about a year ago when she was forcibly ejected from the Hotel Lafayette, has got herself into more difficulty, and now rests under a charge of assault with intent to kill.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 25.--A controlling interest in the steamer Mary Powell has been sold to Capt. Brinkerhoff, of Poughkeepsie. Capt. William Cornell retains an interest and the command. He says the steamer will continue on her old route between New-York and here.

The House spent another day in Committee of the Whole yesterday on the bill extending the time for the payment of tax on whisky in bond. The discussion brought out some very queer ideas of political economy. Mr. POTTER, of New-York, urged the passage of the bill because, while granting relief to an important interest, it would ...

BOSTON, March 25.--A large number of scientific men and representatives of mills attended a lecture by Professor Richie, of Harvard College, before the Essex Institute at Salem last night, on the new process of bleaching, invented by Charles Toppan, of Newburyport. The experiments made were very successful.
BERLIN, March 25.--A police edict has been published warning the people against eating raw pork. It points out that perfect cooking destroys trichinae.

The annual statement of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad shows that, during 1883, the earnings were $3,251,875, and the operating expenses, $1,743,771. The net earnings were $1,508,104, which were chiefly applied to the payment of interest charges and the purchase of new equipment and improvements.
CHICAGO, March 25.--It is stated here that the Post Office officials are planning for an extension of the fast mail service by putting on a train from Chicago to New-York.

CHICAGO, March 25.--The suit of the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company against Samuel J. Tilden, Louis H. Meyer, and Adrian Iselin has been finally disposed of by a decree entered to-day before Judge Drummond. The defendants are the survivors of six persons who were appointed Trustees in January, 1860, under ...

An auction sale of Jersey cattle, imported by John F. Maxfield, of Maple Place, Bloomfield, N.J., last October, began at the American Horse Exchange yesterday, under charge of Peter C. Kellogg Co., and will be continued to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 25.--The heaviest shock of earthquake since 1868 occurred here at 4:44 o'clock this afternoon. The people rushed from their houses in great fright. The shock lasted 15 seconds. Several buildings on made ground near the water-front were seriously damaged. A second, but lighter, shock followed at 5:18 P.M. More shocks are expected.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25.--Special dis patches to the Times show that the boom for Blaine is apparently gaining strength constantly in the State. The Eleventh Congressional District, comprising Luzerne and Lackawanna Counties, to-day instructed its delegates ...

WASHINGTON, March 25.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 278-- The Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steam-ship Company, plaintiff in error, vs. the Commissioners of Emigration. Argument concluded. No. 279--William Drury, appellant, vs. Annie E. Hayden. Argued. No. 280--Joseph Teal, plaintiff in error, vs. James D. Walker. Argument begun.

Mr. Ross Raymond, a journalist who had a somewhat pyrotechnic career in this country several years ago, has bobbed up serenely in Paris as the perpetrator of what is described as one of the "most extraordinary swindles ever practiced upon a hotel-keeper" of that city.

TROY, N.Y., March 25.--The Pulpit Committee of the Fifth-Street Baptist Church tonight reported that they had selected the Rev. H. O. Hiscox, of the Twenty-third-Street Baptist Church, New-York City, as Pastor to fill the vacancy caused by the departure of the Rev. Dr. Griffiths last October. The action of the committee was indorsed.

PORT RICHMOND, Penn., March 25.--The coal miners' troubles in the Schuylkill, Lehigh, Wyoming, and Lackawanna regions are becoming even worse than has been previously reported. The continued suspension of operations and the half-pay plan that has been exacted by the leaders of the combination are creating intense ...

Sunday was a bad day for Italians. There was a riot in Mulberry-street between Italians and Irishmen, in which the latter were the aggressors, and the police arrested seven men--all Italians. There was also a fight in Elizabeth-street between Italians and Irishmen, the latter ...

The West Philadelphia small-boy who launched his sister from the second-story window equipped with a pair of wings and an open umbrella deserves a great deal of credit in spite of the failure of his experiment.

The question whether the Tarrytown Post Office is to be "on the hill" or "under the hill," a subject that has greatly agitated the citizens of that place recently, seems likely to be decided soon. Inspector Newcomb visited the town again on Monday to hear argument on both sides. There had been appointed a committee of three by the up-hill folk, and a like committee by the down-hill people, to argue the question.

The heat generated by the burning stock of the Electric Candle Company in the late fire was frightful. The office safe made by Marvin fell into a vat of burning tallow and could not be reached till the fire subsided. It was opened yesterday and the contents found intact.--Tribune.

The city elections at Yonkers yesterday was the most hotly contested for many years, special efforts having been made by both Republicans and Democrats to elect their candidates, particularly the Mayor. Notwithstanding the excitement the voters kept orderly, and the police did not make a single arrest.

PANAMA, March 15.--Owing to a personal question with some of the members of Congress, originating in the non-approval of an appointment he had made, President Octalora sent in his resignation of office on Feb. 10.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 25.--Whistler and Muldoon wrestled from 8:50 o'clock last night until midnight without either gaining a fall. It was the most exciting contest ever witnessed in this city. At 12:30 Muldoon refused to continue, stating that he was too tired. The referee declared the match a draw.

The trial of Patrolman Dennis Slattery, of the Twenty-third Precinct, who was charged with having, on March 2, on the way to court, released a disorderly woman whom he had arrested the previous night, was resumed before the Police Commissioners yesterday. Slattery, in his defense, said that some other ...
WASHINGTON, March 25.--The House today took up the Bonded Whisky bill in Committee of the Whole. Mr. Potter, of New-York, briefly gave the reasons which impelled him to support the measure.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 25.--The arrest of the notorious Charlie Butler, who murdered his wife near Columbia, Ind., a few months since, and who broke jail and escaped with two other prisoners, has created a profound sensation in Central Ohio, where his deeds are well known. Young Butler has resided in Columbus a number of years, but during the last six, when not ...

Testimony concerning the charge that L.E. Myers, of the Manhattan Athletic Club, is a professional was taken by a sub-committee of the Executive Committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association, at the Knickerbocker Cottage, last evening.

Seven years ago, Joseph Freund, an itinerant dealer in diamonds, left the Eastern District of Brooklyn and went to Europe, after borrowing from a number of friends sums of money ranging in amount from $50 to $200, under the pretense that he wanted the accommodation only for a day or two to pay off a mortgage.

SUAKIN, March 25.--The camp of Osman Digna is 25 miles from Suakin and 13 beyond the advance post of the British. Gen. Graham has determined to attack the rebel leader on Thursday, and will afterward push on to Sinkat with one brigade if this course is practicable.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 25.--The new revenue stamp tax is being published. The law regulating the tax on railroad tickets and documents has not yet been published, but it is understood that the rate will be 2 cents on every $20 or fraction thereof, instead of 1, as now. This is the only tax levied on railroads.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 26.--Henry C. Ely, who chopped off the head of John Hardin, at East Granby, five weeks ago, was to-day declared insane by the Superior Court, and was committed to an asylum.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 25.--Sunday night a stranger called at the residence of Alfred Davis, an old man living near Pikeville, Sequachie County, this State. The man made a liberal offer for the privilege of staying all night. Davis surrendered his bed to his unknown guest, sleeping himself in a rocking-chair ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 25.--The will of the late William S. Merrill, of this city, which was proved in the Municipal Court today, makes the following public bequests: To the American Board of Foreign Missions, of Massachusetts, $1,200; to the American Home Missionary Society, of New-York, $1,200; to the American Missionary Association, of New-York, ...

BOSTON, March 25.--Point of Pines, a well-known sea-shore resort on the north shore, was sold at auction to-day by order of the Trustees, under mortgage. It was purchased by W.G. Saltenstal for the bondholders for $130,000, which is less than half the original cost.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 25.--A fierce legal battle was begun in the courts here to-day before Judge Seely, of Honesdale, for possession of 206 acres of coal land situated at the head of the Lackawanna Valley, and said to be worth $300,000.
Questions of interest to the anthracite coal trade were informally discussed at a meeting of the Committee of Control of the Western Anthracite Association, at the Gilsey House, yesterday.
The Stock Exchange Glee Club will give its seventh private concert at Chickering Hall on Saturday evening.

Two men, clad only in their night robes, engaged in a fierce struggle yesterday morning in a room on the second floor of a frame house just opposite the Gates-avenue car stables, Brooklyn. Both were covered with blood, and one of them was a raving lunatic. The madman's name was George Russell, and he had just shot his wife and put two bullets through his own head.

When the British Government, in the absence of any explicable policy as to Khartoum, hit on the expedient of sending GORDON thither with a general authority to perform miracles, it was thought by Mr. GLADSTONE'S admirers that the Soudan problem had been successfully solved.

BOSTON, March 25.--The annual meeting of the Bell Telephone Company was held here to-day. The session was harmonious. The earn ings for the year were $2,295,594, against $1,576,031 during the previous year. The following officers were elected: Treasurer--William R. Driver; Direetors--Francis Blake, Charles S. Bowditch, Charles S. Bradley, Channing Clapp, Alexander Cochran, William H. Forbes, Charles Eustan Hubbard, Robert P. Minturn, W.G. Saltonstall, and Thomas Saunders.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 25.--It has been stated that Robinson, the Traveling Passenger Agent of the Alton Road, sold a block of 1,000 tickets from Chicago to Kansas City at $7.25 each to a Toledo scalper last December. The tickets purported to be issued by the Cleveland, Mount Vernon and Columbus Road, and were ...

Charles E. Courtney and Wallace Ross have signed an agreement to row a three-mile race on the Oak Point course, New-York, on Friday, May 30, between 1 and 7 o'clock P.M. Messrs. Pilkington and Nagle, the backers of Ross, have put up $2,500, of which $2,000 is to go to the winner of the race and $500 to the loser.

Michael Butler, age 18, while visiting yesterday morning at the house of Mrs. Farrell, No. 131 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, took up an old revolver belonging to her husband, and commenced to examine it, thinking it wasn't loaded. Mrs. Farrell's little boy, a child of 9 years, was playing about the room.
BOSTON, March 25.--The establishment of B.F. Clements, morocco manufacturer, Lynn, has been attached. The liabilities are at present unknown.
"J.R. McD." is informed that she is an American. The sixteenth annual Spring meeting of the New-York Athletic Club will be held at the club grounds (Mott Hoven) on June 7.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 25.--In the Supreme Court to-day the Grand Jury presented a true bill against Bracken and Holmes, the Americans who were arrested some time ago for having dangerous erplosives in their possession.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 25.--There was a great celebration at Carroll Hall to-night in honor of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the landing of the Maryland pilgrims at St. Mary's, March 25, 1633. Archbishop Gibbons was present, with many of the leading citizens of the town.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 25.--S.W. Tallmadge, of this city, is in receipt of late reports from several of the State Agricultural Departments and United States Statisticians in regard to the present condition ...

The Pennsylvania Railroad made a demand yesterday for the reduction of the freight rate on base bullion and pig-lead east bound to the basis of cut rates. Commissioner Fink sent out an order, taking effect to-day, reducing that class of freight, Chicago to New-York, from 30 ...

Yesterday was the first real fine day the ladies have had for shopping this Spring, and they were out in force. They mingled with the busy rush of Broadway, walked five abreast on the broad pavements of Fourteenth-street, and took possession of the dry goods stores.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., March 25.--Receiver Rich, in behalf of the St. Albans Trust Company depositors, has instituted suits against the Trustees to recover about $70,000 damages. The suits are brought under that section of the charter which provides that, in case of loss by improper loans, the Directors shall be held personally ...

Trustees W.E. Connor, Frank R. Lawrence, George J. Gould, William E. Dowd, and C. F. Timpson, and George S. Scott, the Vice-Commodore, of the American Yacht Club, met in the club-house, No. 21 East Twenty-eighth-street yesterday afternoon, and elected the following named gentlemen to membership: Thomas W. Evans, ...

CONCORD, N.H., March 25.--The Republican State Committee to-night decided to hold a State Convention for the selection of delegates to the Chicago Convention at Concord Apri1 30. The First District Convention will be held at Manchester April 22, and that of the Second District at Concord April 29.

NORFOLK, Va., March 25.--On Sunday morning last the police force of this city made a raid on several gambling houses and arrested 50 or more colored men and women who were found there, and captured gambling implements and money.
The lower house of the New-Jersey Legislature has agreed to ask Congress to enact a law to prohibit the immigration of skilled laborers from Europe.

The exception of the Police Department from the operation of the reform bill in the Assembly last week was unfortunate. It was largely the work of Mr. JOHN J. O'BRIEN, who fully appreciates the value of the police for political trading, and ...

ALBANY, N.Y., March 25.--A truce has been patched up between rival Republicans in the Twentieth District, and unless its terms are broken the Hon. John H. Starin will be a delegate to Chicago. Senator Arkell was the mediator, and through his influence a fair understanding was to-day reached between Messrs. Starin and West.

FRANKLIN, Penn., March 25.--The Venango County Democratic Convention to-day elected three Randall delegates to the State Convention. Tariff resolutions were offered, but were rejected. NORRISTOWN, Penn., March 25.--The Democratic County Convention to-day elected delegates to the State Convention and instructed them for Randall for President.

The members of the New-York and Metropolitan Base-ball Clubs reported for duty yesterday afternoon on the Polo Grounds. A large number of persons assembled to see them prac-- tice. Several of the new men are very promising players. Jones, of the New-Yorks, showed up in good form, and Griffin, of the same club, distinguished himself in the field and handled the bat with good effect.

The new rooms of the Manhattan Hay and Produce Exchange, in the basement of the new Field Building, on Battery-place, were formally opened yesterday. The attendance of members and invited guests was large and the rooms were generally commended. They are spacious and apparently well adapted for the purposes to which they were dedicated.

BUFFALO, March 26.--The mid-year conference of the Association for the Advancement of Women was held in this city to-day with closed doors. Several ladies prominently identified with the cause from Boston and Chicago and other cities were present. An elaborate luncheon was served to the ladies at the Genesee at noon to-day, covers being laid for 66. This evening a reception was given. The October meeting will be held in Indianapolis.

WASHINGTON, March, 26.--The consideration of the Bonded Whisky bill was resumed in the House to-day. After several brief speeches for and against the bill had been delivered, Mr. Dunn, of Arkansas, made a severe attack on the measure, which, he said, was favored by only three members of the Ways and Means Committee--Messrs. Morrison, Hurd, and Blackburn.

Davis Mann and Margaretta J. Roney, of New-London and East Nottingham Townships, Chester County, were married last week. Both were over 70 years of age. They were jolly and lively despite the abundance of silver hairs.

"In reference to that Bolivar statue." said Park Commissioner Viele, yesterday, "I want to be placed on record as never having had any aversion to the statue. Gen. Bolivar was of small stature, with a large head. The statue represents just such a man. Royal Phelps, who, as a boy, was familiar with Gen. Bolivar, pronounces the...

TUCSON, Arizona, March 26.--Kit Joy, the last of the Deming train-robbers, who broke jail at Silver City, New-Mexico, has been captured by the Sheriff after a hard fight. Kit was badly wounded, and lies at the point of death.

The Republican conference committee held a meeting yesterday and added a large number of names to the General Committee. Among the number are the following representatives of the Independent Republican Association of Chicago: Edward G.Mason, N.K. Fairbank, Wirt Dexter, Albert A. Sprague, George C. Clarke,...

TALBOTTON, March 26.--With a doublebarreled shot-gun Mr. M.W. Hollis, County Commissioner, to-day shot and killed Jordan Williams, a negro employe. Williams attacked Mr. Holliss with a chair, when a little son of Hollis brought him his shot-gun, which he used on the negro with fatal effect. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict of justifiable homicide.

One of the most astonishing results of the Democratic caucus of last night is that everybody--Democratic tariff reformers, Democratic protectionists, and Republicans--is satisfied. Mr. Morrison, Mr. Hurd, Mr. Herbert, and other friends of the bill reported by the Ways and Means Committee, are convinced beyond a doubt that they have won a victory.

The Senate Committee on Appropriations expects to present the Naval Appropriation bill to the Senate on Friday. It will recommend several amendments to the measure as it passed the House of Representatives, most of them being additions to the sums given for various items.

GONZALES, Texas, March 26.--Yesterday at the examining trial of Bill Burleson, a negro, charged with attempting an assault upon Mrs. Knoeppa, near Harwood, on March 6, the evidence showed that the accused man was in the vicinity at the time the crime was committed, and Mrs. Knoeppa positively identified him as her assailant.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26.--The fish commission firm of J.J. A.G. Uberoth, of this city, has failed, with liabilities of about $6,000 and assets nominal.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners gave a hearing yesterday to the property-owners along Chambers-street who protested against the laying of tracks in that street. D.B. Halstead, President of the New-York National Exchange Bank, at Chamber-street and College-place, asked the Commissioners to go to the corner of Chambers-Street and West Broadway any day and watch the immense traffic there.

The steam-ship Edith Godden, Capt. Bennett, which arrived yesterday from St. Ann's Bay, Jamaica, was run into at 8 o'clock Tuesday evening off the New-Jersey coast, about half way between Cape May and Barnegat, by an unknown schooner.

BOSTON, Mass., March 26.--A crowd of about 5,000 people witnessed the long-talkedof sparring-match to-night between Charles Mitchell, the champion heavy-weight of England, who is anxious of standing up against John L. Sullivan, and John Kirian, of Boston, the champion middle weight of NewEngland, which took place at the Mechanics'...

Several years ago a Brooklyn florist named Fitzsimmons gave $2,000 to Father Philip Kenny, then secretary to Father McGuire, Pastor of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, in court-street. Father Kenny was to use the money for the purpose of bringing Fitzsimmons's daughter out from Ireland and educating her in a convent.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--The President to-day sent to Congress the following message recommending appropriations for the construction of naval vessels:

Officer James Smith, of the Tenth Precinct, while patrolling his post yesterday morning at about ll o'clock heard the muffled report of a pistol in the house at No. 75 Canal-street. On proceeding to the fourth floor and bursting in the door of the middle apartment he found the body of Dietrich Wehrs, a German, 33 years...

CHICAGO, March 26.--A special from Springfield says that the farmers are universally in good spirits. Two or three dry days will start the plows. A little plowing has been done in favored places already. A great deal of corn remains in the fields throughout that section, and on gathering it this Spring it is generally found to be of little value for the purposes of feeding.

The well-known jockey of the Dwyer Brothers, James McLaughlin, has been awarded the two prizes offered by the New-York Sportsman to the jockey or jockeys with the largest average of winning mounts and winning the largest amount of money in 1883.
FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, March 26.-- The steam-yacht Atalanta, with Mr. Jay Gould and party on board, which has been here the last three or four days, sailed this morning for NewYork.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 26.--Railroad communication with the north is again interrupted by heavy land slides on the Southern Pacific Road at Tehachapi Mountain and Soledad Canon. Trains will be delayed for a week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 26.--The appointment of Ira Belts, of Buffalo, a well-known Democratic politician and canal forwarder, as Assistant Superintendent of Public Works has been a good deal discussed here for a day or two. It is generally considered a respectable appointment.

At the meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday, James E. Serrell and William H. Arnoux asked for further time to consider the plans of the proposed water system. Mr. Arnoux said that he had received a telegram from Congressman Potter in which he said that he and Mr. W.H. Webb could not attend the commission before Saturday next. Mr. Arnoux asked that delay be granted.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 26.--Half a dozen residences were broken into in this village last night. From O.F. Chase's room were taken a new suit of clothes and a small amount of money. An elderly woman, living alone, lost $40. At H.J. Pentzer's house two well-filled, purses were secured.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 26.--Archbishop Gibbons to-day issued the following pastoral letter regarding the proposed confiscation of the American College in Rome:

NORFOLK, Va., March 26.--The Board of Police Commissioners met again this morning with reference to the dismissal by the Mayor of certain members of the police force for raiding gambling dens, but May or Lamb declined to take part in the proceedings on the ground that he had to hold court. Turning to go, he said that he was surprised to see the following private conversation published in the morning papers:

Col. Vanderbilt Allen, who is contesting the suit of his wife for a limited divorce, is a graduate of West Point. He stood high on the graduating roll of his class, and was therefore appointed to a Lieutenancy in the Engineer Corps.

One of the main attractions of West Twenty-third-street is the large show window of Le Boutillier Brothers, at Nos. 31 and 33. It contains a perfect representation of an organ, constructed entirely of sateens of all shades and colors, plain goods representing the reeds, black and white stripes the sharps and flats, and figured...
Complete returns from the 22 towns of Westchester County show that the Republicans elected 9 Supervisors and the Democrats 13, which leaves the board politically the same as last year.

EASTON, Penn., March 26.--A letter was sent to Gov. Pattison to-day by counsel for John Dillman, asking him to issue a stay of proceedings and to appoint a commission of experts to examine into and report upon the mental condition of the murderer, who has been sentenced to be hanged April 8. Counsel says that the former commission, which reported Dillman sane and responsible, was not composed of men experienced in cases of insanity.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 26.--The nine reform measures relating to New-York City were the cause of an uproar in the Assembly to-day that has had no parallel this year. Democrats like Oliver, of New-York, have been planning for two days to delay the consideration of these bills, depending upon chance to eventually procure their defeat.

The question of who shall manage the Metropolitan Opera-house next season is not yet settled, but is likely to be by the end of the week. Mr. Gye's contract, or a memorandum of it, is now in the hands of the Directors of the house. The absence of G.G. Haven in Boston during a portion of the present week has prevented a...

A mass-meeting will be held in the Cooper Union to-night, under the auspices of the Committee of Fifty-three, which is working so effectively in behalf of legislation to secure municipal reforms in this city, and all citizens having the interests of good government at heart are cordially invited by the committee to attend.

Philip Pharrars, a hand on the schooner Eilen Tobin, of New-York, now lying at the foot of Morgan-street, Jersey City, was arrested yesterday on suspicion of having drowned his wife. There seems to be no ground for this belief, save that after the woman was drowned Pharrars went to New-York to notify his relatives.

LONDON, March 26.--A man who called himself F.R. Duncan, and represented that he was the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, succeeded in obtaining 30 from Mr. Alfred V. Dockery, the American Consul at Leeds, on pretense that he wished to send a special cable dispatch of great importance to THE TIMES.

An ingenious contrivance for drawing nickels out of the pockets of the curious is in operation in a richly embellished down-town drinking place. It is a good-sized miniature steam-boat engine, with a walking-beam, tightly inclosed in a glass case and set upon a firm pedestal.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 26.--Some time since an application was made by William Bush, a stockholder in the American Ship-building Company, to Attorney-General O'Brien for a hearing upon charges made against the ship-building company.

The Trustees of the Seventeenth Ward transferred, in January, Miss Annie T. Gleese, fourth assistant teacher in the primary department of Grammar School No. 13, in East Houston-street, to the position of tenth assistant. This action was taken because Trustee P.K. Horgan said he saw Miss Gleese administer corporal punishment to one of the pupils.
The following sales of securities were made at public auction by Adrian H. Muller Son at the Exchange Sales-room yesterday.

LONDON, Ky., March 26.--A cyclone, the severest ever known in this section of the country, passed near this place and Pittsburg, two miles north of here, about 4 P.M. yesterday, carrying death and destruction in its train, especially at Pittsburg, where it was the most severe. The Methodist Church was razed to the ground, and much other property damaged.

A fire at No. 210 Fulton-street last evening did damage roughly estimated at about $50,000. The first floor is occupied by P.F. Slave, wholesale dealer in liquors; the basement, second, and part of the upper floor by the United States Twine Company, and the third, fourth, and the other part of the upper floor by Lowe ...

A conference of trunk line railroad officers was held yesterday in the office of President Rutter, of the New-York Central, in the Grand Central Station. There were present beside President Rutter Assistant President Tillinghast, President John Newell, of the Lake Shore; President H.B. Ledyard...

Joshua Barnum, of the firm of J. Barnum Son, clothiers, died yesterday at his home near Brewsters. He was born at South-East, Putnam County, on Sept. 3, 1818, and coming to this city in his sixteenth year, he was employed as a clerk in the clothinghouse of Brooks Brothers.
The jury in the case of Hallet Kilbourn against ex-Sergeant-at-Arms Thompson have rendered a verdict in favor of Kilbourn for $37,500.

Several owners of piggeries in Long Island City were arraigned before Justice Kavanagh yesterday on a charge of violating the health laws in maintaining nuisances. Counselor Walker, in behalf of the pig-owners, praised the point that the proceedings were irregular on the ground that Dr. Muller was not a legal Health Officer, inasmuch as he voted for his own appointment...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 26.--Charles Parrish, one of the leading coal operators in the Wyoming Valley, when questioned to-day in regard to the state of the coal trade, said he thought there would be a six days' suspension in April and May, and that that would put the trade in a first-class condition.

The sale of the Maxfield importation of Jersey cattle was concluded at the American Horse Exchange yesterday. The attendance was good and better prices were realized than on Tuesday. The following are some of the animals sold, with the purchasers and prices:

TORONTO, Ontario, March 26.--The Ontario branch of the Dominion Prohibition Alliance for the suppression of the liquor traffic has been in session in this city for the past two days. The alliance is much encouraged by the result of the vote on the Scott act in Oxford last week, when they succeeded in carrying it by 800 majority.
LONDON, March 26.--The Duke of Arkyll's article in the Nineteenth Century on Henry George, is entitled "The San Francisco Prophet."

The Street has been flooded with rumors for several days in regard to the condition and management of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, most of which could be traced to no specific source, but which have grown steadily as they circulated, until on Tuesday night it was stated that President Jewett and the Board of Directors were about to resign on the demand of a heavy stockholder.

Madison-Square Garden will soon become a thing of the past. The property has been purchased by a syndicate which includes Cornelius Fellowes, John G. Hecksher, A.J. Cassatt, F.A. Schermerhorn, J.T. Hyde, Beverly Robinson, and J.D. Cheever. These gentlemen propose to begin in May the erection of an entirely new building, to cost about $1,000,000, on the site of the present Garden.

Preparations are actively going on for the National Horse Show, which is to take place in May. The entries are not very numerous yet, most horse-owners preferring to wait until as late as possible in order that they may not find their horses unfit for exhibition after being entered.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 26.--The largest sum which has ever been paid at one time by the Pension Office of this city to a single applicant was paid to-day to John F. Pfeiffer, a resident of Chambersburg, Penn., who received $8,500 for an injury received during the war which resulted in total blindness about six years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The promotion of Col. David S. Stanley, Twenty-second Infantry, to the rank of Brigadier-General, vice Gen. S.R. Mackenzie retired, will cause other promotions in the line as follows: Lieut.-Col. P.T. Swaine, Fifteenth Infantry, to be Colonel of the Twenty-second Infantry; Major W. T. Gentry, Ninth Infantry, to be Lieutenant-Colonel...

LONDON, March 26.--The putting of the war sloop Alert, recently presented by England to the United States to participate in the Greely search expedition, into commission yesterday was becomingly celebrated. Minister Lowell hoisted the American colors at the peak. Fifty guests lunched on board, among...

CLINTON, N.Y., March 26.--An article was published in the Utica Herald and THE NEWYORK TIMES of Monday, March 24, holding Prof. Hopkins personally responsible for an Associated Press telegram of March 22 stating the terms on which the difficulty between the Faculty and the Senior Class had been settled. At a Faculty meeting held at noon, March 25, the following action was taken:

Mrs. Anna Wallingford, who some time ago caused the arrest of Nathan H.L. Hawes on a charge of bigamy, was herself arrested yesterday on complaint of his first wife, Mrs. Cecilia Hawes, of No. 61 Lawrencestreet, Brooklyn. The warrant, which was issued by Justice Walsh, sets forth that...

The greatest of Madagascar's Kings, RADAMA I., boasted that no invader could face his two commanders, Gen. Hazo (forest) and Gen. Tazo (fever.) In the Soudan these formidable leaders are replaced by two others equally powerful Gen. Hunger ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 26.--Gov. Hamilton to-night made public a letter addressed to the Republicans of the State, in which he says that he was a candidate for election for the full term, having been elected Lieutenant-Governor and become Chief Executive upon the election of Governor Cullom to the Senate; but he has become convinced that...

Fifth-avenue, between Twenty-fifth and Thirty-fourth streets, and Broadway between the same streets, were left in total darkness during the small hours of yesterday morning. The Broadway lights went out at 12:50 o'clock, while the lights on Fifth-avenue were extinguished some time before that hour.

A large fish, with white, glistening sides and dark fins, dangled from a string in Fulton Market yesterday afternoon, and was turned round and admired by everybody who came along. To it was attached a card on which was labelled "The first shad of the season." It was caught in the North River by B.F. Fisher, of...

Augustus Schell was decidedly weaker yesterday, and though his mind was still clear and he recognized all about him, he spoke very little during the day, and at times it was thought that he was losing consciousness. He had not taken any nourishment whatever for three days, and his physicians said that his vitality was remarkable...

LAWRENCE, Mass., March 26.--In the suit of Ellen Leahy, against Archbishop Williams, growing out of the difficulties of the Augustinian Society, Judge Bacon, this morning, charged the jury. A verdict for the plaintiff was rendered for the full amount claimed, $1,240, with interest.

PRINCETON, March 26.--A mass-meeting of students was held this afternoon to elect football directors for the ensuing year. The contest between C. Vanausdale and J.B. Harriman for the Senior directorship was exciting. The former was elected by a majority of 20. Elections were made from the under classmen as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 280--Joseph Teal, plaintiff in error, vs. James D. Walker. Argument concluded. No. 281--The Corn Exchange National Bank, plaintiff in error, vs. Schappers Brothers. Argued. No 282--Alexander Cochrane et al., appellants, vs. Badische Anilin and Soda Fabrik. Argument begun.
The twenty-seventh annual session of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference was begun in the Halsey-Street Church, in that city, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, Bishop Andrews presiding.

HINESVILLE, Ga., March 26.--Joe Martin was playing with an old gun to-day while his mother was sitting by him knitting. He pulled the trigger, when a load of buckshot went into his mother's head, fatally injuring her.

The President gave a Congressional state dinner party to 54 guests at the White House this evening, the company including 26 Representatives with their wives. The suite of state apartments was more beautifully decorated than usual with fan and sago palms and large foliage plants.

The First Baptist Church in Brooklyn was crowded last night, when the graduating exercises of the February class of the Brooklyn Central School were held and the diplomas awarded. Among those present were Tunis G. Bergen, President of the Board of Education; Joseph C. Hendrix, Superintendent Patterson...

As a result of an examination by Fire Commissioner Purroy and Chief of Battalion McCabe of the Fire Departments of the cities of Toledo, Rochester, Detroit, Milwaukee, and Chicago the Fire Commissioners have decided that applicants for promotion to engineer or assistant engineer; of steamer must pass an examination in the work of the repair shops.

CAPE MAY, March 26.--The schooner Rhodella, Blew, of New-York, went ashore at this place this morning, when there was a dense fog and a heavy sea. Her crew were rescued by the life-saving stations, and the vessel soon after went to pieces. She was bound for Virginia, in ballast, and was not insured. She was owned by the Captain.

The officers of the New-York Petroleum Exchange have made arrangements to enlarge the quarters of that institution. The present large room on the first floor of the Welles Building, No.18 Broadway, will be retained, and with it will be connected the spacious room directly overhead.

LONDON, March 26.--This was the third and last day of the Lincoln Spring meeting. The principal event of the meeting, the race for the Lincolnshire Handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, took place and was won by Mr. J.W. Smith's 6-yearold c.g. Tonans.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 26.--The body of an infant was found near the Rock Island Railroad track, east of Altoona, yesterday. It was naked, and its skull was crushed. The supposition is that it was born on the emigrant car of the Rock Island train for the West, and was thrown out of the window by its mother, who is thought to have been going to Nebraska.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 26.--On 'Change to-day resolutions were introduces and adopted, under a suspension of the rules, protesting against the discriminating freight rate recently adopted by the Northern Pacific Railroad, making the rates on certain commodities the same from Milwaukee and other North-western cities to Portland, Oregon, as from New-York and...
PHILADELPHIA, March 26.--The tide in the Delaware River at noon was extraordinarily high, and along the river fronts fears were entertained for the safety of goods stowed on the wharves.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 26.--President Rumsey will go to Albany to-night with a draft of the new charter to constitute Ithaca a city, and Senator Esty will introduce the same in the Legislature. Anxiety is manifested by certain parties to have the charter passed during the present session.

The following letter, sent by W.K. Vanderbilt and Chauncey M. Depew to David Dows, Roswell P. Flower, and H. H. Porter, is regarded by some outside observers as introducing a new feature in the fight for the control of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company:

The responsibility for the disgraceful proceedings in the Assembly yesterday belongs in the first instance to Speaker SHEARD. Nothing that he has done or is likely to do can redeem his reputation from the stain which he has voluntarily and unnecessarily put upon it.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--Counsel for Representative William E. Kellogg, in the Criminal Court to-day, called the attention of Judge Wylie to the case pending against their client and stated that they had served upon the attorney-General and the special Government counsel a notice that they would ask the court to assign an early day for trial.

TRENTON, March 26.--There was another scene of great excitement on the floor of the Assembly at about noon to-day. Something like bad feeling had been stirred up earlier in the day over Assemblyman Fish's anti-lottery publication act, which passed yesterday by a bare majority.

SUAKIN, March 26.--The cavalry had a two hours' skirmish with the rebels near Tamanieb. Several rebels were killed. Before the skirmish Col. Stewart sent mounted natives to teli the rebels that the English would not quarrel with them and would not injure anybody unless fired upon, and that if Osman Diana would surrender his life would be spared.

We fear that Mr. LOWE, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture of Canada, is rather rash than wise. By challenging the statistics of Mr. NIMMO he has invited a discussion which will not materially advance the interests of the Dominion.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 26.--The people in this county have been annoyed for the past ten days by a female tramp. She passes under the name of Mrs. Glanter, the name of her third husband, who is now living at Elberton.

ELWOOD, N.J., March 26.--The relatives of A.K.H. Doughty, the ex-Collector of Mullica Township, who has been missing for nearly six weeks, received a telegram to-day from the Chief of Police of Lynchburg, Va., stating that the missing man had been discovered in that town in a demented condition, and that he would be kept in safety until the arrival of his friends.

A German, rather well dressed, of about 35 years of age, applied for a room at the Carleton House, at Frankfort and William streets, at about 9:30 o'clock on Tuesday night. He registered as Werner, and went immediately up to his room. The chamber-maid yesterday morning rapped at the door for some time without receiving a response, and then informed the...

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 26.--The suspension of William Butler Co., paper manufacturers, whose mills are at No. 4,230 Woodlawn-avenue, West Philadelphia, was announced this morning. The firm consists of William Butler and his nephew, John Butler, and their liabilities are estimated at somewhere between...

CHICAGO, March 26.--In the different Republican County Conventions to-day Logan men were elected to the district conventions, and in nearly every case resolutions were adopted urg ing the President to veto the Fitz John Porter bill.

Funeral services were performed over the body of the late John Jay Cisco, the banker, in Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth-street, yesterday morning. A large number of the business friends and aquaintances of the deceased attended the ceremonies.

SYRACUSE, March 26.--Chief-Justice William C. Ruger is at home resting from his labors in the Court of Appeals. A reporter called upon him last evening and broached the subject of Presidential nominations.

A special meeting of the Board of Bridge Trustees was called yesterday by President Kingsley, for the purpose of further considering the proposed extension of the bridge railway system at the New-York terminus.

The steam-ship Greece, of the National Line, which arrived from London late Tuesday evening, brought several blooded horses. One of these was an English racer named Charaxus, who is owned by the Hon. Mr. Sands. Mr. Sands was a passenger on the Greece. Charaxus is a bay horse about 8 years old, by Dustin, out of Sappho.

At a meeting held with closed doors the Druggists' Union of Brooklyn has rescinded its former action in reference to fixing a scale of prices for patent medicines. The price list has been abolished and members of the union are now at liberty to sell patent medicines for any price they like, or give them away if that seems to them best.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 26.--The Sharon divorce case was continued to-day. Mrs. Col. Stagg resumed her testimony, and was cross-examined. She said she came here at the request of Sharon, who, through a third party, sent her a check for $500. She did not know whether she and her husband were to pay their own expenses.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--A surpirse was given to the Senate to-day in the shape of a message from President Arthur nominating Mr. A.A. Sargent, united States Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Germany, to fill the same position in Russia as successor of the late Minister Hunt.
The caucus of Tuesday evening is another and conclusive proof, if any were needed, of the incapacity of the Democratic Party for anything but a hunt after the spoils.

A well-dressed man, very much under the influence of liquor, who subsequently proved to be Arthur C. Sweetser, of East Twentyeighth-street, and who is employed in a large dry goods commission house in Broadway, was seen coming out of a disorderly house in Thirtyfifth-street, near Seventh-avenue, on Tuesday afternoon in company with a notorious woman...

Miss Clara Morris, with the sudden movement of the mind which sometimes marks the members of the sex of which she is a distinguished ornament, has resumed her interest in the business of acting. Miss Morris has long been impressed with the belief that she was an invalid, and that she really could not endure the fatigue of continuous acting.
The elegant steamer St. John will make the first trip of the season to Albany to-day at 6 P.M.

Philip Brady, a laborer, was employed by a plumber on Oct. 20, 1881, to make an excavation between the tracks of the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad Company, in Columbia-street. While at work a "bobtail" car came alone and the driver attempted to...

WASHINGTON, March 26.--It may be carrying coal to Newcastle to undertake to inform the people of New-York State from Washington as to the purposes of Republican politicians in a district of that State, but some signs of the times which appear here may not be altogether uninteresting as throwing light upon the selection of delegates to Chicago from the Sixteenth (Dutchess, Columbia, and Putnam) District.

NEW-HAVEN, March 26.--Beaver Brook, a little stream usually about four feet wide, running through the town of Derby and emptying into the Naugatuck, was suddenly converted into a raging torrent this afternoon, and within an hour had wrought over $250,000 damage to property in the manufacturing village of Ansonia.

CHICAGO, March 26.--At to-day's convention of the trade and labor unions of Illinois about 150 delegates were in attendance. The address of the Chairman, ex-Mayor McLaughlin, of Braidwood, touched upon the grievances that must be righted, among them convict labor by contract, which ought to be abolished forever.

CHICAGO, March 26.--At an inquest held to-day on the body of William Lavkenow, death was pronounced to have been caused by starvation and exposure. The last six nights of his life the deceased man passed in the open air, in the rear of No. 722 Canal-street. Lavkenow years ago was a merchant of Brooklyn. He was a son of one of the wealthiest ship-owners of Bremen, Germany.

A large crowd gathered in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning in expectation of the arraignment of Sheriff Davidson and his four subordinates, who are, like him, under indictment. The Sheriff did not appear, his counsel. Joseph H. Choate and Aaron J. Vanderpoel, not being ready.

The members of the Cotton Exchange balloted yesterday on the proposed amendments to the by-laws reducing the rates of brokers' commissions. The contest was an exciting one, and proved to be much closer than had been anticipated. The amendments were lost, the vote standing 116 for and 125 against.

Mr. Ochiltree, the sanguine member from Texas, is said to be extremely happy because of the nominations made yesterday by the President. Mr. Chauncey B. Sabin, selected for United States Judge in the Eastern District of Texas; Mr. Asa E. Stratton, Attorney for the...

Mr. William H. Vanderbilt sat in his library last evening after his dinner hour, reading the newspapers and his correspondence. He wore a suit of plain black broadcloth, and his high white collar was confined by a black tie. His face was ruddy, and he was in excellent spirits. It was misty and muddy without and Mr. Vanderbilt's...

Ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling and ex-Secretary of State William M. Evarts led the opposing hosts again yesterday in the proceeding begun on Monday, before Surrogate Rollins, by Miss Mary Irene Hoyt, to open the probate of the will of her father, Jesse Hoyt. As at the two previous sessions, the court-room was...

TORONTO, Ontario, March 26.--The Ontario Legislature was prorogued yesterday. The committee of the House to investigate the charges of conspiracy to bribe members of the Legislature reported, recommending the issue of a royal commission to investigate the charges, the commission to be composed of...

PHILADELPHIA, March 26.--A reporter of the Philadelphia Times to-day talked with the Countess de Raconska, who on Monday night shot Willie Coad. The conversation was carried on through a little hole in the door of a cell in Moyamensing Prison, where the lady is confined.

BUFFALO, March 26.--The wife of Oran Farrell, at Wellsville, Allegany County, shot her two children, one aged 8 and the other 12 years, and then shot herself, this morning. One of the children is dead and the other dying. The woman is fatally hurt. She had been adjudged insane.
Mr. A.A. SARGENT has been appointed to the position made vacant by the death of Mr. HUNT, late Minister to Russia. The transfer from Berlin to St. Petersburg can hardly be considered as a promotion.

For some time Mr. Alexander F. Roberts, 64 years old, Secretary of the Bookbinders' Provident Association, has occupied a desk in the office of Mr. H.W. Hubbard, a mechanical engineer and draughtsman, at No. 23 Park-row, Room No. 8. Yesterday morning when Mr. Hubbard opened the windows in his once, at about 9:30 o'clock, he was surprised to see the Secretary's desk in a great state of disorder.
Miss Rosalba Beecher will make her first appearance with the McCault Opera Company this evening, at the Casino, as Violetta, in "The Merry War."

Gaetano Gambordelo, Antoine Sauerntino, and Vincennes Guitung, Italian laborers, complained to Mayor Edson yesterday that they and 91 other Italians had been swindled by Henry Zander Co., intelligence agents at No. 16 Greenwich-street, through one J.O. Boitano, a fellowcountryman, at present in this city and employed...
TROY, N.Y., March 26.--John McFeely, of Stephentown, was killed this afternoon by a kick from a horse which he had purchased yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 26.--In cattle to-day there was a somewhat freer movement than on the preceding days of the week. If there was any additional improvement it was infinitesimal. That there was not a further shrinkage in values was because of the unexpected decrease in the receipts.

The Democrats of Newtown, Long Island, at their town convention yesterday nominated Thomas F. McGowan, the present incumbent, for Supervisor, and William O'Gorman for Town Clerk. Upon the suggestion of the Law and Order Society of Woodside, William Kirkpatrick was nominated for Justice of the Peace. This nomination was received with much dissatisfaction by the rank and file of the party.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26.--A special dispatch to the Times from Huntingdon, Penn., says: "The committee appointed to obtain the right of way through this county for the Seaboard, Pennsylvania and Western Railroad...
LONDON, March 26.--M. Gounod, the composer, has completed the oratorio "Morset Vita," a sequel to "The Redemption," for production at the Birmingham Music Festival in 1885.

William Mock, of Mount Vernon, Westchester County, visited Castle Garden yesterday, said he was a widower, 36 years old, and that he wanted a wife. Superintendent Jackson referred Mock to Detective Groden, who took him into the Labor Bureau.

CINCINNATI, March 26.--Petitions were circulated on 'Change to-day calling for a massmeeting to be held in Music Hall to consider means for making the criminal courts more efficient. The indignation over the result of the Berner murder trial continues, and it is that verdict that has led to the present movement.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 26.--The flood in the country along the river continues to be the theme of absorbing interest. On Tuesday night, near midnight, a crevasse appeared in the levee at the P. Guidry plantation, on the west bank of the river, in St. James. This morning the break was about 100 feet wide in a levee which is 12 feet high, with the water within a few inches of its...

The family of James McCormack, alias George Hendricks, the Communist, will not permit the order with which he was connected to make a public demonstration at his funeral. His parents are strict Catholics, and they desire to have him quietly and peaceably interred in the Catholic cemetery. Justus Schwab and Mr. Folan, of the Irish World, were among the members...

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 26.--The Republican City Convention was held this afternoon and resulted in the nomination of Emil Wallber, a prominent German, for Mayor; Lem Ellsworth for City Controller, C.W. Milbraith for City Treasurer, and R.H. Luscombe, City Attorney.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 26.--The Senate this afternoon unanimously passed the House bill increasing the powers of the Railway Commission. It is in substance as follows: The courts shall have jurisdiction to enforce by proper decrees, injunctions, and orders, the rulings, orders, and regulations affecting public rights...
F.A. Beman, a veteran of the war of 1812, died in the Sailors' Snug Harbor, at NewBrighton, Staten Island, on Monday, at the age of 96 years.

NEW-HAVEN, March 26.--It is reported from Birmingham that important revelations may be expected in the Rose Ambler case, and that an arrest will soon be made upon evidence that will insure the holding of the arrested party for trial.

Senator Edmunds has returned from his trip to South Carolina, but he has not reached the capital soon enough to overtake some criticisms that have been made on his account in regard to the employment of the United States steamer Yantic as a conveyance for his family from Nassau, New-Providence, to Charleston.

The gross earnings of the Shenandoah Valley Railroad last year were $854,415 and the operating expenses were $662,157, leaving the net earnings $192,257. This, however, was not sufficient to pay interest charges. A very large increase in the passenger and freight traffic is reported.

Catherine Ross, a white woman of 40 years and great avoirdupois, keeps a boarding and lodging house for colored sailors, stewards, and cooks at No. 161 Leonard-street, which is known as the "Sailors' Welcome Home." The place is in one of the worst neighborhoods in the city.

BANGOR, Me., March 26.--Mrs. Chase, of Foxcraft, who has been reported to have confessed her lately deceased husband's connection with the celebrated Barron case, in conversation to-day denied emphatically the stories afloat. She says she had never made any such statement and has no knowledge whatever of the affair. It is generally believed that the reports of the disclosures are purely sensational.

UTICA, N.Y., March 26.--A call for a Republican caucus to be held on Saturday noon has been issued. Nineteen delegates to the Congressional District Convention will be elected by 12 wards of Utica. At the same time delegates will be chosen to the Assembly District Conventions.

BOSTON, March 26.--The Commercial Cable Company, which owns the new MackayBennett cables, to-day completed the purchase of the land necessary for a landing at Rockport, on the north shore, at a point known as Cape Hedge, at the southerly end of the town, nearly opposite Thatcher's Island.

BANGOR, Me., March 26.--Mrs. Chase, of Foxcraft, who has been reported to have confessed her lately deceased husband's connection with the celebrated Barron case, in conversation to-day denied emphatically the stories afloat. She says she had never made any such statement and has no knowledge whatever of the affair. It is generally believed that the reports of the disclosures are purely sensational.

Mrs. Harvey S. Dennison, of No. 100 Fourth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was shopping at Macy's, at Sixth-avenue and Fourteenth-street, yesterday afternoon. Beside her stood a respectable-looking old woman, decently attired in black and wearing a fur-lined circular.

Two bright little children, May Florence Ames, 4 years old, and Mary Flynn, 3 years old, both living in Union-court, an alley running out of University-place, near Twelfthstreet, stood on the west side of University-place about 6 o'clock last evening.

CHICAGO, March 27.--The charge was published here this morning that the Nickel Plate and Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Companies had contracted to take a consignment of 500,000 bushels of wheat from Chicago to New-York at 12 cents per hundred, a cut of 2 cents below the regular rates.

John Jergens, a tall, fine-looking German, who sings in the chorus at the Metropolitan Opera-house, was before Justice Gorman, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, to answer a complaint of abandonment by his wife, Anna M. Jergens.

John Benson and John Miller, two smart young thieves, were arrested yesterday afternoon for robbing the residence of Col. Eighty-two head of Jersey cattle, imported by T.S. Cooper, of Linden Grove, Coopersburg, Penn., were sold at auction by Peter C. Kellogg Co., at the American Horse Exchange, yesterday. Some very good animals were offered and excellent prices were received.

Fifty graduates of Phillips Exeter Academy ate dinner last evening at the Hotel Brunswick, under the watchful eye of Artemas H. Holmes, and listened afterward to speeches upon the needs and plans of the academy. George S. Hale, of Boston, spoke for the Trustees of the academy.

A number of the Iroquois on the Caughnawaga Reserve assembled at one of the farmhouses the other day, at which various matters of local interest were discussed. One of the old chiefs, Asenasse, took the occasion to deliver a ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 27.--Gov. Waller has created another sensation at the Capitol, this time by sitting down upon a couple of members of the lower house of the Legislature. He hasn't been on the best of terms with the members of the august body which makes laws for our State.

WHEELING, West Va., March 27.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Pittsburg, Wheeling and Kentucky Railroad Company was held this afternoon to hear the report of the President for the past year. The gross earnings for 1883 were $124,511.41; operating ...

The special Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer is anxious to examine William McDonald, the contractor, who is in the Albany County jail for contempt of the State Senate, because he refused to answer questions put to him by an investigating committee of that body.

At a meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration, yesterday, the Secretary read a communication from the United States Consul at Cienfuegos, Cuba, in regard to some immigrants who were said to have been decoyed on board a vessel and sent to a sugar plantation, ...

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 27.--James Barrett, age 6, was fatally shot this afternoon by a 13-year old boy who was firing at rats in the yard of a tenement-house.

The Brooklyn Library held its twentysixth annual meeting last evening at the rooms in Montague-street. The annual report was read by the President, Mr. W.A. White. The circulation of books for the year was 103,669, being a gain of 8,375 volumes over the preceding year.

Mr. Blair's bill to extend national aid to the common schools of the country has now been discussed by the Senate for eight days, and not even a vote on any of the amendments offered has been had. A meeting of the stockholders of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad has been called for April 17 for the purpose of voting on a proposition to increase the preferred stock to $10,830,000. The amount of new stock proposed to be issued is $2,217,000.

The story of the steamer Chateau Margaux shows how little danger there is that a vessel disabled in the track of commerce between New-York and England would escape the notice of other vessels for a longer period than a day or two.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 27.--The news of the defeat of the whisky relief measure in the House to-day caused considerable excitement on 'Change and among St. Louis liquor men. It was ardently hoped by the friends of the bill that it would pass, as the impression prevailed that the amount of money at its back would be sufficient to capture all the votes necessary.

DUBLIN, March 27.--The Freeman's Journal, of which Mr. E. Dwyer Gray, member of Parliament, is editor, publishes an interview with Mr. Parnell. The House of Lords, Mr. Parnell believes, will reject the new franchise bill. The result of this will be a dissolution of Parliament and an appeal to the country.

The Board of Managers of the Cotton Exchange yesterday postponed the sale of Jacob P. Billups's seat indefinitely. The seat was to have been sold at auction to-day, and the postponement is in consequence of the injunction procured by Mr. Billups's counsel.

EASTON, Penn., March 27.--Gov. Pattison has sent a quick and brief answer to the letter of John Dillman's counsel asking a stay of proceedings and the appointment of an expert commission to investigate the murderer's sanity. The Governor says: "I decline to interfere." Dillman's execution will take place in the jail on April 8.

BALTIMORE, March 27.--The Maryland Historical Society celebrated to-night the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Maryland, to-day being the anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims in St. Mary's County. J.H.B. Latrobe, President of the society, presided.

ROME, Ga., March 27.--The murder of a 12-year-old boy near the Trion factory is a subject of much mystery. Henry Foster, the son of a photographer at that place, went out hunting on Tuesday. That night he failed to return home. Search was instituted, in which over 100 men joined, and no clue could be obtained to the ...
NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 27.--The weather to-day was cloudy, but pleasant, and the track good.

McPHERSON, Kan., March 27.--Last Friday a man named Herold opened a saloon in Canton, this county, in defiance of the law. On Monday he got into a row with one of his drunken customers, and was shot by the constable. The women of the place raided his saloon on Tuesday and poured his liquors into the street, and he now realizes that prohibition prohibits.

NASHVILLE, March 27.--The case of Col. William Spence, charged with the murder of Col. Edward S. Wheat, was called in the Criminal Court to-day. There were 35 witnesses called for the State and 46 for the defense. The AttorneyGeneral announced that the State was ready, but the counsel for the defendant asked a postponement on account of the absence of material witnesses. The trial was accordingly set for May 5.

PARIS, March 27.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. de Lanessan's interpellation in regard to Madagascar came up for debate. Prime Minister Ferry spoke at some length in explanation and defense of the Government's policy in Madagascar.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27.--The general feeling among persons interested in the wheat trade is that the downward movement in prices which has been in progress during the past 10 days insures a speedy reduction of the immense stocks which have been held in this country during the Winter.
FARMINGTON, N.H., March 27.--This town, which for years has given a large Democratic majority, elected to-day the entire Republican ticket, after a highly exciting contest.

CINCINNATI, March 27.--James Bohne, one of the jurors who so excited the Judge by their verdict in the Berner murder case, was threatened by a mob last night and would have met with violence had not policemen taken him from his house by a back way.

MARIETTA, Ga., March 27.--While court was in session to-day a pistol was seen protruding from the pocket of a spectator who had recently returned from Texas. Sheriff Coryell took him before the Grand Jury, and within 15 minutes they returned a true bill, and within 15 minutes more a jury was impaneled, the prisoner convicted, and fined $25 and costs. He boarded the first train for Texas.

The performance of "Iolanthe," (by the Ladies' Dramatic Union,) which is to be given on Saturday evening, has awakened a wide-spread interest in fashionable circles. ALBANY, N.Y., March 27.--The officers on the tow-boat Cayuga, the first vessel through from New-York this season, reported on their arrival this morning that a dangerous bar had formed at the head of Backenplant Bar, a few miles below this city. Soundings made in a tenfoot freshet showed but six feet of water.
Ignatius Pollock, Administrator of the estate of the late Samuel Pollock, has caused the arrest of Isaac H. Dreifuss, who is charged with stealing $11,000, while employed in Samuel Pollock's store.
BALTIMORE, March 27.--Capt. Hagemann, of the North-German Lloyd steam-ship Baltimore, which arrived at this port to-day from Bremen, died and was buried at sea on the voyage.

LONDON, March 27.--Gen. Graham telegraphed this morning to the following effect: The evening and night were cool. Reveille was sounded this morning at 3:30, and as quickly as possible the troops were got in readiness to advance on Tamanieb. The cavalry are in front; the infantry follow in echelon of brigade squares, with the guns between the brigades.

SWANTON, Vt., March 27.--Sheriffs Pearson and Atherton, with a posse, raided the Lake Champlain fishing grounds here. Three fishermen were arrested for illegal fishing and two 40rod seines seized. Resistance was made, and several shots were exchanged. The fishermen were held for trial this afternoon. The affair has caused much excitement in Alburg and vicinity, where many fishermen live.

The town of Felicity, Ohio, is just now enjoying something in the nature of a sensation. There lives in the village an aged colored couple by the name of Bright. With the aged people lives a little grandchild, Lizzie Huggins.

A Massachusetts State Democratic Club is to be organized at a dinner to be given in Boston on Saturday, April 12.
CATAWISSA, Penn., March 27.--Henry Wilson, Isaac Hern, and Charles Smith, lumbermen, were fatally injured yesterday afternoon by being caught under a large tree which another chopper was felling.

John Lowry, Jr., Harry W. Brown, and Frederick Addinsell, comprising the firm of Lowry, Brown Addinsell, importers of woolens at No. 23 East Fourteenth-street, made an assignment yesterday to David H. Brown, giving preferences to him and to George W. Addinsell.

SYNAPUXANT BAY, Md., March 24.--This bay is the largest of the system of bays lying between the ocean and the mainland and between the Delaware and the Chesapeake Bay. Winter Quarters is under the beach, about eight miles from the main, and affords an excellent harbor for the small sailing craft mostly in use on this bay.

TRENTON, March 27.--Speaker Stoney, who is generally credited with having brought about the Democratic caucus of the Assembly that yesterday decided to pass a vote of censure on Assemblyman Fish for a defiance of the Speaker's order to sit down, took it all back to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 27.--During the severe storm last evening a boulder of 30 tons rolled down the side of the mountain that skirts the track of the New-Haven and Northampton Railroad between Shelburne Falls and Conway Mass.
