ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 27,--Gov. McLane has appointed George B. Milligan Secretary of State vice R.C. Hallyday, who has resigned on account of ill health, to take effect May 1.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 27.--The Mine Commissioners appointed to revise the laws governing mining coal in the anthracite coal region held its second session in this city to-day, the first meeting of the commission having been held in Mauch Chunk some weeks ago.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27.--Samuel P. Burt, one of the wealthiest citizens of Milwaukee, was married last night to a young woman named Elizabeth Thompson, who was, until quite recently, a servant in the family of the gentleman who is now her husband.

Lobdell.--In error to the Circuit Court of Rhode Island. Dismissed per stiplation. No. 282--Alexander Cochrane et al., appellants, vs. Badische Anilin and Soda Fabrik. Argument continued.

TROY, N.Y., March 27.--Henry S. Church, the defaulting City Chamberlain, who fled from this city on Feb. 4, leaving a deficiency of $77,000, was arrested in New-York last night and brought to this city this morning. He was arraigned in the Police Court and held to await the action of the Grand Jury.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27.--In the suit of Robert E. Jennings against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company for $10,000 damages for injuries sustained in a collision at Western Crossing, a jury in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon gave a verdict for $2,500 in favor of the plaintiff.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 27.--Tuesday night an affray occurred on the reservation of Tuscarora Indians, 12 miles west of Lockport, between two Indians named Alva Hewitt and Frank Chew, which will probably result in the death of Hewitt from his injuries.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 27.--Col. Mapleson's opera company has subscribed $2,300 for Lombardelli's widow. Col. Mapleson gave $600, Patti $150, and Gerster $1,000.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., March 27.--The death of five negro children from eating pork, on a plantation in Glynn County, 12 miles from Brunswick, creates considerable excitement in that locality. The children lingered several hours in great pain. For some unaccountable reason the negroes refuse to tell where they procured the pork.

Mr. Miller, of California, reported favorably to the Senate to-day, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, the joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to offer a reward of $25,000 for rescuing or ascertaining the fate of the Greely expedition.

WICHITA FALLS, Texas, March 27.--A daring attempt to rob J.G. James's bank was made yesterday afternoon by Charles E. Bagley, Wiley Hayes, Frank Parmenter, and John Kinkaid, a Texas ranger, the last named acting with the robbers for the purpose of trapping them.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 27.--Goldwin Smith was interviewed in this city to-day concerning the relations between Canada and the United States. From having been partners in business, Ernst F. Hoffman and Justus H. Rudolph became opponents of one another in litigation. Rudolph was a painter in oils, and, prior to his dispute with Hoffman, had produced a pretty picture of a white setter dog for him.

Lesher, of Michigan, Treasurer, and John J. Geghan, of Cincinnati, Librarian. VicePresidents for each State were also elected.

SAN ANGELA, Texas, March 27.--The stage from Burnet was stopped by robbers on Tuesday, the driver robbed, and the letters opened. The thieves built a fire and awaited the other stage, but fell asleep and let it pass unmolested. On Tuesday night the stage from Abilene was stopped two miles from here by two horsemen, and the mail ransacked. A female passenger named Morris was robbed of a small sum of money.

BALTIMORE, March 27.--The body of John Haugh, for years a prominent contractor for street paving, was found to-day floating in the Patapsco River, near Spring Garden. He was about 60 years of age, and was a local politician of considerable influence. He had amassed considerable means and had many friends. The manner of his death has not yet been determined, whether by accident or suicide.

The Republicans of the town of Oyster Bay, Long Island, at their convention yesterday nominated for Supervisor John L. Bogert; Collector, William F. Johnson, and for Justice of the Peace, Charles Colyer.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Leave of absence for two months, on Surgeon's certificate of disability, has been granted First Lieut. Oscar T. Crosby, Corps of Engineers; First Lieut. P. Henry Ray, Eighth Infantry, Acting Signal Officer, has been ordered to proceed to Vienna, Austria, to attend the international polar conference to be held in that city on April 17.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--It was feared to-day that the Countess Amelia de Raconska would become insane if she was not speedily released from jail. The prison keepers let her out of her cell in the morning and gave her the freedom ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 27.--The members of the Cleveland Oil Exchange have had under consideration for some time a proposition to discontinue the Exchange. Letters were addressed to members living out of the city to ascertain their views, and out of 51 answers received up to date 50 favor closing up. A meeting will be held Saturday to determine whether the Exchange will continue or wind up its affairs.

The differences of opinion that have characterized the meetings of the Rapid Transit Commissioners for several weeks culminated yesterday in the resignation of Daniel Drake Smith and George H. Byrd as members of the board. Mr. Smith has been President since the organization of the commission last December.

A team of horses owned by Isaac W. Blaine, of Preakness, was standing at the Post Office in Paterson yesterday afternoon, when E. W. Blaine, a brother of the owner, got in the wagon. A sudden movement of the team caused him to lose his balance, and he was pitched forward, with the seat, falling between the horses.

ROCKLAND, Me., March 27.--The revenue cutter Levi Woodbury arrived here in tow of the Dallas this afternoon with loss of her propeller. This will complete the cruising season of the Woodbury, which, in saving property and rendering assistance, nearly equals last year's remarkable record. The Woodbury will be repaired at Portland.

PHILADELPHLA, March 28.--Proof has been found to-day to sustain the theory that the man whose headless trunk, tied up in a bag, was found in Wissahickon Creek yesterday was murdered. The developments to-day at first indicated that the body is that of Frederick Stahl, who has not been seen by any of his friends since Oct. 28, 1883. LONDON, March 28.--At the Liverpool spring meeting to-day the Grand National Steeplechase Handicap of 1,000 guineas was won by Mr. H.F. Boyd's 6-year-old b.g. Voluptuary. Mr. M.A. Maher's 6-year-old b.m. Frigate came in second, and Capt. Fisher's 5-year-old Roquefort third. There were 15 starters.

DENVER, Col. March 28.--Probably 50 buildings of all sorts were unroofed by yesterday's wind-storm. About midnight a portion of the rear wall of the Lindell Hotel on the west side was blown in, but the guests, having been warned of the danger, escaped injury.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 28.--The shops of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad here were burned to-night. The building was entirely destroyed, with its contents.

HEMPSTEAD, Long Island, March 28.--A weak-minded old bachelor in this village, Valentine Dorlon, drowned himself this morning in a brook where the water was not six inches deep. Dorlon was 60 years old, and he has lived here since his birth. He had saved a little money by working hard as a stone mason, and his father died some years ago and left him a few thousand dollars more.

BANGOR, Me., March 28.--The Commercial of this city will to-morrow publish the opinion of ex-Chief-Justice Appleton on the proposed constitutional prohibitory amendment, which will have an influence not only on the temperance question, but on politics in general, in this State. Judge Appleton retired last Fall at the age of 75, after having served 40 years as Justice of the Supreme Bench of the State, 20 years of which time he had been Chief-Justice.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 28.--The Ohio woman's Christian Temperance Union, on the defeat of the second amendment last Fall, sent petitions to all parts of the State asking for a resubmission of the amendment in the Fall of 1885, which is the earliest date the Constitution will allow.

LONDON, March 28.--Prince Leopold, the Duke of Albany, fourth and youngest son of Queen Victoria, died suddenly in a fit at 2 o'clock this morning at Cannes. He had gone to Cannes only a few days ago for the sake of his health. Nothing serious, however, had been anticipated. He was looking fairly well, and had been taking part in the festivities of the place.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 28.--Advices from Fargo received late last night state that Michael Ohner, a prominent and wealthy citizen of Dayton, Ohio, who was recently captured by the Indians while prospecting in the Turtle Mountains in Dakota, will not be liberated by his captors until he engages never to return and to remove all the machinery and men he took with him with a view to mining.

LONDON, March 29.--The Berlin correspondent of the Daily News says: "Mr. Sargent will resign the post at Berlin and refuses the St. Petersburg mission. It is evident that his appointment to the latter post was only a previouly arranged formality to facility his recall."

SUMTER, S.C., March 28.--The murderers' cell in the jail at Sumter is empty again. Its last occupant was Joseph Howard, who was hanged to-day for the murder of Simon Gaskins 12 months ago. The scene of the tragedy was the Furman plantation, near the Post Office of Providence, in this county. The murder was one of the most revolting in its inspiration and the most cowardly in its accomplishment known...

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, March 28.--The sealing steam-ship Aurora has just arrived from the ice fields with 28,000 prime seals worth $60,000, all taken in five days. The voyage lasted only 18 days. The Aurora is the first arrival from the sealing grounds. She reports that the Neptune, with 85,000 prime harps, and the Hector, with 25,000, are following.

MORRISTOWN, N.Y., March 28.--The St. Lawrence International Camp Ground Association of Morristown is to be made a stock company with a capital of $20,000. Over $6,000 has already been subscribed. The association assigned last November, when the indebtedness was $19,000. The association will be placed on a solid basis and all debts paid.

Cisco gives to his son, John Ashfield Cisco, his country seat Castleton Heights, on Staten Island, together with all houses, carriages, farming and gardening utensils, household furniture, books pictures, and other personal property.

Prince Leopold George Duncan Albert, Duke of Albany, Earl of Clarence, and Baron Arklow, the youngest son of Queen Victoria, was the most intellectual and popular of all the Queen's sons, and his death has cast a gloom over the entire Kingdom of Great Britain. He was the youngest but one of Queen Victoria's children, his sister Beatrice being his junior.

WINSTON, N.C., March 28.--Dr. Whitfield, of Covington, one of the most prominent physicians and citizens of Randolph County, this State, was drowned in Rochingham County yesterday. His body was swept down one of the swollen streams of that county and found between a lot of drift-wood last evening.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 28.--A freight train on the Northern pacific Raod was thrown from the rails within 12 miles of Miles City, Montana, on Wednesday night. Six cars were wrecked. The engineer was slightly wounded, but the fireman escaped by jumping from the engine.

The special Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday handed an indictment to Judge Barrett. District Attorney Olney subsequently had a long conference with the Judge. No information respecting the subject of the indictment could be ascertained, the District Attorney and his subordinates resolutely refusing to speak about it. It was rumored to be against Sheriff Davidson.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 28.--The indictments against Henry W. Moore, the managing editor, and Florence White, a reporter, of the Post-Dispatch, for abstracting court records, were nolle prossed in the Criminal Court to-day. These indictments grew out of the publication in the Post-Dispatch of the investigation of the Grand Jury, last Fall, into the gambling ring, and caused a great sensation at the time.

The woman who, when arrested on Thursday at Macy's for stealing the purse of Mrs. Harvey S. Dennison, gave her name as Jane Haskins, and who claimed to be respectable, was arraigned for examination before Justice Gorman, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday.

DETROIT, Mich., March 28.--The Directors of the Grand Rapids and Indiana Railroad met at Grand Rapids to-day. President Hughart announced that the suit with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, involving $3,000,000, had been amicably settled, and that the Grand Rapids and Indiana bond coupons of 1883 and 1884, payment of which had been stopped by the suit, would be paid April 1.

BOSTON, March 28.--William H. Foster, believed to be the oldest bank Cashier in point of service in America, resigned his position to-day in the Asiatic National Bank, after a continuous service since 1829.

Louise Lindstrom, 23 years old, of No. 23 Hamilton-street, while walking in Christiestreet last evening was accosted by a man, a stranger to the girl, who made improper proposals to her. LIMA, March 29, via Galveston.--There was a formal exchange of treaties yesterday between Peru and Chili, Ministers Zaldivar and Navoa representing the two countries. They afterward lunched with the President of Peru. The Chilian iron-clad Cochrane saluted the Peruvian flag in Callao Harbor.

CINCINNATI, March 30--1:45 A.M.--The scenes during this memorable night have been indescribable. No mob could have been more poorly equipped or lack more in organization and leadership than this one, nor does it seem that the military and police have had any settled plan or competent leadership.

The sanitary authorities are investigating a complaint said to have been made by a discharged employe of Charles O'Brien, an undertaker, of No. 874 Second-avenue. The Queen is to be congratulated on her prosperity as a landlady. As proprietor of the Duchy of Lancaster estates it might have been supposed that she, in common with other landowners, would have felt the effect of agricultural distress. As a matter of fact, though, instead of losing money, her rentals are gradually rising.

John Sandford, a Paterson lawyer, was arrested yesterday in that city, by Detective Jacobs, of the Pension Office, at Washington, charged with having collected $72 of pension money belonging to James Smith, of Lanestreet, Paterson, N.J. He was taken before United States Commissioner Whitehead.

James N. Rice, a member of the firm of Sanford Smith Co., dry goods commission merchants at No. 130 Church-street, died in the Rossmore Hotel at 3 P.M. yesterday. He had been a sufferer from consumption for several months, and his death was not unexpected. He was about 62 years old, and leaves a widow and a son in Utica. The body will be removed to that city for interment to-morrow.

Twenty-five cabs, the first installment for the cheap cab service which the New-York Cab Company (Limited) is about to establish in NewYork, will be placed upon the streets to-morrow. The service is modeled upon the London system, and has never before been tried in this country. Each cab is licensed and entitled to a place at any hack-stand, but it is not intended that they shall be so stationed.

In September last all Wall-street went to discussing the corn crop. The Anti-Chicken Stealing Society of Hoboken was in a sad and solemn condition at the beginning of the week. A curious exhibition is now being held at Vienna, consisting of the goods and chattels of Josephine Gallmeyer, the popular actress, whose death occurred about two months ago. Two rooms in the residence of Mme. Gallmeyer contain the articles exhibited, in one of which only costumes are displayed.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--Edward Lewis, (colored Coalitionist,) of Chalk Level, Va., was the first witness examined by the Danville subcommittee to-day. He described a disturbance which took place in his precint. Jesse Keen, a Democrat, threatened that the colored people would be shot down like dogs and driven off like Indians if they did not vote with the Democrats. Keen said the Danville people would rule by ballet or bullet.

CINCINNATI, March 29.--The attempt to lynch the murderers in the County Jail last night resulted in the killing of five men and the wounding, so far as is now known, of 32 more. Probably as many more were hurt, but not so badly as to prevent them from walking or being carried home by friends.

Mr. Rafael Joseffy gave the third of a series of four concerts at Steinway Hall yesterday evening. It took the shape of a piano recital, and is to be referred to as by far the most successful of the three entertainments in which he has thus far appeared.

UTICA, N.Y., March 29--The Utica caucuses to-day returned Stalwart delegations to the Congressional District Convention and Assembly District Convention. This result was achieved by Stalwart trickery and Democratic votes on one side, and indifference on the part of the opposition.

The contracts for the building of the new Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, in Fiftyfirst-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, were signed yesterday. The front of the church will be 81 feet and it will run back 100 feet. It will be of stone and will seat 1,500 persons. The roof is to be in position by next October. The cost will be about $100,000, and cash will be paid for everything.

ALBANY, March 29.--The fight between the Draper and anti-Draper factions was continued in the Republican City Convention today. The contest was not so stubborn as at Knowerville yesterday, for it was admitted that, under any condition, the friends of the State Committeeman were in the minority, and the only doubt was about the way his opponents would use their power.

A whale measuring 50 feet 9 inches long and 12 feet 4 inches through the body from back to breast, and with a tail 9 feet across, got ashore on Saturday last on the south inside shore of Pungoteague Creek, Accomac County, Va. Five Fishermen attacked the monster by shooting and chopping it.

The demand for standard silver dollars on the part of banks and large manufacturing establishments is steadily increasing. Last week $75,000 in silver coin was taken out of the SubTreasury in amounts ranging from $300 upward. Individuals and corporations employing large numbers of men complain that it is growing more and more difficult to obtain one and two-dollar bills, and they are therefore compelled to pay off their help largely in silver.

Dr. James Kennedy died yesterday morning of apoplexy at his residence, No. 361 West Fifty-first-street, in the eighty-fifth, year of his age. He was born in Scotland, but his parents came to America when he was a year old, and settled in Castleton, Vt.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., March 29.--During a high wind on Thursday a terrible prairie fire broke out in Castleton Township, which burned over territory 10 miles in length, destroying everything in its path, including houses, barns, stock, grain, One man lost a large quantity of grain and 200 head of sheep. The loss will exceed $15,000.

LONDON, March 29.--The Prince of Wales has gone to Cannes to accompany home the body of his brother. It will be pleced in a coffin to-night, and will start for England to-morrow. The Queen and the Princess Beatrice went to Claremont House, near Esher, to condole with the widow.

The quotation bulletined was 8 3/8 cents, which was one-eighth of a cent below yesterday's figure.

NEW-SMYRNA, Fla., March 16.--The latest arrival at the Ocean House is a dapper blonde, of middle age, from Chicago. He struck this place one evening after dark, and made his first appearance at the supper table. He introduced himself to all the other guests without waiting for the intervention of the landlord, and in five minutes was on as familiar terms with everybody as though he had been here a month.

The chief external charac teristic of the French Basques is the extraordinary skill with which they walk on stilts. PITTSBURG, Penn., March 29.--Dr. J.H. Zukertort, the champion chess player of the world, played 27 simultaneous games here last night with as many local chess players. The contest lasted from 8 o'clock until nearly 2 this morning. The score for Zukertort at the finish was: Won 22 games; lost. 3: drawn. 2. On Monday the champion will play simultaneously 13 games blindfolded.

CINCINNATI, March 30.--The mob, at 11 o'clock to-night, began to scatter from the vicinity of the jail, going in different directions in Squads. What the movement means is not known. If this is an organized movement serious mischief, for which the authorities are not prepared is probably intended.

EASTON, Penn., March 30.--The storm last night was terrible and did much damage. Barns were unroofed, fences blown down, and trees uprooted. An advertising board, 10 by 70 feet, lies broken at Walnut and Seventh streets. A rope-walk, 1,200 feet long, was wrecked, except the brick end of the building. The loss will amount to $2,500.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30.--Gov. Hoadly's official advices to-night are such that he has ordered every military organization in the State to report to Cincinnati immediately. They number in all 17 regiments and 5 batteries.

DENVER, Col., March 29.--At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce and Board of Trade last evening, the building of the Denver and New-Orleans Railroad over the Canadian River, in Texas, to connect with the Fort Worth and Denver Railroad, was unanimously indorsed. Contracts will be executed, and work will be pushed forward immediately.

CAIRO, March 30.--A rumor is current that Gen. Gordon surrendered Khartoum some days ago to a Sheik representing El Mahdi, and that three days afterward he and his secretary, Col. Stewart, were arrested and imprisoned, The Vice-Consul of France, Greece, and Austria were not molested...

Some 10 or 12 days ago Seffor Sebiani, a Spanish gentleman residing at Cadiz, met in the streets of Tangier a little Moor boy, who, although the son of a slave, had become free through the death of his master. Touched with compassion at his forlorn condition, Seffor Sebiani offered to take the boy into his service.

People in Burmah get along very com-- fortable wearing their tatooing and a few yards of muslin wound around themselves. The Burmese bandmen, who make music for Barnum's sacred white elephant, were landed from the City of Richmond yesterday in the ulsters of civilization.

PROVIDENCE, March 30.--The schooner Ambrose H. Knight, mackerel catcher, of Booth Bay, was towed into Block Island harbor to-day by the steamer Rescue. Six miles south-west of the island this morning, in the gale, the Knight lost her head-gear and sprung her foremast. Capt. Lyman Farmer was badly hurt by the main-boom falling upon him.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 30.--The Republican primaries last night for the election of delegates to the State Convention which sends delegates to the National Convention, resulted in a sweeping victors for the Filly faction, they carrying 25 of the 28 wards in the city. The only satisfaction the "silk stockings" have is in beating Filly himself as a delegate, his own ward going against him.

The action of the militia in charging a crowd a little after noon is being severely criticised. An eye-witness of the affair says about 100 men and boys were collected on the north side of Canal, between Main and Walnut, and the boys, to amuse themselves, began throwing stones into the water.

NORWICH, N.Y., March 30.--The recent performance of the Rev. Joseph Cook at Keene, N.H., has brought to light a performance of his while on his way to lecture in this village last January.
OWEGO, March 30.--Frederick E. Sayer's grocery was entered last night by burglars, who broke open the safe and stole $600.

At the meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday, delegates from the Sandy Hook Pilots' Union were admitted and introduced a resolution, which was adopted, denouncing the politicians led by Senator Daly in the effort to tamper with the liberty of the pilots of the port by introducing Assembly bill No. 101, to reduce the Sandy Hook pilotage fees, which, if it became...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 30.--A young man named Bert Cratzenberg, who lived near Oakwood, took a strap from the harness of his horse and hanged himself. It is supposed that an unrequited affection was the cause of the suicide.

The brighter weather of the week brought an improved movement in general trade, but the immediate industrial situation has grown worse rather than better. The iron markets of the country are quiet and practically unchanged. Chicago reports an increasing demand, but otherwise monotony is the rule.

The virtual confiscation of the property of the Roman Propaganda and the suppression of the institution will hardly prove to be a judicious measure on the part of the Italian Government. The Propaganda is a sort of combined theological seminary and missionary society.

The burning of the Court-house was not anticipated. All the plans of defense looked to the guarding of the jail and the protection of a score of murderera who ought to have been legally hanged long ago from the fury of the mob. The broad Court-house square was left open to the rioters and was their gathering place.

BUFFALO, March 30.--The Committee of Transportation of the Merchants' Exchange of this city has issued a circular to merchants and other, requesting them to report any discrimination in railway, lake, or canal charges...

The Fourth Regiment of militia, 275 strong and composed of companies from Xenia, Marysville, Dayton, Miamisburg and Hamilton, clearly showed the white feather. Arriving at the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton station early in the evening, they were ordered to remain there until further orders were received. When the riot alarm was sounded, orders were sent to them to move up Ninth-street and join the Fourteenth Regiment near the jail.

J. McGiveny, the saloon-keeper of Second-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, who enjoyed the luxury of backing Salmi Morse in his "On the Yellowstone" at the Cosmopolitan Theatre, was a defendant in the Seventh District Court on Saturday, being sued by James Solomon, one of his ushers, for $10.50 for services.

The most heart-rendering scenes have been occurring at the Morgue and the City Hospital all day. Families missed one of their number at the breakfast table. A search for the missing one in many instances resulted in his being found either at the hospital or the deadhouse.

CLEVELAND, March 30.--During a heavy thunder-storm at Marion last night John Bush and William Hyatt were killed by lightning. Both were unmarried men and were working on a farm near Owen. They were standing on a porch when struck, though the house was not injured in the least. No wounds were found on their bodies.

CLEVELAND, March 30.--A badly mixed wreck occurred last evening on the Wheeling and Lake Erie Road, near Massillon. A freight train was going at the rate of 25 miles an hour when it met another that was moving slowly. One engine was rendered almost worthless, and the other was badly damaged.

While it is impossible to get a clear and complete impression of the lamentable occurences in Cincinnati since Friday night, there are some facts which stand out plainly. The chief of these is that the failure of justice in the Berner case justified the deepest indignation.

CLEVELAND, March 30.--Many questions have come in from all parts of the country touching the season's outlook in this great iron centre. The invariable answer from candid authorities has been that while the iron business is not active, the indications favor a fair trade.

CINCINNATI, March 30.--The rioting continues and is exciting the gravest apprehension. A crowd was charged upon by the militia at noon and two were killed. All the afternoon there were threatening demonstrations and occasional shots were heard.

Christina Gilbert, a Swede, about 30 years-old, killed herself yesterday morning with rat poison, at Mr. Wilson's lodging-house, No. 98 Macdougal-street. She went there two weeks ago under the protection of a bar-tender, who, a few days ago, abandoned her. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning she announced that she had taken poison, and a physician, though promptly called, could not save her life.

A late edition of the Evening Post says: "At 4:30 the statement is passing from lip to lip of those identified with the mob that an attack will be made either on the city buildings or the Third-street banks to-night, with a view of drawing the militia away from the jail. The greatest precaution against danger should be taken.

Soon after breakfast-time yesterday morning a woman in a brown morning wrapper, with a red wool-knit shawl thrown over her head, crossed Twenty-first-street and knocked at the basement entrance of Mrs. Laura M. Thorp's house. A sleepy-looking messenger boy opened it bout four inches.

COLUMBUS, March 30.--Gov. Hoadly was at the telegraph office all night, and was fully informed of the situation of affairs at Cincinnati. A glance over the hundreds of telegrams received and sent by the Governor yesterday and last night exposes a conservatism almost bordering on cowardice.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30.--Lizzie Maynard, age 26, an inmate of the insane department of the Alms-house, died this morning in the hospital of that institution from the effects of carbolic acid. The poison had been used by one of the nurses and was left within reach of the patient, who, early yesterday morning, took a large dose of it.

Fifteen men and a boy or two assembled yesterday at Kessel's Hall, in Pearl-street, at the meeting of the "Joe Brady Emergency Club." The Chairman, Joseph Roche, bewailed the small attendance, claiming that it was the work of secret enemies in the other branches of the Irish movement.

DELHI, N.Y., March 30.--An old elmtree, four feet in diameter, has stood in this village ever since the place was formed. As it was hollow and badly decayed it was resolved by the authorities a few days since to cut it down.

Early in the present session of Congress it was publicly announced that the Democratic majority would make haste to investigate the Department of the Interior with special reference to the management of the General Land Office.

While Andrew Ward, who lives Bussing's farm, near Jerome Station, was searching for a hog yesterday morning, between 9 and 10 o'clock, in Dickerson's Woods, which lie east of Central-avenue, about one mile from King's Bridge, he saw a man lying half-hidden in the bushes.

Before the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher began his sermon at Plymouth Church yesterday morning he said that he was going West in a day or two to be gone for two or three weeks. Next Sunday he will preach in Indianapolis and the following Sunday in Chicago.

The programme at the Casino last night was a medley of selections from the writings of French composers. The audience was much larger than might have been expected on a night so filled with discouragement to amusementseekers, and the applause was generous and frequent. It cannot be said that last evening's concert was as interesting as the two composers...

Mr. Staunton, Secretary of the Mctropolitan Opera-house Board of Directors, sent to Mr. Gye, in London, by the steam-ship Oregon, on Saturday, the final terms of the board for the lease of the opera-house next season. The letter was in response to a request from Mr. Gye asking for information in regard to certain details which had not been made quite clear to him in the course of the negotiations.

Sir Thomas Brassey's steam yacht Sunbeam is at Portsmouth. She has been found to contain a defective piece of timber in her stern and is undergoing the necessary repairs. They will cost about $20,000.
Moses E. Stanton, 13 years old, died yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital, where he had been eight months. When he was admitted he was burned from the feet to the waist with caustic...

Prof. Fluckiger's work, so favorably commented upon by European journals, has found an able translator in Prof. F.B. Power, of the University of Wisconsin, and the value of the book is no little enhanced by the notes incorporated in the body of the text.

The sixty-fifth annual report of the Board of Directors of the New-York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb gives in detail the names of the officers and employes of the institution, with their salaries, together with the receipts and expenditures last year.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 30.--The flood, which is now standing highest against the levees south of Red River, is having disastrous effects upon them. At 10 o'clock Saturday morning the upper portion of the old Raccourci Levee, in Point Coupee Parish, west bank of the river, gave way immediately in front of A.J. Lacour's residence.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Democratic and Republican politicians are alike coy about expressing their preferences for Presidential candidates. They are indulging in reminiscences and comparisons. It is almost impossible to find anybody in Congress who is prepared to say that he is for Arthur or Logan or Blaine or Edmunds.

The new Church of St. Ambrose, at De Kalb and Tompkins avenues, Brooklyn, was solenmly blessed by Bishop John Loughlin at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. There was the usual procession, sprinkling of the walls with holy water, and singing of the litany, during which the Bishop chanted:

WATERLOO, March 29.--"There's a letter from my o1d home is Elizabeth, Penn." These words, addresed to a representative of THE TIMES, were spoken by the Rev. L.A. Lambert, Pastor of the Catholic church in this village, Father Lambert is one of the most widely and favorably known clergymen of his denomination in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--An Army Retiring Board will convene at Fort Concho, Texas, for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it. The detail for the board is as follows: Col. M.M. Blunt, Sixteenth Infantry: Major C.B. McClellan, Tenth Cavalry; Major W.H. Gardner, Surgeon Capt. W.B. Kennedy, Tenth Cavalry; Capt. B.D. Taylor, Assistant Surgeon, and Lieut. L.C. Allen, Sixteenth Infantry. Capt. E.S. Ewing, Sixteenth Infantry, will be examined by the board.

In the first fire Capt. Desmond fell dead. He was shot through the forehead. Two militiamen fell beside him--one of them fatally wounded through the left lung. The fire of the mob was returned and several men went down. The rioters staggered and drew back, and the troops, picking up their fallen comrades, carried them back to the jail.

BALTIMORE, March 30.--Archbishop Gibbons, in an interview to-day, stated that the American prelates will send to President Arthur this week letters thanking the American Government for its intercession in behalf of the American College at Rome.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 31.--It is reported and generally credited that a settlement has been elected between the respective attorneys engaged in the Fillmore will case. The attorneys refuse to make public the nature of the settlement, but do not deny that the differences have been settled.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--The Supreme Court to-day reversed the judgment of Common Pleas Court No. 4 in a suit for damages brought by James W. Lauderbach against the People's Passenger Railway Company.

Three students of the Harvard Medical School who last week passed their examinations are far from happy.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., March 31.--The decline in the oil market early to-day was due to the anticipations of the trade regarding the monthly oil report, which will be publislied tomorrow. It will show that during March 235 wells were completed in all the divisions of the Pennsylvania oil fields, with a gross daily production of 4,025 barrels.

About 20 Republican Senators met in caucus after the adjournment of the Senate this afternoon to consider the condition of business before the Senate and discuss the order in which it shall be transacted.

D.C. Robbins, of this city, has prepared an elaborate review of the drug trade of NewYork for the twenty-sixth annual report of the Chamber of Commerce.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 31.--At noon Gov. Hoadly ordered the troops en route to Cincinnati to return, the Fourth and Fourteenth Regiments to be relieved, and the rest of the troops to be held in Cincinnati till further orders. The city will be guarded till Wednesday at least.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 31.--Yester day a party of explorers in Lookout Mountain Cave were frightened by groans proceeding from a dark cavity on one side of the main hallway. Examination revealed that the groans came from two men...
GRENADA, La., March 31.--Two hundred mules have been killed in this vicinity within the last 48 hours by buffalo gnats.
President Lovejoy, of the Denver and Rio Grade Railroad, has appointed William Wagner Treasurer of that company in place of william M.Spackman, resigned.

New-ORLEANS, March 31.--The river is falling slightly at this point, but is rising in the Atchafalaya and points to the west. Another crevasse is reported at Devergess, St. James, nine miles above Guidry's. which is closed.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31.--A lively time was had in the Assembly to-night over the Woman Suffrage bill, which came up on third reading. The discussion occupied over an hour of the first portion of the evening.

LONDON, March 31.--The Prince of Wales has arrived at Cannes. The body of Prince Leopold will be conveyed to Cherbourg, where it will be taken on board the royal yacht Osborne, with the Enchantress for an escort.

ROTTERDAM, March 31.--The Chamber of Commerce of this city has forwarded a petition to the Dutch Government authorities asking them to prevent the consummation of the Congo treaty between Great Britain and Portugal.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 31.--The action of Manager Bullard, of the Union Steam-boat Company, in engaging Italians for dock laborers instead of members of the 'Longshoremen's Union, continues to be a subject of exciting interest, and riots are freely predicted.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 31.--A dozen telegraph linemen were going from one point to another on a hand car on the West Shore Road, about four miles from this city to-day, when a serious accident occurred.
TROY, N.Y., March 31.--In accordance with an agreement with the Tax-payers' Association, the Sheriff to-day dismissed 32 Deputy Sheriffs.

The Naval Appropriation bill was not taken up in the Senate to-day, but Mr. Blair's Educational bill was pushed aside by another measure.

Paul Gmehlin, a piano manufacturer, of No. 237 East Eighty-fourth-street, went to Philadelphia on Feb. 20 last to investigate a report that Col. H.W. Gray, manager for a piano company in that city, had possession of one of his instruments, and was trying to depreciate its worth and standing.

Sheriff Alexander V. Davidson was formally arraigned before Judge Barrett in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. Joseph H. Choate, Aaron J. Vanderpoel, and W. Bourke Cockran appeared for him. District Attorney Olney represented the people. Mr. Cockran said that Sheriff Davidson interposed tho plea that he had proposed last Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 31.--Out of the five district delegates elected to-day at the Grundy County Convention four are for Logan and one for Blaine. At the Ford County Convention the preference of the district delegation is for Logan, with Blaine second choice. The same was true of the delegation chosen in Stephenson County. In Edwards County delegates solid for Logan were chosen.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 31.--City Controller Barnard sent to the Common Council today his estimates for the expenditures of the city Government for 1884. The total amount is $2,102,184, which is $292,549 more than was raised last year. The increase is chiefly due to sewer construction, a large trunk sewer being now in progress under the direction of Col. George E. Waring, Jr.
LACONIA, N. H., March 31.--Thomas Samon was arraigned in court to-day for the murder of the Ruddy family and Mrs. Ford, in Laconia, last Autumn.

A good-humored and appreciative audience greeted Mr. J.K. Emmet in "Fritz in Ireland" at Niblo's Garden last evening. Although a trifle hoarse, Mr. Emmet sang with pleasing effect, as usual, and begged to be excused from encores on the ground that he had too many songs to sing to spare time for anything extra. The "Lights o' London" will succeed Fritz" next week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 31.--The disappearance of Nettie Brackett, the companion of Miss Hill, the plaintiff in the celebrated Sharom divorce case, is the main topic of conversation here. Her mother says she is in the city, but refuses to say where. She says the reason her daughter left Miss Hill was that they had quarreled. The testimony to-day was unimportant.

ALBANY, March 31.--The Senate to-day had under consideration Mr. Vedder's bill to tax gifts, legacies, and collateral inheritances. It was ordered to a third reading without a division, but it is doubtful whether it will pass the Senate. A similar bill has been several times defeated by previous Legislatures.

BOSTON, Mass., March 31.--The fourth Winter meeting of the Harvard Athletic Association, previous winners barred, except for best on record prize, was held this evening. The two hand vault was won by C.M. Walsh, '84, 6 feet 9 inches. The running high kick was won by E.C. Henry...

Man appeared before the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday and asked that work be deferred for three weeks, or until engineers whom they should select should examine the plans for the Quaker Bridge Dam. Mr. Potter wanted witnesses subpoenaed and sworn in legal form, so that their testimony could be placed on record.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., March 31.--John H. Morrill owns a drug store and Samuel Pimlott a bakery in adjoining buildings in Broadway here. Each used to be a good customer at the other's store, but they now spend much of their time standing in their respective doorways glaring at each other.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 31.--Gov. Stockley has appointed ex-Congressman William G. Whitely as Associate Judge, to fill the vacancy on the State bench caused by the appointment of Judge Wales to the United States District Judgeship. Col. Whitely received the unanimous indorsement of the Delaware Bar.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--Martin Culp, the defaulting Gas Trust receiving clerk, convicted of embezzling funds of the Trust, was sentenced to-day to an imprisonment of one year. An application for a new trial was refused.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--Nine cases of involuntary manslaughter against Joseph Harvey were abandoned to-day by the Commonwealth. NEW-HAVEN, March 31.--In the trial of the case of Miss Dinah Johnson, Captain of the Salvation Army, against Charles Webster, Chief of Police, for false imprisonment, a verdict for the defendant was rendered.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31.--Peter Edwards, the old man who murdered his wife at Preston Hollow on the 20th inst., died at the jail this afternoon. It has been apparent for a week that the broken-hearted man could not long survive.

NEW-IBERIA, La., March 31.--The small steam-boat Key West, from New-Orleans to St. Martinsville, struck a snag and sank in Bayou Teche last night. No life was lost, and most of the cargo was saved.

BALTIMORE, March 31.--A meeting of the creditors of C.W.S. Banks, who made an assignment last week, was held to-day.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 31.--The steam-ship San Marcos, from New-York, for Galveston, with 185 passengers, principally German immigrants, is ashore eight and one-half miles west of here.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 31.--The Yale University Lawn Tennis Association held a meeting this evening, which was the largest meeting in point of numbers that it has ever had. MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 31.--Edward J. Bennett, who was convicted of setting fire to his house, has been sentenced to six years in the penitentiary.

George S. Walsh, the man who on Friday night shot Mrs. Laura M. Thorp at her home, No. 206 West Twenty-first-street, remained a prisonor in the hospital ward at the Jefferson, Market Prison yesterday.
The will of Gen. Godfrey Weitzel was admitted to probate yesterday. The testator devises his entire estate to his widow for life, with remainder to his daughter Irene in fee.

About 40 of the 120 members attended the first annual meeting of the American Yacht Club last evening, at the club-room in East Twenty-eighth-street.

An interesting revival of "Much Ado About Nothing" was made at the Star Theatre last evening, when Mr. Henry Irving began his second engagement here; as a matter of fact his last engagement in this country. The theatre was not crowded, although it contained a large audience. Mr. Irving and Miss Terry were welcomed cordially when they came forward, and other actors in Mr. Irving's company were shown friendly treatment.

Mr. Edmunds and a few other Senators are in a distressed frame of mind because THE TIMES and other newspapers were able to publish the fact that the Senate confirmed the nomination of Minister Sargent to represent the United States at St. Petersburg and also to give the substance of the discussion in executive session.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 31.--The race meeting here was continued to-day. The weather was cloudy, but pleasant, and the track dry.

BOSTON, March 31.--The Advertiser's revision of its canvass among prominent Republicans in the State on preferences for Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates, gives for President, Edmunds, 359 votes in a total vote of 471; Arthur, next with 73; Blaine third, with 25. On second cloice Arthur leads with 87, Edmunds has 75, and Blaine 39. For Vice-President Lincoln has 259 out of a total vote of 291.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--There was a short parliamentary skirmish in the House this afternoon preceding the discussion of the bill to retire the trade dollar, which served to show that the trade dollar proposition had more friends than Mr. Ellis could summon to support his motion to take up the Indian Appropriation bill.
CINCINNATI,, Ohio, March 31.--The city has been quiet all day. Up to this hour (10:30) no disturbance has been reported and none is now expected to-night.
Andrew Jackson Mahoney, a peddler of vegetables, fruits, and fish, from Keyport, put up at the Railroad House, at Spotswood, N.J., last Tuesday night.
LONDON, March 31.--Mr. Gladstone was present in the House of Commons to-day. The Government has placed Col. Butler at the disposal of the Canadian authorities to inspect the defenses of the Dominion.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 31.--The wife of the Hon. George W. Julian died suddenly to-day of heart disease, at her residence in Irvington, a suburb of Indianapolis, Mrs. Julian was the eldest daughter of the late Joshua R. Giddings, the famous Ohio abolitionist. She was a woman of fine attainments and was greatly beloved by a large circle of friends.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31.--A national cat show opened here to-day. The prizes offered amount to $1,500.

LONDON, March 31.--The Mark-Lane Express in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: Colder weather has checked vegetation; wheat was not too forward.

The members of the Metal Exchange have had an exciting canvass for the election of officers and managers which takes place to-morrow.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 1.--One of the most industrious workers for Mr. Arthur in this State at this present time is ex-Senator Norris Winslow, of Jefferson County. He occupies a Government office whose duties do not demand such close attention as to prohibit daily excursions from one point to another in the carrying out of the general scheme to capture Arthur delegates.

Frank Deane Moore, a lawyer well known to the Bar of this city, of which he was a member, died at the residence of his brother-inlaw, Gen. Ayer, in Anderson, S.C., on Sunday March 23, of hasty consumption. Mr. Moore, although only 35 years old, had passed through a somewhat remarkable career.

The twenty-first Commencement of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women was held last evening in Association Hall, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street. The platform, which was tastefully decorated with bunting and flowers, was occupied by the ...

WASHINGTON, April 1.--Dr. Morrison Munford, of Kansas City, by authority and at the request, he asserts, of Col. Oliver H. Payne, makes formal announcement that under no condition of circumstances will the Hon. Henry B. Payne either be a candidate for the Presidential nomination or if nominated accept the honor. Col. Payne directs the statement that this conclusion has been reached after mature consideration and is positive, unequivocal, and unalterable.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--George Bliss today continued his testimony relative to the star route trials before Mr. Springer's committee. He said that Mr. Cook kept in his possession for several weeks abstracts of 16 routes prepared by Mr. Woodward. "In my opinion," Mr. Bliss said, "these abstracts were retained for the other side to copy."

"Gillie the Blue" appears once more before the public. He does not court publicity, but his associations are such that often he cannot avoid it. Detectives drag him into the light at times, and tell reporters who and what he is.

When the ladies go shopping they always find it to their advantage to visit the store of Stern Brothers, Nos. 32 to 36 West Twenty-third-street. Everything that is novel, new, and fashionable in wearing apparel may be found on their counters. At present they are offering an assortment of the fashionable changeable silks and satins, in plain, figured, and striped goods, which it is hard to equal.

At the fifth annual meeting of the Methodist Church Society last evening, in the HansonPlace Methodist Church, Brooklyn, the Treasurer's report showed that the receipts during the year were $7,337 25, and the expenditures $7,636 70. Mr. William H. Preston presided, and addresses were made by the Rev. G.P. Mains, and the Rev. Drs. A.K. Sanford and J.O. Peck.

MADRID, April 1.--The Cortes has been dissolved, and a new Cortes will assemble on May 20.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 1.--The Second Assembly Republican District Convention was called to order in the City Hall at 8 o'clock this evening with 160 delegates in attendance. H.H. Edgerton, a prominent anti-Arthur man, was made Chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--As published in these dispatches a few days ago, the special committee to investigate the charge made by Keifer that Gen. H.V. Boynton had attempted to corrupt him at the close of last Congress, today reported that Keifer's charges were not sustained by the evidence.

According to the story of Stenographer William J. Patten, told by him in an affidavit in opposition to an application made by his wife, Victorine, for alimony pending her suit for a limited divorce on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment, he has had a hard time since he was married in 1870, and the persons who have employed him have shared his misery.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 1.--The work of sinking a shaft through the treacherous quicksand of the banks of the Susquehanna river, which was hailed a few months ago as an accomplished fact and as a great feat in mining enterprise, is now very likely to turn out disastrously.

Gen. Grant arrived at the Capitol about 2 o'clock to-day, accompanied by Washington McLean, of Cincinnati, and was shown into the room used for official purposes by the President. After a short stay he was escorted by Senator Beck to the cloak-room of the Senate, on the Republican side, walking rapidly and with apparent ease by the aid of his crutches.

BOSTON, April 1.--The strength of the ticket of Edmunds and Lincoln in Massachusetts is still further shown by later returns of the Advertiser canvass. Since the first publication a hundred additional returns have been received from Republican Party committeemen and business men.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 1.--The Salvation Army have made 300 recruits in this city. Major Moore, the Commander-in-Chief of the army in America, has arrived here, and he has decided to build a barracks at a cost of $2,000. A lot opposite the City Hall has been leased for 10 years to the army, and the barracks will be erected upon it. The Mayor started the subscription with $10.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 1.--Four years ago Miss Annie Stouffer and Mr. A.E. Guess, both living near Cary, were engaged to be married. The time was set for the marriage, and the parents of Guess objected to and broke off the match.
One hundred and eleven applications for appointment on the police force of Brooklyn have been filed since the publication of the new regulations providing for a competitive examination of candidates.

WASHINGTON, Penn., April 1.--The Hon. J.R. McLain, Claysville; B.F. Bentley, Monongahela City; A.M. Todd, South Strabane; the Hon. John S. Duncan, Cross Creek; Dr. D.M. Anderson, Peters, and George L. Hill, East Bethlehem, have been chosen delegates from Washington County to the Republican District Convention.

John A. Osborn, who has been a United States Commissioner and Deputy Clerk of the District Court for 21 years, resigned his clerkship yesterday, and was succeeded by Samuel M. Hitchcock, cashier in the clerk's office.

BOSTON, Mass., April 1.--President Bates, of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company, and W.H. Fairbanks, General Superintendent of Construction of the Postal Telegraph Company, were in this city to-day to testify before a legislative committee in favor of the proposed legislation ...

The work done in the drawing department of the evening high school, at No. 60 West Thirteenth-street, was on exhibition in the school building last night. A large number of the pupils and their friends spent two hours in the examination of an exceedingly creditable display.

Bridget Colwell, age 38, was struck and almost instantly killed last evening by a train on the Newark and New-York Road. She was returning from seeing her sister off on a train, and stepped from one track only to meet her death on the other. She leaves several children, the youngest being 7 months old.

George A. Reed, of Concord, Staten Island, is in jail awaiting trial for arson. The circumstances of the case are peculiar. About two years ago Reed made an agreement with Mortimer Taxter, an employe of the Staten Island Ferry Company, under which his house and personal property were deeded over to Taxter on condition that he should take care of him so long as he lived.

The annual meeting of the Staten Island Railway Company was held in this city yesterday. Directors were elected as follows: Nathan G. Miller, B. Kreischer, Nathaniel Marsh, John W. Mersereau, W.W. Macfarland, Louis De Jonge, William King, J.H.F. Mayo, Charles Watrous, James M. Davis, R.M. Gallaway, George F. Kreischer, and Erastus Wiman.

PITTSBURG, April 1.--The Republican county conventions to elect delegetes to the State Convention held to-day resulted in the election of Blaine delegates from the Fortysecond, Forty-fourth, and Forty-fifth Senatorial Districts, and from the First, Fifth, and Sixth Legislative Districts, making 70 in all.

A "round robin" was started in the Produce Exchange yesterday in favor of holding a grand ball in the new building, either on the evening before or the evening after the formal opening, which occurs Tuesday, May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--A McPherson boom is reported to exist here and to be under the patronage, in its embryo state, of an exjournalist, who is ingeniously presenting the claims of the New-Jersey Senator upon the national Democracy. It is urged by Senator McPherson's advocates that a strong reaction ...

ELLIJAY, Ga., April 1.--A movement is on foot to develop the marble quarries in this section, which are among the finest in the world. Mr. H.C. Clement, of Chicago, representing a wealthy syndicate, has purchased a large property for this purpose.

Edward S. Stokes stated last evening that it was true that he had inspected the big hotel at Rockaway Beach, in company with some other gentlemen, with a possible view to taking charge of that hitherto unprofitable structure during the coming season. Whether or not he would undertake the task he was not prepared to say.

TRENTON, April 1.--The Senate to-day took up the bill of the special Senate committee for the taxation of railroad and canal property, otherwise known as Assembly bill No. 313, as amended by the committee. Senator Gardner moved that the majority report be adopted.

The Directors of the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and Indianapolis Railroad, or Bee Line, at a meeting yesterday decided not to make the stock dividend of 20 per cent. requested by James McHenry. Gen. J.H. Devereux said the matter was fairly and thoroughly considered. No other dividend was declared.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--The commission of Medical Director F.M. Gumel to be Surgeon-General was received at the Navy Department this morning, and that officer entered upon the discharge of his new duties, relieving Surgeon W.K. Van Reypen, the Assistant Chief of the Bureau of Medicine and Surgery, who has been acting Chief of the Bureau.

School Trustee George H. Beyer, of the Seventeenth Ward, has gotten himself into hot water with Major Patrick K. Horgan, one of his colleagues, and at the monthly meeting of the Ward Board last evening the two Trustees talked to each other with charming candor, while the rest of the board enjoyed the fun.
Gen. E.F. Winslow was asked yesterday what had been done in the matter of the West Shore and Ontario terminal bonds, which became due yesterday. He said: "The amount of these bonds is $5,325,000.

A tailor named Isaac Goldstein joined in the wholesale immigration of Russian Jews to this country last year, and took his wife and 6-yearold child with him to London, to take advantage of the Mansion House fund. Goldstein continued his journey to America alone, leaving the other two to starve.

NEW-HAVEN, April 1.--Anxiety in Waterbury was heightened to-day by the discovery of two new cases of small-pox. The Board of Health held one meeting to-day and will hold another to-morrow to devise means to prevent the spread of the disease. Nathan J. Carpenter and his wife are expected to die. The town pesthouse has been placed in order to receive a large number of patients.

The beginning of the trout season was marked yesterday at Fulton Market by one of the finest exhibitions of fish ever displayed in this city. WASHINGTON, March 31.--A Government Official just returned from Florida tells a good story at the expense of Jay Gould. When Mr. Gould'n yacht was lying off Fernandina a party of gentlemen, including several of the English noblemen traveling in Florida this season, received an invitation from him to pay a visit of inspection to his vessel.

Mrs. Ottendorfer, wife of Oswald Ottendorfer, publisher and proprietor of the Staats Zeitung, died at about 6 o'clock last evening at her residence, No. 7 East Seventeenth-street Mrs. Ottendorfer was widely known and highly esteemed, especially among the Germans of the city, for her business ability and her numerous charities.

Mr. Mills's Tribune evidently appreciates the advantage of advertising in the Herald, though it prefers the economical method of having sample copies folded into the Herald in order to reach the reading public.
