The bill introduced by Mr. Edmunds, and reported favorably from the Committee on Naval Affairs, for the relief of the Jeannette survivors was taken up in the Senate to-day, read three times, and passed. It provides for the compensation of the survivors for losses incurred on the expedition. The names and amounts are as follows: George W. Melville, Chief Engineer, $1,000; John W. Denenhower, Lieutenant, ...

The people of New-England are beginning to see that the destruction of their forests threatens to ruin the water power upon which hundreds of factories have relied, and to diminish the profits of agriculture, which are already small. A resolution has been passed by the Connecticut Senate directing the State Board of Agriculture ...

CLEVELAND, April 1.--As the April elections draw near, and it becomes necessary to look the first skirmish of the Presidential year fairly in the face, men are beginning to take more interest in politics, and to define their desires and declare their positions.

At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association yesterday Gen. C.F. Robbins reported that the Long Island Railroad Company had decided to issue tickets to members of the association at the same reduced rate of fare as is charged to the State National Guard.

A number of city officials have evidently been in need of money lately. Assistant District Attorney Fellows on Dec. 20, 1883, gave a power of attorney to George H. Purser, a lawyer, for his salary for that month, and on Feb. 14, 1884, gave another power of attorney to collect his salary for March to John O'Byrne.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1.--A special examination will be held at the Naval Academy tomorrow for admission of candidates as naval cadets. The applicants are O.W. Koester, of Pennsylvania: R.M. Smith, Wisconsin; C.A. Way. Ohio; F.D.S. McGillicuddy, Indiana; L. McMillan, Kansas, and W.S. Hollis, Massachusetts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1.--There was issued yesterday a writ against Miss Carrie Godfrey for the recovery of $100 obtained from the McCaull Opera Company on Friday night. The writ, which was placed in the hands of the Sheriff, alleges breach of contract and extortion. Miss Godfrey had several times taken the leading part in "Falka," now on the boards at Haverly's ...

Mr. THACHER'S bill to appoint a commission to investigate tenements and "slums" in New-York appears to be suggested by the commission lately appointed to conduct a like inquiry into the condition of the poor of London. As originally introduced, the bill named as investigators the President and the Chief Sanitary Inspector of the Department of Health, the Superintendent ...

WASHINGTON, April.--A committee, consisting of Richard Vaux, Chairman; Henry Reed, Frank P. Prichard, Walter George Smith, and N. Du Bois Miller, representing the Law Association of Philadelphia, appeared before the House Committee on the Judiciary this morning, and presented an argument on behalf of certain proposed legislation for the relief of the United States Supreme Court.

ROCK HILL, S.C., April 1.--At 1 o'clock this afternoon a negro named Frank Elliott assaulted the 6-year-old daughter of W.A. Fewell, a farmer, living three miles north-west of this place, and inflicted severe injuries upon his victim. Search was made for Elliott by the girl's father, who captured him and brought him to Rock Hill.
The annual Spring elections in Queens and Suffolk Counties were held yesterday. In Queens County the following town officers were elected:

WASHINGTON, April 1.--The reduction in the public debt for March was over $14,000,000, and for the nine months ending yesterday nearly $82,000,000, against $9,000,000 and $112,000,000, respectively, for the two corresponding periods of last year. The reduction for the month just closed is unusually large, and except September exceeds that for any previous month of the current fiscal year.

It was the fate of a great many people, when they went to bed Monday night, to forget that the following day was the 1st of Apirl. It was reserved, to the favored few to be forcibly reminded of that fact. Among this minority was Nicholas J. Macklin, a job printer, at No. 48 Broad-street, who resides at Stapleton, Staten ...

The Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads is making slow progress in its preparation of a bill to establish a postal telegraph system, and it will be some time before the proposed measure will be reported. There are some differences of opinion among the members of the committee as to how the system should be created. Some, including Chairman Hill, are in favor of having the lines built or purchased ...

NORTH SCITUATE, Mass., April 1.--The schooner Australia, of Booth Bay, Me., came ashore during the gale Sunday, and is now on the flats near the Glades House, loaded with lime, which is burning. The crew were all saved.

PETERSBURG, Va., April 1.--The Rev. John T. Edwards, Pastor of the Market-Street Methodist Episcopal Church and one of the most prominent ministers of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, is lying at the point of death.
RALEIGH, N.C., April 1.--The Republican Convention of the First Congressional District to elect delegates to Chicago has been called to meet in Elizabeth City on Wednesday, April 23.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 1.--The flight of Frank J. Akerley, a lawyer of this city, and a member of the Dutchess County Bar, is still a topic of conversation, and almost every hour something new in relation to his transactions is developed. For three years he had been wayward and fast.

At the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference yesterday the Committee on Superannuated Ministers asked that an endowment fund of $100,000 be established for the better support of aged clergymen, which, after some discussion, was indorsed by the conference. Presiding Elder Craig and the Rev. Solomon Parsons were elected delegates to the General Conference.

The report of the committee of the House charged with the duty of investigating the allegations made against Gen. H.V. BOYNTON by ex-Speaker KEIFER, concludes with a resolution to the effect that the charges by KEIFER are not sustained by the evidence, and that there is no ground for action by the House.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 1.--A pretty state of affairs exists in this city to-night regarding the control of the Fire Department. It has now two heads, each claiming to be in authority and neither recognizing the authority of the other. This has been brought about in the following way: The obnoxious ordinance to abolish the office of Fire Marshal and substitute a commission, which caused a bolt of the reform members ...

A singular exhibition of fidelity on the part of a house dog was shown in Stapleton, Staten Island, during the past week. Last Tuesday morning Mrs. Walter Odell, wife of a tinware dealer in that village, died. A Scotch terrier, named Fido, had been a pet of Mrs. Odell for the past 12 years. During the two months that Mrs. Odell was sick Fido remained continually by her bed.

Judge O'Gorman has decided, in Superior Court, Chambers, to continue the injunction restraining the United States Illuminating Company from erecting a pole or poles and from stringing wires for electric lights in front of the premises of Tiffany Co., at Union-square and Fifteenth-street.

Michael Courji is the name of a young Syrian who finds himself stranded on this shore without money and without friends, and who yesterday applied to the authorities at Castle Garden for relief. To a TIMES reporter who spoke with him yesterday afternoon he said that he was born in Damascus and was educated in Beyrout.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 243--William Irvine, appellant, vs. Summer T. Dunhum. Argument concluded. No. 289--T.W. Spindle, Assignee, , appellant, vs. Charles M. Shreve et al. Argued for the appellees and submitted for the appellant. No. 290--Greene County, Mo., plaintiff in error, vs. John Brown, Passed, No. 291--Robert C. Chambers, et al., appellants, vs. James Harrington et al. Argument begun.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 1.--Three nominations of candidates for Alumni Trustee of Cornell University have been received up to this day, and within the time required by the charter. There are four nominations of Mr. Francis W. Halsey, of New-York City, each signed by the required number of 10 or more of Boston, New York City, Washington, and Ohio Alumni, ...

A large number of teachers in New-York schools met last night in the Broadway Tabernacle, at the invitation of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union. The object of the meeting was mutual congratulation on the recent passing of the bill which provides for the instruction of ...

Fewer flowers were displayed at the monthly meeting of the New-York Horticultural Society yesterday than is usual at the April exhibition. No special reason could be assigned by the officers for the lack of interest in the exhibition. The society itself is flourishing and gaining in membership. Although the number of exhibits was not large, some fine specimens were shown.

Steam-ships Edith Godden, Bennett, St. Ann's Bay, G. Wessells Co.; Amerique (Fr.,) Santelli Havre, Louis de Bebian; Chatahoochee, Daggett, Savannah, Henry Yonge, Jr.; Colan, (Br.,) Fraser, Kingston, , United States Mail Steam-ship Co.; Nereus, Coleman, Boston, H.F. Dimock; Acapulco, Porter, Aspinwall, Pacific Mail Steam-ship Co.; Cephalonia, (Br.,) Walker, ...

In the Marie-Garrison suit yesterday Mr. Conkling objected to R. L. Cutting, Jr.'s, answering a question put by Mr. Day, by referring to his books, on the ground that the books were not those of Mr. Cutting personally, but of a firm of bankers, and that the witness had already stated that he could remember the details ...

The sub-committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association, to whom has been intrusted the duty of deciding the all-absorbing question to amateur athletes whether or not L. E. Myers, of the Manhattan Athletic Club, is an amateur, met last evening in the Knickerbocker Cottage and concluded the taking of testimony.

On Monday the landlord of No. 311 East One Hundred and Third-street ejected the Ross family from the house for non-payment of rent. The husband has been a sufferer from rheumatism for weeks past, but sick as he was, he spent the night in the street watching his household goods.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--The House to-day completed the consideration of the Trade Dollar bill, by a vote of 198 to 46. During the debate Mr. Cassidy of Nevada attacked the fourth section of the bill, which he maintained would have the effect of contracting the currency to the amount of the trade dollars which would be retired.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 1.--No facts are known here concerning the reported filibustering expedition against Cuba. The reports are regarded as mere rumors. It would be impossible for an expedition to organize here secretly. One or two individuals might possibly go to Cuba on a filibustering expedition, but nothing of importance or magnitude could be organized without publicity.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 1.--The Mexican Congress opened to-night. The President's message was read. It says: "The relations of Mexico with foreign powers are cordial. The negotiations for renewing relations with England continue with deliberation. The reciprocity treaty with the United States will exercise a powerful influence on the commerce of both countries.

Counters and shelves heavily laden with rich and stylish dress goods, marked down to temptingly low figures, meet the gaze of the visitors to Le Boutillier Brothers, at Broadway and Fourteenth-street. Not only are dress goods, in all their extensive and beautiful variety, displayed in this well-known establishment, but also a very comprehensive assortment of fine laces, linens, hosiery, and other dainty articles of feminine need.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 1.--The Republican primaries were held to-night for the election of delegates to the city convention and to nominate ward officers. The gatherings were large and an unusual interest was shown, partly because this is the first election under the redistricting of the city wards and partly because the ...

The fifty-second annual report of the Eastern Dispensary shows that the work of the institution was successfully carried on during 1883. The number of patients treated in the course of the year was 21,948.

UTICA, N.Y., April 1.--The Republicans of Richfield send to the Otsego County Convention H.H. Getman, Elias Bronson and M.D.V. Martin, and to the First Assembly District Convention S.H. Barker, Peter Seeber, and H.C. Brockway. They are understood to be anti-Arthur.

ALBANY, April 1.--Speaker Sheard has redeemed his pledges of fealty to Mr. Roosevelt and the reform measures--pledges made necessary after the disgraceful events of last Wednesday. The friends of reform, believing that another somersault is unlikely, now breathe more freely.

A lady who had imported a dress from Paris sent an anxious letter to the Custom-house authorities a few days ago. She stated that she paid duties on the dress when she received it, but that it did not fit, and she wanted to send it back to Paris to be altered.

NEWARK, N.J., April 1.--William A. Hall, ex-chief clerk of the Newark Controller's office, yesterday retracted his plea of not guilty, and pleaded non vult to two indictments for embezzling taxes paid to him in 1878 and 1879. He will be sentenced on Friday. There are yet five indictments, two for forgery and three for embezzlement, against him, which will be disposed of then.

Mr. George Kemp, the owner of the Buckingham Hotel, on the south-east corner of Fiftieth-street and Fifth-avenue, filed plans at the Buildings Bureau yesterday for an extension to the house, which is to cost $150,000. The addition will front on Fort-ninth-st., and will have 77 feet front, be 100 feet deep and six stories high.

BOSTON, April 1.--The liabilities of the Biddeford Machine-works, of Biddeford, Me., are reported at $40,000. The assets are mortgaged, and it is thought that unsecured creditors will receive but little of their claims.

The nine bills reported by the special committee of the Assembly for the reform of abuses in this city were taken up yesterday and dealt with in an orderly manner. Three of them were ordered to a third reading in the Assembly, and the others were "progressed," with the understanding that they shall be considered in the next Committee of the Whole.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 1.--The Iowa editorial excursion party which arrived in this city by the Illinois Central Railroad were the guests yesterday of the Louisville and Nashville Road on a trip to Mobile. Yesterday they stopped at Beauvoir and visited Jeff Davis's residence.

The proposed retirement from "the Street" of Charles J. Osborn was one of the chief topics of discussion among Wall-street brokers yesterday. Mr. Osborn resigned his position as a member of the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange about two weeks ago, and his withdrawal from the firm of C.J. Osborn Co., of which he is a special partner, will take effect May 1.

The Jersey City Republicans held a large and enthusiastic meeting at the Academy of Music last night to indorse the nomination of Gilbert Collins for Mayor. Speeches were made by Col. John McAnerney, John Linn, E.F. McDonald, and Mr. Collins. F.G. Wolvert, a Democrat, presided, and there were several Democrats on the platform, the nomination having been originally made by the Citizens' Association.

LUMPKIN, Ga., April 1.--An attempt was made last night to burn the County Court house, in which are stored valuable real estate records, the object being, it is supposed, to de story the titles to large estates. The fire made great headway, but the records were saved.

CROWN POINT, N.Y., April 1.--A determined effort is now in progress by the friends of Mr. Arthur to debauch this, Twenty-first Congressional District: The evil-faced Rockwell, ex-Senator of Warren County, is a secret candidate for national delegate, and in conjunction with Gen. John Hammond, of Essex County, is trying to swing the district for Arthur.

When the Court of Oyer and Terminer was adjourned yesterday, a lot of men who have for years got their living through the Sheriff's office left the court-room with disgust and dismay depicted on their faces. At the opening of the court District Attorney Olney read an affidavit made by William T. Bridge, clerk of the ...

Senator Mahone was taken suddenly ill at his rooms at the Arlington last night, and is much prostrated to-day. His physicians ascribe his trouble to indigestion and nervous prostration, caused by over-work.

A correspondent suggests, in a communication printed in another column, that the problem of rapid transit would solve itself if New-York were properly paved. With smooth pavements he believes that a cab service of lighter vehicles than those now employed, driven at a much higher rate of speed and at a much lower rate of fare, would come into existence.

The Executive Committee of the Western Anthracite Association met at the Erie Railway offices in this city yesterday and discussed measures pertaining to the Western coal traffic for about five hours. William L. Scott, of Erie, presided, and nearly all of the various interests combined in the association were represented.

Angry Italians crowded into the Yorkville Court-room yesterday to convince Justice Murray that Paolo Defario, Antonio Grispino, and Joseph Falvo, the men arrested on Monday night at the Grand Central Station for selling bogus tickets to Pittsburg, Penn., for $3 each, were swindlers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 1.--It is reported that the village of Oakville, between Muncie and New-Castle, Ind., was swept away by a cyclone at 5 o'clock this afternoon, and that several lives were lost. No particulars have yet been received.

The Old Guard decided at a meeting last evening to celebrate the anniversary of its organization Tuesday, April 22, by having a church parade and dinner. Assembling at its armory at 1 P.M. it will march to the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison-avenue and Forty- ...

WASHINGTON, April 1.--Trouble is brewing between the intimate friends of Blaine and Logan, the latter intimating that the, "holy alliance" between the two aspirants has proved a "iug handle" friendship, and that Blaine has the ...

BALTIMORE, Md., April 1.--In view of the many conflicting "interviews" with Mr. Tilden which have been published the Sun yesterday sent one of its most trusted correspondents to New-York to see that gentleman for the purpose of eliciting something that might be regarded as authentic. The Sun will publish to-morrow the following dispatch received to-night from its correspondent in NewYork:

Four boys climbed on a dray coming from Brooklyn, just before 6 o'clock last evening, to steal a free ride over the bridge. Fifty yards this side of the New-York tower the horse became unmanageable and came down the roadway on a canter.

BOSTON, April 1.--The Transcript presents the following figures taken from an advance sheet of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company's report for 1883. The total gross earnings of the company, including leased roads and branches, were $26,110,369; operating expenses, $13,496,478; net earnings, $12,613,891, as against $10,266,842 in 1882.

John I. Davenport has sent the Directors of the Broadway Underground Railroad a long communication, arguing, first, that additional facilities for rapid transit are certainly needed in New-York, and, second, that the arcade plan presents the best and most suitable mode for present and future necessities.

QUEBEC, Quebec, April 1.--Within the past few weeks the mails between this city and Toronto have been plundered five different times, and no trace can be found of the robber. On four occasions since the middle of February all the registered letters made up here for Toronto have mysteriously disappeared from the bags, and in one instance a Toronto package for Quebec was stolen.

The election in Rhode Island for State officers and members of the Legislature occurs to-day. Representatives in Congress will be chosen in November. For State officers the Republicans have nominated the present incumbents throughout, Augustus O. Bourn being again the nominee for Governor.

A telegram received at the Indian Bureau from Gov. Crosby, of Montana, states that the greatest destitution prevails among the Indians in that Territory, many of them being on the verge of starvation.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 1.--Emil Wallber (Rep.) is elected Mayor. The balance of the ticket is Democratic, as follows: Frederick Kuehn, Controller: William Maywarm, City Treasurer; P.J. Somers, City Attorney. The Council is Democratic.

The annual report of the Panama Railroad Company for 1883 has just been issued. It states that the gross receipts for the year were $2,811,983 92, and the expenses, including interest and subsidies, $1,660,192 25. This leaves a net profit of $1,151,791 67, which is said to be an increase over the net profit of 1882 of $69,256 38.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 1.--Last night was absolutely quiet. When the smallest nucleus of a crowd appeared anywhere within sight of the barricades the soldiers ordered the people to move on, and in every instance the order was promptly obeyed.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--The President to-day transmitted to the House of Representatives, in response to a resolution concerning undervaluation of foreign merchandise, a letter from the Secretary of the Treasury inclosing a draft of a bill to prevent such irregular practices, and it was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.

"Life Lessons from Goethe's 'Faust'" was the subject chosen by Mr. Courtlandt Palmer, the President of the Nineteenth Century Club, for discussion at the monthly meeting of that body last evening. The parlors of Mr. Palmer's house were comfortably filled, when Mr. Thaddeus B. Wakeman began a eulogy of Goethe ...

Senator Anthony has replied as follows to the hearty expression of regard for him embodied in the resolution adopted by the recent Republican State Convention in Rhode Island, his letter being addressed to the Chairman of that convention:

A natty little vehicle wheeled out of Union-square into Broadway about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The lower part of the body was painted a bright yellow, and a yellow circle on the black panel above bore the words "New-York Cab Company."

The sub-committee of the Committee of One Hundred for the protection of the Adirondack forests held a meeting in the office of Henry Clews, No. 346 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, to make arrangements for the grand mass-meeting in Chickering Hall next Wednesday evening.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 1.--The steamship San Marcos, which was reported yesterday aground 16 miles west of here, was not beached, as at first stated, but is on San Lus Bar, a mile and a half from shore. All of the passengers, including 185 German immigrants, have just arrived here on tugs. Most of the cargo will be taken off by lighters and the vessel will soon be floated.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 1.--During the present session of the Legislature four bills have been introduced to abandon property belonging to the Miami and Erie Canal at the southern terminus for railroad purposes. This consists of about three miles of the canal in the city of Cincinnati valued at about $2,500,000.

The concert given by Miss Henrietta Beebe at Chickering Hall last evening was very numerously attended. Many of the performances afforded lively satisfaction and were enthusiastically applauded, although the artistic interest of the programme was rather slender. From a musical standpoint, Miss Beebe's rendering of a "Cantilene" from Gounod's "Cinq Mars" claimed most attention.

The New-York Club played a game of base-ball with the Jasper nine, of Manhattan College, on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. The collegians were in good form, and for the first half of the contest played a very good game with the League men.

When the Legislature passed the act authorizing the annexation of a portion of Westchester County to this county in 1873, it provided for the transfer to the city police force of all policemen in the townships to be annexed who were in service on Jan. 1, 1874, when the act went into effect.

The pilot-boat Enchantress, which was abandoned Sunday night after having been in collision with the schooner Sarah and Lucy, was brought into port yesterday by a prize crew, which boarded her about 25 miles from the scene of the collision. Capt. Rackett, of the fishing ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 1.--The legislative caucuses were held last night to choose Trustees for the various State institutions. The Republicans made up their ticket, leaving blank one Regency of the University, one Trusteeship of the Agricultural College, the tutorship of the Reform School, and three others, after which a committee was sent to notify the opposition that these places were at their disposal.

A warrant was issued yesterday by Justice Patterson for the arrest of Miss Fannie O'Keefe, Acting Principal of the Industrial School of the Children's Aid Society, No. 211 West Eighteenth-street. The complaint was made by a scholar, Ida Miller, 12 years old, of No. 345 West Sixteenth-street.

SALT LAKE, April 1.--President Lovejoy issued an order yesterday dismissing Col. Dodge from the general management of the Denver and Rio Grande. Also, Mr. McMartin, chief engineer, and Mr. Woodward, Superintendent of the telegraph laws. Col. Dodge ordered Superintendent Bancroft and the agents of Denver and Rio Grande Western to obey only him.
A meeting of the members of the Produce Exchange has been called for to-morrow afternoon to consider the relative values of gold and silver coinage.
BOSTON, April 1.--The following has been received by the authorities of the State Board of Health, Lunacy, and Charity:

CLEVELAND, April 1.--This morning's Leader published a long and circumstantial account of the arrival of Samuel J. Tilden and a number of other prominent Democrats for the purpose of consulting with Mr. Payne on the Presidential question.

Officer Harty, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, found John Meyers, a laborer, in Greenwich-street early yesterday morning unconscious from drinking. He was taken to the station, and in his pockets were $1,300.

Alphonse Gourdier, through his counsel, Robert J. Mahon, has begun an action in the Superior Court against the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company to recover $7,000 damages for injury to his property in West Fifty-third-street. Mr. Gourdier claims the rights of an abutting owner in the street.

Representatives A.S. Hewitt, Potter, and Hardy, of New-York, presented memorials in the House to-day, signed by William Dowd, President of the Bank of North America; Thomas Dickson, President of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company; E.H. Mead, Pennsylvania Coal Company, and many other prominent bankers, ...

It was reported in the office of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday afternoon that Joseph M. De Veau, of No. 37 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street, President of the Mount Morris Bank, and Edmund D. Randolph, of Riverdale, President of the Continental Bank, had been appointed Commissioners ...

CAIRO, April 1.--Gen. Gordon has decided to abandon his policy of conciliating the natives, having become convinced that it is utterly useless. His new policy will be more vigorous, and as the first step toward carrying it out, the Egyptian soldiers who had been detailed to give a safe conduct to persons leaving Khartoum and ...

The annual boat-race between the crews of the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge, which was to have taken place on the Thames, in England, on Saturday has been postponed until Monday next, in respect to the memory of the late Duke of Albany.

PORT ALLEN, La., April 2.--A break occurred last night 30 feet wide and 8 deep in the Woolford levee, on the Bayou Grosse Tete. Efforts will be made to close it. The Mulatto Point crevasse is now nearly 400 feet wide from Prophet's Island up.

HOUSTON, Texas, April--2. G. Weimers, alias Schubert, a resident of Houston for the past year, has been arrested, charged with embezzling $26,000 while Treasurer of St. Claire County, Ill. It is alleged that he left a wife in Illinois, but married again in Houston. He was first employed in this city as book-keeper of the Anheuser Beer Agency, and was afterward bartender in a prominent saloon.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 2.--A largely attended meeting of the members of the Yale Athletic Association was held to-night in the Lyceum. The following officers were elected:

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 2.--About 3 o'clock this morning a very high gale sprang up and prevailed with great violence throughout the day. The effect in this city has been slight. Fences and trees were blown down, and a few buildings were slightly damaged.

The committee appointed for the trial of the Rev. Dr. G.R. Bristor, who was charged before the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference with immoral conduct, reported to that body yesterday that they had found him guilty.
Taken altogether, yesterday proved one of the most disagreeable of the many disagreeable days which have characterized the Spring season thus far.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 2.--Judge Field writes from Washington to ex-Gov. Johnson that he is not and does not wish to be considered a Presidential candidate.
SCOTTSBORO, Ala., April 2.--W.F. Robinson, candidate for Congress, committed suicide this morning by stabbing himself through the heart. The cause of the deed is not known.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--The bolt in the Fourth Legislative District Convention last evening has afforded a topic for an unlimited amount of talk among the politicians to-day, and the final result, either at Harrisburg or Chicago, has been freely canvassed. "I have no idea," ...
The bill for the construction of a building for the Congressional library was made a special order for to-morrrow in the House of Representative, but it will hardly get a hearing at that time.

The entries in the six-day walk to begin in Madison-Square Garden on Monday, April 28, are: Charles Rowell, Patrick Fitzgerald, Robert Vint, George D. Noremac, Frank H. Hart, William Wallace Lounsbury, Charles Thompson, Peter Napoleon Campana, Daniel J. Herty, ....
An oil train on the Erie Road caught fire while approaching Jersey City yesterday morning, and two of the oil tanks were consumed. The damage is estimated at $10,000.
While Lizzie O'Neil was lying in bed sick at her home, No. 9 Boyd-street, Newark, yesterday, her sister, Margaret Cattingham, entered the room and began a savage attack on her.
Although there were six tickets in the field the annual election of the New-York Metal Exchange yesterday was less spirited than had been expected.

Deeming it but natural that with our increasing population there should have been more births during the past three months than in a like period a year ago, and by the same reasoning there might have been a greater number of deaths, especially as the weather we have ....

CHICAGO, Ill., April 2.--The new plan of the hall of the National Convention submitted to-day at the meeting of the local Sub-committee on Arrangements contemplates the seating of 9,000 people, including seats in the galleries, and the cost is estimated at $12,000. The plan meets with general approval and will be finally passed upon next Saturday at a conference with the national sub-committee.
LOUISVILLE, April 2.--The great racehorse Leonatus broke down in his right fore leg to-day while taking exercise, and will be retired to the stud.

The announcement that a valuable picture by Hogarth was to be sold at auction, among other things, at No. 3 Fifth-avenue yesterday, attracted many people to the place in spite of the bad weather. The Hogarth was the chief object of interest, and many and various were the comments made upon it.

DENNISPORT, Mass., April 2.--The body of an unknown man was found yesterday on Harding's Beach, which is supposed to be that of a Captain or officer of some wrecked vessel. Two receipts for merchandise were found in his pockets dated Jersey City, March 17, from Washburn Brothers. The signatures are unintelligible.

Helen M. Johnson brought a suit in the Supreme Court for a limited divorce for abandonment from Samuel E. Johnson. The dismissal of her complaint was asked on the ground that Johnson procured a decree of absolute divorce in 1876 in Massachusetts.
LYNCHBURG, Va., April 2.--A young white woman named Bettie Eagle, residing in the lower end of Campbell County, was brutally outraged several days ago by an unknown negro.

It is reasonable to suppose that Mr. SARGENT would sooner come home than go to St. Petersburg. The Russian capital is an expensive city for a foreigner to live in, as American diplomatists have invariably found to their great loss.
President French, of the Board of Police, on Saturday received from D.J. Whitney, Chairman of the Committee for the Enforcement of Law, the following letter:

There were two sharp taps against one of the windows of the publication office of THE TIMES on the Park-row side at noon yesterday, and two round spots appeared in the centre of the two upper panes of glass.

There are not a great many Republicans in this State who desire the nomination of President ARTHUR, but they make an imposing showing for their numbers. They are nearly all of them working politicians. They are experienced, watchful, active, and, of late, bold.

ROCHESTER, April 2.--To-day has been one of intense excitement in political circles, the halls of the city building being thronged the entire day with politicians. The proceedings of last evening's Second District Republican Convention has engendered the most ....

The members of the Stock Exchange Governing Committee were called together yesterday afternoon for the special purpose of considering matters relative to the dissemination of quotations from the Exchange trading-room.

The report is current that in a few days the stockholders of the Richmond and Danville Extension Company will receive another dividend in Georgia Pacific securities and that soon afterward the extension company will be wound up. The amount of securities to be divided is said to be about 50 per cent. Georgia Pacific stock and 30 per cent, of Georgia Pacific second mortgage bonds.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 2.--Reports concerning the small-pox in this city are grossly exaggerated. There are only two mild cases of varioloid, which are isolated and well cared for. There is no apprehension of an epidemic.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 2.--The publishers of the New-Lexington Herald (Democratic) filed a petition in the Common Pleas Court of Perry County asking for a mandamus compelling the County Commissioners to publish their ...

A veteran picture-hanger, as he balanced himself on a step-ladder, said this to a TIMES reporter: "I have been in this business 30 years, and I have put a wire on nearly all the gems of art in this city. But let me tell you, young man, that all the rare pictures are not to be found in the mansions of the millionaires. Hidden treasures adorn the walls of bachelor apartments in up-town flats.

At a meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday a map was filed fixing the boundaries of High Bridge Park. It will extend from Fort George on the north to One Hundred and Fiftyfifth-street, and from the Harlem River to Edgcomb-avenue.

TORONTO, Ontario, April 2.--Horace F. Allkins, age 31, an artist, to-day shot his wife, age 21, and a street car conductor named Hackett, whom he accused of being too intimate and whom he caught together at the house of a friend. Both of the injured persons were taken to the hospital, where Hackett's injuries are pronounced fatal. Allkins was arrested.

WATERTOWN, April 2.--The certificate of character which was recently given by Congressman Parker to ex-Attorney-General Russell does not seem to satisfy the Republicans of St. Lawrence County, and very many of them are anxiously inquiring regarding Mr. Parker's position.

The Surrogate's office was crowded yesterday when the hearing was resumed in the suit of Miss Mary Irene Hoyt to open the probate of her father's will. Miss Hoyt was accompanied by her mother and several other ladies. The counsel on both sides came in together in an imposing body--Mr. Conkling, ex-Judge Shipman, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--A summons has been served on Rudolph Schalk, of the firm of E. Schalk Co., New-York, in the suits of S. L. Roseburg and J.R. Johnson to recover on oil contracts made by the defendant company's agent in this city, W.T. Daws.
Mme. Antonia Janisch will have her benefit performance to-morrow night at the Thalia Theatre. "Lady Clare" will be followed at Wallack's Theatre on Monday evening, April 4, by Mr. Burnand's "Betsy."

In the Westchester County Circuit Court, at White Plains, yesterday, William J. Dean commenced a suit for $1,000 damages against J.B. Lent, otherwise known as "The Walking Armory." Both parties live in the town of Somers.
BALTIMORE, Md., April 2.--Fire Marshal Herskell to-night surrendered to the extent of vacating his office and leaving it for the occupancy of the new Board of Fire Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, April 2.--It is not expected that the bill providing for the recoinage of the trade dollar, which passed the House of Representatives yesterday, will be acceptable to the Senate. The members of that body are credited with too much conservatism to permit the passage of any measure that increases by any amount ...
Messrs. Wilmerding, Hoguet Co. sold yesterday for Messrs. Oberteuffer, Abegg Daeniker a lot of hosiery and gloves on a credit of four months.

UTICA, N.Y., April 2.--Sixty carpenters, employed by different contractors, struck yesterday for an advance of 50 cents a day, which was refused. To-day a number of journeymen from other places have been engaged, and employers say they have many applications for work on file. Present scale of wages, $2 to $2.75.

It was with pain that we yesterday transferred to our columns what the Baltimore Sun heartlessly described as "a good story," and inaccurately added that it was "at the expense of JAY GOULD." As all our readers know, the bad story was that Mr. GOULD invited ....
EMINENCE, Ky., April 2.--J.F. Randall, Postmaster at New-Castle, Ky., is a defaulter to the amount of $800, and has disappeared. The Government agent is in possession of the office.

Gens. Newton and Hunt and Major J.A. Stine called on Gen. Grant yesterday and invited him to accompany them on the historical visit to Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, and the Wilderness on May 15. The General could not accept the invitation now but said if well enough at the time he would be glad to go.

WASHINGTON, April 2.--Mr. Bliss, in beginning his testimony before Mr. Springer's committee to-day, said that the original contracts on the 19 routes included in the Dorsey prosecution amounted to $41,135. When increased they amounted to $448,670.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2.--At a largely attended meeting of the Philadelphia County Medical Society a proposed amendment to the constitution permitting the admission of female physicians to membership was defeated by a vote or 79 yeas and 48 nays, it requiring a two-thirds vote for the passage of the amendment. The admission of females has several times before been denied by the society.

WASHINGTON, April 2.--The following named officers will be relieved from duty at the Military Academy at West Point on Aug. 28: Capt. Charles H. Hoyt, Assistant Quartermaster: Capt. Robert H. White, Assistant Surgeon; First Lieuts. James O'Hara, Third Artillery; Edward W. Casey, Twenty-second Infantry; ...

The public hearing before the Aqueduct Commissioners on the plans of the proposed water-works was continued yesterday. The Mayor was present for a short time only. E.H. Lacombe, Assistant Corporation Counsel, who drafted the act under which the commission was formed, was ....
John F. Slater, of Norwich, Conn., is at the Hotel Brunswick. Prof. J. Henry Thayer, of Cambridge, Mass., is at the Everett House.

At a meeting of the military order Loyal Legion last evening the following new members were elected: Capt. John H. Coster, United States Army,(retired,) Brevet Major United States Volunteers; Paymaster Henry T.B. Harris, United ....

Edwin Wainwright has begun a suit in the Supreme Court for the recovery of $3,000 damages against Reuben W. Howes, Henry H. Landon, and Leander T. Howes, who composed the banking firm of Howes Co., of No. 11 Wall-street, that recently failed.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 2.--Schenectady County elected six Republican and four Democratic Supervisors.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 2.--A fatal railroad accident occurred 25 miles from this city last night, about 10:30 o'clock. The south-bound passenger train on the Alabama Great Southern Road, when near Trenton, Ga., ran into a large tree that had fallen across the road.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2.--Much excitement was caused to-day by an explosion of benzine and a fire at the store of Simon Co., oildealers, North Front-street. Charles Simon, senior member of the firm, and Henry Johnson, an employe, were badly burned. The loss will not exceed $7,000.

Five young candidates for the ministry sat in the meeting-room of the Broadway Tabernacle, at Thirty-fourth-street, the greater part of yesterday, and were plied with questions on Greek and Hebrew, theology, church history, and religious doctrines by the Rev. Drs.A.J. Lyman, ...

An inquest was held yesterday afternoon by Coroner Menninger in the case of James Halpin, who died on Friday afternoon at the Brooklyn City Hospital. Halpin was found on the morning of the day of his death under a shed at the rear of the liquor saloon at No.181 Myrtieavenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 2.--At the instigation of James Gallagher, of this city, the Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, A.E. Burr, the editor of the Hartford Times, and who for the last 20 years has been dictator in State ...

ATLANTA, Ga., April 2.--The white man's Republican Party in Georgia is gaining strength from the class for whose benefit it is intended, but the colored people are more united than ever on governing the party.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 2.--The news that the miners would work three weeks out of every four for the next four months is received very favorably here, and it now thought that whatever dissatifaction there is among the miners and laborers will soon pass away.
The New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church opened its thirtysixth annual session yesterday in the HansonPlace Church, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--Anthony O'Donnell will shortly enter suit against the Guion Steam-ship Company for $100,000 damages. Mr. O'Donnell alleges that his wife, who took passage in the steam-ship Arizona, in October, 1881, died from neglect while en route to America.

Senator Mahone's condition to-day is neither better nor worse than it was yesterday. His physician insists upon quiet and rest as essential to his restoration to health, and friends of the Senator, among them Mr. Riddleberger, admit that his illness is serious.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 2.--A cable dispatch was received here to-day stating that the Yarmouth bark Souvenir, from St. John, New-Brunswick, for Liverpool, has been abandoned at sea and her crew landed in the United Kingdom. The vessel was owned. by N.D. Lovett, of Yarmouth, and is partly insured in Halifax offices.

KEY WEST, April 2.--Trustworthy reports say that the schooner Sholers left here last night with Gen. Aguero and 20 men well armed for Cuba. The Spanish Consul is aboard the Dix. There is great excitement here.

The managers of the Produce Exchange have decided to have a ladies' reception in the large trading-room of the new building on Monday night, May 5. There will be music and flowers, and it is more than likely that there will be dancing.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., April 2.--At Fairview yesterday, John W. Gibson, a young ruffian, walked into a grocery store and fired two pistol-balls into the heart of John McCoy, killing him instantly. No reason is assigned for the deed. Gibson escaped, but a party of citizens are in pursuit. If Gibson is caught he will be lynched.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 2.--The Secretary of the Missouri State Board of Agriculture, who has received reports from every county in the State, says the average of the growing wheat is 98 per cent., and is improving. He also states that the percentage of wheat now in the hands of producers is 17 , and of corn 24. Peaches have been severely injured. Apples promise fairly, but the crop of small fruits will be short.

The very fine 160-acre farm belonging to the estate of the late Jeremiah Van Reed, in Amity Township, Berks County, Penn., has been willed to James Warren Van Reed, now 5 years old, thus descending in uninterrupted succession in the Van Reed family for over 150 years.
BOSTON, April 2.--The liabilities of I.W. Dodge, grain-dealer, of Beverly, are stated to be about $52,000, of which $19,000 is secured by mortgages. The remainder is unsecured.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 2.--The Methodist Boundary Commission began its session here to-day. The commission is composed of five members of Vermont Conferences.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 2.--The House to-day passed the Biennial Session amendment, 174 to 40, the necessary two-thirds vote for its submission to the people. The Senate had previously passed it by a vote of 20 to 1.

Perry, who stated that Mr. R.K. Eliot, who was the prisoner's counsel, had this morning written that he was quite unwell.
LOUISVILLE, April 2.--Deputy United States Marshal Campbell arrived in town to-day with 20 moonshiners captured in Greene and Casey Counties, where their distilleries were destroyed.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 2.--The latest intelligence from the scene of the attempted murder of a farmer named Owens and his wife in Roanoke County is to the elect that Owens is still alive, but in a critical condition, and that his wife will recover. BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 2.--The body found near Owego on Monday afternoon in the Susquehanna River proves to be that of Alexander Wayne, of Bath, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 2.--The cattle situation to-day was even less confident than the preceding days of the week. A considerable increase in the supply without a corresponding improvement in the demand placed holders at a disadvantage.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 2.--The railroad between McMinnville and Sparta will be completed, in a few days, within six miles of Sparta. The owners are constructing another road from Dickson to Centreville.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 2.--Large conflagrations are raging along the line of the Charlotte, Columbia and Augusta Railroad and the Central Road. On the former line several houses have been swept away by the flames and the fires are spreading.
TRENTON, April 2.--The Railroad Tax bill was called up in the Senate again this morning, and was discussed more or less during the entire day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 2.--The German Independents have looked the field over carefully and have decided that no ward nominations will be made by them, and that they will take no position concerning city officers until after the Republican and Democratic Conventions have made their nominations.
BERLIN, April 2.--That the German Liberal Party is beginning to be recognized as a new and important force in German politics is daily becoming more evident.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--A wind storm that in many respects resembled a cyclone, passed over the city this morning at 9:30 o'clock. The sky grew intensely dark very suddenly, and for a few minutes the streets were swept by a terrific gale, accompanied by thunder, lightning, and hail. Chimneys and signs were blown down in all directions; and in some quarters serious damage was done.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., April 2.--An explosion of powder occurred in a cross-heading in a breast of Mount Carmel colliery this afternoon, horribly burning John Shovelowsky and serious-- ly injuring Francis Entowk and another miner. The explosion was caused by a spark falling into a keg of powder while Shovelowsky was preparing a cartridge.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 2.--In the United National and Mercantile Banks the former has five local Directors and the latter ten. In transactions in which the amount involved exceeds $1,000,000 the five Directors of the National residing in Paris can vote. The total capital is $20,000,000, of which $8,000,000 is paid up. The Government has encouraged the fusion, and the consolidated banks can if they desire have the settlement of the national debt.

An open competitive examination of applicants for positions in the State service will be held in New-York and Brooklyn on April 24. Applicants for vacant positions in the emigrant depot at Castle Garden will be examined at that time. All applications must be on blank forms, which will be furnished by the Civil Service Commission at Albany upon request by mail. The completed applications must be made on or before April 14.

DETROIT, Mich., April 2.--In three of the Congressional districts in this State the Republican Committee have called district conventions to elect delegates to the National Convention at Chicago. In the remaining eight districts the plan heretofore adopted in this State will be pursued.

BOSTON, April 2.--A peculiar slander case was decided in the State Supreme Court to-day, in the suit of Plummer Chesley against Samuel Thompson.

ALBANY, April 2.--Six more of the NewYork City reform bills were discussed in a rational manner by the Assembly to-day, and were ordered to a third reading. There were no hitches in Speaker Sheard's rulings, and all went well with the proceedings necessary to enter the Committee of the Whole.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 2.--Prof. Cyrus Northrup, of Yale, has accepted the Presidency of the Minnesota State University at Minneapolis. He will leave Yale in June and will enter upon his new duties in September.

MILFORD, Penn., April 2.--The fishermen of Pike County rejoiced grimly yesterday. There was a cold and biting northerly wind blowing. Something like a foot of snow was still lying back in the woods along some of the best trout streams. The creeks were swollen by recent rains until they were higher than usual.

BOSTON, April 2.--The proceedings in the suit of Henry A. Brassey, of London, against the New-York and New-England Railroad Company for the appointment or confirmation of a Receiver have been suspended pending the negotiations for an amicable adjustment.

LONDON, April 2.--Dispatches from Gen. Gordon of March 18 have been received. These state that El Obeid is poverty-stricken and destitute of trade. Few of the Mahdi's followers are there. There are no signs that the Mahdi is about to advance upon Khartoum.
LONDON, April 2.--The Stock Exchange will be closed on Saturday, the day of the funeral of the Duke of Albany.

VERMEJO VALLEY, New-Mexico, April 3. --Two desperadoes, named S. Langston and G. Hill, entered the store of Poller Romero to-day and asked for whisky. On being refused, they drew revolvers, Killed Poller Romero and his brother Juan Romero and wounded two other persons. They then made their escape.

The Chamber of Commerce held its last monthly meeting in its old quarters in Williamstreet yesterday noon. Before the first of next month the Chamber will occupy its handsome rooms in the new Mutual Life Insurance Building in Nassau-street.

Capt. Abraham Latourette's schooner, the James Butler, of Tottenville, is supposed to have been lost with all on board during the fierce gale on Saturday night last. Capt. Latourette was one of the oldest oystermen and seamen on Staten Island, having been engaged in the business over 50 years.

The third concert given by the NewYork Chorus Society this season took place at Steinway-Hall last night in presence of a very numerous audience. The programme included a "Stabat Mater" by Anton Dvorak, Wagner's "Siegfried Idyl," and excerpts from "Der Fliegende Hollander" and "Die Meistersinger."

RICHMOND, Va., April 3.--Much anxiety is felt among the Coalitionists here about the illness of Senator Mahone. Many of the leading members of that party in this city have to-night manifested a great desire to hear the latest and most trustworthy information from the bedside of their sick chieftain.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 3.--Miss Fannie G. Porter, daughter of Mrs. Porter, Postmistress at Russellville, Ky., was married at Ocala, Fla., March 26, to Mr. Clem Dickey, of Colorado. There is quite a romance in Miss Porter's life. Over a year ago, late in the evening, she was walking with some young lady friends, when an old, grayhaired, ragged tramp approached the party.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 3.--Up to to-night the river here has fallen 10 inches below the highest water mark. As the water falls in front the back-water of the crevasses is coming up in the rear of the levees on the westbank, so that the streets of Algiers and Gretna, opposite NewOrleans, are invaded.

NEWPORT, Penn., April 3.--The Republican Convention of the Eighteenth Congressional District, representing Huntingdon, Juniata, Fulton, Franklin, Perry, and Snyder Counties, elected Blaine delegates to the State Convention today. The credentials were not given to the delegates until they signed a written pledge to support Blaine for the Presidential nomination.

UMATILLA, March 16.--In answer to a request made by a delegation of Columbia River Indians to the commander at Fort Walla Walla, for a conference where they might be permitted to state their grievances and get information and advice concerning the locating of their land by the whites, Capt. Upham, of the First Cavalry, by appointment, met a delegation on Saturday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 3.--Judge Baxter, of the United States Circuit Court, to-day ordered a decree to be entered in the suit of the National Telegraph Company against the NewYork, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company, enabling the National Telegraph Company, now controlled by the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company, to open its lines between New-York and Chicago over the West Shore and Nickel Plate Roads at once for business.
Edward L. Hedden, who was appointed Rapid Transit Commissioner in place of A.L. Earle, took his seat in the board yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 3.--The State Democratic Executive Committee will meet on April 18 to select a time and place for the meeting of the State Convention to nominate a candidate for Governor and to elect delegates to the National Convention.

Smith, of and from Rockland, Me., for New-York, lime-laden, went ashore near the Peaked Hill Bar life-saving station, about 2 o'clock this morning. The crew of the station got a line to the wreck and landed the crew. The cargo of lime will probably catch fire.

CLARKESBURG, West Va., April 3.--Noah Kittle, leader of the notorious Doddridge County Red Men, and the last one of the gang indicted for mail robbery, was to-day sentenced by Judge Jackson to four years' imprisonment in the penitentiary.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 3.--George, alias "Babe," Jones, the colored boy murderer, convicted of killing JOhn Foster, also colored, was hanged in the County Jail yard here this morning in the presence of several hundred spectators. The doomed boy met his fate unflinchingly. He slept soundly last night from 9 o'clock until 5 this morning, when he arose and partook...

CLEBURNE, Texas, April 3.--Word was received last night from Alvarado that Dr. Nix, at that place, was shot in the head by his brotherin-law, and will probably die. The affray was a continuation of an election difficulty of the previous day. Officers from Cleburne have been called by telegraph to Alvarado to aid in restoring quiet.
William Brown, 28 years old, of No. 553 West Thirty-ninth-street, an old offender, was arrested yesterday afternoon for counterfeiting ten-cent pieces.

NORWICH, N.Y., April 3.--In November, 1878, when Walton Dwight died at Binghamton, he had policies of insurance on his life amounting to $256,000. This amount was distributed among about 22 companies. Two of these companies--the Equitable, of New-York, and the National, of Washington--paid their losses promptly when the investigation was completed.

NEWTON, N.J., April 3.--The Suit of Christian Fiegenspahn, the Newark brewer, against Judge William H. Morrow, of Belvidere, for alleged libelous remarks in a temperance address at this place last Winter, was begun in the Circuit Court this afternoon.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 3.--Yesterday exSenator Norris Winslow was here in consultation with Collector of Customs Lamore and other Federal office-holders for the purpose of arranging plans to carry the caucuses and conventions in this county in the interest of Arthur.

BOSTON, April 3.--There was an unusually quiet observance of Fast Day in Boston and the vicinity to-day. The Federal and local Government buildings were closed and all other business was neglected, and services were held in nearly all the churches, including the cathedral, and in the State and city charitable institutions. LONDON, April 3.--Reports are current that Gen. Gordon has had another reverse. The explorer Schweinfurth has received a letter from Gen. Gordon, in which the latter says that the demeanor of the people has changed since he was last in the Soudan.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 3.--A terrific wind-storm prevailed throughout this section last night. Several houses were blown down in adjoining counties and great destruction was caused in the suburbs of this city. Two large tobacco factories were unroofed here. Trees were uprooted and fences were torn to pieces.

Capt. Charles F. Woolsey, one of the oldest of the pilots of this port, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, No. 344 Bedfordavenue, Brooklyn. He was born at Cornwallon-the-Hudson in 1820.

From having been one of the most cultured and interesting of men John F. Delaplaine has become weak in mind and unable to care for himself. For many years Mr. Delaplaine was Secretary of the American Legation at Vienna. He was wealthy, and artistic in temperament.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 3.--A. Taloner, of Chicago; Frank Bosallton, James Gilberry, and two others were killed by a blasting accident at Port Arthur, on the line of the railroad, yesterday.
RICHMOND, Va., April 3.--The Providence League Club played its first game of the season here to-day when it encountered the Virginia nine.
Mr. Archibald Forbes is a graduate of the University of Aberdeen, and his Alma Mater has just done him the honor of conferring upon him the degree of LL.D.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 3.--This evening Fannie, second daughter of A. C. E. Bondaurant, of Altoona, was married to Samuel Perdue, a thrifty young farmer near that place. Among the presents was a four-thousand-dollar farm from the bride's father. A large party of students in Drake University attended the wedding.

Between 400 and 500 members of the Produce Exchange met yesteday afternoon to discuss the question of silver coinage. Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, upon invitation of the Exchange, made a speech in which he declared that the interests of capital and labor were the same on this subject. The rich man and the poor man were interested in having a dollar worth 100 cents at all times and in all countries.

DETROIT, Mich., April 3.--The copper product of Calumet and Hecla Mine for March was 2,062 tons; Quincy, 230 tons; Franklin, 175 tons; Atlantic, 175 tons. Last year's output of Atlantic foots up 1,928 tons.

It is not always that school children are benefited by a rule forbidding corporal punishment. Where this rule exists ingenious school teachers have frequently invented punishments which are decidedly worse than the old-fashioned flogging. There are means of defense against the rod which deprive it of half its terrors.

MONTREAL, April 1.--What is said to be an unprecedented ruling of a Judge of the Supreme Court, and which has caused some indignation in English-speaking legal circles here, was given a few days ago by Justice Henri Taschereau, at Riviere du Loup.
LONDON, April 4.--Charles Reade, the novelist, who has been passing the Winter at Cannes, has returned to London in very ill health, and is said to be rapidly sinking.

NORWICH, N.Y., April 3.--When the charter was granted to the New-York and Oswego Midland it authorized the building of a branch extending from the main line to Auburn, branching at Norwich. This branch was built as far as Cortland, where it connected with a road running from Utica to Auburn, and the remainder was never built.

SHREVEPORT, La., April 3.--Major C.G. Thurmond, a prominent member of the Cotton Exchange and a well-known cotton operator, committed suicide last night by shooting himself through the head. The act was caused by financial embarrassment.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 3.--Manager McKee, of the Milwaukee Base-ball Club, to-day secured E.L. Cushing for pitcher, at a salary of $3,000. Cushing was with the Buffalo Club last year. The Milwaukee team is now complete, and the expenses for the season will amount to $53,000. Fifty-three regular League games will be played.

UNION HILL, N.J., April 3.--On complaint of the Rev. Mr. Sheik, who has charge of the German Lutheran Church, Otto Schultin was arrested here to-day for molesting the Pastor and his flock. Yesterday Schultin hung an objectionable card on the Pastor's door. Schultin was put under bonds to keep the peace.
The "San Joaquin Valley Regulators" have Modesto County under their thumb. The regular County Government seems to have gone out of business.

Jones came up for decision yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, before Justices Smith and Ford. Mr. Humphrey was present, cool and collected, with counsel.

With her were several other ladies and a gentleman, all of whom scanned closely the faces of the different prisoners who were arraigned at the bar for sentence.

CHICAGO, April 3.--Jacob Schaeffer and George F. Slosson were matched to-day to play two games of billiards, in accordance with the terms of Slosson's challenge issued last week. The first game will occur May 12, and will be for the balk-line championship, now held by Schaeffer, 800 points, 8-inch line.

Knox, Controller of the Currency, does not rest under the remarks made concerning him by Mr. Knox on March 24 in the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House.

The bill was not engrossed until 3 o'clock, but was taken up on third reading as soon as it was finished and rushed over to the House for concurrence in the Senate amendments.

A Detroit lawyer received a visit the other day from a farmer in a neighboring county, who stated that he had fallen into trouble with some of his relatives over the division of an estate.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 3.--The complete vote for Gov. Bourn (Rep.) is 15,903 and for Segar (Dem.) 9,599; scattering, 15.

Mr. Henry George, who is now in London, after carrying the fiery cross of land nationalization and confiscation through the United Kingdom, called in at the Pall Mall Gazette office yesterday, and in the course of conversation gave a very enthusiastic account of the success that has attended his tour.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 3.--John Gangsloff, a miner employed at Plymouth mine No. 3, was instantly killed last evening by a heavy fall of top rock. William Hunt, while repairing the track at Reynolds mine, No. 16, Plymouth, was run over by a car and killed.

LEXINGTON, Ga., April 3.--Five prisoners escaped from the jail this morning. When the tailor went to give them their breakfast one of them knocked him down with a chain and all five escaped.

The Board of Managers of the National Temperance Society gave a receptien, last evening, in the parlors of the Broadway Tabernacle, to Thomas H. Barker, Secretary of the United Kingdom Alliance, and William Hoyle, of the Alliance Executive of Manchester, England.

Society people in Brooklyn were busy last evening attending weddings. One was the marriage of Miss Mary Belle James, the eldest daughter of Congressman D.R. James, to Mr. Horatio M. Adams, by the Rev. Mr. Foot, at the Throop-Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 3.--Benjamin Bissell, a farmer, was stopped by three teamsters at Torrington, on Monday, and assaulted for blocking the road. He defended himself with a cart-stake, and whipped all three, being himself badly beaten. James McCone, one of the teamsters, has since died, and is found to have his skull fractured in many places by Bissell's blows. Bissell is sick in bed, and the inquest has been adjourned until next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--The Evening Star to-night prints the following: "A Star reporter was informed this afternoon, by authority entitled to credit, that a dispatch had been received from Mr. Oliver Payne denying the statement imputed to him that his father would not accept the Democratic Presidential nominatior as a 'pure fabrication.' It is understood that the dispatch was sent to Representative Paige, of Ohio."

Logan, the Assignees of W.J. Best, for $600,000 in cash. The interest of the State is $520,000, and the State is also bound for the interest...

EUFAULA, Ala., April 3.--The steamer Rebecca Everingham, one of the Central Line boats plying between Columbus, Ga., and Apalachicola, Fla., was burned to the water's edge at Fitzgerald's Landing, four miles above Florence, Ga., and 28 miles above Eufaula, at 4:05 o'clock this morning.
The Shoe and Leather Reporter has made the painful discovery that very few brass bands can play as many airs as a Drum Major puts on.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 3.--The race meeting was continued to-day. The weather was cloudy and cool. The track was dry.

NEW-ORLLANS, April 3.--On April 19, 1883, an old and faithful police officer named John Coffey was called upon to arrest a noted negro assassin and highwayman named Gosset for a theft he had just committed in a negro deadfall on Franklin-street, in this city. Gosset resisted arrest, and finally drew a weapon and shot the officer, who died in a few minutes.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, April 8.--The steamer Neptune has just arrived here from the seal fisheries with 41,500 prime harp seals, the largest fare on record. They were all taken in 12 days with 300 men. The cargo weighs over 800 tons, and is approximately valued at $125,000.

HAVANA, April 3.--An earthquake occurred at Santiago de Cuba on March 25, doing slight damage.

HAVANA, April 3.--An order has been received from Madrid reinstating Anibal Arriete as Custom-house Collector. He is the man who has strenuously imposed fines on American vessels and who within five months fined merchants $120,000.
WASHINGTON, April 3, 1884. William H. Woodward, of Carbondale, Ill., and Albert T. Summers, of Decatur Ill., have been suspended from practice before the Interior Department as pension attorneys.

WASHINGTON, April 3.--Alexander W. Miller, (white,) of Danville, was the first witness examined by Senator Sherman's sub-committee to-day. SCHENECTADY, April 3.--Cantine Co., manufacturers of agricultural implements, assigned to-day. Liabilities, $30,000; nominal assets, $40,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 3.--The trial of Dr. G.J. Robinson for the murder of Dan Laughlin is in progress at Smithfield, N.C. The murder was committed nearly two years ago, and was the result of a quarrel about a young lady of whom both men were admirers. Robinson stabbed Laughlin with a surgeon's lancet. The examination of witnesses was begun to-day, when six were examined. The case will be or several days. It attracts universal attention.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 4.--The meeting of the New-Orleans Jockey Club was continued here to-day. The weather was cloudy, but the track was in good condition.
MERRICK, Neb., April 4.--In an altercation here to-day about a young lady, Charles Willmore stabbed and killed Charles F. McCullum. The murderer has been arrested.

LONDON, April 4.--In Mincing-lane during the week sugars were dull; beet-root was lower. Coffee was irregular. Rice was firm. Tea was quiet; green was lower.

A.J. Drexel, of Philadelphia, is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Col. Burnley Campbell, of Scotland, is at the Windsor Hotel.

PORTLAND, Me., April 4.--Word was received here to-night that the schooner M.B. Tower, Capt. Maxwell, which sailed hence for Nassau on Feb. 24. has been wrecked. The crew were saved and taken to Gibraltar.

BOSTON, April 4.--The police of Chicopee and Springfield have traced to the vicinity of this city Louis Willett, the Kingston (N.Y.) boy murderer. Station Agent Cleveland, of Cottage Farm Station, remembered that a young man answering his description had lounged around the station from 9 A.M. till 1 P.M. yesterday, when he took the train for this city. The police here are making a diligent search for him.

A Berlin dispatch announces the death of Gustave Richter, the German painter. Herr Richter was born at Berlin, Aug. 31, 1823, and at an early age proceeded to Paris, where he studied painting under M. Leon Cogniet. In 1846 he exhibited a portrait in the Salon.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 4.--The high water news is favorable at every point. The water in front is slowly falling and the backwater is causing no new damage. Attention is now directed mainly to the work of relief, Major Whitehead, of the United States Commissary...

ALBANY, N.Y., April 4.--In the Court of Oyer and Terminer this afternoon Justice Westbrook announced that he had been unable to complete his decision in the case of McDonald, the contumacious witness, but would have it prepared by Thursday of next week, when it would he handed down.

It appears that the Weekly Tribune, unlike the daily, is not published exclusively for the best people. A recent advertisement asserts that it is the "People's Paper," and ready to descend like a depressing rain alike upon the just maidens of Vassar and the unjust farmers engaged in the milk business.

A few weeks ago the House passed a bill to relieve persons from the charge of desertion who had left their commands before being regularly mustered out. There was some doubt expressed at that time as to whether the measure was a carefully prepared one.

The entrance to Halifax Harbor is between Chebucto Head and Sambro Island on the west, with Devil and McNab Islands on the east. Sambro Island is small and rocky and lies about four miles south-west of Chebucto Head and about 15 miles east of south in a direct line from Halifax. It is surrounded by a multitude of shoals and rocks, which are known on the charts as the Sambro ledges.

BUFFALO, April 4.--The ward caucuses to elect delegates to the Congressional District Convention, and to the three Assembly District Conventions of Buffalo, were held in this city to-day. There was no contest on the general issue, and the vote was everywhere light.
MOBILE, Ala., Apri 4.--The Russian bark Finland, from Barcelona Feb. 10, has arrived here and reports the death of Capt. Sjahlom on March 8. when 500 miles east of the West Indies.
George W. Conkling, of Reno, who shot and killed Haverstick, the seducer of his sister, Mrs. Uhler, in New-York, is reported to be dying in this city of consumption.
Means to secure municipal reform were discussed by the City Reform Club in Lyric Hall last night.
"Do you mean to say you sell many of those fraudulent bonbons?" asked a TIMES reporter yesterday of the presiding spirit of an uptown candy store.

FORESTPORT, Oneida County N.Y., April 4.--The 15-year-old daughter of James Johnson, living four miles east of this place, was found dead in her bed on Thursday afternoon, with a bullet hole in her left breast.

WHEELING, West Va., April 4.--Casper Blumer, in charge of the Wheeling branch of the New-York cheese manufacturing firm of Roethlesburger Gerber, has left for parts unknown, first collecting all outstanding accounts and taking the money with him. Mr. Gerber, the junior member of the firm, has arrived in this city and is making an investigation. The amount involved is as yet unknown, but is thought to be large.
LONDON, April 4.--The Cabinet, after a thorough discussion, have decided against formally establishing a protectorate over Egypt.

WARRENSBURG, Mo., April 4.--On Monday the body of a man mangled by a train was found on the railroad track. It now appears that the deceased man was Carl Steedle, supposed to be from Erie, Penn., and traveling westward.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 4.--The Rev. J. A. O'Connor, of the Catholic Reformed Church, New-York City, has been delivering lectures in this city during the past three days, in which he exposed and denounced the Roman Catholic Church in the most bitter terms.

John Kelly presided over a meeting of the Tammany Committee on Organization last night. The question of attending the National and State Conventions in a body or as individuals way discussed, and, after hearing from the various district bosses, it was resolved to charter special trains and attend both conventions in a body.

That excitement may have seized some of the Democrats, but it is so skillfully concealed in their manly breasts that only a clairvoyant can discover it.

Dyer, and on being arraigned before Commissivner Hallet was held in $1,500 for examination. Dyer was also held in $1,000 for complicity in the matter for examination at the same time.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April. 4.--The delegates elected at the Republican County Convention met to-day in Congressional districts to elect delegates to the National Convention at Chicago. As predicted, there was a split in the Twentysecond Congressional District Convention, and two sets of delegates were elected who will go to Chicago and demand recognition from the National Convention.

Wickham, a member of the Virginia Senate, who said his position in the canvass was a peculiar one. Since 1865 he had been a Republican, and was so still. He was requested by the Democratic Convention to announce himself as a candidate.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 4.--For three days and nights the most destructive fires ever known in that section have been devastating the southern border of the State, extending into six or seven counties. Vast forests of long leaf pine have been attacked.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 4.--For the first time this season municipal politics are becoming interesting. Last night the combined opponents to the Democratic ring ticket submitted their list of candidates under the name of "the citizen and parish Democratic ticket." It has developed unexpected strength.

Dr. J. Adams Allen, President of Rush Medical College, Chicago, in speaking of Platt's chlorides, the universally approved houshold disinfectant, says: "I am much pleased with it. It is compounded scientifically, is odorless, yet very efficient, while not the least of its advantages is that it is afforded at a price which puts it within the reach of the vast majority of housekeepers."--Exchange.

NORWICH, N.Y., April 4.--On Dec. 13. last, after the verdict in the suit of Anna N. Dwight, Executrix of Walton Dwight, against the Germanic Life Insurance Company, had been rendered, the counsel for the defendant moved for a new trial on the ground that the verdict was contrary to the evidence.

Stephen La Forge. Jr., of Woodrow, Staten Island, took offense because his sister staid at the house of the Rev. William Cole, Pastor of the Methodist church of that village, as a companion to the clergyman's wife while that gentleman was attending Conference.
WASHINGTON, April 4, 1884. Senator Mahone is in an improved condition to-day. The Indian appropriation bill was passed by the House to-day.

A blustering wind howled around the office at No. 16 Court-street, Brooklyn, yesterday, where the investigation of charges against the two lawyers, Isaac Boyce and Robert Shannon, of this city, was continued. It crept under the windows, whistled through the key-holes, and gently toyed with the curly iron gray locks of Referee Bergen.

BLAIRSVILLE, Penn., April 4.--A boiler explosion in W. H. Healey's flouring mill, yesterday wrecked the building and seriously injured Peter Stump, a fireman. Capt. Healey the proprietor of the mill, was also badly scalded about the legs and feet. The boiler had been considered unsafe for a long time.

Several of them werer recently taken from the train sick and are now in the Lehigh County Alms-house suffering from small-pox.

In the examination yesterday, in the Essex Market Police Court, of James E. Wright, a reputed officer of Mr. Whitney's society, charged with black-mailing George Herbener, proprietor of a saloon at No. 381 Bowery, the prisoner said that about six weeks ago he was working in a book-bindery, when Charles Rilling came to him and said: "You are not doing very well here. Suppose you help me sell fire-escapes for Mr. Whitney."

RALEIGH, N.C., April 4.--There was an alarm of fire here to-day, and the chemical engine, in going to the fire, knocked down and ran over Jonas Rosenbaum, a prominent dry goods merchant. The fire was in the lumber-yard of T.H. Briggs, and was quickly put out. Mr. Rosenbaum is seriously hurt about the head, and probably both legs are broken above the knee.
The Executive Committee of the Maritime Exchange ascertained recently that the expenses for last year exceeded the income by about $7,000.

The main agony is over. The minor agonies begin. The great army of the rejected has finished lamenting its dead and now proceeds to the more convincing sport of criticising the accepted. The unfailing argument against the justice of committees of acceptance, "If they took that thing, how dared they decline mine?" has plenty of material to work with.

Two years and a quarter have passed since Postmaster-General JAMES, in obedience to the law, asked Mr. GEORGE BLISS, a representative of the Department of Justice, to cause civil suits to be brought against several star route contractors to recover hundreds of thousands of dollars which they had fraudulently taken from the Treasury.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 4.--The Assembly committee appointed to investigate alleged frauds in repairs to State armories met here today and held a secret session. Several officers of the militia and local mechanics testified to what they knew concerning the matter. It is reported that the evidence shows that the bills for repairs to the Oswego Armory were raised to large and fraudulent figures before they were finally audited.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4.--About 30 leading colored citizens visited Mayor King yesterday, in the office which he will vacate next Monday, their mission being to express to him, in a formal address, the gratitude of the colored people for the position he took and maintained in their interest.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., April 4.--Joe Hartado, whose death sentence was recently confirmed by the United States Supreme Court, died in jail last evening from consumption.
The Connecticut Democratic State Convention is called to be held in New-Haven on Thursday, June 5.

Ryle. The corespondent is Sergt. Edward A. Gaus, of the Twelfth Precinct Police, Brooklyn.
