TROY, N.Y., April 4.--While T. Dorsey, a " clay breaker" in the steel-works, was busy at his work this afternoon his clothes caught in the machinery, and he was hurled around a shaft feet to the ground and lived but a short time after being picked up. He leaves a widow and family.
Emilia Merkuls, aged 40, of No. 149 East Houston-street, charged Jacob Merkuls, a tailor, of No. 310 Broome-street, with abandonment, yesterday, in the Essex Market Police Court.

PANAMA, March 25.--Andres Lopez, who attempted to assassinate Gen. Aldana, President of the State of Cundinamarca, and who severely wounded him and killed a bystander, has been tried and sentenced to eight years in the penitentiary.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 4.--The Premier of British Columbia telegraphed to his Provincial Secretary yesterday not to allow 500 Chinese, who are hourly expected, to land in the Province. The Smithe bill, recently passed by the Legislature of British Columbia, gives the Government power to prohibit Chinese immigration, and the Premier intends to exercise this power until the bill is disallowed by the Dominion Government.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 4.--George W. Clay Co., wholesale notion dealers, have failed. Their liabilities are $22,000 and the assets $30,000.

Harrington, who are charged with conspiracy to defraud the American Legion of Honor by securing the insurance of dying persons, were arraigned in Judge McGill's court, Jersey City, yesterday, on a new indictment. It is based on the Insurance of Catharine Dinan, who died soon after the policy on her life had been secured of a chronic disease. They pleaded not guilty and were remanded for trial.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 4.--The preliminary hearing in the case of James E. Crann, the striking spinner, charged with manslaughter in causing the death of John Schofield, the old man who took a striker's place in the Chase Mill, was begun in the District Court to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 4.--Senator Miller to-day sent a dispatch from Washington to the Republican State Central Committee absolutely declining the Presidential candidacy of the Republican National Convention at Chicago.

MAGNOLIA, Miss., April 4.--George Lee, colored, age 18, was arrested in McComb City today for committing an assault on a girl of 4 years. He was conveyed to this place and lodged in jail. ALBANY, N.Y., April 4.--The steamer City of Troy last night ran into an ice barge which had stranded on a newly formed bar below this city. Both boats were damaged, but the steamer proceeded on her way to New-York.

TROY, N.Y., April 4.--While Alexander Geddes, a boy, was examining a revolver of 38 calibre this afternoon, the cartridge exploded, and Joseph Edwards received the ball in the fleshy part of his arm, passing out, striking and going through the left arm of Arthur Schudder. The next victim of the ball was Jeremiah Hennessy, who received it in the back. The latter's wound may prove fatal.

LONDON, April 4.--Mr. Bright, who has bees suffering from congestion of the lungs, is better.

The Arion Society gave a concert at Steinway Hall yesterday evening, in presence of an overflowing audience. The performances, both vocal and instrumental, introduced to the public the new musical director of the society, Mr. F. van der Stucken, who approved himself a very rara avis among local conductors by making known several works that showed him in the light of a composer as well as a leader.

The Daniel Steinmann was one of the vessels of the White Cross Line. She was owned by Daniel Steinmann and Herman Ludwig, of Antwerp, and was originally known as the Khedive. She was built by Smeler Co., of Antwerp, in 1875, for the Baltic trade. She was constructed of iron, and was 277 feet and 5 inches long, 34 feet and 5 inches broad, and 22 feet and 4 inches deep.

TROY, N.Y., April 4.--M.R. Peck, one of the oldest and most prominent physicians of Glenn's Falls, dropped dead of heart disease, near his residence on Elm-street, this evening. He was 60 years of age.

UTICA, April 4.--The Herkimer County Republican Convention, to elect five State and ten Congressional district delegates, met in the Court-house in the village of Herkimer this afternoon. ELIZABETH, N.J., April 4.--At 6 o'clock last evening sparks from a locomotive on the Pennsylvania Railroad set fire to a frame building on Morris-avenue, near Broad-street, occupaid by William Neil as a butcher's shop.

MONTREAL, April 4.--A run-off attended by fatal consequences occurred on the Grand Trunk Railway two miles west of a place named Wales, 70 miles from Montreal, this morning. The accident happened to the morning express from the West, which consisted of engine, tender, baggage van, and 10 passenger cars. The engine left the track, dragging with it the baggage car and three passenger cars, which were set on fire by the lamps breaking.

The Spring season through the country has thus far been a good deal worse than the Winter. It was generally supposed by theatrical managers that nothing could be much worse than the business of the Winter. They have found their error, however, and many companies are canceling their time as rapidly as possible and making tracks for New-York. Here the worst Lenten season known for a long time is now being experienced.

GREENSBURG, Penn., April 6.--Last night while a dance was in progress at a farm-house near Salem a drunken row occurred in which one man was fatally, and three others severely, injured.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 6.--By last week's contest, in which the Gem City Polo Club defeated Indianapolis twice, the former becomes the national champions for another year, winning by 53 games out of 56.
Jem Ward, whom the cable reports as dying yesterday at the Licensed Victuallers' Asylum in London, was probably the oldest pugilist in England, and, perhaps, in the world.

PARIS, April 6.--Advices from tonquin report that the expedition to Hunghoa has started. The troops are massed at Sontay.

Patrick Doyle, 17 years old, was arrested on Friday by Policeman Eastwood, of the Ninth Precinct, who found him drunk and staggering through West-street.

SYRACUSE, April 6.--Last Tuesday evening while the young ladies sodality were engaged in devotional exercises in the school-house attached to the Church of the Assumption in this city, Joseph Hess, who has for several years been employed as engineer, entered and declared the boilers to be at the point of explosion.

CLEVELAND, April 6.--Unusual interest centres in the city elections of to-morrow, as they will largely show what effect the dilatory work of the Legislature in relief of the liquordealers has had on the position of that element, and also will give a "pointer" toward the result next Fall.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton sat in a chair behind the chancel rail of the Anthon Memorial Church yesterday morning for the first time in seven weeks.

Guffin, an employe of the Custom-house in Charleston, and formerly the Republican boss in this county, came up to control the convention and elect delegates to the State Convention pledged to Arthur.

Mme. Patti arrived at the Windsor Hotel last evening a little before 10 o'clock. Col. Mapleson and the other members of his company arrived in Jersey City about midnight by a special train over the Baltimore and Ohio Road.
It costs $2,000 a year to keep Augusta citizens in chewing-gum. Young ladies, especially those in school, are proverbially gum chewers, and it takes no small amount to keep them supplied.
At the meeting of the County Medical Society last evening Dr. Alfred C. Post occupied the chair. A paper on "Intestinal Obstructions" was read by Dr. David Webster.
Barnum's great show in Madison-Square Garden was witnessed by a large throng last night, which testified its delight by repeated bursts of applause.
Four philosophers sat about a round table in a hostelry in Twenty-fourth-street Sunday afternoon, and discussed the signs of the times as they quaffed their lager.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 7.--The Red Cross relief steamer Mattie Bell, from St. Louis, arrived at noon yesterday, and left last night for points on the lower river, the ultimate destination being New-Orleans. Miss Clara Barton, President of the society, was on board, with three other ladies, Gen. Field, and Agent Hubbell.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--A large crowd gathered at Pastime Park this afternoon to witness a dog race, in which the prizes were larger and on which more money was staked than on any similar contest ever held in this country.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 7.--To-day the stamp tax on wines, liquors, canned and preserved goods, foreign glassware, fancy goods, jewelry, fine hardware, boots, and hats went into effect.

Gen. Grant, who is staying at the Arlington, walked around his room without the aid of either stick or crutch last Saturday evening. This is the first time since the accident that he has been able to walk without assistance. The General is rapidly getting better.

Persons passing along Lexington-avenue at Forty-sixth-street, at about 6:45 o'clock last evening, were startled at suddenly seeing a mass of flames and smoke burst from the tall belltower of St. Peter's German Lutheran Church, on the south-west corner of those thoroughfares.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 7.--The long-expected turn in the wheat market began shortly before noon to-day, and in a few hours there was an advance on 'Change of nearly 3 cents. There were many peculiar features about today's market.

SUNBURY, Penn., April 7.--The Republicans of Northumberland County to-day elected J.H. Wagner as delegate to the National Convention, with instructions for Blaine.

ONEONTA, N.Y., April 7.--Mr. Wilbur wants two delegates to enable him to make a tie in the Congressional District Convention to be held at Cooperstown on Friday. A tie will secure his election as a national delegate, and once in the Chicago Convention his purpose is to support Mr. Arthur to his end.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 7.--The Hon. T.V. Powderly, Grand Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, accompanied by the Hon. W.H. Hines, addressed a large audience of miners and laborers at Nanticoke this evening.

PARIS, April 7.--Advices from Tonquin state that the French will attack Hung-Hoa on April 11.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 7.--To-night the Capital Hotel lobbies have been crowded with delegates to the Republican State Convention which meets here to-morrow. It will be a large convention.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 7.--The Governor to-day pardoned Edward Jones, convicted in New-York County of the crime of grand larceny from the person in the night-time, sentenced, Aug. 14, 1879, to the New-York State Reformatory, and subsequently transferred to Auburn Prison, the maximum term of imprisonment being 10 years.

Thomas B. Asten, President of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, has returned from his yachting trip to the Bermudas greatly improved in health, and was present yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.
The Cleveland and Metropolitan Clubs played the first of a series of three games of base-ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday.

TALLULAH, Ga., April 7.--The quiet prevailing for several days around the residence of John Hogan, a white hermit, who lived about five miles from this place, induced several persons to force an entrance to the house, when they found him dead upon the floor, face downward. A leather pouch was found on his person.

In the New-York Methodist Conference yesterday a resolution was presented vigorously protesting against the passage of the "Freedom of Worship" bill, now for the seventh time before the Legislature.
BALTIMORE, April 7.--Alexander F. Lusby committed suicide in Philadelphia to-day. He was 37 years of age, and had been librarian and actuary at the Maryland Institute since 1877.

BOSTON, April 7.--The annual meeting of the Mexican Central Railroad Company was held here to-day. The report submitted by the Directors shows: Gross earnings for 1883, $3,583,414; operating expenses, $1,988,048; net earnings, $1,595,366. Benjamin Fitch gave during his life more than $1,500,000 to charity, and in addition founded the Fitch Home for Soldiers in Danbury, Conn.
CHICAGO, April 7.--The Garden City Warehouse Company was closed by the Sheriff this afternoon on judgments aggregating $30,000 entered by confession to-day.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 7.--The dispatches received by the Journal from more than a quarter of the State indicate the most decided Republican gains.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 7.--District Attorney S.W. Melton, before leaving this city to attend the United States Circuit Court, which met in Charleston this morning, drew up from 15 to 20 bills of indictment against Deputy United States Marshals for malfeasance in office. This is the outcome of the investigations made by Special Agent Balean.

WHEELING, West Va., April 7.--David Keller, the pilot of the steam-boat Scioto, which was sunk by a collision with the John Lomas at Mingo, Ohio, on the night of July 4, 1882, when nearly 70 lives were lost, was to-day sentenced by Judge Jackson, in the United States District Court, at Parkersburg, to pay a fine of $500 and undergo imprisonment in the Moundsville penitentiary for a term of two years.
Mrs. J.W. Culver, of No. 990 Dean-street, Brooklyn, made some clam soup one evening in the earlier part of February.

The ship St. Paul, Capt. Williams, which arrived last evening from Liverpool, brought the crew of the Norwegian brig Varnaes, Capt. Tonnesen, which was abandoned on March 9 in latitude 42 29' and longitude 31 13'.
When the Alaska stopped at Quarantine last evening seven people climbed down a rope ladder into a tug.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--A reporter for the Philadelphia Times this afternoon saw George Dever, 6 years old, standing before Magistrate McClintock with a badly swelled nose, watery eyes, a head that looked as if it ached, and all the other evidences of a recent recovery from a terrific spree, while his father told the story of his debauch.

ERIE, Penn., April 7.--To-night's mail brought Caroline Steidler a confession of murder from the notorious Billy Hamilton, now in jail at Warrensburg, Mo., with one Charles Hamilton upon the charge of murdering Karl Steidler, of this city, last Wednesday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 7.--The Baptist Church at Tivoli is under the charge of the Rev. L.M. Ferris, who is unmarried. Four young ladies claim to have received attentions of a marked character from Mr. Ferris.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Mr. Joseph Medill, editor of the Chicago Tribune, made an argument to-day before the Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads in favor of the reduction of the present pound rates of postage on newspapers issued from the office of publication.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 7.--Edward Clayburg, of New-York, filed an answer this morning in the suit of his wife, "Lillian Spencer," the actress, for divorce. He denies that he was cruel to her, or pointed a revolver at her, or abused her in any way, and wants her to take him back. He demands a trial by jury. He also claims that she is not a resident of this State, and cannot bring a suit here.
A discussion was had in the Board of Aldermen yesterday on the evils of theatre ticket speculation.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 7.--The newly elected city officials assumed their offices to-day, and the Municipal Government was organized for the ensuing year.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 7.--Morgan I. Bulkeley, (Rep.,) was re-elected Mayor to-day for two years, being his third term, over Charles M. Joslyn, (Dem.,) by 830 majority.
The Democratic General Committee of Kings County met last evening in Music Hall, at Fulton and Flatbush avenues.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 7.--Judge Greer, in the Criminal Court this morning, overruled the motion of Attorney-General G.P.M. Turner for a new trial and sentenced him to pay a fine of $50, or to be imprisoned, in default of payment, for 30 days in the workhouse.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 7.--In the Sharon divorce case to-day George Dudley Gillard, employed in the Masonic Cemetery, testified in relation to the placing by Miss Hill of a package of Sharon's undergarments in a newly made grave.

In this wild hunt for Presidential candidates, either for the first or second place, the South is conspicuously ignored when it comes to naming men, as much so as the fitness and statesmanship are disregarded.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 7.--Complete returns from all the wards of the city assure a Republican victory by a decisive majority on the city ticket. At the Democratic head-quarters it is conceded that the Republican majority will be at least 2,500.

NEW-HAVEN, April 7.--Chief of Police Webster to-day informed the family of Owen Kelley that their son Charles was shot and killed in the Cincinnati riot and that the body awaited their disposal. Kelley was 16 years old, and was a wayward youth here. His mother is nearly dead with consumption. The family had not heard from him for three years.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 7.--This was the day fixed by the house carpenters for the inauguration of a strike for $3 per day.
The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company propose to capitalize the expense of making necessary improvements in its system, building new roads, About $7,000,000 will be needed.

A struck jury was sworn yesterday, before Judge O'Gorman, in the Superior Court, to try the suit of the New-England Iron Company against the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company, as the successor of the Gilbert Elevated Railroad Company.
CHICAGO, Ill., April 7.--Peter St. Claire Johnson, employed on the Grand Trunk Railway at Montreal, was arrested here to-day, and started in charge of an officer for Montreal.

LONDON, April 7.--The annual boat race between the Oxford and Cambridge University crews, which was to have taken place last Saturday, but was postponed on account of Prince Leopold's funeral, occurred this morning.

SHILOH, April 7.--The day broke bright, mild, and beautiful over Shiloh yesterday morning as the steamers John Gilbert and W.F. Nisbet, lashed together, steamed up to Pittsburg Landing with about 400 excursionists on board, mostly members of the Grand Army of the Republic from Illinois, Indiana, and Iowa.

At a meeting of the Republican District Committee of the Ninth Assembly District last evening, resolutions were adopted disapproving the action of the Republican County Committee "in assuming to apportion the representation of the various Assembly districts to the Congressional Convention as being in excess of its functions and of no binding effect."
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 7.--John M. Hickey's "Rip Van Winkle" company, who played an afternoon and evening engagement at the Grand Opera-house here Saturday, have come to grief.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 7.--A large number of the coal miners of Western Indiana have been on a strike for nearly two months. The strike was caused by the operators demanding a reduction of 25 per cent. in the price of mining.

READING, Penn., April 7.--Some years ago the divorced wife of Samuel Barto, the son of a liquor-dealer in this city, was married to Dr. James Y. Shearer, of Sinking Springs Village, a short distance from here, taking with her to her new home a child, the offspring of her marriage with Barto.

BOSTON, April 7.--A young man who tried to enlist in the navy this morning at the navy-yard was rejected and was afterward arrested on suspicion of being Willetts, the boy murderer, of Kingston, N.Y. He gave the name of Scully, and said he was from Woonsocket, R.I., and denied that he was the murderer.

ALBANY, April 7.--The indications are now that the Congressional District Convention to be held at Slingerlands on Wednesday to elect delegates to the Republican National Convention will be in the hands of the anti-Draper faction.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--A question of considerable interest to travelers returning from abroad, namely, what constitutes "wearing apparel in actual use," which, by the law, is exempted from duty, was decided by the Supreme Court of the United States today, in the case of William Astor, plaintiff in error, against Edwin A. Merritt, Collector.

QUEBEC, April 7.--The proportions of the exodus from this neighborhood to the United States are becoming alarming. From one parish in Montwagny alone last week 325 persons left, of whom 200 never intend to return to Canada.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 7.--The three men who brought the schooner Shavers back have been held by Judge Locke until to-morrow under $500 bonds each. The schooner has heretofore been incorrectly called the Shoters.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 7.--The Point Breeze Trotting Park, the principal racetrack in this city, was sold at Sheriff's sale this afternoon, to satisfy a mortgage held by the Fidelity Trust Company.
TORONTO, Ontario, April 7.--The Welland Canal is expected to be opened to navigation about April 28.

CHICAGO, April 7.--The receipts of cattle during Sunday and Monday were 5,700 head; same time last week, 4,872 head. Although the receipts were something like 1,000 head larger than for the same time last week the number was not above the average for a Monday, and under an active general demand the entire supply was exhausted by the middle of the afternoon.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 7.--S.W. Tallmadge, of this city, has late reports from the several State Agricultural Departments, the United States Statistical Agents, and private crop reports in regard to the present condition and general outlook of the growing Winter wheat.

JACKSON, Mich., April 7.--Judge Gridley to-day granted the application for bail for Dan S. Holcomb and Judd Crouch, who are charged with the murder of Jacob D. Crouch.

The facts elicited in the case of Camilio Farach, who was found dead in New-Brighton, Staten Island, on Saturday, are thought by the Staten Island authorities to warrant the conclusion that the death was the result of a duel between Farach and Antonio Flacomio, who is under arrest charged with his murder.

BOSTON, April 7.--Relative to the proposed changes in the management of the Union Pacific Railroad, it has been decided that Mr. Atkins will continue as Vice-President, and will, as for a number of years past, be in charge of the finance department, while the other gentlemen named for a Vice-President's position will act as the executive heads of their respective departments.

The international gun trial, under the direction of the Turf, Field and Farm, was bad on the grounds of the Carteret Gun Club last Thursday, Dr. William Crenshaw, John O. Macfarlane, and T.C. Abbott acting as judges.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--A meeting of the legislative committee to investigate the affairs of the Standard Oil Company was held at the office of the Chairman this afternoon.
A messenger boy delivered a note in Deacon Ranney's office last night. It was opened before a dozen gentlemen who had called to talk over the affairs of the Madison-Avenue Church.

Nevertheless, the poor baby toddled into Part I., Supreme Court, yesterday, while his sombre-looking nurse held his hand and occasionally spoke to him.
LONDON, April 7.--The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The outlook for the wheat crop is very good. Trade in wheat off strands was depressed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 7.--When the Court of Oyer and Terminer convened this morning, Judge Charles Daniels charged the Grand Jury at great length, and with a vigor that is believed to have been partially inspired by the Cincinnati riots.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 7.--New interest has been given the Bertha Chester alleged abduction case to-day by her elder sister Maud's denial that they were met in the street an hour or more after the alleged abduction is said to have taken place.

The first log-rolling scene of the present session of the House was witnessed this morning, when Mr. Stockslager was recognized to make a motion to fix a day for the consideration of the bills appropriating about $6,500,000 for public buildings.
CHICAGO, April 7.--The yearly meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company was held at the offices of the company to-day.
AUGUSTA, Me., April 7.--A special freight train bound south came into collision with a passenger train going north on the Maine Central Railroad, two miles below Hallowell, this afternoon.

EASTON, Penn., April 7.--The execution of John Dillman, the wife murderer, takes place at 10:30 o'clock to-morrow. The preparations are all complete, the scaffold having been erected in the jail yard this morning.
CAIRO, April 7.--Gen. Graham reached this city to-day. Gen. Stephenson, Commanderin-Chief of the British troops in Egypt, will tomorrow review the troops which have returned from Suakin.

Samuel Day, the champion twelve-houra-day pedestrian of England, who is to participate in the go-as-you-please race at MadisonSquare Garden, arrived in this city on Saturday on the White Star steam-ship Baltic.

Somebody proposes to cross the Atlantic this Summer in a small boat, and the press is now occupied in denouncing him as an idiot, and as far as is possible in discouraging him from making the attempt.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 7.--D.P. Crocker, Secretary and Treasurer of the American Paper Manufacturers' Association, has sent out a circular to the paper mill owners of the country calling for an assessment of 10 cents per inch on the width of the machines used in their mills.
The General Committee of the German-- American Independent Citizens' Association held a meeting last evening at Beethoven Hall, in Fifth-street, Gen. Franz Sigel in the chair.

NEWTON, N.J., April 7.--Judge Morrow, testifying in his own behalf in the libel case today, swore that he did not use Fiegenspahn's name in connection with the rat in a beer vat, nor in connection with the charges on the books of a brewery for drugs and chemicals used in the manufacture of beer.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Fireman Bartlett, of the Jeannette, resumed his testimony this morning before the committee charged with the investigation of the loss of the Jeannette. Witness had spoken to several of the seamen about the expedition previous to going before the court of inquiry.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 7.--George Peck, Jr., son of George W. Peck, the Milwaukee humorist, left to-day for New-York, where he will be married to Miss Annie Fitzgerald on April 23. The young man is associate editor of his father's paper.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 7.--No more bodies have been recovered from the wrecked steam-ship Daniel Steinmann. Divers went down this morning and made an inspection of the sunken vessel.
The resolution passed by the House Painters' Union on Saturday evening last to demand an advance of wages to $3 50 per day was carried into effect yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 7.--Congressman Davis was in the city to-day for the purpose of fence inspection, and had a prolonged conference with Collector Spalding.

A resolution was adopted by the Board of Aldermen yesterday declaring that all special privileges granted by the board to individuals or corporations to occupy any part of the surface of any street or public place for street stands, barber poles, storm doors, stepping-stones, banners, flags, or other obstructions shall terminate on May 1.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 7.--The sentence of John Thomas, to be hanged in Fairburn next Friday, has been commuted by Gov. McDaniel to imprisonment for life.

A quarrel occurred on Saturday night between William Anderson and Joseph Jefferson, both negroes, in the Virginia House, a disreputable resort on Coney Island, kept by a colored woman named Blanche Emerson.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--At last the Democrats have faced the tariff question, or a branch of it, and they have voted that tariff rates shall not be increased, in deciding that the tariff on wool shall not be restored to the rate in force in 1867.

Mr. J.C. Burrows, the newly appointed Solicitor of the Treasury, who is now at his home in Michigan, has been notified to take the oath of office, so that the Assistant Solicitor may legally perform the duties of the office until his arrival in Washington.

READING, Penn., April 7.--A feeble old man named George Ritner, living in an attic of a boarding-house, in this city, for a week past, met his death in a singular manner last night. He had attached to his bed-post a string of sleigh-bells, by which he could summon the family in case of need.
ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 7.--Chairman Hensel, of the Democratic State Committee, arrived here this evening, and with him were a number of delegates.

The Roosevelt investigating committee continued its examination of the methods of the Police Department yesterday, in the presence of as audience which filled the large parlor of the Metropolitan Hotel. Commissioners Mason, Matthews, and Nichols, Inspectors Byrnes and ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 7.--It is practically settled that Mrs. Angenette Haight, who is under sentence of death in the Madison County Jail for the murder of her husband, will not be hanged on April 18, the date fixed for the hanging.
COLUMBUS, Ga., April 7.--Disturbance of public worship in this city has grown so general that the authorities have been called upon to suppress it.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--The Philadelphia and Athletic Clubs met for the first time this season here to-day in the presence of fully 8,000 persons.
A Democrat well known in New-York, a gentleman who has been spending the Winter at the capital in the enjoyment of social pleasures, was met in the rotunda of the Capitol to-day.

CANTON, April 8.--The Republican convention in the Second District of St. Lawrence County elected H.O. Sweet, Ira, C. Miles, George C. Mowitt, and Worth Chamberlain as delegates to the Congressional Convention.
The Superintendent of the Prisons of this State, in reply to the Senate's resolution of inquiry, presents his views on convict labor at considerable length.

BOSTON, April 8.--Many prominent members of the Bar of this vicinity met here last evening to discuss candidates for the vacancy in the First Circuit Court Judgeship caused by the resignation of Judge Lowell.

BUFFALO, April 8.--The Republican Conventions in the Second and Third Assembly Districts of Erie County to elect delegates to the State Convention were held in this city to-day. In the Second District the following delegates were elected: John Kreitner, Louis Lorenz, Frank Sipp, Philip Steingoetter.

WATERTOWN, April 8.--The city caucuses this evening elected Blaine delegates to the Assembly Conventions from every ward. This gives the First District indisputably to the halfbreeds. The Second District is somewhat in doubt. The stalwarts worked hard to carry the caucuses, but they failed.

CROWN POINT, April 8.--Quiet indignation has been expressed among the rank and file at the idea of Gen. Hammond having taken a contract to deliver the delegates of Essex County, both State and Congressional Convention, to President Arthur.

Many immigrants who apply at Castle Garden for railway tickets to the West are provided with funds, although they profess to be destitute. Yesterday a Mrs. Eisenberg, who recently landed, asked for a ticket for herself and her four children to Chicago.

Helen Crane, of New-Jersey, at the recent session of the Wyoming Methodist Conference, continues to attract a good deal of attention throughout this region, owing to the unjust report of the ...
NEW CITY, April 8.--Rockland County is one of the many Assembly districts in the State which is opposed to the nomination of President Arthur for another term in the White House.

The committee having in charge the arrangements for the mass-meeting to be held at the Cooper Institute to-night to interest the members of the Grand Army of the Republic in the "Home" for disabled ex-Confederate soldiers, to be established in Richmond, Va., met last evening at the St. James Hotel.

The New-York Indian Association held a meeting last evening in the Calvary Baptist Church, Fifty-seventh-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues. Chief-Justice Noah Davis presided, and made an address urging the importance of atoning in some measure for the wrongs done the Indians.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 8.--Dr. P.C. Jewett, the eminent medical expert of NewHaven, Conn., is dangerously ill with pneumonia at the Narragansett Hotel in this city.

JUNCTION CITY, Kan., April 8.--Yesterday noon, as Tim O'Connor and his brother Mike were driving along the road adjoining Dry Creek, 12 miles from here, they were warned by Ernest Allen and others not to cross a certain piece of land belonging to the school district.

A young man who gave his name as Butler appeared at Castle Garden in a state of great excitement yesterday. He said that his sweetheart, who was named Clara Miller, had arrived on the Alaska, but he was afraid that she was lost, as she was not among those whom he had seen leave the Garden.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 8.--The street car conductors on the different lines about Pittsburg and Allegheny have formed a protective association and intend making a demand upon their employers for an increase in wages of 15 per cent. From one of the conductors it was ...

ALBANY, April 8.--Mr. House attempted to persuade the Assembly to drag the Anti-Free Pass bill out of the Judiciary Committee and pass it. There was an overwhelming vote against him, and the bill will continue to slumber in the committee, Mr. Van Cott's bill authorizing ...

JAMAICA, April 8.--If any lingering doubt of their waning power existed in the minds of the machine Republicans of Queens County the three conventions held here this afternoon must have gone a long way toward dissipating it. The bosses who have planned to begin at Montauk Point and deliver every delegate from Suffolk to St. Lawrence County over to Mr. Arthur will ...

FONDA, April 8.--The Republican Convention for Montgomery County was held here to-day. It was a disorderly body, and finally resulted in a split and two sets of delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions.

The horse cars on Madison-avenue left load after load of passengers in front of Dr. Newman's church last night. Cheap cabs, livery teams, and private carriages dropped groups of people at the wide-open doors. Pedestrians with dripping umbrellas marched up the steps in a constant stream.
SEDALIA, Mo., April 8.--Both Van Horn and Filley arrived in the city this morning, and are busy mustering their forces for tomorrow's battle in the State Convention.

In the suit of Albert A. Levy against James H. Corey a verdict for $2,000 was rendered far the plaintiff by a jury in the City Court, yesterday. Mr. Levy sued on the ground that Mr. Corey extorted $2,500 from him in August,1882, ...

RED BANK, N.J., April 8.--George W. Walling, Superintendent of Police of New-York City, is lying ill from nervous prostration at the house of John S. Conover, at Holmdel. Mr. Walling's illness is thought to have been caused by overwork and anxiety.

DENVER, Col., April 8.--At the annual meeting of the Colorado Coal and Iron Company, at Colorado Springs to-day, the following nine Directors were elected: A.H. Danforth, John H. Small, Henry E. Sprague, W.B. Lawrence, J.E. Devlin, A. Rutten, W.A. Dick, Coleman Benedict, and Thomas F. Ryan. The Palmer faction represented 31,000, and the anti-Palmer 56,900 shares of the total of 100,000. Henry Sprague will probably be chosen President.
BOSTON, April 8.--The Committee on Railroads resumed this morning its consideration of the question whether the locations of railroads shall not be used for the stretching of telegraphic wires.

Congressman Potter was accompanied to the meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday by Samuel McElroy, an engineer, who was prepared to give his opinions of the proposed water system for New-York. The certiorari cases of the Manhattan Railway Company and the New-York and Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Companies against the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment and the Board of Aldermen, were all on the calendar of the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8.--The Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners of Virginia met to-day for the purpose of construing an act of the Legislature intended to set apart a fund for the payment of interest on the public debt and the purchase of coupon bonds.

In the Hoboken charter election the Democrats were successful yesterday. Herman Timken was re-elected Mayor over E.V.S. Besson, his former antagonist, by 400, and all the other city officers are Democratic by majorities ranging from 400 to 800. The Democrats also elected a majority of the Board of Aldermen.

Mme. Adelina Patti was happy and vivacious in her parlors at the Windsor Hotel last evening. She had come back from her trip to the Pacific coast in the best of spirits and in perfect health. The large store of H. O'Neill Co., at Sixth-avenue and Twentieth-street, was thronged all day yesterday with ladies who had gone there to view the handsome display of goods comprised in the "Spring opening." The Jersey City charter election, which was held yesterday, was a tidal wave for the Republicans. The vote was very heavy, exceeding that of two years ago, when a Mayor was last elected by a majority of 3,250. The city is usually Democratic by about 2,000, but yesterday these figures were reversed, and Gilbert Collins (Rep.) was elected over John D. McGill ...

The Republicans of the District, who only enjoy the privilege, of voting when they exercise it in primary meetings and other ineffectual gatherings, have been in convention today in Willard Hall endeavoring to decide who shall be the District delegates to the National Convention.

UTICA, April 8.--The Rome caucuses tonight to elect delegates to the Twenty-third Congressional District and Second Assembly District Conventions resulted in the defeat of Arthur candidates in four of the five wards.

The first business at the meeting of the New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference yesterday was the unanimous adoption of resolutions with reference to the liquor question. The ministers held that the overthrow of the liquor power was to be secured only by constitutional prohibition.

Elliott Sandford, counsel for John Savage and other clerks who were removed from the City Court in January last, informed the Controller yesterday that he intended to institute proceedings for the reinstatement of the clerks or compensation while they are deprived of their situations.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 8.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Allegheny Valley Railroad was held to-day.

NEWTON, N.J., April 8.--After six hours' deliberation the jury found for the defendant in the Fiegenspahn-Morrow libel case. Judge Morrow is receiving congratulations on the verdict. It was thought that the jury would disagree. The temperance people feared that an adverse verdict would damage their cause throughout the State.
At the annual election for Directors of the Long Island Railroad yesterday, at the company's office in Long Island City, 177,296 votes were cast.
The Jewish festival of Pesach, or the Passover, will begin at sunset this evening and continue for seven days.
Mme. Modjeska is at the Clarendon Hotel. Capt. Henry Wilson, United States Navy, is at the Westminster Hotel.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 8.--The Government Inspector of Live Stock has lately returned from La Prairie County, and reports that four-fifths of the sheep in that county are infected with disease, and that a strict quarantine in the infected districts to prevent the spread of the disease is being enforced. Some of the sheep are without any wool whatever, and their meat is not recommended for food.

Several ex-policemen, who have been heretofore retired on pensions, met last evening at Military Hall, in the Bowery, to discuss a provision of the new Pension bill, which they believe will affect them injuriously.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, April 8.--There is official information that the Government has made an arrangement with the merchants regarding the stamp law which will remove all cause for trouble and anxiety. The situation at no time was as alarming as has been reported. All the merchants will reopen their places of business on Thursday.

The passage of Mr. BLAIR'S Education bill in the Senate on Monday marks the close of a difficult and laborious piece of work by that body, and is in strong contrast with the obstinate waste of time of which the House has been guilty. The voters who are interested in reform in this State will watch with keen interest the action of the State Senate on the Cities Civil Service bill when it comes up for passage. The amendments made on Monday evening were, as we have said, in part foolish and in part bad, and were wholly hostile to the bill.
MAHONOY CITY, Penn., April 8.--The Eastern Conference of the Primitive Methodist Church has been in session in this city for the last week. About 250 ministers are in attendance.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, April 8.--The eleventh annual meeting of the Wyoming Stock Growers' Association was held here yesterday. A delegation of 125 persons was present from the Colorado association.
BALTIMORE, April 8.--A convention of colored delegates, 60 in number, representing all the counties in the State and the several legislative districts of Baltimore, met in this city this afternoon.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 8.--The city election to-day was more than usually interesting on account of the interest attached to the prohibition fight, Lockport being the only city in NewYork which has voted for prohibiting the sale of liquor and beer.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 8.--It is generally admitted here to-night that the Democratic Convention is wholly in the hands of exSpeaker Randall. There are to be chosen tomorrow six delegates at large and three Presidential Electors at Large. The convention will also ratify the selection of district delegates to be made by the representatives of the several districts, and nominate a Congressman at Large.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 8.--Gov. J.M. Rusk will be renominated by the Republicans this Fall and the Democrats will run Congressman P.V. Deuster for Governor. John Black will be the Democratic candidate for Deuster's seat, and Edward Sanderson will probably be the nominee of the Republicans for Congress.

CHICAGO, April 8.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day and badly unsettled, though they did not fluctuate so widely as on some previous days. They started out stronger, but the strength did not last, and the final hour on 'Change was one of positive weakness, due to more confident ...

BERLIN, April 8.--Prince Bismarck, in a private conversation in which he explained his withdrawal from the Prussian Ministry, is reported to have said: "I am 70 years old. My nerves are in bad condition.

CLEVELAND, April 8.--Republicans and Democrats alike are surprised at the sudden change of front in Cleveland, going from some 4,000 Democratic last Fall to 3,000 Republican this Spring. There is a general feeling on both sides that the liquor question has much to do with the result, Republican leaders claiming that ...
QUITMAN, Ga., April 8.--A large force of negroes at work on the plantation of Col. F.J. Spain, while singing plantation songs, aroused the anger of one of their number.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.--The hearing in the New-York and Long Branch Railroad injunction suit was resumed in the main office of the Pennsylvania Road this morning by the cross-examination of Max Riebenach, Assistant Controller of the Pennsylvania Road. The witness figured the apparent profit of the Central ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 8.--Last Sunday a set of bells was blessed for the new German Catholic Church in this city. The Rev. Joseph Pickl, the Pastor, had announced an English sermon by the Rev. Mrs. Bathand Sherman, of No. 169 Hesterstreet, made a charge of abandonment before Judge Power yesterday against her husband, John Sherman, a Stage machinist, lately connected with John W. Ransome's "Across the Continent" Company.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., April 8.--A number of aged people have died in this vicinity during the past few days. John Lewis died at Franklin Furnace, aged 104. The day before he died he was out of the house and took a long walk. Previous to his fatal illness be had never been sick.

A verdict for $20,000 damages has been rendered by a jury in the Supreme Court in favor of Julius H. Hartenstein and against Adolph Vogel. Mr. Hartenstein alleged that Vogel had first been a frequent visitor at his home and next became a boarder there.

GREENSBURG, Ind., April 8.--Ben Jenkins, a druggist, shot and killed his son-in-law, Taylor Trimble, at St. Paul, last night. It is said that the murder was the result of an old grudge, and that Trimble fired first.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 8.--Three diving schooners with well-equipped crews were at the wreck of the D. Steinmann yesterday, and began taking out the cargo.

LONDON, April 8.--The returns issued by the Board of Trade show that during March British imports increased, compared with that month in last year, 1,400,000, and that during the same period the exports increased 3,300 as compared with the previous March.

EASTON, Penn., April 8.--John Dillman was hanged here at 11:10 this morning. Dillman slept well last night and ate a hearty breakfast this morning. Religious services were held in the cell by ministers of the German Evangelical and Reformed Churches.

ERIE, Penn., April 8.--Last week Mrs. Clark, wife of Dr. Clark, obtained a verdict against the Lake Shore Railroad for injuries sustained by being carried beyond her station and being put off at a dangerous place.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 8.--It looks at midnight as if the Democrats had for a second time cheated Dr. John Swinburne out of the office of Mayor by fraudulent voting, repeating, and wholesale bribery.

TORONTO, Ontario, April 8.--The Police Magistrate this morning gave his decision in the bribery conspiracy case. He said that owing to the unique nature of the case he had been careful to give it the most anxious consideration. There were two points, he said, to be considered:

PLATTSBURG, April 8.--At the primaries last night the straight Republicans carried two districts--the Second and Third--and the Democratic-Mooers--McCaffrey combination the other two--the First and Fourth.

The sixth and last concert of chamber music given by the Standard Quartet Club this season took place at Steck Hall last evening. Quartets by Beethoven, Schumann, and Haydn were played, Messrs. Brandt, Roebbelen, Scnwarz, and Bergner having the assistance of Mr. S.B. Mills in the Schumann number.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 8.--H.S. Remington, of Providence, R.I., a dealer in horses, arrived her last night, and was on his way to a hotel when he was struck down from behind and robbed of $2,800, which he had in a leather belt under his shirt. His condition is critical. It is supposed that the wounds were inflicted with a sand-club by some one well acquainted with Remington's affairs.

The Republican primary meetings of Essex County, N.J., were largely attended yesterday, and delegates were chosen for the State and district conventions unpledged. The Eleventh Ward of Newark expressed its preference for Lincoln as first choice for President, and then Blaine or Edmunds. At East Orange the vote stood 32 per cent. for Edmunds, 32 for Arthur, 28 for Blaine, 4 for Grant, and 4 for Lincoln.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 8.--The United States Circuit Court is in session here. The political cases arising out of the election in 1882 have been postponed, it is said, by order of the Department of Justice.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., April 8.--Frank James was arraigned this morning before Judge Bruce for the Muscle Shoals robbery. He pleaded not guilty. The hearing of the case was set for April 16.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8.--Bob Johnson, the well-known trainer and owner of Blue Grass trotters at Lexington, was murdered last night by a negro named George Jones. Johnson trained Lady Mack, and for many years was well known ...

The subscription-books of the Rapid Transit Commission's new cable railway corporation were opened yesterday and closed, and what was advertised as a "grand mass-meeting" in favor of cable railways was held in the large hall of Cooper Union in the evening.

HAZLEHURST, Miss., April 8.--Bob and Hans Penn killed R.B. Rials here this morning. During the Christmas holidays Rials and one of the Penn brothers had a difficulty, in which Rials shot Penn and afterward left the town.

NEW-ORLEANS; April 8.--The conflict of jurisdiction between the United States Circuit Court and the State District Court of the Parish of Plaquemine received another impetus to-day.

BRADFORD, Penn., April 8.--Milton Roblee, of Syracuse, arrived in Bradford yesterday in search of his sister, Della, whose sudden disappearance from home was published in THE TIMES of Monday.

A very pretty girl, attired in a long seal dolman and carrying an alligator skin bag with initials in silver on the outside, stood at Veseystreet and Broadway yesterday afternoon waiting for a Sixth-avenue car. A youth of about 21 or 22 years was also awaiting the car, and he occasionally glanced at the pretty girl, who turned indignantly away from him.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 8.--The United States District Judge to-day, in the case of the crew of the schooner Shaver, which took Agnero and party to Cuba, released the Cuban and one negro, and held the Captain for trial at the next term, the Judge sitting as Commissioner.

Col. Mapleson was sitting in his private office in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon when a TIMES reporter entered. When asked to tell something about his visit to California the impresario threw up both hands and said that he did not know how to begin. It was suggested to him to begin at the beginning, and he did so.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 8.--The correspondence relative to the termination of the fishery clauses in the Washington treaty was laid before Parliament this afternoon.
The special order in the Senate to-day was the Bankruptcy bill, but that was laid aside and the consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill begun.

Mr. MURPHY'S bill providing for the repavement of Fifth-avenue was passed by the Senate yesterday with little opposition, but it is by no means certain that it ought to become a law without material changes. The Mozart Musical Union, an amateur orchestral society, numbering 65 performers, gave a concert at Chickering Hall yesterday evening.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--The Democrats of the House have to-day approved the policy said to have been adopted last Fall by the President after his tour through a part of the West, when he was represented as declaring at Chicago that he should thereafter appoint to Territorial offices residents of the Territories to which the appointments were to be made.

MALONE, April 8.--Franklin County's Republican Convention to choose delegates to the Congressional District and State Conventions met in Malone to-day and elected Floyd J. Hadley, Hiram N. Burns, Julius D. Beckwith, and Charles W. Breed to the former and Senator Gilbert, Assemblyman O'Neil, Howard E. King, and Thomas Adams to the latter.

The Spring rush of European immigrants has already begun, and yesterday was the busiest day which the clerks of Castle Garden have had since last sear. During the day 3,151 immigrants were registered.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--The House Committee on Public Lands to-day adopted the report prepared by Mr. Henley on the bill to forfeit a portion of the land grant of the Northern Pacific Railroad. Messrs. Oates, Van Eaton, and Strait voted against the report.

Louisa Fredericks, a 9-year-old girl, assisted her 12-year-old brother yesterday to make a fire near their house, at Breslau, Long Island. The boy told his sister to sit-down and warm herself and he would go and get some potatoes to roast. The flames swept through the dry brush and the little girl's clothing caught fire. She screamed, but before assistance reached her she was burned to death.
Two Constant Readers--1. Yes. 2. No. Since Friday six cases of typhus have been reported from the east side of the city.

LYONS, April 8.--The Republican Convention for the Second District of Wayne County is to be held at Palmyra to-morrow. Delegations from all the towns in the county show that Edmunds and Blaine have a large number of followers here, each having about the same number of delegates. Arthur has several delegates from Lyons, Galen, and Arcadia.

A handsomely dressed woman, with pale, clear-cut features and light golden hair, entered the clothing store at No. 478 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, apparently laboring under suppressed excitement. She was accompanied by a lady friend.
ATLANTA, Ga., Apirl 8.--The Supreme Court of this State to-day affirmed the sentence of death against Alfred Inman, of Emanuel County, who was convicted of the murder of his wife about a year ago.
LONDON, April 8.--A riot has taken place at Kidderminster, directed against the employment of female labor.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 8.--A private marriage, which has just gained publicity, has set society circles in a whirl.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.--An adjourned meeting of the legislative committee charged with the investigation of the charges against the Standard Oil Company was held to-day at the office of the Chairman.

CANANDAIGUA, April 8.--Ontario County, though the home of Secretary Folger and Senator Lapham, is not by any means favorable to their school of politics.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., April 8.--The First National Bank announced this morning that its doors would be closed to-day. Bank Examiner Hendee closed the institution because the did not have sufficient funds to pay drafts in Boston on Saturday. Several correspondents have called the attention of THE TIMES to apartmenthouses which they allege to be as insecure against fire as the St. George's. It is not necessary to particularize.

CHICAGO, April 8.--Sellers of cattle had no occasion to find fault with the course of to-day's market. It was active from the start and higher than any day within the last three weeks. There is evidence, however, of most outrageous frauds, and notices of contests will be filed by several, and perhaps all, of the other Republican candidates.

The Pennsylvania Democratic Conven tion yesterday performed the simple duty for which it met with celerity and precision. It placed the name of Mr. RANDALL officially before the country, adopted the resolutions which Mr. RANDALL had dictated, chose delegates to the National Convention, listened to a speech lasting 30 seconds from Mr. RANDALL, and went home.

ALBANY, April 9.--The Assembly Railroad Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on the Street Surface Railway bill. Francis L. Stetson, of New-York, advocated a favorable report on the bill.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9.--The court-room during the trial of the Sharon-Hill case this morning was the scene of a great commotion. Mrs. Shawan, a witness for the defense, was on the stand. Judge Tyler, attorney for Miss Hill, was subjecting the witness to a severe cross-examination.
GLOVERSVILLE, April 9.--The Republican District Convention for the Counties of Fulton and Hamilton met at Gloversville to-day for the election of delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions.

MITCHELL, Dakota, April 9.--J.T. Pierce, City Marshal, was murdered this morning while endeavoring, with the assitance of a posse, to arrest Hank Lewis, the turbulent keeper of a low saloon. The Coroner's jury held Lewis for murder. Much excitement has prevailed and lynching was threatened this morning, but a quiet feeling exists this evening.

The question whether the Astor Library shall or shall not be opened in the evening is not, we admit, so easy as it may at first appear. The library is not intended as a place of innocent resort for persons who might otherwise be worse employed.
BUFFALO, April 9.--The Republican Convention for the Thirty-second Congressional District, which includes 12 wards of the City of Buffalo, was held to-day.

CLEVELAND, April 9.--On the face of the returns there are 25 Democrats and 25 Republicans in the new City Council, but the Republicans claim that they have a clear majority of one. A fight will be made over the organization of the new body.

ALBANY, April 9.--To-morrow Judge Westbrook will render a decision in the case of Contractor McDonald, who was committed to the County Jail for contempt in refusing to answer the questions propounded to him by the Committee on Cities while it was investigating the Department of Public Works, of New-York. The decision is lengthy and numerous similar cases are cited in support of the decision, which sustains the authority of the Senate in imprisoning McDonald.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--Gen. Mahone, according to Mr. John F. Dezendorf's representations, will be responsible for the failure of an attempt made by the straight-outs in Virginia to effect an amicable arrangement with the Coalitionists. Mr. Dezendorf has to-day written another letter to Gen. Negley, inclosing a circular, dated April 2, recently issued by Senator Mahone.
WHEELING, West Va., April 9.--A certificate incorporating the Coal and Iron Railroad of West Virginia was sent to the Secretary of State, at Wheeling, to-day.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 9.--Mrs. Edward Wright, of Saugerties, attempted to elope yesterday, with a young man, whose name is unknown, but just as the runaway pair were getting on the boat Mrs. wright was caught by the arm by her husband, who insisted on her returning home. A scene ensued, but finally she returned with him. Mrs. Wright has been married for some years and has a family of children.

Sidney Dillon, President of the Union Pacific Railway, filed on Monday in the United States Circuit Court, at Philadelphia, a petition in the case of Rowland G. Hazard against the Credit Mobilier and the Union Pacific Railway.

Miss Rose M. Donnelly, a teacher in Grammar School No. 21, in Marion-street, died yesterday morning at her home, No. 130 Whitestreet. She had been ill since the beginning of March, but was convalescent Saturday morning, when she left the dining-room in the basement and ascended the stairs to the hall on the first floor.
WASHINGTON, April 9.--Gen. Terry arrived here this morning to consult with Gen. Sheridan relative to the proposed concentration of posts in the Department of Dakota at Fort Snelling, Minnesota.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 9.--A special dispatch from Mitchell, Dakota, to the Pioneer Press, says: "An unprovoked murder was committed at Hank Lewis's saloon at 3 o'clock this morning, the victim being Capt. J.T. Pierce, City Marshal, and the murderer being Hank Lewis, the saloon-keeper. A city ordinance requires all the saloons to close at ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 9.--In 1866 the City Council of Charleston passed an ordinance authorizing the Mayor to issue bonds to aid in rebuilding that part of the city destroyed by the great fire of 1861. The Legislature passed two acts ratifying the action of the City Council and the bonds were issued.

BOSTON, April 9.--Georgie knight Miller has brought suit against the Boston Loan Company for $2,000 damages. This is the case in which it is alleged that the Miller woman tried to secure a loan for some African "straw diamonds," as they were called, and way detained in a back room in the office of the company by the Treasurer. She now seeks damages for detention.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 9.--A bold and partially successful attempt to rob the Adams Express Company's office in Allegheny was made this morning. The burglars commenced work on a door in the rear of the building.

An examination was held yesterday before Justice Patterson, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the complaint made agninst Mrs. Louise Bonnard, at the instance of Superintendant Jenkins, of the Society for the Prevention of Crucity to Children.

Col. T. Allston Brown is expected to arrive from England on Sunday. He went abroad some months ago to engage either a burlesque company or Sarah Bernhardt, and he was quite indifferent as to which he might succeed in getting. Col. Brown comes back without either. But he has bought a play. It is by the author of "Confusion," and has not been produced in London.

WASHINGTON, April 9, 1884, The House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures decided to-day to hear next Tuesday the arguments of a committee from the New-York Chamber of Commerce on the suspension of the coinage of silver for two years.

BOSTON, Mass., April 9.--The steam-ship Grecian, of the Allan Line, brought among her 516 steerage passengers 336 "assisted" immigrants from Galway, Ireland. Their debarkation was superintended by Charles Colcard, agent of the State Board of Health, Lunacy, and Charity, and they were inspected and examined by him.

"The Mountain Queen," which is described as a fairy opera, will be produced at the Cosmopolitan Theatre on April 28 under the direction of Prof. Carl Marwig. The cast will be composed of youthful performers.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9.--Once more the long-expected exhibition of the Keely motor has been indefinitely postponed.

The janitor of the St. George flats, William O. Cloyes, took a seat in the Fire Commissioners' office yesterday, and was called to account for certain statements attributed to him by two newspapers. Cloyes was quoted as accusing the firemen of ransacking bureau drawers during the fire in the apartment-house Monday.

MADRID, April 9.--News has been received here from Cuba that Aguero's force now numbers 225 men. Of these 43 are either exchiefs of late insurrections in Cuba or have been otherwise identified with those movements, and the remainder are escaped slaves.

CLARKSVILLE, Ga., April 9.--Charles Phillips was fatally wounded to-day by Felix House at the Court-house. The parties had a misunderstanding while on a carousal some days ago, and meeting again in the Court-house yard a fusillade of pistols took place, when two shots ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 9.--James E. Williams's hotel at Luzerne was entered, it is supposed, by professional burglars last night. The inmates were chloroformed and the house robbed. Several hundred dollars in money and gold watches and other jewelry were stolen.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 9.--Christian Seibent, of Glasco, got drunk yesterday and drove his wife and children from the house, threatening to kill them. He then attempted to commit suicide by cutting an artery in his arm. He was arrested and sentenced to three months in the penitentiary.

Early yesterday morning a lithe, slender well-dressed woman was seen restlessly moving from corner to corner at Broadway and Veseystreet. Her face had a very determined look, and she was apparently waiting for some one. Soon a stylish, robust middle-aged woman came along.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, April 9.--A special says that the shortage of R.H. Turner, agent of the Pittsburg and Cleveland and the Pan Handle Railroads at Mingo Junction, who disappeared several days ago, will exceed $13,000. Daniel Potter and 800 others are victims.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., April 9.--President Sowles, of the suspended First National Bank, comes out with an open letter to-day, in which he says the bank has resources to pay all depositors and save its stockholders from loss if only permitted to continue business.

Bynum, of the same county, to be Republican Elector for the State at large, subject to ratification by the State Convention. NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 9.--So far returns have been received of five municipal elections held in this State this week, in all but one of which the Democrat-Bourbon ring was most completely routed.

CHICAGO, April 9.--At the Fifteenth Disrict Republican Convention at Danville to-day Joseph G. Cannon was renominated for Congress, and the delegates to the National Convention were instructed to support Logan for the Presideney until the find he cannot be nominated, and then they are to vote for the next best man, which will likely be Blaine.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9.--The Sixth District Republican Contention to-day elected Herman Lehlbach and William Riker delegates to the Chicago Convention. A platform was adopted indorsing Arthur's Administration, rehearsing Republican acts, strongly favoring a protective tariff, and opposing the Morrison bill. The delegates are unpledged but are understood to favor Edmunds and Lincoln.

ALBANY, April 9.--The whole of the morning session of the Senate was consumed in the discussion of Mr. Lansing's bill providing three Commissioners to lay out the lands belonging to the State in the Adirondacks and protect them from trespass. Mr. Gilbert opposed the bill, and, not being able to defeat it outright, sought to kill it by loading it down with amendments.

BAYONNE, N.Y., April 9.--Henry W. Gear, a dealer in artists' materials, at No. 102 Fultonstreet, New-York, shot and killed himself at his residence here this afternoon. He had been in ill-health for some time, and, it is thought, was deranged at the time he took his life.
There was something of a breeze in the Produce Exchange yesterday, in consequence of the announcement of the programme arranged for the opening of the new building on Tuesday, May 6.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., April 3.--When the Democratic State Convention was called to order this morning in the Academy of Music a small hall with one gallery and a very low ceiling, the delegates saw before them in a conspicuous place on the wall this warning: "All persons creating a disturbance will be arrested immediately."
Miss Emily Faithfull is at the New-York Hotel.

The steamer Chateau Lafitte, which arrived yesterday from France, had on board among her steerage passengers seven Arabs--two women, two grown up sons, one grown up daughter, and two boys. They told Capt. Heinzman, through an interpreter, that they had come from the Lebanon, in Syria.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9.--The schooner Ounalaska, with Licut. George M. Stoney in command, sailed to-day for Alaska. Lieut. Stoney goes to make further explorations of the great river discovered by him last year.

HAMPTON, Va., April 9.--A fire here today destroyed 30 houses, and but for the assistance of two fire-engines from the Soldiers' Home and Old Point the whole business portion of the town would have been consumed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 9.--John P. Watson, of Philadelphia, who is largely interested in the railways of the State, was in this city to-day. In conversation with THE TIMES'S correspondent he said: "Railway building is going to be unusually active and extensive in all parts of the State.

Savvillar Downing appeared in Part II., Supreme Court, yesterday, attended, as usual, by her mother and Mrs. August P. Wagener. Her face was ghastly in its pallor, her cheeks sunken and her whole appearance was expressive of extreme dejection.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9.--Considerable excitement is expressed in Republican circles to-day over the discovers that at the Seventh District Convention at Lexington yesterday to select delegates to the National Contention Blaine captured both delegates.
PARIS, April 9.--Le Monde, Clerical newspaper, says that five French missionaries and 30 catechists have been massacred at Thanhoa, a Tonquin town of some importance, not far from the coast.
Steam-ship Solis, (Span.,) Cairo Rio Janeiro Jan. 26 via St. Pierre March 30, with coffee to Arbuckle Bros. --vessel to Menacho Puig Co.

LA CROSSE, Wis., April 9.--H.C. Atkins, Assistant General Manager of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, was stricken with paralysis here to-day. His physicians say there is no immediate danger.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 9.--Stephen Dunn, a native of Armenia, N.Y., was arrested about two years and a half ago on the charge of having murdered an attache of Cole's circus named Fletcher.

Suit for absolute divorce has been begun in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, by Edward O. Kindberg, son of a retired merchant living in Henry-street, against Ella R. Kindberg. Counsel for the plaintiff made an effort to have the case sent to a Referee, but Judge Barnard denied the motion, and the case will be put on the May calendar.

PITTSBURG, April 9.--The time of holding the National Prohibition Convention has been changed from May 21 to July 23. This will secure representation from 22 States now organized and represented in the National Committee. The convention will meet in Lafayette Hall. In searching the house of Flacomio, the suspected murderer of Faraeh, at Staten Island, the police have found, it is said, a suit of green or plaid clothing belonging to Flacomio that corresponds with that described by the ferry men.

Donnohue, and more than 200-other citizens of New-York, praying the Forty-eighth Congress to authorize the Secretary of War to contact with Charles Stoughton and his associates for the world of the Harlem improvement.

Representative Dorsheimer is not quite hopeless of securing consideration of his Copyright bill. He said to-day that it still holds its place, No. 10, on the House calendar, and that when some of the special order, have been disposed of he will endeavor to call it up.

The question whether the Astor Library should be thrown open in the evenings has for some time past agitated not only the minds of the Trustees of that institution, but also of a large portion of the reading public.
CORNING, April 9.--Three Republican conventions were held here to-day--the Steuben County Convention, and the First and the Second Assembly District Convention.

SEDALIA, Mo., April 9.--The Republican State Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning, and was called to order by R.T. Van Horn, Chairman of the State Committee, who introduced the Hon. Chester A. Krum, of St. Louis, as the temporary Chairman.
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 9.--Gen. Wallace, the American Minister, has received a dispatch from Secretary Frelinghuysen assuring him that the Porte has not asked for his recall.

TROY, N.Y., April 9.--T.T. Kendrick who claims Washington, D.C., as his place of residence, was arrested here this afternoon upon a charge of forgery. He had in his possession 11 five-hundred-dollar notes of the Loan and Trust Company of Washington, one of which he attempted to pass. He was held for examination.

In the contest of the will of the late Louis C. Hamersley, which was resumed before Surrogate Rollins yesterday, Dr. Clarkson C. Schuyler testified that he had treated Mr. Hamersley for bronchitis in Troy during the month of December, 1882.

On Tuesday afternoon Paul Hawthorne, a bright-looking young clerk, drew $35 on a check in the Nassau Bank, at Nassau and Beekman streets. He tucked the money into his waistcoat pocket and walked out, followed by two young men who had stood behind him in line at the Teller's desk. Hawthorne dodged the vehicles on Park-row and started on a quick walk through Mail-street toward Broadway.
A man and a woman engaged a room at the Cooper Union Hotel, No. 2 St. Mark's-place, on the night of Nov. 5 last, and the man registered simply "Wright and wife, New-York."

CAIRO, April 9.--A messenger who left Khartoum on March 27, has arrived at Berber. He reports that the condition of affairs at Khartoum is extremely critical. The irregular troops in Gen. Gordon's command are in a state of mutiny.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9.--Parker Hardin, 15 years old, son of W. Hardin, Attorney-General of Kentucky, shot and wounded a boy named Arthur Glove at Frankfort to-day. The boys were returing from school and had a quarrel. Glove applied very offensive epithets to Hardin, who went home, got a shot-gun and fired both barrels, one of them taking effect in Glove's head, inflicting an ugly wound.
BALTIMORE, April 9.--At 6:30 o'clock this morning a slight rain was succeeded by a wild snow-storm, which continued until noon. The wind blew from the north-west at a velocity of 20 miles an hour.

A meeting of the Cotton Exchange was held after business hours yesterday for the purpose of discussing the question of silver coinage.
ALBANY, April 9.--Senator Gibbs has introduced an amendment to the consolidation act which is suspected of possessing far greater importance than appears on its surface.
MONTREAL, Quebec, April 9.--J.B.A. Beuve, a contractor, has absconded. His liabilities are $55,000, and his assets nominally $25,000. A meeting of creditors has been called.

Richard H. Eames, confidential clerk of E.S. Topping, Superintendent of the Express and Telegraph Department of the Long Island Railroad, was arraigned yesterday before Justice Kavanagh, at Long Island City, on a charge of embezzlement and defrauding the company preferred by General Manager J.D. Barton.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--While some of the Democrats of the House and nearly all the Republicans are solidly resisting any attempt to pass a bill to reduce the tariff, and so lighten the burdens of the tax-paying millions, the reform Democrats, as well as the Republican opponents of reform, exhibit a surprising readiness to use the money raised by taxation in erecting more or less necessary and extravagant public buildings.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 9.--Lewis Tracy who keeps a saloon in one of the low wards of the city, to-night shot and killed a French Canadian named George Ethier. The affair occurred in Tracy's saloon. They had been skylarking, and Tracy, taking up a revolver, almost it at Ethier's heart, and pulled the trigger. The latter fell dead without uttering a word. The pistol had been loaded during the day without Tracy's knowledge.

ROCHESTER, April 9.--The canvass for Republican delegates to Chicago from this Congressional District, which for the past two or three weeks has been characterized by great energy and no little bitterness, ended at to-day's convention in this city in what some Administration men may possibly claim to be a drawn battle, but which is, however, a most decided victory for the anti-Arthur forces.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 9.--The entrances to the Pocahontas coal mine were opened to-day by several experienced miners. The fan will be ready for operations to-morrow, when the bodies of the victims of the disaster will be recovered. Several bodies were discovered to-day upon opening the entrances. A firm of this city has just received an order for 36 coffins.

LONDON, April 9.--Princess Helen of Waldeck-Pyrmont, mother of the Duchess of Albany, will remain with her daughter, at Claremont House, until the accouchement of the Duchess, which it is expected will take place about five weeks hence.
Mozart's "Don Giovanni" will be sung at the Metropolitan Opera-house this evening, which has been made a subscription night to avoid an operatic performance on Good Friday.

Wallace Ross will leave New-York today for his home in St. John, where he will remain about a week, when he will return in time for his race with Courtney at Oak Point. Plaisted will accompany him as far as Portland, Me., where the latter is to train a crew at Bowdoin College.

ALBANY, April 9.--Potter's Hotel, at Slingerlands, was garrisoned with Draper henchmen before the sun set last evenings. At every door and window in the hotel where the Republican Congressional Convention was to be held today was stationed stalwart fellows armed with slung-shots and other weapons.

MANCHESTER, N.H., April 9.--The fiftyfifth season of the New-Hampshire conference opened here to-day, Bishop Hurst presiding. Eighty-one members were present. In addition to the routine business, addresses were made by the Rev. A.H. Gillett, of the Sunday-School Union, and the Rev. Jean Paul Cook, of France.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9.--The cold weather along the peninsula of Delaware and Eastern Maryland ie causing much anxiety in that section for the safety of the peach crop.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 10.--A letter has been received from John H. Perry, now living in Texas, who has been missing since 1865, when he was mustered out of service at Rock Island, Ill. His parents, believing him dead, erected a tombstone last year. His letter gives an incoherent account of his wanderings, finally ending in Texas.

There was a sale by auction of the leases of market cellars, buildings, and other city property in the Controller's office yesterday. The market cellars were leased for five years from May 1, 1884.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 10.--A woman named McGarvis is in jail at Medina awaiting a requisition from the Governor, which is to take her to Michigan to be tried on a charge of robbery.

FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, April 10.-- The Board of Managers, comprising Gens. Franklin, McClellan, Negley, McMahon, Roberts, and Brown, with Congressmen Morgan, Maginness, Slocum, Murray, Cutcheon and Knox, of the Military Committee, visited the National Soldiers' Home at Hampton to-day. They were much pleased with Gov. Woodfin's administration. Gen. Sheridan lunched with the party and inspected the buildings and grounds. The board returned to Washington to-night.

DECATUR, April 10.--Near Chico, on Saturday night, a band of armed men went to the home of Smith Drew, a noted character, and, without any words, began a fusillade of the building. Drew's nephew, lately from Missouri, attempted to run from the house, and was shot through the neck and instantly killed. Nine arrests have been made, including some of the most respected citizens of the county.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 10.--The old Elisha Graves house at Northampton, Mass., was destroyed by fire this morning, causing a loss of $500. It was probably the oldest house in Northampton, was built as a block-house, and was over 200 years old.

Conductor Flint recently had a very venerable married couple among his passengers on the fast express. The gentleman was 93 years old and the lady 30, and they had been married 70 years--a very unusual thing. The aged couple took the train at Essex and were going to Northampton, Mass. People of that age and relation are not often found among the busy traveling public.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 10.--The city ordinance compelling barbers to close on Sunday was amended to-day by the City Council so as to allow them to keep open until 10 o'clock A.M. Up to six weeks ago all places of business were closed except saloons, which kept the back door ajar.

The Senate, in executive session to-day, rejected the nomination of G.A. Windus to be Postmaster at Brackettville, Texas.

ST.JOHN, Newfoundland, April 10.--A dispatch from the Channel reports the arrival last night of the steamer Leopard, with a full cargo of seals. It also reports that the steamship Tiger was crushed in the ice of the Gulf of St.Lawrence and sank immediately. The crew was rescued by the Leopard. Seals are reported to be abundant in the Gulf of St.Lawrence.

LONDON, April 10.--The debts of A.M. Gillespie Co., the firm of East and West Indian merchants who failed yesterday, are $1,250,000.

MATTOON, Ill., April 10.--An atrocious double murder was committed near Rardin, Coles County, last night, an aged couple named Fleetwood being the victims. They were found in bed this morning with their throats cut. No trace of the perpetrators has yet been discovered, and no motive can be assigned for the crime, unless it be robbery.

MILLERSTOWN, Butler County, Penn., April 10.--Frederick Jackson, a member of the firm of Jackson McCaull, machinists, of Bald Ridge, has left for parts unknown, taking with him $3,000, the funds of the firm.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 10.--In the district conventions to-day the Republicans of Indiana have put their best foot forward and chosen an exceptionally strong delegation. If the State Convention next Thursday will supplement the districts' selections by an equally strong choice of delegates at large, no State will be better represented at Chicago than Indiana.
