UTICA, N.Y., April 10.--Richard Miller, age about 65, formerly of Marcy, in this county, died suddenly in the Central Hotel here to-day. HARRISBURG, Penn., April 10.--Representative Trout, of Erie County, was held in $200 bail to-day on a charge of assault preferred by Miss Katie Fairman.

PETERSBURG, Va., April 10.--Senator Mahone, accompanied by his wife and daughter, arrived here last evening from Washington. The Senator's presence here was not generally known until to-day, when a number of intimate friends called to see him. He is looking feeble, and will remain here for the next two weeks in the hope that rest and quiet will restore his failing health.

BALTIMORE, April 10.--A meeting of the Board of Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal was held in this city to-day. The principal question before the board was an application on the part of the boatmen for a reduction of toll. WASHINGTON, Penn., April 10.--It is reported here this evening that the Niagara Oil Company to-day struck at the Bush Well, near Middletown, the largest flow of gas in the world, beating that of the McGugan Well, in the same vicinity. The tools were sent from the bottom of the well, 1,100 feet deep, high into the air with such force as to break the derrick all to pieces.

RELEIGH, N.C., April 10.--An explosion of dynamite occurred this morning at the stone quarries near Franklinton, killing Dock Robinson, fatally wounding Edwin Strong, and injuring William Brodie, William Hawkins, George Hampton, and Sanderson Mayfield, all colored. The cause of the explosion is not known. Fifteen men were employed at the works.

BOZEMAN, Montana, April 10.--Prospectors who have just arrived from the Upper Yellowstone bring information that they discovered a new geyser basin on the east side of the Yellowstone, in a region that is almost inaccessible because of its ruggedness. The discoverers saw two geysers in action, and the evidences of geyser action were generally very marked. The new basin is 10 miles south of the petrified forest.

Johnston, a farmer of Peters Township, while taking a walk over his premises yesterday, found the dead body of a man in one of his fields, where it had evidently lain for two or three weeks. PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--Willie, the 6year-old son of Policeman Black, died this morning from injuries received by being kicked by Dominic W. Brett on Thursday last. The boy was playing in the street when he accidentally ran against Brett, who kicked the little fellow in the back. The boy was speedily seized with paralysis and suffered much pain. The Coroner caused Brett's arrest.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 11.--The Woman's Baptist Foreign Missionary Society of the West, after a three days' session in this city, adjourned to-day to meet next year in Toledo, Ohio. The society covers the territory from West Virginia to New Mexico, and the reports showed that $25,000 had been expended in missionary work during the past year. Mrs. J.H. Howe, of Chicago, was re-elected President.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 11.--Capt. Caleb Norton, aged 56, died in his chair, while waiting for breakfast, at his house, in Bemus Point, on Chautauqua Lake, this morning. Heart disease was the cause. He was a well-known lake navigator. A dozen years ago he was permanently injured in the explosion of the steamer Chautauqua, in which several persons lost their lives.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 11.--Senator Logan had his Waterloo in the Chicago district primaries to-day, electing but one delegation out of the four districts. In the the First and Third the unpledged, or anti-Logan tickets, were elected.

Last Sunday Mr. TALMAGE preached a powerful sermon in behalf of free rum. The text of the sermon was the High License bill. TALMAGE is opposed with every muscle of his arms and legs to high license. He thinks the bill is infamous. This is precisely the opinion of the friends of free rum, and therefore it is quite proper to characterize the sermon as a defense of free rum.

Mr. L.J. Land killed a very large wolf one day this week about five miles from town. He was calling wild turkeys, when the wolf came bounding toward him, supposing him to be a genuine turkey, which he appeared eager to capture. A load of buckshot in the breast brought him to the ground. Mr. Land says he was the largest and fattest wolf he ever saw.

CHICAGO, April 16.--The cattle market was stronger to-day, but the receipts were disappointingly light, and under a good general demand trade was brisk at prices ruling 10 to 15 cents higher than on Tuesday.

WAYNESBORO, Ga., April 16.--Edward Dowse, who is held in jail charged with the murder of his five children, has confessed his guilt. He states that his children kept accumulating upon him, while his ability to support them diminished.

SCHENECTADY, April 16.--The Twentieth Congressional District Republican Convention met at the Union Opera-house in this city at 1 o'clock to-day, with full delegations from all the five counties of Fulton, Hamilton, Montgomery, Saratoga, and Schenectady. B.B. Grippen, of Saratoga, was elected Chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16.--A number of lady admirers of cricket, to show their interest in the coming trip of the Philadelphia team to England, have agreed to act as representatives of the different clubs at the game to be played May 9 and 10 between the team and the New-York Eleven.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--Ex-Judge Curtis, who is endeavoring to draw statements from the witnesses before the Naval Affairs Committee that will justify Dr. Collins's assertions that Commander De Long, of the Jeannette, was cruel, unjust, and incompetent, again provoked laughter to-day in his desperate attempt to turn one of the statements of the witness Noros to account.

The Park Commissioners yesterday adopted a map of the proposed park in Port Morris. It will comprise 50 acres, and be bounded by the Southern Boulevard, St. Ann's-avenue, the Port Chester branch of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad, and One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street.

The New-York and Brooklyn Clubs met on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of 1,500 persons. Both clubs had their strongest teams in the field. Kimber pitched for the Brooklyn nine, and he was supported behind the bat by Corcoran, while Welch and Ewing composed the battery for the New-Yorks.

CHICAGO, April 16.--The leading produce markets were weaker to-day. Grain sold up some early in the day, partly because of the lowering weather, but fell off toward the close. There was apparently not much new business done on outside account, but a good deal of changing over from May into later months, providing for the deliveries of a fortnight hence. Wheat led in the trading and suffered for lack of an export demand.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16.--The Republican State Convention to nominate delegates for the State at large to the National Convention is attracting as much interest and attention as the regular State Convention, probably from its novelty, this being the first time that a convention solely for this purpose was ever called.

KINGTON, April 16.--Eighteen delegates, representing the Republicans of the Seventeenth Congressional District, met here to-day and finished the good work of smashing the stalwart machine by electing as delegates to the National Convention the Hon. Thomas Cornell, of Kingston, and Duncan Ballantine, of Andes. Theodore Teale, of Greene County, called the convention to order at 12:30 o'clock, and named Dr. Robert Loughran, of Kingston, Chairman.

It is expected that a conference of the anthracite coal producing companies will be held to-day. President Hoyt, of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, is reported to be disposed to urge the adoption of his plan to stop the production a full week instead of every other three days.

The action of the Republican State Convention of Pennsylvania yesterday will not seriously disturb Mr. BLAINE'S literary studies. He will hardly suspend them to reflect on the changes which his recently developed simplicity of taste would require him to make in the fittings of the White House.

ALBANY, April 16.--The Assembly spent the whole of the morning session upon the General Surface Railroad bill and again took it up at the night session. The discussion was long and much of it tedious. The bill was the special order of the day, but Mr. Littlejohn managed to get the floor as soon as the Journal was read and ...

At a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday a report was received from Superintendent Jasper, in which he recommended the consolidation of several schools, by which, he estimated, $26,000 will be saved.

William H. Vanderbilt has deeded to the United Brethren, or Moravian Church Society, of New-Dorp, Staten Island, 10 acres of land in consideration of $7,000. The land is part of a tract that formerly belonged to Commodore Vanderbilt, and adjoins the Moravian Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--The House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures today unanimously instructed Representative Lacey to report favorably his bill to prohibit the issue of Treasury-notes of less than five-dollar denomination, and to provide for the issue of one, two, and five dollar silver certificates.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 16.--The City Council last night repealed the ordinance, passed some time ago, granting the Texas and Pacific Railroad the right of way for tracks and station grounds in front of the Exposition Grounds, upper city park, by a vote of 25 to 4.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 16.--It is understood that a settlement of the celebrated Fillmore will case has been made on the basis of the payment to the contestants of $10,000. The details have not yet been arranged, but the settlement on the basis stated has been agreed to by all the parcies to the case, and the appeal from the decision of the Surrogate, which was made to the Supreme Court will be withdrawn.

CHERAW, S.C., April 16.--Sheriff Spofford, of Chesterfield County, asserts that Boggan Cash, the murderer, is now in Canada. He says that he received a letter from Boggan from Meridian, Miss., while he was on his way to Canada, and ...

A large and brilliant audience witnessed a performance of "The Moonlight Marriage" at the Madison-Square Theatre yesterday afternoon. Several persons in the cast--composed of well-known amateurs--have been seen already on many occasions this season, on one occasion, especially, when "The Romance of a Poor Young Man" was given.
The Baron von Liebenstein and Theodore Steinway were among the passengers of the North German Lloyd steam-ship Werra, which sailed for Bremen yesterday.

PARIS, April 16.--In his speech at Periguex, yesterday, Prime Minister Ferry gave a general review of the present political situation in France. He said that most of the foreign questions which were awaiting solution when he assumed office had been settled. He spoke in high praise of the gallantry of the French troops in Tonquin, and said that to them was due the settlement of the troublesome Tonquin question.

The village folk of Mariner's Harbor, Staten Island, have found a liberal theme for gossip in the elopement on Monday evening of Adelaide Frawley, a young woman living with her parents in that village. Two years ago Adelaide met John Halloran, of No. 150 Avenue B, this city, and he became a devoted admirer of hers. A disparity in their ages, however, made the young lady less interested in Halloran than he was in her.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 16.--The delegates to the State Republican Convention, which will meet to-morrow, say that the convention will be the largest and most enthusiastic that has met for years. It is said that the platform of principles will declare for protection to American industries, will favor national aid to public education, oppose the convict...
DAYTON, Ohio, April 16. The Narrow Gauge strike in this city was compromised last week by the issuing of transferable due-bills, or orders on the road, for money to pay board and grocery bills.

MOBILE, Ala., April 16.--The bids made yesterday for the revenue cutter Crawford were rejected to-day by the Secretary of the Treasury as insufficient. Orders were received this afternoon to fit out the batteries of 20-pounders on the cutter and prepare her for active service.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 16.--The funeral to-day of H.C. Atkins, late Superintendent of the St. Paul Railway, was a most remarkable one, 12,000 to 15,000 people being in the funeral procession.

It has been ascertained by a careful study of statistics that habitual indulgence in astronomy actually prolongs life. Few young men become addicted to astronomy before they have reached their eighteenth year. According to insurance tables, a young man who is 18 years old ...
We are afraid the Albany Evening Journal is too hasty in some of its political conclusions. It accepts Mr. TILDEN'S letter to the Iroquois Club as a "withdrawal," and it declares with a good deal ...

J.E. Dailey, of Cypress Hills, Long Island, made inquiries last night for Margaret Smith, a widow, 51 years of age, who formerly lived at No. 575 Ninth-avenue, and who has been missing for nearly a month.

Ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling wore his blue necktie, the one with polka dots, into the Surrogate's Court yesterday morning, and sufficient bric-a-brac dangled from his fob-chain to have furnished a small cabinet. Lawyer Cornelius Van Santvoord, the witness who has been undergoing cross-examination all the week in regard to the making of Jesse Hoyt's will, arrived before him, and sat down in the witness chair to await his inquisitor with pathetic resignation.

OLEAN, April 16.--The Republican Convention for the Thirty-fourth Congressional District was held in Olean to-day. It was the first time that the three counties of Allegany, Cattaraugus, and Chautauqua had been represented in one convention since the reapportionment, consequently there was only one certainty before the convention was called to order, and that was that Blaine was the favorite by at least two to one.

CLEVELAND, April 16.--A very peculiar elopement is the sensation of the city. This morning M.R. Patterson, a colored plasterer, reported that a white man named J.H. Bingham, a sewing-machine agent, had eloped with his wife.
SYRACUSE, April 16.--The Republican Convention for the First Assembly District of Onondaga County met in this city to-day, the Hon. Wallace Tappan, of Lysander, presiding.

Two deaths occurred yesterday at the Astor-Place Hotel, at Eighth-street and Thirdavenue, one of which was a suicide. At 1 o'clock in the morning a man and a woman went to the hotel and asked for a room.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 16.--The Executive Committee of the State Liquor-Dealers' Association met this afternoon and organized by electing P.J. Fitzgerald, of Troy, Chairman, and William Hall, of New-York, Secretary.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 16.--George and John Clay and J.M. Springer, charged with conspiracy to defraud Eastern creditors, had a preliminary hearing to-day, and were held in $8,000 bail each for their appearance at a final hearing next Monday. In default of bail they were lodged in jail.
Hearing angry voices at Twelfth-street and Third-avenue, about 7:30 o'clock Tuesday night. Policeman Keyes went to the spot and found a man and woman quarreling.
WASHINGTON, April 16.--Chairman Buckner, of the House Banking and Currency Committee, has received a letter from Mr. John Jay Knox, Controller of the Currency, in which he says:

The representation of "L'Elisir d'Amore" given during the Fall season by Mr. Mapleson's artists, and then referred to as one of the very best of the many good performances supplied by that impresario, was repeated at the Academy of Music last evening, to the delight of a fairly numerous audience.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 240-- The Eagleton Manufacturing Company, appellant, vs. The West Bradley and Cary Manufacturing Company. Argument concluded. No. 327--Mary E. Barrett, appellant, vs. C.D. and X.F. Ailing. Argument begun.

In the rooms of the Xavier Union, at No. 20 West Twenty-seventh-street, Mgr. Caper last evening delivered a lecture upon "The Spoliation of the Propaganda Property in Rome by the Italian Government." Among the different congregations around the Pope the one that deserves most attention from Americans, he said, is the Propaganda, which for 260 years has directed all associations connected with the mission work of the church.

TRENTON, April 16.--Gen. Sewell comes to the State Convention fresh from his battle with ex-Secretary Robeson backed by two-thirds of the delegates to the State Convention for delegate at large to the Chicago Convention.

The Republican Committee of Forty of the Sixth Assembly District held a caucus last evening to make nominations for the primaries that are to take place to-morrow evening. The following gentlemen were nominated for delegates and alternates to the State Convention: Delegates--John Simpson, Fred Sinzer, C. Major.

A large block of valuable securities belonging the estate of the late Samuel Willets was sold at auction by Adrian H. Muller Son, in the Exchange Sales-room, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday noon. Stocks that are seldom offered on the market, much less sold at auction, were disposed of. Fifty shares of Sixth-Avenue Street Railroad stock, of a par value of $100 ...

Mr. Leonard Grover is a constructor of plays who has in the past proved that he was possessed of some ingenuity. Filled with reminiscences of the acrobatic humor of Prof. Gillypod and Col. M.T. Elevator, a good-natured gathering of actors, actresses, journalists, and personal friends of the author gathered in the Comedy ...

The first of the regular series of experiments with the new pneumatic dynamite gun, which is to be carried on during the Spring at Fort Hamilton, took place yesterday, under the direction of Col. John Hamilton and Lieut. E.L. Zalinski.

Mrs. Nat Goodwin, better known to the public as Eliza Weathersby, is seriously ill in her husband's apartments in the Hoffman House. Mrs. Goodwin took a severe cold last week, and she is now suffering from a threatened attack attack of pneumonia.
Mrs. Emma Wilson, the alleged mother of Carlos Wilson, who is claimed by Mrs. Savvillar Downing as her own child, was one of the first witnesses before the Referee yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 16.--The Republicans of Pennsylvania elected six delegates at large to-day and instructed them to vote for Blaine and Lincoln. They even bound their Committee on Resolutions to report such instructions. Notwithstanding the apparent preponderance of Blaine sentiment shown...
Louis Myers, one of the many experts in law and languages employed in the County Clerk's office, has a new suit of clothes, which he is almost as proud of as if he had paid for them himself.

The trial of Sheriff Alexander V. Davidson was begun before Judge Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday. The courtroom was inaccessible to hundreds who applied for admission. Of the 150 jurors summoned on the panel 75 were present. They were called up as their names were drawn and District Attorney Olney asked them the following questions:

Assistant District Attorney Allen yesterday telegraphed to Albany, in accordance with instructions from District Attorney Olney, for the remittitur in the case of ex-Assemblyman and ex-Alderman James Irving, in which the Court of Appeals on Tuesday affirmed the decision of the lower court in regard to the sentence ...

WASHINGTON, April 16.--A bill introduced in the Senate to-day by Mr. Sabin to revive the grade of General of the Army provides that the President be authorized to nominate and, with the advice and consent of the Senate, to appoint a General of the Army, and, in the same manner, to fill any vacancy that may occur in the office of Lieutenant-General through the death, resignation, retirement, or promotion of the present Lieutenant-General.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 16.--Upon motion of the Government attorney, the James trial, at Huntsville, Ala., was postponed until tomorrow. Two witnesses from Tennessee failed to appear. James was ready for trial, and his attorneys were willing to admit the testimony expected from the absent witnesses, but the Judge allowed the motion.

The Assembly spent the entire day yesterday in considering the Street Surface Railroad bill in Committee of the Whole. Unlimited opportunity was given for discussion and amendment, and several amendments were adopted which remove possible objections. The original limitation of 1,000 feet as the distance over ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 16.--In the Sharon divorce case to-day Mrs. Fannie M. Simpson testified that Miss Hill told her in March, 1883, that she had been engaged to Sharon, but ...
Several petitions were presented in the Senate to-day in opposition to the pending Newspaper Copyright bill.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 16.--The Seventh or black District elected T.B. Johnston, white, of Charleston, and W.H. Thompson, colored, of Berkley. Both are for Arthur.

Alderman "Tommy" Sheils, the Seventh Ward Democratic politician and saloon-keeper, was a prisoner at the Mercer-Street Police Station last night on a charge of drunkenness and disorderly conduct. He was arrested at the Theatre Comique, where he became engaged in a disgraceful fight with the door-keeper and the policeman on duty there.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 16.--This evening, about 8 o'clock, as watchman Rogers Hayes was going through the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western yard at this station, where he is employed, he saw a worthless fellow, known as Fred Ehle, prowling around among the cars.
BOONEVILLE, April 16.--Large delegations of politicians reached this town this evening in anticipation of the Oneida-Lewis District Convention to-morrow.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 16.--A bitter feeling has arisen in the vicinity of Kingston within the last week between the driver boys and the Hungarian laborers which is likely to lead to trouble.

The conference committee of Independent Republicans met on Tuesday afternoon in its office, at No. 160 Broadway, to consider the attitude which the committee should assume toward particular candidates for the Republican nomination at Chicago.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16.--The Hon. T.A. Hendricks returned home to-day after an absence in Europe of four months. The purpose to receive him at the station with music and a crowd was abandoned, and he arrived quietly, being met by a few family friends. On the trip through Indiana Mr. Hendricks was waited upon at every stop, and a general desire to hear him speak was expressed.
DETROIT, Mich., April 16.--Elections for local officers took place last week in every township in the State and in about 30 of the largest cities outside of Detroit.

The French occupation of Hung-Hoa may fairly be said to terminate the campaign in Annam. Hung-Hoa was the objective point of the invaders from the time when they first fired a gun in the territory of Indo-China. It is, so to speak, the gateway of Yunnan, the Chinese Province next north of Annam.

LONDON, April 16.--Skye crofters to the number of 150 are about to emigrate to Manitoba. The steam-ship Faraday cleared for Nova Scotia to-day. She carries the first installment of the Mackay-Bennett cable to the amount of 1,100 miles.

BOSTON, April 16.--The report about an uprising against American residents in Mexico at a point about 700 miles from El Paso, Texas; the tearing up of the rails of the Mexican Central Railroad, and the burning of bridges, is regarded here as without substantial foundation.

At the meeting of the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday a communication was presented from Engineer Newton, of the Department of Public Works, pointing out that Congressman Potter, in his computation of storage required in the Croton basin, made an error of 8,520,000,000 gallons.

BOSTON, April 16.--The first Republican District Convention to choose delegates to Chicago was held to-day. This was in the Second District, represented by Congressman Long. The delegates were chosen after three ballots. They are Frank M. Ames, of Canton, and Eben L. Ripley, of Hingham. The contest was between friends of different candidates for delegates, ...

TROY, April 16.--The Republicans of the Third Assembly District of Rensselaer County held their convention at Sand Lake at noon today and elected as delegates to the State Convention Gardner Morey, of Nassau; I.W. De Freest, of North Greenbush; William T. Pratt, ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 16.--Manager McCaull made out a prima facie case of forgery and conspiracy against Gustav Amberg to-day before Magistrate Lennon on the hearing in the "Beggar Student" quarrel, and the accused was held in $1,000 bail on each of the two charges.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 16.--Considerable excitement was created here by the suspension of the funeral services of Mrs. J.H. Johnson, whose death was reported yesterday, which were held at Trinity Church.
When Senator Beck interjected a vigorous tariff reform speech into the debate on the Blair Educational bill some time ago Mr. Morrill said he would answer the Kentucky Senator at a future day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 16.--The owners of horses in this city are much alarmed at a new disease, "black erysipelas," which has made its appearance among the horses here. Four cases have already proved fatal and half a dozen animals have been ordered killed by a veterinary surgeon.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 16.--At noon today, at Madison, Gerritt H. Worthington was married to Miss Susie Ingram. The wedding was a very fashionable one, as both parties are very prominent in social circles.

The Southern railway passenger agents held their semi-annual meeting in this city yesterday and ordered the continuance for the next six months of the schedules now in force. They also adopted the resolutions of last week's convention in Cincinnati relative to the uniform system of train signals, and adjourned to meet again in this city on Oct. 15.
DOVER, Del., April 16.--The Republican State Convention will meet to-morrow at noon. Both factions are vigorously claiming a majority of the delegation.

MADRID, April 16.--The Cabinet Council yesterday was a lively one. The King, who has each Spring a recurrence of the malaria contracted by him at the English school in Sandhurst, was suffering from a violent attack and was in a nervous condition.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 16.--Mike Rice, a young man residing in Sevastopol, a Des Moines suburb, disappeared on Saturday night, after leaving a saloon in company with John Watkins, who says Rice robbed him, under duress of a pistol at his head, which statement is verified by the bar-keeper.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 16.--The Republican Convention met at 12 o'clock yesterday, and after a temporary organization adjourned to 4 o'clock for the Committee on Credentials to report.

MILWAUKIE, Wis., April 16.--T.W. Tallmadge is in receipt of letters to-day from official sources concerning the condition of the wheat crop in Michigan, Dakota, and Iowa. James Baynes, United States Agricultural Statistician, of Alexandria, Dakota, writes of the outlook in that Territory:
A meeting of the Brooklyn Bar Association was held in the Court-house yesterday for the purpose of taking appropriate action in reference to the sudden death of Justice John C. Perry.

A verdict for $5,075.84 was rendered yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas against the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company and in favor of Frederick M. Peyser, the owner of the premises No. 106 West Third-street, on the grounds that his use and enjoyment of the street and of his premises were interfered with by the railway structure.
WASHINGTON, April 16.--Mr. A.E. Bateman, of the firm of Bateman Co., bankers, of this city, to-day filed with the Secretary of War a letter, in which he says:

LONDON, April 16.--Patrick Joyce, Secretary of the Fenian Brotherhood, has issued a manifesto addressed to all Irishmen, in which he says: "The Brotherhood has good cause for rejoicing at the discomfiture of John Bull.

It is now definitely fixed that Mr. Robert Mantell will not play in the Cincinnati Festival. This decision was adopted by Mr. Mantell for the reason that the part of Romeo, for which he was originally cast, was claimed by Mr. Thomas W. Keene, the tragedian, and the managers of the festival, after a good deal of hesitation, were ultimately led to adopt Mr. Keene's view of the situation.

CAIRO, April 16.--Dispatches of April 8 have been received from Gen. Gordon. He says that Saleh Pasha, who is coming down the Blue Nile with 500 horsemen and 57 boat-loads of grain, is safe and sound.

Queen Pomare V., of Tahiti, arrived from France yesterday by the steam-ship Labrador. She was met at the dock by M. Gaston Pario, of the French consulate, who accompanied her to her old quarters, at the Panama Hotel.
It appears that a number of cases of apoplexy have occurred among young men wearing the tight trousers that have been in fashion during the past Winter.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 16.--A gentleman just arrived from the interior of Mexico expresses the opinion that the Government of Mexico cannot long avoid a collapse without a radical change of policy.

CHICAGO, April 16.--Emmet C. Fisher, who committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself through the head in a cigar store, was in 1882 elected Secretary of the Iroquois Club, and held the position about a year.

UTICA, N.Y., April 16.--The Rev. Merrit N. Capron, cf Leyden, Lewis County, formerly of Rome, has been deposed by the Northern New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference here on charges of imprudent and immoral conduct and fraud. The investigation lasted for nearly a week. Capron has given notice of appeal.

WATKINS, April 16.--The Twenty-eighth Congressional District Convention was held here to-day and elected the Hon. J.W. Dwight, of Tompkins, and Walter L. Smith, of Chemung, delegates to the Chicago Republican Convention.

Ground has been broken in West Fiftyfirst-street, near Tenth-avenue, for a new Catholic church, to be known as the Church of the Sacred Heart, and plans for its construction were filed in the Bureau of Buildings yesterday.
An additional attraction for the forthcoming six-day walking-match arrived in this city on Tuesday evening in the shape of a fullblooded Indian, who is to be one of the competitors.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 16.--The Spanish Consul here makes the following statement: "This morning the Spanish Vice-Consul, Mr. Delgado, went to the Consulate box at the Post Office and took out a letter mailed in this city and addressed to Mr. Bermudez, Consul of Spain.
PROVIDENCE, April 16.--This was the third and concluding day of the trial of the Neilson case, wherein a Swedish farm laborer sues to recover for the alienation of his wife's affections.

CHICAGO, April 16.--The Illinois Republican Convention at Peoria, to-day, was a harmonious, well-ordered gathering. There was here and there a collateral fight, such as the unsuccessful attempt of the Loganites to defeat the selection of Collector Spalding as member of the State Central Committee from the First District, but the work of the convention proper was performed in good feeling.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 16.--Col. Smith, a prominent citizen of Milwaukee, who is in Cuba, in a letter received in this city to-day, gives the following interesting information about the sugar crop: "Cuba at present produces onethird of the cane sugar used in the world.

The trial of John D. Harrington and Rufus W. Peacock for attempting to defraud the American Legion of Honor by the insurance of Martha Dinan, who died shortly after from consumption, was continued at Jersey City yesterday, before Justice McGill.

Miss Edith Evelyn Jaffray was married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Mr. Poultney Bigelow, the Rev. Dr. John Hall performing the ceremony. The building was crowded to overflowing with the many friends of the bride and groom.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--Second Assistant Postmaster-General H.D. Lyman was examined before the Springer committee to-day with relation to the claims against mail contractors for fraudulent overcharges. Mr. Lyman said he had been in the mail service since 1875, first as a first class clerk, then as a Special Agent, and finally as Second Assistant Postmaster-General.
READING, Penn., April 16.--Osmund Geier, the Building Association Secretary who has been charged with embezzlement, and who successfully eluded prosecution for the past two years, was tried to-day.

The Fifth Congressional District Republican Convention met in the wigwam at Bushwick-avenue and Jefferson-street, Brooklyn, last night, and elected Clark D. Rhinehart and George C. Bennett, Sr., delegates to the National Convention. James D. Cochrane and Michael Buckmann were named as alternates.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., April 16.--Intelligence reached here to-day of the killing of Charles Shenton by his son, Frank Shenton, both living in the lower part of Dorchester County, one and a half miles from Gilden Hill.
DETROIT, April 16.--An assault and battery case, in which $100,000 damages is claimed, is on trial in the United States Circuit Court in this city.

CHICAGO, April 16.--As the name of Secretary Lincoln has been mentioned as a candidate for the Presidency, and as in nearly every combination that has been suggested it appears in connection with the Vice-Presidency, the following correspondence will prove of interest as bearing upon that point.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 16.--The Presbytery of Lehigh has been in session here to-day and selected as its Moderator for the ensuing year the Rev. W.R. Templeton, colored, Pastor of the Washington-street Presbyterian Church, Reading. This is the first instance of a colored Pastor being elected Moderator in this State.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 16.--The trial of Thomas Wilson, who was arrested last week for conversing with Grand Jurors and trying to persuade them against indicting gamblers, was concluded to-day.

PARIS, April 17.--The activity of the Irish Anarchists in France continues unabated. The funds of the Fenian agents in Paris have been augmented during the past week by the receipt of $3,000 from America. Small packets of dynamite have recently been forwarded from France to England.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17.--Edwin F. Smith, Secretary of the State Agricultural Society, submits the following as his conclusions concerning the California wheat crop from advices up to April 11: "From the present indications the yield will exceed that of 1880.
COSHOCTON, Ohio, April 17.--A freight train wreck occurred at Hanover, near Newark, on the Pan Handle Railroad, last night, an engine and four cars going over an embankment.
A meeting of Republicans of the Ninth Assembly District was held last night at Nos. 398 and 400 Bleecker-street to make up a ticket for delegates to the State and Congressional Conventions.
PORT JERVIS, April 17.--About four years ago Katie Burns, a handsome young woman, living with her parents in Monticello, was married to James Reardon, a respectable young man.

ALBANY, April 17.--An application has been made to the Attorney-General for the commencement of an action to vacate the charter of the Mutual District Telegraph Company, of NewYork, on the ground, among other things, that its capital stock was issued without consideration.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 17.--There is a great feud between the followers and opponents of the negro incendiary, Clarke, in Middle Georgia. Two churches have been burned down in Baldwin County by the Clarke men.
BOSTON, April 17.--In the United States District Court here to-day Mary Walker, of Lawrence, as Administratrix of the estate of James Walker, filed a maritime libel suit against ...

Arthur Simpson, a good-looking young Englishman, who has been living with his wife and children in a cozy cottage in Blissville, Long Island, ran away with his wife's niece, Katie Dolan, a few nights ago.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, April 17.--The Sixteenth District Republican Convention this afternoon elected two delegates to the Chicago Convention, of whom one is a Sherman man and the other is supposed to be indifferent. A Blaine man, W.A. Bovey, of Tuscarawas County, was nominated for Presidential elector.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 17.--Lorenzo Dimick, late of the insurance firm of Crosby Dimick, of this city, was again arrested to-day on three new warrants charging him with grand larceny in connection with the insurance business.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 17.--This was the fourth day of the Spring meeting of the Louisiana Jockey Club. There was a good attendance. The weather was clear and pleasant, and the track was in good condition.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 17.--A special dispatch to the Daily Times from Gadsden, Ala., says: "George Coates, colored, who set fire to Jeremiah Green's house while Greene and his wife were at church, the four children who were left in the house being burned to death, has been captured and is now in jail.

Messrs. Hess, Porter, and Brennan, Commissioners of Charities and Correction, yesterday decided what changes should be made in the Tombs with the $90,000 appropriated for that purpose.

BOONVILLE, April 17.--The Arthur forces in the Twenty-third District were squarely beaten here to-day, after as disgraceful an exhibition of rowdyism as was ever seen in a convention in Central New--York. It was the first meeting of Lewis and Oneida Counties in district convention.

PORT JERVIS, April 17.--The Court of Appeals has decided in the case of Mary A. Seybolt against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad that a railroad company is responsible for damages in case of the death by an accident ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 17.--The Mechanics' Grand Council, representing the unions composed of house-builders of all trades, ordered a general strike to-night, to take effect to-morrow. The strike affects all classes of buildings, the Exposition included. The unions have formed a co-operative bureau, and propose to urdertake the business of contractors and builders.
Mr. R.H. Hatch will give a literary and musical entertainment next Tuesday afternoon at the Madison-Square Theatre.

JAMESTOWN, April 17.--The Thirty-fourth Congressional District Convention, at Olean, broke up in a row. In 1880 Chautauqua County cast 10,000 Republican votes, Cattaragus cast 7,000, and Allegany cast 6,000.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Gen. Terry will return to Fort Snelling, Minn., to-morrow. He has been in consultation for several days with Gen. Sheridan upon the proposed concentration of the military posts of the Department of Dakota. Gen. Terry will prepare estimates for the extension of Fort Snelling.
A long line of carriages drew up in front of the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening and discharged elegantly attired ladies and gentlemen, who had come to attend the Bachelors' ...

About 10:30 o'clock Wednesday night the ferry-boat Long Island City, while crossing to Thirty-fourth-street, ran down a skiff containing Andrew Gorman, Frederick Bender, Joseph Beck, Joseph Welbeck, Charles Goldar, ...

Alderman TOMMY SHEILS yesterday told the magistrate before whom he was arraigned that he "keenly felt his position," and that he did not remember a thing that had happened the night before. There can be no doubt that the first of these propositions is true.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17.--The dispute growing out of the advance in freight rates by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to points on Washington-avenue, in this city, has brought forth various statements concerning the relations between the Pennsylvania and Philadelphia and Reading Companies.

LOCKPORT, April 17.--The primary selection of delegates to the two Assembly District Conventions of this county took place to-day, and in the First Assembly District the Blaine men carried the convention.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Ex-Senator McDonald was formally announced as a candidate for the Presidency by the Indiana Democratic Association of this city, at a meeting held tonight. Representative Cobb offered the following resolution:

LONDON, April 17.--At the Newmarket Craven meeting to-day the race for the Craven Stakes, for 3-year olds, was won by Mr. Foy's br. c. Scot-free, (formerly Donald II.) Mr. E. Bird's b.c. Doncaster Cup came in second, and the Duke of Hamilton's b.c. Loch Ranza third. There were ten starters, including Mr. P. Lorillard's blk. c. Pontiac.
At the Madison-Square Garden yesterday two camels, a male and female, were born. One is a white double humped and the other is of the ordinary single hump kind.

BAY CITY, Mich., April 17.--The boiler in one of Dolsen, Chapin Co.'s drill-houses, in this city, exploded yesterday afternoon, instantly killing Xavier Sovey and William McCauley and fatally injuring John La Fountain, John Kelly, and John Connelly. Four others were also injured.
WHITE PLAINS, April 17.--Young Theodore Hoffman will be hanged for the murder of Zife Marks, the Jew peddler, as soon as possible after 7 o'clock to-morrow morning, in the jail yard here.
The Purim ball which was recently given at the Metropolitan Opera-house in aid of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum netted $14,150.

President French, of the Police Department, received a letter on Wednesday from Louis P. Tibbals, of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, complaining that cane and flower peddlers sold their wares in Fifth-avenue and Broadway on Sundays.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 17.--Mrs. Pierce, wife of Dr. George Pierce, of Colleton, has been a paralytic for years, unable to walk without assistance or render herself the slightest service. She has just been cured by a miracle, it is said.

BALTIMORE, April 17.--A special to the American from Frederick says: "At the Republican County Convention to-day John C. Motter, William S. Guthrie, Upton Buhrman, G.W.F. Vernon, John Sweadner, and William W. Ogburn ...

A hopeful effort to smash the machine is making in the Twenty-first Assembly District in this city. That district is supposed to be the personal property or Mr. JAKE HESS.

Arthur Rendle, of No. 10 Horatio-street, declares that he is a victim of base ingratitude and misplaced confidence. A needy man named John W. Clements came to him from Castle Garden about six months ago, and was employed out of sympathy.

The jury chosen to decide upon the innocence or guilt of Sheriff Alexander V. Davidson did its best to get interested in the monotonous testimony submitted to it yesterday, but it was evidently hard work.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 17.--The police arrested Emma A. Perkins and J.C. Seely this afternoon for obtaining goods under false pretenses, and unearthed a gigantic scheme of plunder.

Those eminent exponents of the Mikeand-Barney brand of New-York Republicanism-- the Hon. "Jake" Hess and the Hon. "Sol" Smith --are engineering a scheme to cheat the antiArthur men in the Twelfth Congressional District ...

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Mr. Bateman, the banker, who yesterday furnished a copy of his charges against Gen. Swaim, says this afternoon that the five-thousand-dollar due bill mentioned therein having to-day been returned to ...

The tickets of admission to the fair now being held in the hall of the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, in West Twenty-third-street, were printed with numbered coupons, each entitling the holder to a chance in a gold watch which is given away each evening. The lucky number last night was 5,196, and the holder of that coupon can obtain the watch from the Rector of the church.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 17.--Reports have been received at the Department of Agriculture showing that the farmers are well up with their work, with a good outlook for the growing crops. The consolidation of nearly 300 reports, covering ...

WASHINGTON, April 17.--In the investigation of the Jeannette expedition to-day Seaman Noros was cross-examined by Mr. Arnoux, counsel for Mrs. De Long. Witness thought it was the intention of Capt. De Long, in trying to reach Wrangell Land, to find there a secure wintering place.

Hisses greeted the announcement yesterday afternoon, at Haverly's Theatre, Brooklyn, that Prof. Rossitti, of the Novelty Theatre orchestra, refused to allow his men to play because his name was not on the programme in large type.

There was but a slim attendance at last night's meeting of the New-York Yacht Club, and it was nearly 9 o'clock before a quorum was present. It was announced that James Gordon Bennett, the commodore of the club, had cabled from Europe that he would present cups to the value of $4,000, to be raced for by steam and sail yachts this season.
Commercial travelers are discouraged from entering the District of Columbia by the imposition of a heavy tax upon them, and they are prevented from entering several States for the same reason.

ST. LOUIS, April 17.--A case of the mysterious disappearance of a young girl has just come to light. In October last Mr. John Weber, a wealthy dry goods merchant of Atchison, Kan., sent his daughter Cora, aged 14 years, to the Visitation Convent, in this city--a course of action ...
About 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon a poorly dressed man jumped from the Fulton ferry boat Farragut while she was on her way from New-York to Brooklyn.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 17.--This afternoon President Harris, of the State Miners' Association, and the officers of the Pittsburg District will start for Irwin station, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, to address the striking miners and endeavor to effect an organization among them. The 1,500 miners in that district are out against a reduction of 10 cents per ton.

DOVER, Del., April 17.--The Republican State Convention to-day resulted in a triumph of the half-breed element of the party. Bird, Hastings, McMullen, and other stalwarts were early on the ground, and worked industriously, ...
CHICAGO, April 17.--The demand for cattle to-day was as active as the most exacting seller could ask for, and it required very little effort to effect sales at the advance of the day before.

Johan Blannstein, an immigrant on the French steam-ship Labrador, which arrived Wednesday afternoon, jumped overboard soon after the vessel had left Havre. He was supposed to be insane.

TRENTON, April 17.--On the face of things Arthur will find cold comfort in the results of to-day's Republican State Convention. But there is a wide-spread suspicion that his case is not as hopeless as it seems.

Robert B. Roosevelt, in immaculate evening dress, presided last night at Pinard's over the deliberations of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game. The association departed from its regular custom in beginning its meeting with a dinner, at which sixteen gentlemen, including Vice-President B.L. Ludington, Secretary Thomas M. Cuthbert, Dr. S.A. Main ...

Representatives of the leading coal companies held an important conference in the new Field Building, on the Battery, yesterday. Presidents Hoyt, of the Pennsylvania Coal Company; Sloan, of the Delaware and Lackawanna; Keim, of the Reading, and Messrs. Olyphant, Tillinghast, and Harris were present.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 17.--Gov. Sherman has made the following appointments, which have been confirmed by the Executive Council: B.W. Blanchard, of Dubuque, State Oil Inspector; Dr. E.R. Hutchins, of Des Moines, Labor ...
TROY, April 17.--The Republicans of the Second Assembly District to-day elected at Lansingburg the following delegates to the State Convention: Norman S. Taylor, William M. Peckham ...

The calls for exclusively inactive securities, which were ordered at the last meeting of the Stock Exchange Governing Committee, were begun yesterday. President Hatch made a short address from the rostrum at 10:15 A.M., just before the first call.

The first annual meeting of the Huguenot Society of America was held yesterday at the Young Men's Christian Association Building. The society, which was organized April 12, 1883, started with 12 members, and now numbers 150. It has at present 300 volumes in its library, treating exclusively of the history and genealogy of the Huguenots.

The will of Joseph Agate, of Yonkers, who shot himself in Earle's Hotel, in this city, on April 10, was admitted to probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's office, at White Plains, on Wednesday.

ALBANY, April 17.--In the Court of Appeals today--Chief-Justice William C. Ruger and associates present--the following business was transacted: No. 148--The People, respondents, vs. The Mutual Trust Company, appellant.

EDINBURGH, April 17.--The celebration of the tercentenary of the foundation of Edinburgh University was continued to-day. The feature of the day was the conferring of degrees honoris causa, to the number of 120.

Mgr. Capel took part for the first time in a marriage ceremony in this city yesterday morning in St. Francis Xavier's Church, on Sixteenthstreet. The bride was Miss Ada Marie Nye and the groom Mr. W. O'Donnell, formerly of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--The AttorneyGeneral sent to the Senate to-day, in reply to the Senate resolution of Jan. 24, 1884, copies of all papers and data bearing upon the compensation of special attorneys in the star route cases. He accompanies these documents with a letter explanatory of the action of the Department of ...
LONDON, April 17.--A death from cholera is reported to have occurred aboard the Indian troopship Crocodile, between Lake Timsah and Pord Said, on the Suez Canal.

Mr. John J. Adams, of New-York, introduced in the House of Representatives to-day a bill of considerable interest to the promoters of the project of running a fast line of steam-ships between Montauk Point, Long Island, and Great Britain.

The decline in the stock market, coupled with the peculiar movements of the Gould stocks, has given rise to considerable discussion, and the corridors of the Windsor Hotel were buzzing last night with rumors of various kinds.

PORT JERVIS, April 17.--On the 9th of April Nary Huban, the 14-year-old daughter of John Huban, of Germantown, a suburb of Port Jervis, died from diphtheria after a short illness. Before she was buried another child, George, aged 4 years, was taken with the disease. He died on the 11th.
Alice M. Laughlin, a girl of 18, who says she resides at No. 306 Henry-street, in this city, was found lying on the sidewalk in Johnsonstreet, near Washington, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

The trial of John D. Harrington and Dr. Rufus W. Peacock, before Judge McGill, at Jersey City, on a charge of conspiring to defraud the American Legion of Honor by the insurance of a consumptive patient, Martha Dinan, ended yesterday in a verdict of guilty.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17.--A reporter of the Philadelphia Times learned this evening that the Countess Racouska, who a day or two ago was convicted of aggravated assault and battery on Willie Coad, her landlady's nephew, whom she shot because he disturbed her by knocking on the door of her room, was lying at the point of death in her cell at Moyamensing prison.

When the House Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds yesterday asked for the passage of a resolution authorizing an investigation of the reasons of the Secretary of the Treasury for selecting the Johnson-street site for the near public building in Brooklyn, Mr. Skinner, of New-York, objected.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 17.--The State Convention completed its work to-day with great harmony and with satisfactory results. It was the first convention of the kind ever held in the State, and its composition was of the leading and representative men of the party.

A large audience expressed unlimited delight, last evening, at a revival of "Der Wasserman," a three-act operetta by Millocker, familiar to a moderate number of American play-goers as "Apajune," and originally brought out in this country at the Thalia Theatre, where it was reproduced on the occasion under notice.

Mr. M.M. Shelley bustled about yesterday afternoon at Clarendon Hall, and effusively welcomed the representatives of the press, whom he had invited to witness the second full rehearsal of "Othello" by the Astor-place company of colored tragedians.

As the Jeannette investigation goes on it becomes more and more evident that the chief mistake in the organization of the expedition was that naval officers were placed in command instead of able seamen and firemen.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 17.--The Government Civil Engineer John Ewens arrived in this city last evening with the Government steamer Patrol, that was drawn into the Davis crevasse on the 27th of March.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 17.--Frank James appeared before the United States Court at Huntsville, Ala., to-day. He was neatly dressed in a suit of broad-cloth, and sat near his wife and child. Mrs. James is of comely appearance.
TRENTON, N.J., April 17.--The first session of the Legislature to-day began at 8 o'clock this evening, and the prospect of an all-night sitting is unusually good.
Mr. J.H. Maben, of the firm of W.H. Goadly Co.. bankers, No. 8 Wall-street, was walking up Broadway on Saturday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, when he beheld in front of him a well-dressed man.
ALBANY, April 17.--The Rev. A.F. Vedder, of Saratoga County, was convicted to-day of malpractice and sentenced to three years in Clinton Prison.

OMAHA, April 17.--The Arthur machine men, with Utah Commissioner Paddock at their head, have been making a still hunt in Nebraska. The editor of the Omaha Bee, an independent anti-monopolist, has been enlisted in their support, and the office-holders have been forced to work for Arthur or give up their positions.

EASTON, Penn., April 17.--E.B. Hollister, a Justice of the Peace, of Hollisterville, Wayne County, was before United States Commissioner Kirkpatrick at this place to-day charged with taking $140 too much in collecting a pension for a widow. Hollister gave bail for a hearing on Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17.--The sale of the remaining assets of the Jay Cooke estate, held for the redemption of the dividend scrip of the first and second issues, began here to-day.

The representatives of the trunk lines running eastward from Chicago met yesterday in Commissioner Fink's office and submitted arguments to Arbitrators Adams, Galt, and Riddle for a revision of the percentages now in force.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 17.--This morning the Hon. J.D. Husbands, Register in Bankruptcy, formally handed down his decision and opinion in the litigation which has for its object a fourth and final dividend and final audit of the accounts of Hector McLean, as Assignee of the late Farmers and Mechanics' Bank of Rochester.

CHARLESTON, West Va., April 17.--After a good deal of preliminary caucusing and manipulating of wires, the Democratic State Convention assembled in the opera-house at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, being called to order by D. H. Leonard, Chairman of the Executive Committee.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17.--Judge Richard Reid, of the State Superior Court, was assaulted at Mount Sterling, Ky., last night, by John J. Corneilson, a prominent lawyer, beaten with a cane and then with a raw hide.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 327--Mary E. Barrett, appellant, vs. C.D. and X.F. Failing. Argument concluded. No.328--J.H. Pugh, surviving Trustee, , appellant, vs. The Fairmount Gold and Silver Mining Company ct al. Continued per stipulation. No. 329--The Board of Supervisors of Genada ...

KEY WEST, Fla., April 17.--Advices from Havana state that the Government refuses all the newspapers information regarding Aguero and the movements of the insurgents, thereby increasing the alarm and distrust.

JAMAICA, April 17.--The Republicans of the First Congressional District held a rather lively convention here to-day and elected George William Curtis, of Richmond County, and John M. Crane, of this village, as delegates to the Chicago Convention.
The long pending suit brought by Coroner James R. Robinson, of Long Island City, against Anthony Comstock has been settled out of court.
Time was when the Easter card was new. It was then no larger than a man's hand, and no one dreamed of the awful possibilities that it contained. Year by year it grew in size and costliness.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 17, via Galveston. --The Government is negotiating with the representative of the France-Egyptian Bank here for a loan of $20,000,000, $10,000,000 to be paid to the present administration and $10,000,000 to the incoming administration.

Several crack flyers were out on the road yesterday and the upper part of Seventhavenue presented a very lively appearance. The sensation of the afternoon was a brush between Mr. W.H. Vanderbilt and Mr. T.C. Eastman.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--The Secretary of the Navy issued to-day, in accordance with the resolution recently adopted by both houses of Congress, a proclamation offering $25,000 reward for the discovery and rescue of the party of Lieut. Greely.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 17.--A riot, which is certain to result in the loss of one and probably three lives, occurred at Braddock, a town 10 miles east of this city, about 1 o'clock this morning.

Under the title, "A bill to promote the cultivation of fruits," a majority of the Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives has reported in favor of the passage of a measure permitting any person to manufacture apples, peaches, and other perishable fruits, raised by himself or his tenants, into brandy, free from ...
A circus in the West advertises "the only coal-black sacred elephant ever seen in captivity."

A pathetic scene that had in it a touch of tragic interest was enacted yesterday in the top room of a squalid apartment at No. 84 Bergen-street, Brooklyn. On a mattress in one corner lay a young woman in the last stages of consumption, and from her side came occasionally the fretful cry of a baby only a few months old.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 17.--The Rev. Alfred A. Watson, D.D., was to-day consecrated Bishop of the new Episcopal Diocese of Eastern North Carolina. The ceremonies took place in St. James's Church, and the building was crowded to its utmost capacity. Bishop Watson is a native of New-York, but has been a resident of this city for a great many years.
A young man named Richard Watson, of No. 172 Smith-street, Brooklyn, was discharged from Julius Johnson's machine shop, foot of East One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, two days ago.
Major Edwin H. Weirman, who was known among his associates as a rich railroad man, has been staying at the Coleman House, at Broadway and Twenty-eighth-street, since January last.

Several of the New-York theatres threw open their doors yesterday afternoon for the third annual benefit of the Actors' Fund of America. The reigning attractions were presented in most of the theatres. At Haverly's Theatre, Brooklyn, a medley of attractions from the various theatres of that city was to be seen.
The Metropolitan Club placed another victory to its credit on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, when it defeated the New-York League team.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17.--The Grand Jury to-day returned 10 indictments against D. K. Mason, who was arrested charged with hypothecating tobacco warehouse receipts when he had no tobacco in warehouse.

A phenomenal case of "conscience" has come to light in Lewiston. A man who has spent nearly all the past 10 years in prison for theft and drunkenness, has come out and has now engaged in paying off his old debts as well as compensating those from whom he had stolen.

MONROE, Ga., April 17.--Several days ago Mrs. Milley Gower, 81 years of age, came to this county on a visit to her daughter, Mrs. Smith. A large circle of descendants and friends called to see her, and the old lady seemed to be in the best of spirits.

A suspension of the rules will, it is reported, be asked on Monday by the Select Committee on the Payment of Pensions, Bounty, and Back Pay of the House to take up and pass a bill reported by Mr. A.J. Warner to regulate the granting of pensions in certain cases.

PITTSBURG, April 17.--The convention for the Twenty-first District to elect delegates to the Republican Convention at Chicago assembled in Plattsburg to-day and elected Gen. John Hammond, of Essex County, and the Hon. George Chahoon, of Clinton, as delegates, and Jerome Lapham, of Warren, and Capt. T.A. Beman, of Franklin, as alternates.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 17.--The National Flint and Lime Glass Association is considering the advisability of establishing a pool for the disposition of the product of the tableware factories of Pittsburg, Wheeling, and vicinity.

Thomas Pearce, an Englishman, 60 years old, a locksmith by trade, committed suicide yesterday morning by cutting his throat with an old razor after he had taken a large dose of Paris green. For three weeks Pearce had lived alone in a small room which he had hired from Leonard Forster, at No. 624 Sixth-street.

CINCINNATI, April 17.--The Grand Jury, which is investigating the late riots, is believed to have been placed in possession of testimony of a sensational character. It is still pushing its investigation, and it will probably be continued for some days to come.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 17.--At the Third Congressional District Convention of the National Party, held here this afternoon, the Hon. Washington L. Hope, of Monmouth County, and Harris McFarland, of Union County, were elected delegates to the National Convention, which meets at Indianapolis, Ind., on May 28. The delegates favor Gen. Butler for President.
Both factions of the Republican organization of the Sixteenth Assembly District met last evening to make preparations for the struggle to-night, which promises to prove an exciting one.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 17.--The body of George Leah, who has been missing for three weeks, was found in White River this afternoon where it had evidently lain since he wandered away from the home of his son in this city. He was 82 years old and was the oldest locomotive engineer in the country, having run the one on exhibition in Chicago upon the Baltimore and Ohio Road in 1883.
One and a half million mackerel were brought into Fulton Market yesterday in fishing vessels whose cargoes ranged from 20,000 to 150,000.

Charles Mehnest, foreman of the machine shops of Julian Jonson, at One Hundred and Eighteenth-street and Harlem River, and Richard Watson, a workman under him, have for a long time been on the most unfriendly terms.

CALAIS, Me., April 17.--The two shore piers of the passenger bridge at Union Mills gave way this morning. Fears are entertained for the other bridges across the St. Croix. The water is higher than for many years and is still rising.

DETROIT, April 17.--A chattel mortgage of a unique character has been filed in the City Clerk's office here, being nothing less than a lien executed by a Russian Hebrew congregation on the five Books of Moses, written on parchment and called in the Hebrew language Seier Darah. These sacred books the congregation mortgaged for a loan of $70.
DETROIT, Mich., April 17.--The Republican County Conventions are now being held throughout the State to elect delegates to the State Convention.

The red-curtained walls of Ortgies Co.'s auction-rooms, at Nos. 845 and 847 Broadway, inclosed an elegantly-dressed assemblage of ladies and gentlemen, last night, at the sale of the John La Farge collection of oil-paintings and water-colors.

BOSTON, April 17.--John P. Hunter, who has committed forgeries and thefts in many cities in this country and in England, and who was arrested here recently for forgery and larceny, has been sentenced to five years' imprisonment on the former and two years on the latter charge.

PARIS, April 18.--The dynamite taken to England is conveyed by persons who conceal the explosive between the lining and the cloth of their coats. The dynamite is wrapped in oiled paper in cakes like blacking. The cakes, which are an inch in thickness and five inches in diameter, are left at one place in England, where they are joined into one mass.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18.--A special dispatch from Mays Landing, N.J., says that the jury in the case of Robert Roehl, who was indicted by the recent Grand Jury of Atlantic County for the murder of August Rosenberger, at Egg Harbor, last January, acquitted him last night after deliberating only a short time.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 18.--The fifth day of the Spring meeting was warm and cloudy. The attendance was light and the track good.

Schedules in the matter of the assignment of William H. Guion for the benefit of his creditors were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

WASHINTON, April 18.--The examination of Lieut. Danenhower was resumed this morning before the committee investigating the loss of the Jeannette. The witness was questioned in regard to the quality of Lieut.

CINCINNATI, April 18.--A decline here today of 3 cents in the quotations of highwines causes some excitement in whisky circles, and is done without the orders of the whisky pool. The sales reported to-day were those of the leading members of the pool in this city.

ST.LOUIS, Mo., April 15.--The dead body of an unknown man was found on the brick sidewalk in front of No. 310 Olive-street before daylight this morning and taken to the morgue.

DENVER, Col., April 18.--The mining towns are excited over alleged important gold discoveries in the vicinity of Pike's Pea, is miles south-west of this city, and crowds of people are flocking to the new camp.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19.--The body of Mrs. Anna Fries, which was found by the life saving crew at Asbury Park, N.J., yesterday evening was brought to this city to-night and taken to Mrs. Fries's elegant residence, No. 1,720 Spring Garden-street. The dead woman was a member of one of the oldest and wealthiest families of this city.

ATCHISON, Kan., April 19.--There was an unprecedented rain-fall here last night, accompanied by lightning, causing the White Clay, a stream running through the city, to rise between two and three feet in a few minutes. Some houses were swept away, but no lives were lost so far as known. Great loss was occasioned by the flooding of houses and cellars. It is thought that there must have a been a water-spout near the city.

CINCINNATI, April 19.--The primary elections held to-night for delegates to the Cleveland Convention indicate a preference for Sherman, with Blaine as second choice. The delegates are ready, however, to make concessions if necessary. Efforts are being made to secure the election of one colored man as a delegate to the National Convention from the State at large.

Richard J. Williams, a resident of Orange, pleaded not guilty yesterday, in the Essex County Court of Common Pleas, to an indictment for alleged libel. The complainant is Lawrence T. Fell, Child Labor Inspector. The alleged libel, of which Williams is said to be the author, appeared in a Newark newspaper a few days ago, and charged Mr. Fell with misappropriating money placed in his hands for election purposes in the campaign of 1880.

CHICAGO, April 19.--There is trouble ahead among the anti-Logan Republicans of the Second District in Chicago, who swear to be revenged for a trick played upon them by "Long" Jones and Dan Shepard, at the Peoria Convention. There were two contesting sets of delegates to the County Convention from the Sixth Ward.

BALTIMORE, April 19.--A special to the American says that at the Montgomery County Convention, at Rockville, to-day, John McDonald, Francis Miller, P.M. Smith, and J.W. Lancaster were chosen delegates to the State Convention, and Samuel R. Priest, Thomas Martin, Henry Drozer, and Daniel Higgins delegates to the district convention, which will meet on April 24. The delegations are for Blaine and Lincoln.

The boldness of the criminal classes in this city has reached such a point that hardened felons in the shape of small boys and little girls actually sell flowers in Fifth-avenue and Broadway on Sunday.
QUEBEC, April 19.--The grand Colonization Lottery bill was passed to-day by the Legislative Assembly, and is now before the Legislative Council.

A dress rehearsal of "The Mountain Queen," a fairy operetta, in three acts, by Charles F. Hanson, was given last night at the Cosmopolitan Theatre, under the management of Carl Marwig. The operetta is without plot, and deals with gypsies, who entice the fairy queen to their camp, keep her there for two acts, and then finally restore her to her home and friends.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19.--A special from Limerick, Penn., says that the stove-works of Buckwaiter Co., of Rogersford, Montgomery County, are to be moved to Elizabeth, N.J. This is done in order to avoid the hands lately employed at the works, who intimidate all workmen taken on since the strike.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 19.--It is thought the danger to the city from flood by the breaking of the North Pond dam has been avoided. Large gangs of men worked all night in filling in the old flume way where the weakness manifested itself, and in constructing a new wasteway ...

A man, almost unconscious, was found by three boys yesterday morning in a ditch in Stevens's woods, near the West Side Driving Park, in Jersey City. The boys notified the police authorities, and an ambulance was sent to take the man to the Charity Hospital. Before it arrived, however, the man expired, and the body was sent to Speer's morgue. What has been actually done for the sufferers by the earthquake in Ischia is thus summed up by the Naples press: Much more than 150,000f. (the sum contributed by France) was promptly distributed among the inhabitants, not counting the food and shelter afforded to all the destitute.

The report of the Master appointed to take testimony tending to show whether or not the salaries paid by Shipping Commissioner Duncan to his sons as Deputies are unreasonable and out of proportion to the work performed was taken up by Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday morning.

-It would seem that the soil of Italy is in incessant movement, there being periods of excessive activity usually lasting about 10 days. Such a period may be called a seismic storm. These storms are separated by periods of relative calms.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 19.--The Polk County Democrats to-day elected a delegation of twice the number authorized, giving each member half a vote. A resolution warmly commending Tilden for President was adopted with much applause.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 19.--For the second time it has been proved in Cincinnati that a flood instead of being followed by sickness prepares the way for a period of unusual healthfulness. It was so after the flood of last year, and is so now.
The disastrous failure of the attempt to get up a performance in aid of the treasury of the Anti-Chicken-stealing Society of Hoboken nearly ruined the club. A special meeting was called.

John Fitzsimmons, a fisherman, of this city, was rowing opposite the ferry landing at Clifton, Staten Island, yesterday morning, when he saw the body of a man floating in the water. By order of Coroner Frank Schindler, Undertaker Michael Oates took the corpse from the bay. It was that of a German, weighing 210 pounds, between 45 and 50 years of age, with dark hair and mustache, and 5 feet 10 inches in height.

For the last time, yesterday, the principal actors in the Savvillar Downing case met in Part II., Supreme Court, where the proceedings were brought to a conclusion. The girl herself was present, and stood leaning both hands on the desk at which the lawyers sat and gazing wildly from one to the other.

WASHINGTON, April 20.--1 A.M.--For New-England, partly cloudy weather, local rains in northern portion, north-east to north-west winds, nearly stationary temperature, followed by colder weather during Monday.

UTICA, April 19.--The first Assembly District Republican Convention to-day elected Thomas Wheeler, William H. Comstock, Albert P. Seaton, and Isaac L. Addington to the State Convention. Three of these are for Arthur, or for whatever Arthurism proposes or represents. One is as positively against Arthur.

The Staten Island Athletic Club opened the season yesterday by a parade in the Kill Von Kull of a large portion of its flotilla of boats. There were in the parade one eight-oared shell, three four-oared barges, two four-oared shells, one pair-oared gig, seven single shells, and two canoes. These were manned by upward of 40 oars-men.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 19.--R.H. Turner, the defaulting ticket agent of the Pan Handle and Cleveland and Pittsburg Railroads at Mingo Junction, Ohio, has returned from Canada, where he fled with some $16,000 belonging to the Pennsylvania Company. He returns of his own free will, and intends affecting a compromise with the railroad officials by returning the bonds.

The funeral of Edward H. Weirman, who died suddenly in the Coleman House on April 16, and in whose pockets were found a loaded revolver and a letter stating that he was about to attempt suicide, was held yesterday afternoon in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. There were no relatives present, and his friends have not yet succeeded in finding any of them.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--A sub-committee of the House Committee on Commerce to-day decided to report favorably to the full committee Representative Mutchler's bill providing for the appointment of a scientific commission to attend the International Electrical Exhibition, to be held in Philadelphia next Fall, under the auspices of the Franklin Institute of Pennsylvania, for the promotion of mechanic arts.

LONDON, April 19.--The news from Gen. Gordon which is sent out from Cairo by Sir Evelyn Baring, the English Minister to Egypt, is known to be very fragmentary. Large portions of Gen. Gordon's letters are quietly suppressed at Cairo and never come to the knowledge of the public.

The New-York Cab Company has adopted a system for the protection of its patrons. It consists or a printed card containing a record of the trip, which has to be filled up and signed by the driver and handed by him to the passenger. The card also has a table of distances and a tariff both for time and distance. The company has also provided a uniform signal for its cabs.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--In addition to the charge of paying private bills with postage stamps, a further charge of being personally interested in the mail messenger service at Camden, N.J., has been preferred against Postmaster Bailey, at that place, and the latter charge has been referred to Second Assistant PostmasterGeneral Lyman for investigation.

A panic occurred last evening in Haverly's Brooklyn Theatre, which at one time threatened to produce very serious results. The house was crowded at a performance of the "Romany Rye."

The committee having in charge the entertainment which is to be given at the Metropolitan Opera-house to raise funds for the building of a home for ex-Confederate soldiers met last evening at the St. James Hotel. About $1,500 worth of boxes and tickets were sold, among those purchasing boxes being John R. Fellows, E.A. Boyd, H.G. Dickerson, William M. Conner, and H.R. Gordon.

An open lawn-tennis tournament was held yesterday afternoon in the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, The prizes were a silver cup and a pair of handsome "racquets." Play was opened at 2 o'clock, the contestants being Messrs, Spencer and Smith, of the Twenty-third Regiment, and the O'Connor brothers, of this city.

There is a great demand for the use of tennis courts in the Brooklyn parks. The Park Commissioners have sent out blank forms to be filled in by the different clubs wanting courts. All players are required to wear tennis shoes, to avoid injury to the turf.

Father J.J. Riordan writes that Cardinal McCloskey has erected the "Mission of Our Lady of the Rosary" at Castle Garden. Although emigration from Ireland is not encouraged, temporary protection and good advice are offered to the Irishimmigrants who pass through the Garden. In order to distinguish the deserving immigrants from those who are sent here by poor law guardians the former are requested to bring, if possible, letters from their Pastors at home.

George W. Cable, the New-Orleans novelist, spent Sunday with friends in Monson, attended the Congregational church, and was invited to talk to the Sundayschool in the afternoon. Mr. Cable's fondness for children is proverbial, and he accepted. In the course of his remarks he raised his hand, expanded the digits, and said: "I have so many children at home. How many is that?" "Five."

It is, I believe, the opinion of most scholars and men of letters, who are competent to pronounce an opinion, that the "New Dictionary of the English Language," the first number of which has lately issued from the Scriptorium at Mill Hill, will be regarded by the men of the next generation as the literary magnum.

To-day Prince Bismarck celebrated his sixty-ninth birthday amid manifold tokens of esteem and devotion. In the morning he was, as usual, serenaded by two military bands, and in the course of the day he received thousands of gifts and congratulatory messages from high and low in all parts of Germany, and, indeed, all parts of the world.

BATAVIA, N.Y., April 19.--Possibly interest in the principals in the recent sensational trial in this village is to be revived, for Edward Newton Rowell has instituted proceedings for divorce against his wife, Jennie Luce Rowell, and summons and complaint have been sent to Oneida County for service upon the defendant.

The new warehouses under the Brooklyn bridge, between Rose and Vandewater streets, have been nearly completed, and are to be ready for occupancy on May 1. The State Historical Society has received as a gift from Mr. W. Dickinson, photographer, New-Richmond, Ohio, a picture of the house at Mount Pleasant, Ohio, in which Gen. Grant was born. In the foreground in this picture is a fulllength portrait of the venerable Dr. J.G. Rogers, the family physician, who was in attendance at the birth of Gen. Grant.
CHARLESTON, West Va., April 19.--The Republican County Convention to-day elected delegates to the State Convention at Martinsburg. They are said to be for Blaine, but were not instructed.

McDonald, Second Vice-President; L. Riggs, Third Vice-President, and J.R. Flaming, Secretary and Treasurer. Several new clubs were admitted.

Gen. James Longstreet's newly organized "White Republican Party," in Georgia, has received the qualified adherence of Col. Jack Brown, who is pretty well known in Georgia politics and is the Republican leader of the Third Congressional District of that State.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 19.--The will of the late A.T. Stewart, of New-York, was ordered to be recorded and filed in the Probate Court in this city to-day. It has been before the court for more than a year, having been brought there in order that the title to the real estate might be legally settled. It was contested by parties in Vermont who claimed to be heirs to the estate.
METROPOLIS, Ill., April 19.--C.H. Meyer Co., dealers in dry goods, made an assignment yesterday. Liabilities, $40,000; assets not given, but the firm declares that they are adequate to pay in full.

The Guion steam-ship Oregon, which sailed from Queenstown last Sunday at noon, anchored off the bar late yesterday afternoon after having made the fastest passage on record. Owing to the low water on the bar the Oregon was obliged to remain outside until a late hour last night. She will reach her dock at the foot of King-street about 8 o'clock this morning.
