CHICAGO, April 19.--Mr. and Mrs. H.C. Fillmore, the old couple of Fayetteville, N.Y., who blew out the gas in their room at the Palmer House, Thursday night at 10 o'clock, and were not discovered until 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, died to-day. The three physicians attending the case put forth extraordinary efforts, and applied every agent known to science to bring their patients back to consciousness, but without success.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 19.--Cottages are renting very slowly at this place. Bad weather is alleged as the cause, but there are other causes, viz.: high rents and the many attractions in Europe. Many of the prominent gentlemen who own, as well as those who hire, cottages propose spending the Summer in foreign lands.

Muldoon, the wrestler, left this city on Friday last for Los Angeles and New-Orleans. SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19.--Catholic circles here are still in ferment over Bishop McNeirny's prohibition of an English sermon at the blessing of bells in St. Joseph's German Church on Palm Sunday. The latest development in the case is a summons to the Pastor, the Rev. Joseph Pickl, to appear before his episcopal superior.

SYRACUSE, April 19.--Republican delegates to the State Convention were elected today as follows: Second District--Francis Hendricks, George D. Cowles, D.F. Hayden, William F. Gregory, Charles Cole; Third District--Martin A. Knapp, Charles Peck, George Baxter, L.S. Merrick, Adam Nies. The delegates are all for Blaine and for the appointment of Frank Hiscock as delegate at large to the National Convention.

PIPER'S POND, Penn., April 3.--The creek half a mile away beyond the stretch of hemlock forest was swollen to three times its natural size, and the roar of its angry torrent could be heard in the cabin above the tumult of the fierce wind that swept through the intervening woods.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19.--Dell Roblee, whose alleged elopement with a commercial traveler from this city two weeks ago created a great sensation, has returned. She was cared for to Mrs. Marks's infirmary, in Bradford, until last Thursday morning, when the house took fire. Miss Roblee was in an upper room alone.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 19.--Whisky has dropped 10 cents a gallon in this market in two days--three cents yesterday and seven cents today, or from $1.15 to $1.05. Two hundred and eighty barrels were sold to-day at $1.05, which is less than the cost of production. Stephens, Dair Co., commission men, who negotiated nearly all the sales made to-day, were beseiged at the close for goods at $1.05, deliverable on Monday.

ERIE, Penn., April 19.--This afternoon Dr. Bousteel, of Corry, was acquitted by a jury on a charge of malpractice. Costs to the amount of several dollars were imposed on the plaintiff, Thomas Hughes. The effect of the use of intoxicating liquors upon the health, manners, and morals of a community is of course one of the most important of social questions. It cannot be said to have been really investigated.

BOSTON, April 21.--A new telegraph system by which the present code is simplified has been exhibited here. Chemically prepared paper, moved by clock-work, receives the record of signals sent over the lines, which are represented by dots and dashes as in the Morse code.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 21.--The Coroner's iuquest in the case of Henry Kane, who was wounded in the Poughkeepsie saloon affray and died here yesterday, was held to-day. The jury found that Kane came to his death from a blow given by William H. Stirrup in the latter's saloon.

UTICA, April 21.--The delegates are slowly straggling in. State Prison Superintendent Baker, though not a delegate from Washington County, journeyed hither in the interest of peace and harmony. The four delegates from the upper district of his county, he said, were not for Arthur.
TROY, N.Y., April 21.--At 7:45 o'clock this evening the steam-boat Saratoga left her dock, at the foot of Broadway, and in turning was assisted by the tug-boat Charles S. Many, of Albany.

ERIE, Penn., April 21.--To-day the wellknown firm of Cochran Young, rag merchants and paper manufacturers, failed. The liabilities will not exceed $130,000. This afternoon the five principal city banks. Keystone, Marine, Dime, First National, and Erie County, entered judgments against the firm for over $90,000, upon which executions were issued upon the firm's real and personal property, valued at considerably over $100,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 21.--The storm that set in Saturday night continued until today and was especially severe on Lake Michigan. The damage to lake craft has been very great, and a number of small crafts are reported lost.

At 12:20 yesterday the bugle of the Pioneer was heard in the vicinity of the Brunswick, and a crowd of about 500 people witnessed the return of the Coaching Cluh from their visit to Hempstead, Long Island.
ALBANY, April 21.--The fact that 22 members of Assembly have been sent as delegates from their respective districts to the convention at Utica induced the Assembly to jump one day's proceedings.

The case of John Jeffreys and wife for the murder of her child came up before Justice Barnard, at Riverhead, Long Island, yesterday. The child was the offspring of Mrs. Jeffreys by another man, and Jeffreys killed it by breaking its neck.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21.--A.J. Reynolds, formerly a Director of the so-called People's Railway, organized in Indianapolis, was horsewhipped to-day by Emil Kennedy, President of the same company.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 21.--A few arrivals to the coming State Republican Convention have been recorded to-night, but little can be said about the outlook beyond what has already been given. Several of Senator Sherman's tried political veterans are already on hand, and their talk and position show that he is by no means out of the field.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 21.--The Ulster April Circuit convened in this city this afternoon, the Hon. Charles R. Ingalls, of Troy, presiding. The calendar contains over 150 cases, many of which are very important, and, besides two slander cases and one seduction case, has 21 lien suits brought against the North River Construction Company, against the West Shore...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 21.--Profs. Elias Loomis and Hubert A. Newton, of the Winchester Observatory at Yale College, have resigned as Directors, owing to differences with Dr. Leonard Waldo, the head of the Horological and Thermometrical Bureau.

RICHMOND, Va., April 21.--Senator Mahone and other prominent coalition leaders arrived in this city to-night and held a conference to cut out the work for the State Convention of their party, which meets here Wednesday at noon.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21.--A foot-race, 75 yards and repeat, took place yesterday afternoon between two sporting men named Kittleman and Harmon for $1,000 a side. The first heat was won by Harmon in 0:07 , and the last two by Kittleman in 0:07 5/8 and 0:07 . Two thousand persons were present.

Among the bills introduced in the House to-day was one by Mr. Beach, providing for an appropriation of $37,500 for the erection of additional buildings at West Point. Of this sum he proposes that $10,000 shall be used for building a Quartermaster's warehouse, $12,500 for barracks for the cavalry detachment, and $15,000 for a gymnasium.

Considerable excitement was caused on the Brooklyn bridge, near the New-York entrance, about 6 o'clock last evening by a runaway. Five coaches containing members of the Beethoven Bowling Club were returning from Greenwood, where they had been to decorate the grave of Bernard Zahn, their former Vice-President, who died a year ago yesterday.
ALBANY, April 21.--Billings P. Learned, Jr., of New-York, has been elected President of the Union National Bank, to succeed his father, who died last week.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--"M.S. Quay," called the Crier in Judge Mitchell's Court of the Quarter Sessions to-day, as he ran down the roll of new jurors.

The Rev. Arthur R. Naylor, a, Presbyterian clergyman and missionary, nearly 72 years old, and an inmate of the Presbyterian Minister's Home, at Perth Amboy, N.J., came to this city yesterday, and tried to cross Broadway at Murray-street.

There are seven indictments altogether against Charles H. Rugg for crimes committed on Long Island. The display of fancy waistcoats, gorgeous cravats, fragrant boutonnieres, and costly canes made by the Union Club men yesterday tinged the sombre surroundings of Judge Van Vorst's court-room with a replendent glow of warmth and color.

The Boston League Club again defeated the Metropolitan nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. For six innings the Metropolitans held the advantage, but in the seventh they were forced to relinquish the lead.

Politicians of high and low degree assembled in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon to assist at the examination in the complaint of assault preferred against Alderman "Tommy" Sheils by Eugene Callahan, door-keeper at the Theatre Comique.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 21.--The special train of five cars which left this city for NewOrleans over the Erlanger roads with excursionists to the Knights of Pythias Convention, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, made the run in 23 hours and 20 minutes. It was the most remarkable run ever made south of the Ohio.

Edward Chiardi, of the Charity Organization Society, found this person in Broome-street yesterday with an elliptical-shaped tin sign hanging from his neck. On it was printed:

The managers of the New-Orleans Exposition have found their undertaking so much larger than they anticipated that they feel unable to do it justice without the aid of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--Oliver Ames, of Massachusetts, to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court his answer to the petition of the Union Pacific Railway Company asking for his removal from the Receivership of the Credit Mobilier.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--In anticipation of the Presidential vote being very close this year some uneasiness is being caused in Republican circles with regard to the presence of Directory of national banks on their Electoral ticket.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 21.--There are rumors in this city of trouble among the officers of the Western and Atlantic Railroad about the delay in removing the debris of the late wreck on that road. Vice-President Morrill and F.J. Kimball had, it is said, interfered in the prosecution of the work with those having it in charge, and in consequence Superintendent R.A. Anderson and Supervisor M.H. Doley have tendered their resignations.

At a meeting yesterday of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a resolution was adopted to distribute $138,710 from the excise fund among the various charitable institutions, dispensaries, homes, and asylums for the support and relief of persons committed to their care for the past year.

BOSTON, Mass., April 21.--Officers of the Union Pacific Railroad deny the report from Wall-street that it has been decided to pass the next dividend. They say the question of the July dividend has not been mentioned.

The first appearance in New-York of Signor Anton, a Spanish tenor whom Mr. Mapleson intercepted on his way from the West Indies to Europe, proved a not unpleasant incident of the closing week of the season at the Academy of Music.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund yesterday received a communication signed by a large number of the prominent residents of NewBrighton, Port Richmond, Elm Park, Stapleton, Tompkinsville, and many other towns on Staten Island, in relation to the sale to-day of the franchise of the ferry from Whitehall-street to the North Shore of the island.

Assemblyman "Jimmy" Oliver distributed Jacqueminot roses around the Grand Central waiting-room, yesterday afternoon, while he and other members of the Legislature were waiting for the 3:30 train up to Albany.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--Two hundred employes of the Baldwin Locomotive-works have been discharged owing to lack of orders, and the remaining men are to work on twothirds time during the next 30 days. The number of employes will be reduced one-half.
Gen. F.A. Starring, of Washington, is at the Grand Hotel.

CHICAGO, April 21.--In an interview today Burton C. Cook. Solicitor for the Northwestern Railway Company, and one of the delegates at large to the Republican National Convention, said: "I know it has been reported that, though elected as a Logan man, I am secretly for Blaine.
M. and L., Glen Cove, are informed that in a game of quoits the stakes should be 18 yards apart, and that 21 points constitute a game.

BALTIMORE, April 21.--Every county which held Republican primaries on Saturday had been heard from this evening, and the result has utterly demoralized the office-holding element, which, headed by Mr. Creswell, has been booming Arthur.

BOSTON, April 21.--Ten of the twelve district conventions in this State, to choose delegates to the Republican Convention at Chicago, will be held to-morrow, Wednesday and Thursday. One of the other two has already been held, and the other will come off the day before the State Convention of April 30.

The stockholders of the Chicago and North-west Railway Company will be asked to vote on June 26 on the proposition to buy outright the Blair roads and tributaries, which are now only leased. These lines consist of the Chicago, Iowa and Nebraska, Cedar Rapids and Missouri River, and the Maple River Roads.

With the formal organization of the New-York Cable Railway Company, and the accompanying transfer to it of the recently created franchises for cable railways in this city, the Rapid Transit Commission finished its work.
Frank Hardenbergh, the veteran actor, who is a temporary inmate of the Hartford Retreat, created some excitement by escaping and appearing on the streets Saturday evening.

BOSTON, Mass., April 21.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Francis W. Hill, Daniel E. Marston, S.H. Chandler Co., of Portland, and James P. and W.H. Baxter, stockholders of the Maine Central Railroad, on behalf of themselves and other stockholders of the road, filed a bill in equity against the Maine Central, the...

JACKSON, Miss., April 21.--The State Republican Convention assembles to-morrow. A large number of delegates has already arrived, and a full representation is expected. The Arthur element seems to predominate, and is lead by John R. Lynch and James Hill, the Revenue Collector.

CHICAGO, April 21.--The political expectations and calculations of Mayor Harrison for this year are, on good authority, summarized as follows: To be a delegate at large to the National Convention, as well as not to be the Democratic candidate for Governor; to be a district...

PARIS, April 21.--La France says that M. de Brazza, the French explorer in the Congo country, has signed a treaty with the most powerful sovereign in Western Africa, who has placed all the right bank of the Congo from Brazzaville to the Equator under the protection of France.

CHICAGO, April 21.--The dispatch of last Saturday night relative to the death by asphyxiation, at the Palmer House, of Mr. and Mrs. Fillmore, of Fayetteville, N.Y., was incorrect as regards Mr. Fillmore, who, though believed to be dead, subsequently rallied, and is now alive. Mr. Frank B. Fillmore, a son of the old couple, reached Chicago this morning.

ALBANY, April 21.--As almost every day brings contradictory reports with regard to Samuel J. Tilden's declarations, or intentions, touching the Presidential nomination, it may be in order to give the latest report that has arrived at the State capital, which, like those that emanate from other points of the compass, is vouched for as being authentic, authoritative, and to be implicitly relied on.

Coroner Merkle yesterday visited Kate Murphy, the girl who was shot in the neck while returning from a picnic in Jones's Woods late on Saturday night, and, as she was not expected to live, took her ante-mortem statement. She said that while passing down Avenue A and Sixtyninth-street she suddenly heard a pistol-shot and felt something pierce her neck.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 21.--The Erie Railroad Company made another cut to-day in coal rates from their mines to Buffalo, making the rate $1.05. Some railroad men claim that this is aimed at the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Road, while others say it is aimed at the Rochester and Pittsburg.

LONDON, April 21.--The Paris correspondent of the Times has talked with several of the prominent Irishmen in the French capital, such as Patrick Casey, of the Moniteur Universal; James Stephens, formerly the Fenian Head Centre: John O'Leary, who used to be the editor of the Irish People, and Father Hogan, of the Catholic College of St. Sulpice.

When the Roosevelt committee resumed its investigation of the Police Department yesterday morning, John E. Simmons, who was formerly known as the reputed backer of a great number of policy shops in this city, was recalled.

The State election of Louisiana is held to-day. The political condition there is peculiar. The administration of Gov. McENERY has been neither efficient nor honest. It has bean disgracefully mixed up with land jobbery and the corrupt lottery ring.

SALEM, Mass., April 21.--A number of places here were entered last night, and property stolen to the value of over $500. A man was arrested at the station this morning, in whose baggage was found most of the property. He gave the name of W.M. Gale, of Providence, R.I. On him was found a list of places he intended to break into.
LAPORTE, Penn., April 21.--James Grubb, a farmer living near here, was divorced from his wife at Chicago in December last. She came East and established a dress-maker's shop here.

SHANGHAI, April 21.--The recent changes in the Cabinet have caused no difficulty. Prince Chun, who, has been placed in control of the Grand Council of the empire, has sent a notice of his nomination to the various Chinese Legations in foreign countries, but he gives no indication of the policy which he contemplates pursuing.

Gorman, Edward Kearney, William P. Kirk. Charles H. Haswell, Sidney P. Nichols, Richard...
The agents of the German steam-ship lines said yesterday that they were making no further reductions in immigrant rates, and that probably they would not make any, unless forced to do so.

It was reported in Wall-street yesterday that William H. Vanderbilt had closed out his interests in Union Pacific by the sale of $1,000,000 of Oregon Short Line bonds to a syndicate of bankers at 90. Oscar W. Rosenberg and Meyer Stern, cigar manufacturers, at No. 311 East SeventyFifth-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edmond C. Brown.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 21.--Three persons of suspicious character, believed to be the men who robbed Lyth Sons, in this city, last Saturday, have been arrested at Niagara Falls, on the Canada side, and are detained there for proof.

ALBANY, April 21.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 153 --The People vs. the City Bank of Rochester in the matter of the application of Sartwell, Hough, and Ford, respondents, to compel the payment of certain notes by Hobart F. Atkinson, Receiver, appellant.

WASHINGTON, April 21.--A decision was rendered in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the important railroad cases entitled F.L. Ames et al., the Board of Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, plaintiffs in error, vs. The State of Kansas, ex rel. F.A. Johnston, Attorney-General, and The Kansas Pacific Railway Company, plaintiff in error, ...

The Executive Committee of the Democractic General Committee of Kings County met last evening at Jefferson Hall, in Adams-street, Brooklyn, and organized by electing ex-Senator William A. Murtha as Chairman and Commissioner of Jurors William A. Furey and ex-Supervisor George Brown as Secretaries.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 21.--The Rev. J. V. Given was to-day expelled from the NewYork Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, now in session here, on the charge of immorality. In pronouncing the sentence of expulsion Bishop Moore held the hand of the accused and delivered an address that moved the Confrrenee and audience to tears.

UTICA, April 21.--Remembering, perhaps, Mr. Roscoe Conkling's sneering quotation, delivered four years ago, in the convention which met here to prepare for the Chicago Convention of 1880, about the murmuring of the shallows and the dumbness of the deeps, the Arthur men ...
PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--This was gamblers' day in the Court of Quarter Sessions. From 10 o'clock till 2 the indicted hosts of faro deployed before Judge Finletter in the old Courthouse.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 21.--The difficulty of pleasing everybody was never better illustrated than in the case of Gov. McDaniel, about whose cars there is now a din of censure, which may result in his defeat for another term in the Gubernatorial chair.
The following "open letter" to Mr. Abbey from Mme. Scalchi has been given for publication:
While temporarily insane, last evening, Samuel P. Banham, an English carpenter, age 49, shot himself three times in the mouth at his home, No. 307 Magnolia-street, Brooklyn. He cannot recover.

All the fathers and mothers and brothers and sisters and cousins and aunts of the members of Company I of the Seventh Regiment were present in full dress in the University Club Theatre last evening to witness a minstrel performance designed and carried out by the gay young gentlemen who compose the gayest company of the Seventh. The programme was headed: "Aches and pains at 8; ambulances may be ordered at 10."
HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 21.--Social circles here are in a ferment over the sudden disappearance of John Cameron, a highly respected resident of this county and a Deacon in the church for 20 years.

When, in the Hudson County Court of Sessions yesterday, Judge McGill called upon John D. Harrington to stand at the bar for sentence for his conspiracy with Dr. Rufus W. Peacock to defraud the American Legion of Honor, the Irish Count, as Harrington is called, did not respond.

VIENNA, April 21.--While the performance was going on at the Sidolia Circus, in Bucharest, this evening, the roof of the structure fell in upon the spectators. The lights were extinguished by the crash and a terrible panic ensued, which was increased by an outbreak of fire. Five dead bodies and 100 wounded persons have been carried from the spot. A large number of persons are missing.

Representative Beach, of New-York, had a little scheme mapped out for a Summer jaunt with his Committee on Public Health to the principal sea-port cities of the United States during the recess of Congress.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 21.--The dramatic festival, which has been little talked of outside of those who have been engaged in advertising it, opened to-night to 2,500 people. It was not a fashionable audience, though there were society people present.

The millinery department of James G. Johnson's store, No. 8 East Fourteenth-street, contains, just now, an uncommonly attractive display of round hats and bonnets, trimmed with fashionable shades in color and material. This house has a reputation of long standing.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 21.--There were no sales of whisky to-day and consequently no quotations were made. Had there been sales the price would have been $1.05 or lower. Members of the pool were in session at the Burnet House the greater part of the morning with "Buffalo" Miller in the chair.

The fair of the ladies of the Church of St. Boniface in the large hall of the parochial school building, in East Forty-seventh-street, the proceeds of which will go to swell the building fund, is quite a success. Every evening a series of panoramic views is presented. There are numerous wheels of fortune and turnrounds, and five large tables filled with articles, both useful and ornamental, for sale. The fair will continue all this week.

Coroner Robinson, of Long Island City, will begin on Friday the inquest in the case of Dr. E.M. Fitzgerald and Frank Lyons, who were killed at the Thompson-avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad on Sunday night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 21.--Ludwig Statler, a German, aged 38 years, employed at the large soap works of R. Thompson Co., at Brooklyn, this county, was crushed to death in the elevator yesterday morning. He was engaged in hoisting a number of heavy barrels to the third story, and in some unaccountable manner he slipped and his body fell over the edge of the elevator platform.

Capt. Nelson Magee, who was pilot of the Riverdale when her boilers burst last year, was at the wheel and in command of the ferry-boat Hoboken yesterday morning when she left the Hoboken slip at 10:20 o'clock. She had about 150 passengers, the majority of whom were ladies ...

At a meeting of the Tammany delegates to the last State Convention at Buffalo, held at Tammany Hall last evening, Mr. Edward Cahill was unanimously elected a member of the Democratic State Committee in place of the Hon. Augustus Schell, deceased. Mr. Cahill's last service on the committee was during the campaign of 1877.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., April 21.--For many weeks the oil trade has been watching suspiciously the operations of a few producers in what for the past 20 years has been known as the Macksburg oil field, near Macksburg and Marietta, Ohio.

On Saturday night Philip Barber, who lives in Shepherd-avenue, East New-York, went to his home drunk. On Sunday morning Mrs. Barber went to Ira Dunn's saloon, in the village, where she knew he was in the habit of going, and asked that Barber be given no more liquor.

Superintendent Jackson received a letter yesterday from Mr. W.P. Pierce, the United States Consul at Cienfuegos, who states that the immigrants who were taken to the sugar plantation in his neighborhood and held practically as slaves will be liberated and sent on to this city.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 21.--A year ago the employes of the Bay View Rolling Mills attempted to enforce a system of bi-monthly payments without success. The company insisted upon paying off monthly, as it had always done, and carried its point.

William Taylor, of No. 386 Adams-street, Brooklyn, the than who caused the panic in Haverly's Theatre on Saturday night, was sentenced by Justice Walsh yesterday to pay a fine of $10 or spend six months in the Kings County Penitentiary.

Marksmen's badges for the year 1883 were presented to 35 members of the Twelfth Regiment Infantry, at the armory, Forty-fourthstreet and Broadway, last evening. The battalion was formed for dress parade, and the marksmen were called to the front and centre.

We congratulate the Hon. WILLIAM PITT KELLOGG upon the near approach of that opportunity for vindication for which he has so long ineffectually clamored. The course of the Government toward him has amounted to a denial of justice.
WASHINGTON, April 21, 1884. The House adopted a resolution to-day fixing the hour of daily meeting hereafter at 11 o'clock, instead of 12.
WASHINGTON, April 21.--Naval Constructor William H. Varney has been detached from the Norfolk Navy-yard and ordered to report to the Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair for special duty.

The members of the Valley Forge Engine Company, one of the oldest fire organizations under the old volunteer system, celebrated the twenty-fourth anniversary of their change from a hose company into an engine company by a dinner at Martinelli's last night.

Messrs. Van Tassell Kearney, auctioneers, sold yesterday the right to collect and retain all wharfages for vessels of more than five tons burden for three years from May 1 on the following piers: Bulkhead, south of Old Pier No. 54 North River, T. Shea, $6,500; Jane-street pier, $1,600, Decker Rapp: Horatio-street pier, $1,230, Consumers' Ice Company; Forty-sixthstreet pier, $150, Patrick Donohue; East River, ...

BUFFALO, April 21.--The propeller William Edwards, loaded with coal, will start for Chicago to-morrow morning, provided she can get through the ice about the harbor. This will be the first vessel out this Spring.

The Trunk Line passenger agents met in Commissioner Fink's office yesterday and made special rates to Bellefontaine, Ohio, for the delegates attending the meeting there in June of the United Sons of Ireland. They also ordered a reduction to emigrant rates for those attending the Greenback Convention at Indianapolis in May.

At a meeting of the Directors of the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad Company held Saturday afternoon at Hunter's Point, Long Island, James M. Oakley was elected President, John B. Thompson Vice-President, D.C. Fisk Secretary and Treasurer, and A.S. Hatch, John B. Thompson, Julius F. Cheeseborough, and D.C. Fisk Executive Committee.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 21.--Republican caucuses were held in all the wards to-night. They were thinly attended and excited little interest. The result insures the election of Edmunds delegates to the Chicago Convention from this Congressional district. The delegates to the State Convention are unanimous for Senator Hoar as delegate at large.

The Primary Teachers' Association, composed of ladies having charge of primary classes in the different public schools, sent a petition to the Board of Education last November requesting a readjustment of salaries.

By a vote of 175 to 44 the House passed to-day the bill introduced by Mr. Dingley, of Maine, and recommended by the secretary of the Treasury to create a Bureau of Navigation in the Treasury Department.

The Paris correspondent of the London Times has reported for that journal several interviews with Irishmen resident in Paris. One of these interviews seems to show more promise for the future of Ireland than anything that has been made public for a long time past.

A letter from the managing editor of the most important paper published in the West Indies, the Diario de la Marina, of Havana, says: "In regard to the situation in this island, it has been exaggerated by the statements in Havana papers.

The Free Kindergarten of All Souls' (Anthon Memorial) Church, at No. 139 West Fortyeighth-street, celebrated the one hundred and second anniversary of the birth of Frederick Froebel, the founder of the kindergarten system, by a festival for the little ones in the chapel of the church yesterday afternoon.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 21.--The people of this city are exercised over a decided sensation. The trouble arose in the camp of a band of Spiritualists, which boasts of a boy medium-- Harry G. Van Auken.

A Quaker ghost is a novelty. In fact, until a day or two since the annals of the supernatural did not contain the name of a single Quaker ghost. Suddenly we find that a swarm of Quaker ghosts of disorderly habits has appeared in the village of Flushing, and has naturally created an immense amount of astonishment.

NORWICH, N.Y., April 21.--An Irishman, Kip Burlison, employed in the gas-house in this village, had orders to admit no one to the buildings. A colored man, William Johnson, attempted to enter, and Burlison objected.

The House passed, yesterday, by a large affirmative vote, a bill to organize a Bureau of Navigation. The measure was introduced by Representative DINGLEY, of Maine, and is honored with the indorsement of the Secretary of the Treasury.

BOSTON, April 21.--In the House to-day the Senate order that the Committee on Election Laws consider the expediency of amending the constitution so that it shall provide for biennial sessions of the General Court was rejected.

The champions of the National League regarded it as a joke when one of the Metropolitan players said the latter would defeat them in at least one of the series of exhibition contests. yesterday the Bostons began the game full of confidence, but the Metropolitan men had gone on the field with determination in every eye and a week's salary in every pocket, and from the outset they played in rare form.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22.--A middle-aged woman, poorly dressed and dissipated looking, but still showing traces of high breeding and great beauty, sat in the Quarter Sessions dock to-day, charged with the larceny of some trifling wearing apparel.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 22.--Three prisoners have escaped from the Newburg Jail. They had been indicted for burglary. They made a skeleton key with a stout wire and opened the door. They were pursued but not overtaken.
HAVRE, April 22.--The Hamburg-American Line steam-ship Wieland, Capt. Hebich, from Hamburg, aid, hence to-day for New-York.

RICHMOND, Va., April 22.--The indications to-night point to a stormy time in the Mahone convention, which meets here to-morrow. The Senator was on the ground early, ready to cut out the work for his convention. Some of the younger and equally brainy members of his party had anticipated him and sown seed some time ago.

The steam-ship Alert, which was presented by the British Government to the United States, and will be one of the vessels of the Greely relief expedition, arrived here yesterday from London, and was docked at the Brooklyn Navyyard. Lieut.-Commander C.F. Goodrich, of the United States steam-ship Lancaster, brought over the Alert, with a crew of about 30 seamen of the British merchant service, who merely shipped for the run.

In September, 1882, the Board of Aldermen passed over the mayor's veto a resolution granting to storekeepers in Fourteenth-street, between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, permission to place show-cases for the display of their goods on the sidewalks, within six feet of the house line.

BANGOR, Me., April 22.--To-day is a clear, cool day, and it is hoped the great rain-storm is over. The damage and the loss of business have been great, lumbermen having been able to do almost nothing this Spring.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 22.--Morris McDonald, of New Albany, sends a statement to the Journal which should put at rest the silly story that his election as a delegate to Chicago over the Hon. Will Cumback was in any sense a contest between Gen. Gresham and Harrison,
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 22.--Alfred Rainey, a landed proprietor in Washington County, Tenn., is in this city looking after his interests in oil and mineral lands there.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22.--The State Greenback Convention will assemble in the hall of the House of Representatives in this city tomorrow to nominate a candidate for Governor and elect delegates to the National Convention. The attendance will be comparatively small and the session brief. The nomination will doubtless be given to the Hon. John R. Beasley, of Franklin County. The Greenbackers hope to gain accessions from the ranks of dissatisfied low-tax Democrats.

CHICAGO, April 22.--The Tribune gives the following reasons why Emery A. Storrs and Green B. Raum were set aside by the Peoria Convention and Gov. Hamilton and Clarke Carr chosen instead as delegates at large to the National Convention: "When the Committee on the Selection of Delegates at Large, made up from each Congressional district, began to discuss the persons to be recommended to the convention it...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22.--The committee appointed to solicit subscriptions to the five-hundred-thousand-dollar stock of the proposed Cincinnati, Green River and Nashville Ralroad have secured up to to-night $225,000. Large amounts are daily subscribed and it is believed that the necessary sum will be raised.

The first of the three Wagner concerts announced to occur at the Metropolitan Operahouse this week was given there last evening in presence of a large audience. The programme was made up of music from "Tannhauser," "Die Walkure," and "Siegfried," and its interpretation occupied two hours.

COCHRAN, Penn., April 22.--A frightful story is told of the managling to death of the son, Henry, 9 years old, of Harrison Barlow, by dogs. Henry had taken a bow and arrow for the purpose of hunting. His unusual absence caused search to be made for him, in which a number of the neighbors joined. James Mullis found the boy in an open field, about 300 yards from the house.

Mme. Etelka Gerstar will appear as Amina in "La Sonnambula" at the Academy of Music to-morrow night. There has been a generally expressed desire to hear Mme. Gerster once more in this beautiful impersonation.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 22.--Judge Sheldon, of the Superior Court, to-day rendered a decision in the dispute between the Union Steamboat Company and the city over the maintenance of a fence across Front-street.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 1,250--Mary M. Morrison et al., appellants, vs. Martha S. Withers et al.--Appeal from the Circuit Court for the Southern District of Mississippi.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 22.--There have been filed in court here two suits for damages by Joseph Evans against Mr. George W. Collier, one of the wealthiest property-owners in this county. The first suit is brought to recover compensation "for work and labor done and performed for the defendant on his farm by the plaintiff for five years at $20 per month, amounting to $1,200, besides interest."

NEW-ORLEANS, April 22.--The morning opened upon a registered population prepared to vote four to one against the continuation of the Democratic ring rule in New-Orleans. At the opening of the polls everything was in readiness to give the Democracy its Waterloo, when the dominant ring disclosed its tactics, for which the opposition was unprepared.

The warmth of the controversy for the selection of delegates to Chicago, which turns upon nothing but personal preference, leads some Republican papers to complain that other papers, and especially in this State, say frankly that certain candidates could not carry the State. But what should be said? If the election were lost in New-York, for instance, because of the ignorance of delegates from other parts of the country.

A fire occurred yesterday afternoon in George Bothner's piano-forte action factory, which is a four-story brick building, at Nos. 135 and 137 Chrystie-street, in the rear of Harry Miner's Bowery theatre, owned by Bothner.

One of Deacon Ranney's faithful followers said last night: "You reporters haven't dropped to the quiet game the Newman Committee on Revision of Members have been playing the past week, have you? Well, Sir, they have cut down the church roll one-half, that's what they have done. It's a fact, for one of our men saw the books and counted them.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22.--Reliable reports from all sections of Middle Tennessee state that the apple crop will be the largest known for years. Reports concerning the peach crop are discouraging in some districts. Not a single peach plessom has made its appearance, and now it is too late for the trees to bloom. Strawberry plants sustained but little damage from recent frosts.
The plan for funding the first mortgage coupons of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad will be officially announced, it is said, in about 10 days.

UTICA, April 22.--If President Arthur's claim for nomination at Chicago depends upon his success in the New-York Convention his friends may as well give up all hope. With nearly all of his stanchest friends here, and with the knowledge that they have gained since their coming of the hopelessness of making a slaughter fight in his behalf, they now openly admit that he is beaten.

A number of the city delegates to the Republican State Convention, which is to meet in Utica to-day, started on the 10:30 Hudson River train yesterday morning, and the waitingroom in the Grand Central Station was filled with politicians from 10 o'clock until the cars started. The statesmen did not have a special train, nor even a special car, but each secured his seat in whichever of the six drawing-room cars he could.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 22.--A special to the News from Laredo says: "The costly club and hotel buildings erected by the construction company of Gould's extension of the International Road into Mexico have been seized and appropriated by the civil authorities of New-Laredo because of some alleged failure to comply with the requirements of the General Government."

JACKSON, Miss., April 22.--The Republican State Convention now in session at the State-house is large but not harmonious. There is bad feeling between the two factions of the party. The faction led by John R. Lynch and James Hill, both colored, is the largest and exercises control. The other, led by George C. McKee, Postmaster at this place, has been defeated at every step, and thus far has been able to do nothing.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22.--John Schoffner, colored, who, with Meyer Morris, white, and Zeke White, colored, was arrested last night on the charge of complicity in the fatal assault upon Meyer Friedman, in this city, 10 days ago, made a confession to-day.

Now that the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House ef Representatives has decided that it has no fault to find with Controller of the Currency John J. Knox, in connection with the failure of the Pacific National Bank of Boston, Mr. Knox will to-morrow...

Four-fifths of the Republican voters of the North who are not active politicians believed a few months ago that they were to be allowed to choose a Presidential candidate and were not to be deprived of their rights by the interference of Federal officers working night and day, not in behalf of the Government that employs them, but in the service of their chief in the White House.

The managers of the World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition, which is to be held in New-Orleans, have asked Congress to loan them $1,000,000 out of the National Treasury. The people of New-Orleans have taken $500,000 of the capital stock, and are now engaged in increasing the amount subscribed to $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--By an arrangement between Mr. Morrison and Mr. Randall, as representatives of the Committees on Ways and Means and Appropriations, the tariff debate was reopened to-day, and after three speeches had been delivered Mr. Morrison gave way to the Appropriations Committee to finish the consideration of the Pension Appropriation bill.

CHICAGO, April 22.--A meeting was held to-day by Mr. Clark, General Manager of the Union Pacific Railroad, and representatives or managers of the four Eastern allies of the Union Pacific--the North-western, the Milwaukee and St. Paul, the Rock Island, and the Wabash--for the purpose of agreeing upon some basis of adjustment of the difficulty with the Burlington.

ALBANY, April 22.--In the Court of Appeals today, present the Hon. William C. Ruger and association, the following decisions were handed down: Marie M. Miller, appellant, vs. Marilla Mackenzie, et al., Administratrix, , respondents; Charles Sandford, Assignee, appellant, vs. Willston D. Lockwood, et al., respondent--Judgment reversed and a new trial granted, costs to abide the event.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 22.--A fight with pistols between brothers-in-law yesterday afternoon gave the neighborhood of Cockeysville, in Baltimore County, a sensation the like of which it has not had for years, and resulted in the serious wounding of one of the participants and the arrest of the other.

WHEELING, West Va., April 22.--On inquiring at the Custom-house this evening it was learned that J.H. Duval, Collector of Internal Revenue, who recently handed in his resignation to Commissioner Evans, for political reasons, had concluded to accept Secretary Folger's advice to remain at his post.

Judge Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday dismissed the indictments against Deputy Warden Philip Kiernan, of Ludlow-Street Jail, holding that the evidence taken on the trial of Sheriff Davidson proved that it would be impossible to convict Kiernan of the forgery alleged against him. Kiernan was therefore released and his bail discharged.

BRADFORD, Penn., April 22.--Charles Riebly, a baker of this place, was drowned at Carrollton while out hunting to-day. He waded into a stream for fish and lost his footing, and was carried down by the weight of his ammunition and clothing. The body was recovered.

LONDON, April 22.--In the House of Commons to-day the Right Hon. George J. Dodson, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lausaster, confirmed the report that 15 head of cattle had been found at Wimpole, in Cambridgeshire, infected with the foot and mouth disease. These were a portion of a herd of 51 head recently sent into Cambridgeshire from Liverpool, and the Cattle...

A special meeting of the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church was called yesterday morning to meet in Grace House. The meeting was opened with a service in Grace Church, participated in by Bishops Williams, Whipple, and Scarborough.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 22.--Samuel W. Tallmadge, the Chamber of Commerce statistician, to-day received a letter from the Territorial Secretary of Dakota, stating that Spring wheat seeding in that State is about half completed.

Mr. R.H. Hatch, a young elocutionist, who has met with favor in London, but who is an American, made his first appearance in this city yesterday afternoon at the Madison-Square Theatre, where he was heard with many signs of delight by a large audience, almost wholly composed of ladies.

The equity suit by which the Pennsylvania Railroad Company hopes to prevent the Reading Road from annulling the contract under which it enjoys the use of the tracks of the NewYork and Long Branch division of the Central...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 22.--Speaking of the effect the defeat of the Bonded Whisky bill has had upon business affairs in Kentucky, a prominent resident of the interior of the State said to-day that the effect was very apparent of the money market.
CHICAGO, April 22.--Cornelius Schugrue, owner of a livery stable in State-screet, was arrested last night for the murder of his hostler, Samuel Atkinson, who was killed on Feb. 6.
MONTREAL, April 22.--There have been rumors for the past day or two to the effect that Mr. Duncan McIntyre, First Vice-President of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, intends...

Persons interested in bringing about a settlement of the triangular coal rate war between the Erie, Rochester and Pittsburg, and Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Roads believe that an amicable adjustment of differences will be made within a few days.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 22.--Five cars and the locomotive of a New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad freight train were thrown into the Erie Canal to-night by a misplaced switch. The employes escaped by jumping.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--An order was issued from the War Department to-day assigning Brig.Gen. David S. Stanley to the command of the Department of Texas, in place of Brig.-Gen. Mackenzie, retired. Lieut.-Col. Orlando M. Poe, Corps of Engineers, has been relieved from further duty in this city, and will proceed to Detroit and take station at that place from May, 1884.

Ricci's bright and melodious little opera, "Crispino e la Comare," was sung once more at the Academy of Music last evening. Mme. Patti's impersonation of Annetta has been witnessed before in this city with much pleasure.
I am glad to note the growing evidences that THE TIMES is the great paper of America, as the other Times is of the British Empire, and trust that no good cause will ever lack its powerful support.

The House continues to turn out tariff "copy" for the Congressional Record in regular and large installments, and of the usual character--not interesting nor valuable to the student of the subject, but worth something to the readers whom it ultimately reaches.

The committee appointed last year by the various companies using electric wires to see what could be done toward clearing the streets of poles and wires has at last reported. Its report is to the effect that a subway, large enough to hold all the wires so arranged that they may easily be got at for repairs, is the only practicable device for that purpose.

ALBANY, April 22.--The general Street Surface Railroad bill, that passed the Assembly last week with amendments, was announced in the Senate this morning, and Mr. Baker moved that the Senate concur in the amendments of the Assembly. Mr. Thomas moved as an amendment that the Senate reconsider the vote by which it passed the bill, and that the amendments be then considered separately.

CINCINNATI, April 22.--The whisky pool has been patched up, and will now hold together until June, and perhaps till Fall. Another meeting was held to-day of the Executive Committee, and it was agreed that the price should be $1 10 for the present.

When the Republican members of the Legislature shall have returned from the Utica Convention and resumed their duties at Albany they and their associates will do well to turn their thoughts to the question of winding up the work of the session.

BOSTON, April 22.--Delegates to the Chicago Republican Convention were chosen today in four Districts--the Fifth, Seventh, Ninth, and Eleventh. In each district pronounced Edmunds men were chosen and Edmunds was shown to be decidedly the choice of the great majority represented in each convention. In the Essex District--the Seventh--where it had been said that...

On the representation of Inspector Byrnes that the efficiency of the ward detective would be increased by remanding 11 officers to patrol duty and filling their places by men whom he considered abler, the Police Commissioners made the following changes yesterday:

WELLSBURG, West Va., April 22.--What is claimed to be the heaviest flow of natural gas in the world was struck at the Barclay No. 2 well, at this place, at 8 o'clock A.M. to-day, at a depth of 1,237 feet.

Uncle Rufus Hatch was going down town in a cab yesterday noon when one of the Havemeyer Sugar Refinery's trucks, turning from Cortlandt-street into Broadway, stopped his passage. Charles Russ, of No. 43 Grand-street, was the driver of the truck, and he came pretty near running the cab down.

UTICA, April 22.--A horrible suspicion arose in the minds of some of the anti-Arthur people when they saw a curious story in the Utica Morning Herald. Its purport was that Mr. Arthur's warm personal friend, Chairman Warren, of the State Committee, had a long conference with Mr. Whitelaw Reid in New-York yesterday, and that a compromise had been agreed upon there and then.

The windows of Yee Lee, washerman, at No. 176 Greenwich-street, were smashed on Monday night by his amiable neighbors for the fifth or sixth time this year, and for the fiftieth or more in all. No arrests.

LONDON, April 22.--At 9:30 o'clock this morning an earthquake shock of considerable force was felt in the eastern counties of England. Localities in Essex and Suffolk were the scenes of great disturbance. At Ipswich, the capital of Suffolk County, the shock was so severe that the walls of the houses were perceptibly shaken, plates were rattled, and bells rung. The railway station was partially destroyed.
Mr. "Calamity" Weller's dislike to the national bank system defeated to-day Representative Dingley's attempt to pass a measure of considerable importance.
TORONTO, Ontario, April 22.--Chief-Justice Hogarty, addressing the Grand Jury at the opening of the Criminal Assizes to-day, referred to the conspiracy case at length.

The ceremonial at the Chapel of St. Dominic, in the new Monastery of the Sisters of the Second Order of St. Dominic, Newark, commenced at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. It included the solemn consecration of the beautiful marble altar and the celebration of a Pontifical mass, with a sermon bs Archbishop Corrigan.

The representatives of 22 roads in the Joint Executive Committee. Passenger Department, met at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday and adjourned late in the afternoon without accomplishing very much or taking up the more important questions that have to be considered at the present time.

Miss Mary Mason Jones, daughter of Mason R. Jones, was married last evening to Louis C. Hassell, son of Mr. B.D. Hassell, of Charleston, S.C., at the residence of her grandmother, at Fifty-seventh-street and Fifth-avenue.

COVINGTON, Ky., April 22.--J.J. Douglas and R.B. Spencer, managers of the Henry College Lottery, were arrested here to-day by Gen. Edgarton, Herrick, and Hanna, Post Office Inspectors, on the charge of using the mails for lottery purposes. They were taken before Commissioner Finnell and released on bond.

HARTFORD, April 22.--The Republican State Convention for the nomination of delegates to the National Convention at Chicago will be held at Allyn Hall, this city, to-morrow. Delegates from all parts of the State are now in town, and county caucuses were held to-night.

A number of gentlemen assembled yesterday at Uldrich's Bay Shore House, Greenville, N.J., to witness the first public experiments that have ever been made with the object of showing that dynamite can be fired from an ordinary cannon. Mr. F.H. Snyder, general manager of the Dynamite Projectile Company, W.W. Horton, Robert Sherwood, J.W. Blake, William H. Kimball, W.K. Marvin, and Z.K. Pangborn were among those present.

DETROIT, Mich., April 22.--The Republicans of the Eighth Congressional District held a convention at East Saginaw to-day, which was fully attended. W.S. Track, of Gratiot County, and W.E. Watson, of Shiawassee County, were elected delegates to the Chicago Convention.

Forty years ago ex-Mayor A.C. Kingsland bought about 120 acres of land in what is now the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Wards of Brooklyn. The land was part of the old Wyckoff Farm, which had been in the Wyckoff family since 1790.

CAIRO, April 23.--It is reported that the rebels have captured Berber. It is uncertain whether or not the garrison and inhabitants have been massacred. The Khedive and Ministers are deeply affected by the reports. Hussein Pasha has been asking for assistance for a month past. Aid will be too late now.

Mr. John Malkle, of Hazleton, Penn., who was married yesterday to Miss Mary Robinson, of this city, bade adieu to single-blessedness on Monday night at a farewell bachelor dinner which he gave to the wedding ushers and a few very intimate friends in room No. 1 at Delmonico's. The guests were his brother, George B...

The dignity of the office of Commissioner of Agriculture has been vindicated, and the Hon. Mr. Loring is now a personage of more importance than ever. The attempts of Senator Plumb and others to raise the head of the Agricultural Department to the rank of a Cabinet officer have not yet been successful, but the Senate to-day gave to the Commissioner of Agriculture the...

The dime novel is steadily doing its demoralizing work. The other day seven youthful desperadoes, all of whom were under 12 years of age, were arrested in a small country town through which runs the White River Canal. The prisoners had formed a secret society called the "Robeson Gang," and it was their habit to go...

Immediately after the French had left Mexico and Maximilian had been shot, a provisional Government was formed there, which made a contract with Daniel Woodhouse and other American capitalists for the negotiation of its bonds.

Mr. William Pitt Kellogg's vindication is at hand. The long--sought witness, John A. Walsh, who was found in Montreal be Special Counsel Ker and Mr. Brewster Cameron, arrived in Washington on the late train to-night and is now enjoying himself at Wormley's. Mr. Walsh's journey from Montreal was not unenventful.

Patrolman Richard Flynn, of the Sixteenth Precinct, saw two men fighting in Seventh-avenue, near Twentieth-street, and by his interference put a stop to the disturbance. The men proved to be Williamn Carroll, of No. 536 West Fortieth-street, and James Rielly, of No: 330 West Twenty-fifth-street.
Tarrytown in the neighborhood of the railroad station and Orchard-street was ablaze with tar-barrels, bonfires, and torches, and a great din was produced by a cannon and a brass band on Monday night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 22.--The delegates and candidates are beginning to flock in, ready for the opening of the Republican State Convention to-morrow afternoon. The questions touching the State ticket are swallowed up in interest by the Presidential contest, and nearly all the talk revolves around Chicago and its possibilities.

Charles Van Homan, a German street sprinkler, 52 years of age, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself with a piece of rope in the cellar of the tenement-house No. 327 East One Hundred and Ninth-street, where he had lived for many years.

A well-dressed man, who labored under the dual disadvantage of lameness and inebriety, staggered erratically up Nineteenth-street in an effort to reach Broadway, about 6 o'clock last evening, just as the thoroughfares were crowded with the toilars of the metropolis on their way home from work.
ERIE, Penn., April 22.--An attempt was made this morning to burn St. Patrick's Cathedral, but the fire was discovered and but out before much damage was done.

VERPLANCK, April 22.--Among the 50 shad boats which drifted down the reach opposite this place when sun went down last night was one in which were Jacob Kiefer and his 11year-old son, Caleb, George Hilliker and wife, and Nathaniel Wright.
CHICAGO, April 22.--The tone of the cattle market was weak. With a supply for the two days of 14,000 head, and adverse reports from the markets below, shippers tried hard to buy the cattle cheaper.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 22.--William Harder, Assistant Traffic Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway, has resigned at the request of the General Manager.

BALTIMORE, April 22.--Six more Republican counties wheeled into line to-day, and their conventions almost unanimously repudiated Arthur, and declared for Blaine. These were Cecil, the home of Mr. Creswell; Anne Arundel, the home of Collector of Internal Revenue Sillman; Garrett, where lives H. Wheeler Combs, who was promised the office of General Appraiser, at Baltimore, if the county went for Arthur; Talbot, Washington, and Somerset.

The opinion which Mr. William H. Gale entertains of Mr. Leonard Grover is exactly the reverse of flattering, in spite of the fact that the latter has produced one or two very successful plays. Mr. Gale is the senior member of the firm of Gale Spader, who are dramatic agents and lessees of the Comedy Theatre, in Broadway,...

WASHINGTON, April 22, 1884. The Controller of the Currency has appointed the Hon. Daniel Roberts, of Burlington, Vt., as Receiver of the First National Bank of St. Albans, and R. M. Stevenson, of Monmouth, Ill., to be Receiver of the First National Bank of that place.

The Ninth Regiment band, wearing brilliant scarlet uniforms, formed in line at Fifthavenue and Fourteenth-street yesterday afternoon. A crowd at once collected. The band marched into the armory of the Old Guard, and the crowd attempted to follow, but was kept back by stalwart policemen. Gentlemen in sombre black, or in the latest Spring costumes, disappeared between the files of policemen into...

Ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling permitted his associate, ex-Judge Shipman, to conduct the cross-examination of Abram Van Santvoord about the making of Jesse Hoyt's will, in the suit of Miss Mary Irene Hoyt to open the probate before the Surrogate yesterday.

PALMETTO, Ga., April 22.--A personal difficulty ending in a tragedy occurred near this station yesterday in which Mr. John A. Cathcart and Mr. Nathan L. Thomas figured as principals. The men were cousins and had spent the day in Newnan.

NORFOLK, Va., April 22.--The Virginian will publish to-morrow the following interview with Mr. Dezendorf with reference to Chairman Sabin's "clerical error" in sending him the circular asking for the Virginia delegation to the National Convention. Mr. Dezendorf said he attached no sort of significance to the publication,...

RICHFORD, Vt., April 22.--A Special train was run over the Montreal, Portland and Boston Railroad yesterday from Farnham to Frelighsburg, Province of Quebec, and all the train hands, with Superintendent Macdiarmid and General Roadmaster Shanks, were arrested at the instigation of Ashley Hibbard for trespassing. Bail was obtained and the prisoners were released. A hearing is to be had on Friday.

BOSTON, April 22.--Samuel McSheehey, who keeps a drug store in the basement of the Waverly House, Bunker Hill district, and his clerk. William Beddle, have been arrested, charged with robbing the rooms of Mrs. Snow, a boarder in the Waverly House, of about $4,000 worth of jewelry, bonds, , a few weeks ago. In court to-day they were held in $10,000 each for future examination.

MONTREAL, Canada, April 22.--The suspension is announced of the old established firm of Cassils, Stimson Co., leather dealers. The firm, which does the largest business in fine leather and shoe findings in this city, consists of Archibald M. Cassils, Col. E.A. Whitehead, and Charles Cassils. The firm at one time controlled the whole business in their particular branches in the city, if not in the Province, but of late the...

Quite a stir was created in the Diocesan Conference of Roman Catholic priests held in the Catholic Institute, Newark, N.J., yesterday, by the Rev. Father Hugh Murphy, of St. Joseph's Hospital, Paterson.

TRENTON, April 22.--Gov. Abbett's proclamation convening to-day a special session of the Senate for the purpose of confirming such nominations as remained unacted upon last Friday, when the Legislature adjourned sine die, resulted in the attendance of every Senator. The proclamation set noon as the hour, and though all the Senators were either loitering in the halls or lobbies of the State-house when Secretary...

The "learned counsel," as they were pleased to call each other, monopolized most of the time in the Loubat suit against the Union Club yesterday, and assailed Judge Van Vorst with a continuous storm of objections and exceptions. Secretary Oliver K. King took the witness chair again and repeated to Lawyer Robinson the circumstances of the dinner at the club-house and his difficulty with Loubat.

SHANGHAI, April 22.--The disgrace of Prince Kung for his dilatory action in the Tonquin affair, has been favorably received by the population of the Provinces. They believe that the accession of Prince Chun to the control of the Grand Council of the empire is is a forerunner of war.

Persistent Mr. Charles Stoughton, of New-York, who wishes Congress to authorize the Secretary of War to contract with him for the improvement of the Harlem River, has prepared a fresh appeal to Senators and Representatives, which was distributed at the Capitol to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22.--"Several causes have operated to bring about the present depression in the locomotive building trade," said a member of the firm of Burnham, Parry, Williams Co., known as the Baldwin Locomotive Company, to a Philadelphia Times reporter to-day, "and the paramount reason has not been, as is generally supposed, the reaction against the projection of new railroad lines.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Apri1 23.--At Swainsboro, Ga., to-day, J.C. Coleman, a merchant, and J.F. Meyers, editor of the Itemizer, resorted to arms to settle a difficulty. Thirteen shots were fired, and Coleman was shot in the abdomen.

The three competitive designs for the bridge to be-erected over the Harlem River, half a mile above High Bridge, under the direction of the Park Department, may now be seen at the offices of that department in Union-square. The competitors, Mr. Alfred P. Boller, Mr. Joseph M. Wilson, and Messrs. Buck and McNulty, are engineers of the highest standing, well known in ...

BOSTON, April 23.--Republican Conventions were held to-day in the Fourth, Sixth, Eighth, and Twelfth Districts, and eight more delegates to Chicago were chosen, whose first choice is declared to be for Edmunds. The Fourth District Convention was without incident.
WASHINGTON, April 23.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Conrt to-day were as follows: No. 1,282--Benjamin Butterworth, Commissioner of Patents, ...
Coroner Levy began an inquest yeaterday on the death of James Ritchie, who was shot on Ward's Island last Saturday.
The wines and liquors in the cellars of the St. Nicholas Hotel were auctioned off yesterday by Mr. Edward Schenck. The prices realized were exceedingly low, and especially so to those ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 23.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Fergus Falls says the Republican Fifth District Convention, held to-day, was entirely harmonious, and completed its work within an hour.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 23.--Measured by the attendance on this convention and the interest shown by all present as to who shall be sent to Chicago, the Republicans of the State are found to be full of hope and courage and prepared to carry the State in the Fall if such a thing can be done.

Miss Cora H. Rutter, daughter of Mr. Thomas Rutter, was married last evening to Mr. Thomas Blake Kent, at the residence of the bride's father, No. 849 Fifth-avenue, the ceremony being performed by the Rev. C.B. Smith.
TRENTON, N.J., April 23.--The New-Jersey Nationalists held a convention here to-day, and selected four delegates at large to attend the Presidential Convention to be held at Indinapolis on May 28.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 23.--In the James trial at Huntsville, Ala., to-day, the Government examined J.W. Davis, who kept peden's saloon at Muscle Shoals April 11, 1881.
DUBLIN, Ga., April 23.--Proceedings of a curious nature have been instituted here for the establishment of a will. Papers filed in court allege that on Nov. 9, 1883, Miss Penelope Wilberly died.

BOSTON, April 23.--An examination of the books of the Massachusetts State Prison shows a deficit of over $12,000 in the accounts. It is said the deficit is the result of bad bookkeeping and is not really a defalcation. Warden Usher claims that the accounts are all correct.

CHICAGO, April 24.--The irregularity of cattle receipts keeps the market unsettled. It was active today, but weaker. The receipts were nearly 3,000 head in excess of the total reported for Wednesday, and buyers took advantage of that fact to depress prices.

LONDON, April 12.--Mr. Charles Reade's death, deeply as it is regretted, was no cause for surprise to those who knew how great a sufferer he had long been. CANTON, Miss., April 26.--The Board of Supervisors of Madison County, Miss., at a recent meeting resolved to contest the legality of bonds, amounting to $75,000, issued 10 years ago by the county to the Canton and Vicksburg Railroad Company. The road was never built, and the county will refuse to pay the outstanding bonds and interest. The bonds are held principally in New-York and Chicago.

The second engagement of Henry Irving and his company at the Star Theatre came to an end last night. KINGSTON, N.Y., April 26.--In the suit for $36,000 damages against Mr. William Belden, whose yacht Yosemite sunk the steam-boat Charlotte Vanderbilt by a collision in July, 1882, a verdict of $13,000 against Mr. Belden was rendered this morning.

There exists no more interesting and instructive spectacle for the student of human nature than that of the shirt-fronts round a dinner-table. A shirt-front is a phenomenon of infinite humor--full of expression in every part of it, possessing vast potentialities or achievement from the bottom of the throat to the pit of the stomach. As is the aspect of the shirt-front, such will be the look impressed on the physiognomy of the wearer.

VERPLANCK'S, April 26.--"How in blazes a shad ever gets up the Hudson River to spawn," said Landlord Jim Williamson, of the Westchester Hotel, the other night, "is beyond my comprehension. LIVERPOOL, April 26.--John Daly, the suspected dynamiter, who has been in jail here the past two weeks waiting trial, was brought into court this morning. The annual report of the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railway for the year ending Dec. 31, 1883, shows the gross earnings to have been $573,491, an increase of $34,353 over the previous year. PHILADELPHIA, April 27.--Max Michael, an insane man, 50 years old, set fire to the bed in which he and his 1-year-old child were lying, at his house, No. 945 Lithgow-street, at 10:45 o'clock to-night. WASHINGTON, April 27.--The National Republican, of this city, changed hands last week, and to-day the new management took possession. WASHINGTON, April 28.--Jack Cole, one of the sailors of the lost arctic exploring steamer Jeannette, died at the Insane Asylum here this morning of cardiac dropsy.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 28.--Glens Falls was visited this morning by the most disastrous fire known there since May, 1864, when the thriving village was nearly destroyed. ALTOONA, Penn., April 28.--Dr. B.F. Ghrett, a prominent physician of this city, died last evening of spine disease, from which he had been a sufferer for several years. When the announcement of his death was made Miss Harvey, 20 years old, his sister-in-law, who had been an invalid and a member of the doctor's family, fell on her face and died in a few minutes.

The funeral of Dr. Willard Parker was held yesterday afternoon in the old church where he had worshiped so many years, the UniversityPlace Presbyterian Church, and the building has seldom held a larger congregation. There was a chort service of prayer at Dr. Parker's late residence, on Twelfth-street, and then the coffin was borne on the shoulders of young men to the church.

PANAMA, April 28, via Galveston.--A terrible fire raged here from 11 o'clock last night to 4 o'clock this morning. There was no water available with which to extinguish the flames, and the market and two blocks of houses were destroyed. How the fire started is unknown.

UTICA, N.Y., April 28.--An attempt at incendiarism, by which 200 lives were imperiled, was by mere accident frustrated here to-night. The Odd-fellows, whose rooms are on the third floor of the Exchange Building, Genesee, were celebrating the anniversary of the founding of their order.

The meeting was earnest in its demonstrations of sympathy with the sentiments expressed in the call.
MADRID, April 28.--The elections in 46 districts for members of the Chamber of Deputies have resulted in the choice of 206 ministerialists.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 28.--Work was begun with a large force of men on the street railway to-day. Five miles will be built in this village. Cars and rails have already been purchased of Philadelphia parties.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--The Jeannette investigation was resumed this morning. Lieut. Danenhower continued his testimony, stating, in reply to inquiries by Judge Arnoux, that to the best of his knowledge and belief he did not, in his interview with Dr. Collins and his brother at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, say that Mr. Collinslead a "h--of a life."

Workmen were engaged yesterday in clearing away the rubbish caused by the fire of the previous night at No. 16 Spruce-street. One side of the street was made impassable by a pile of glaring circus posters.

The light of early dawn forced its way through the dirty windows of Madison-Square Garden yesterday morning before one-half of the 10,000 people who went to see the start of the six-day walking-match had departed for their homes, Rowell took the lead until the building was nearly empty, when he dropped behind for few moments' rest and some fresh air, letting Day's name go to the top of the blackboard.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 28.--News is received here of the discovery on Saturday morning, in West Falls, this county, of the dead body of an aged woman named Frank, who had been assaulted and either murdered or left by the roadside to die.

During the coming Summer there will be more canoes afloat in this country than in England. Canoeing has grown with unprecedented rapidity during the last year, and hardly a week has passed without the organization of a new canoe club.

A fifteen-cent night rate now prevails on all the telegraph lines. The Western Union Company limits its messages to 10 words, with 1 cent for each additional word; the Bankers and Merchants' to 15 words, and the Postal to 20 words. Yesterday was the first day of the fifteencent rate on the Baltimore and Ohio lines. General Superintendent Tinker, of the Western Union, claimed yesterday that there was no war ...

WASHINGTON, April 28.--The President sent to the House of Representantives to-day a long communication from the Secretary of State in relation to the proposed reduction in the amount to be appropriated by the Consular and Diplomatic bill and the changes suggested in the Consular and Diplomatic Service of the United States. Secretary Frelinghuysen says that the diplomatic officer does for the nation what the ...

The Trustees of the Madison-Avenue Church are preparing their argument to show why the injunction against Dr. Newman's continuing to minister to the spiritual wants of the congregation should not be made permanent.

FORT SMITH, Ark., April 28.--Thomas L. Thompson and Daniel Jones, (white men,) Jack Womankiller, (Cherokee,) John Davis, (Choctaw,) and Fanny Echols, (negress,) convicted in the United States court of murder in Indian Territory, and Matt Music, (negro,) convicted of rape in Indian Territory, were to-day sentenced to be hanged on Friday, July 11.

When Roscoe Conkling began to question John H. Beach in the Marie-Garrison case in the rooms of the Bar Association last evening, he had for an audience only Referee Dwight, the friendly and the opposing counsel, and a picture of himself on the opposite wall.

The hall boys of the Windsor Hotel were not allowed much repose yesterday afternoon. They were employed at regular intervals of five minutes in carrying silver waiters with cards upon them to Mme. Christine Nilsson's apartments, on the first floor, and in ushering up dressmakers, florists, and milliners to wait upon the amiable soprano.

The funeral of the late Benjamin Wheeler Merriam took place yesterday morning from his late residence, No. 312 Fifth-avenue. The body was enveloped in a plain, cloth-covered coffin, and a cross of calla lilies, a sheaf of wheat, and a bunch of flowers were the only decorations.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 28.--When the body of John Coyle, Jr., the murderer of Emily Myers, of Marietta, was taken from the scaffold at Gettysburg, it was taken charge of by the father of the murderer, who wished to inter it in the Marietta Cemetery, but the authorities of the ...
MADISON, Wis., April 28.--A few delegates to the State Convention from the northern districts arrived to-night, but the great body of the elect will not be here until this time to-morrow.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 28.--Mining troubles in the Hocking Valley, Ohio, are increasing, and a bitter feeling against the operators has sprung up in that region. On Saturday a circular addressed to the miners in the Hocking Valley was circulated by the Columbus and Hocking Coal and Iron Company and the Ohio Coal Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--Mr. Hewitt, of New-York, rising to a question of privilege in the House to-day, said that on Thursday last he had made a statement that the Secretary of the Navy had not complied with the law which required him to cover into the Treasury the net proceeds of the sale of condemned vessels.

CHICAGO, April 28.--The coal-laden steamer William Edward arrived here from Buffalo last night. This is the first arrival of the season from a lower lake port. The Captain reports having had little difficuly in passing through the ice in the straits.

It is unlikely that HAZAEL'S wonderful record will be surpassed in the walkingmatch begun on Sunday night. It is rather to be hoped that it may not be surpassed. A six-day race is not a particularly elevating spectacle.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--There are some State secrets more carefully preserved than others, and one that has been a long time kept is the fact that President Arthur was anxiously debating in his own mind and canvassing with his constitutional advisers a quiet appropriation of Mr. Blaine's "Jingo policy" so far back as last January.

UTICA, N.Y., April 28.--The report that the wife of Dr. Walter Kempster, Superintendent of the Asylum for Insane at Oshkosh, Wis., has begun suit for divorce causes a painful sensation here, where both are well known, and where the defendant is held in the highest esteem.

BOSTON, April 28.--The meeting of the Republican and Democratic State Conventions on Wednesday will make that a very busy day for Massachusetts politicians. The Republican Convention will be held in this city and the Democratic in Worcester. The Republican Convention will probably be short and not discordant. Ex-Gov. Long will preside, and the Hon. William W. Crapo will be Chairman of the ...

Mr. Henry Pettit's play, "Queen's Evidence," was given at the Comedy Theatre last night. This piece, it is said, was successful when it was acted in England. It was not popular in Boston, where it was called "A Free Pardon," two or three years ago. "Queen's Evidence" is a howling melodrama in four acts.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 28.--The Republican State Convention will meet in this city at 3 P.M. to-morrow to elect four delegates to Chicago and nominate Presidential Electors. There is no strife for the latter position. A large number of delegates is already here, and an active canvass is going on. The fight is in the main by those who have not heretofore been to a national convention, against what they call the "old set," ...

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28.--The game of lacrosse between the National American and Princeton College teams, which has been awaited with much interest, was played on the university grounds here to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28.--Emma Bickell, who shot and killed William J. Menow, her former lover, on Sept. 3, 1883, was put on trial for murder to-day. No milder-looking murderess than the accused ever sat in the dock of a criminal court. She has a round, childish face, which was made more infantile by the mournful look which it wore.
A slimly built young man, with dark Jewish features, entered the laundry of Wing High, at No. 525 Grand-street, on Sunday, and represented himself as an officer of the Bureau of Incumbrances.

BALTIMORE, April 28.--The New-York League Club was defeated here to-day by the Baltimore Association nine by a score of 8 to 6. The game was a stubborn one up to the seventh inning, when the score stood 5 to 5.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 28.--The Dexter Cotton Mill, which is owned by the Groton Manufacturing Company, has been sold by the Assignees to the Whitestone Company, consisting of Francis M. Smith, Amos D. Smith, and Howard W. Stone, for $75,000, and will be put in running order and started in a few weeks.
