The concert given by Mrs. Harriet Clarke at Chickering Hall last evening was quite largely attended. The programme afforded gederal satisfaction, and most of the numbers were en cored. Mrs. Clarke, who has a mezzo-soprano voice of good quality, and sings with expression ...
LONDON, April 28.--Lawrence Barrett appeared in Richelieu at the Lyceum Theatre this evening. The house was two-thirds filled.

VICKSBURG, Miss., April 28.--Samuel T. Wilson, a convict guard on Richardson's plantation, on Washington Bayou, was lynched by a negro mob last night. The latter claim that Wilson made the convicts beat a negro insensible and then throw him into the river.

LONDON, April 28.--Five arches of the new cavalry barracks in process of erection at Portsmouth suddenly fell this morning. The workmen, all of whom were convicts, were buried in the ruins, and 30 of them were injured.

LAWRENCE, Mass., April 28.--Political circles here are greatly agitated to-day by the issue of a warrant for the arrest of ex-Mayor Caleb Saunders on a charge of tampering with the ballot-box in Ward Six in December last, while it was in the office of the City Clerk, during the time between the deposit of the returns and the recount.

The Senate made some progress with the Pleuro-pneumonia bill to-day, and it has been agreed that the measure shall be put upon its passage to-morrow.

The Congregational Club last evening discussed over the remains of their monthly dinner at Clark's "The Best Method of Reaching the Non-church-going Classes."

BEAVER, Penn., April 28.--Five prisoners in the County Jail here made a bold dash for liberty on Saturday night, and succeeded in getting out by knocking the jailor down. As soon as he recovered from the attack he gave an alarm. Officers went in pursuit of the criminals, and two of them were captured.

The negro murderer, Charles H. Rugg, was sentenced yesterday to be hanged on Friday, June 6. Judge Brown's remarks were brief and to the point. He said that the law left him no alternative.
Francis Gunning, a recent arrival from the wilds of Colorado, started on a tour of the Bowery yesterday. He is a tall, lithe, well-built young man, bronzed from exposure to the sun and wind.
HAVANA, April 28.--Elections for members of the Cortes have been held throughout Cuba. In the Provinces of Havana, Matanzas, and Pinar del Rio the Liberal Conservative candidates have triumphed.

Mr. Joseph H. Choate made his appearance in Surrogate Rollins's court yesterday, in place of Mr. Evarts, as one of the counsel for the proponents of the Hoyt will. CINCINNATI, April 28.--Reports from difrerent sections of South-western Ohio indicate that wheat has come through the Winter in better shape than has been supposed.
CHICAGO, April 28.--The Rev. Arthur Ritchie was tendered a farewell reception prior to his departure for New-York at the Church of the Ascension this evening.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 28.--At Pine Grove, Pennsylvania, Sunday afternoon, incendiaries burned two barns belonging to Messrs. Lukins and Wilsey. Nine head of cattle, a large amount of hay, and much farming machinery were destroyed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28.--Reports from about one third of the State have been received from Saturday's Democratic primaries. The majority of instructions are for Tilden and Hendricks, McDonald following.
FORT WORTH, Texas, April 28.--The Republican Convention to-morrow promises to be exciting, due to the feeling aroused between the white and colored members of the party in the State.
Much interest was taken in the Stock Exchange yesterday in the reports that numerous deliveries were being made of Union Pacific Railroad stock in the name of Samuel J. Tilden.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 28.--Owing to the country being sparsely settled and the blockaded condition of the roads accurate details of the recent cyclone cannot be obtained. About 6:45 o'clock last night, as Janitor James Dangerfield was making his last rounds in No. 159 Front-street, he noticed that the door of Room No. 7 on the third floor, facing Fletcherstreet, was partially open. He was unable to open it further because some heavy body had been placed against it. Thrusting his head through the aperture, he saw a man lying at full length on the floor apparently dead.

Signor Italo Campanini sat in his smoking-room, at No. 159 West Thirty-fourth-street, last evening with a perplexed look on his round, genial face. A note-book rested on the tenor's knees. A well-pointed pencil was placed behind his right ear, and occasionally Signor Campanini brought the pencil to bear upon the note-book, in a column of figures which presented a positively formidable appearance.

The passenger coach Greyhound, the property of the Country Club, made the first trip of the season yesterday between the Hotel Brunswick and the club-house in Bartow, Westchester County, and back again on schedule time. LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28.--The Republican primaries to-night have all broken up in violent disorder. The revolt against the Arthur machine was terrific and several district meetings were changed into free fights.
The United States Consulate at Yokohama, Japan, is having something of the experience of the Shanghai establishment, by which trouble Consul Denny was relieved of his official honors.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 28.--Considerable delay was caused to trains on the Camden, Gloucester and Mount Ephraim Railroad to-day by the washing of the road-bed, caused by a break in the river bank.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 28.--A few weeks ago Moses Fraley, of the brokerage firm of Donaldson Fraley, was the big man on 'Change in St. Louis. He had done business here for 12 or 15 years, and when he left here six weeks ago and transferred all his operations to the Chicago market, it was said that he would make his mark there.
The former secretary of President Lincoln, Mr. W.O. Stoddard, was the principal speaker at the meeting of the Baptist Pastors, yesterday, his subject being the "Religious Life of Abraham Lincoln."

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 28.--The preliminary arrangements for the National Conference of Colored Men, to be held in this city, are about completed, and the gathering promises to be a very lively one, judging from the variety of opinions expressed as to the action which may or should be taken. On account of the failure of the local committee to secure a hall, the sessions will be held in the Select Council Chamber, and it ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 28.--Representative William Roche, of this city, is missing, and his family and friends are alarmed and solicitous as to his whereabouts. He has not returned to his family since the Legislature adjourned.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 28.--The Republican Convention of the Seventh Congressional District met on Saturday last, at Salisbury, to elect two delegates to Chicago. Several of the counties composing the district were unrepresented, ...

Now that RUGG has been found guilty of the murder of two women, he has become extremely popular with the sex. On Sunday last he was visited by a crowd of curious people, among whom were many women, who gazed pityingly upon him and humbly presented him with flowers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 29.--Congressman Abram S. Hewitt and his brother-in-law, ex-Mayor Edward Cooper, of New-York City, to-day began suit in the United States Circuit Court in Cleveland against the Cleveland Rolling Mill Company for $200,000 damages for alleged infringement of a patent.

The General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines met yesterday, and devoted the day to a consideration of the effect of the ocean steam-ship war on emigrant rates.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29.--The prosecution in the case of Emma Bickel, charged with murdering her lover, William Menow, closed at 11 o'clock this morning and the defense opened. The dead man's mother sat impassive while the lawyer for the defense sketched the story of a false marriage by a bogus Parson; ...

Reuben Bowler, a lawyer, who lived in the Bowery, registered as Charles Johnson, NewYork, at the Putnam House Sunday afternoon. He was found dead there yesterday by a servant. On the toilet table was a bottle which had contained elixir of opium. It is thought probable that he took this habitually and died of an overdose. He had for a long time past neglected his practice and had become addicted to drink.

RICHMOND, Va., April 29.--A conference of several members of the delegation elected by Mahone's convention to the Chicago Convention was held here to-day, and a policy to be pursued in the latter body was agreed upon. It is understood that the Mahone delegates will support Arthur as long as he stands any chance of securing the nomination.

MOUNDSVILLE, West Va., April 29.-- Blaine and a high protective tariff carried the First Congressional District Republican Convention with a rush to-day. Every county in the district was represented, and the convention was an exceptionally large and enthusiastic one.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 29.--Two men, named Richards and Smith, were arrested on Sunday near Berne, Ind., on suspicion of having murdered Amos Bookes last Friday morning.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 29.--The Democratic State Convention which meets to-morrow in this city to choose four delegates at large to Chicago is the same body which nominated Butler at Springfield last September.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., April 29.--There have been 16 deaths from scarlet fever in this village within eight days. The Board of Health has issued an order prohibiting public funerals and recommending the adoption of other sanitary regulations as long as the epidemic continues.

A Brooklyn jury convicted Martin D. Tyrrell on Wednesday, the 23d inst., of keeping a disorderly house at Nos. 25 and 27 Clintonstreet, in a fashionable district of Brooklyn. Tyrrell had amassed a considerable fortune in his disreputable business, and money was poured out lavishly to defeat the ends of justice.

A dark-haired boy with Jewish features, named Harris Aronson, met another dark-haired boy, named Louis Strauswursky, in East Broadway yesterday morning. Aronson was accompanied by a long, thin yellow dog.

Coroner Kennedy was asked yesterday what foundation there was for the allegation that he caused the body of Mr. Moreno, who committed suicide on Monday, to be taken to his brother's undertaking establishment in spite of the fact that Moreno's family had engaged another undertaker.

There was nothing especially new in the six-days race at Madison-Square Garden yesterday except the figures on the score-board. The contestants with the strongest legs and the stoutest hearts kept pushing the figures higher and higher, while the weaker ones fell more and more hopelessly in the rear.
TROY, N.Y., April 29.--The Rev. Mr. Delo, for four years Pastor of the Lutheran church at Centre Brunswick, has recently had trouble with his congregation.

John Trainor, an oysterman, of No. 22 Prince-street, while uuder the influence of liquor came suddenly upon his wife Frances, at Fourteenth-street and University-place, last Monday night. She was in the company of another woman and two men.
Henry A. Hahr, who deserted his bride while he and she were going through Philadelphia on their wedding trip several days ago, was arrested in Hoboken yesterday.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 29.--The Republican State Convention for the choice of delegates at large will meet here to-morrow, and many of its members are here to-night. RALEIGH, N.C., April 29.--At Halifax to-day, James E. O'Hara was renominated as the Republican candidate for Congress from the Second District. At the same convention, Isaac J. Young, Collector of Internal Revenue for this district, and John C. Daney, colored, were elected delegates to Chicago.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 29.--The keeper of the life-saving station at Lower Brigantine reports an unknown three-masted schooner ashore abreast of that place. A crew have gone to her assistance.

PORTLAND, Me., April 29.--The steamer Falmouth, of the International Steam-ship Company's line, caught fire at her wharf this morning. The vessel has been lying above the railroad wharf for some time undergoing extensive repairs, which were nearly completed.

The chapel of the Broadway Tabernacle was filled with ladies yesterday morning, who had gathered to listen to an account of the work in France of the McAll Mission, a Protestant mission established 13 years ago by Mr. and Mrs. McAll.

A large number of ladies and gentlemen assembled yesterday morning at St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Hudson-street, to attend the funeral services of the sculptor George Edwin Ewing, the friend and protege of Henry Irving.

Rugg is, to-day applied to the Supervisors for authority to employ additional assistance in the jail until after the execution of Rugg, whose actions lead him to fear he may make an attempt to take his own life.

A preliminary statement was made to Mayor Edson yesterday by the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments for the quarter ending March 31 as to the assessed valuations of real estate, showing the increase and decrease by wards, by the record-books of 1884 and the Receiver's books of 1883.

WASHINGTON, April 29.--In the Criminal Court to-day, Justice Wylie presiding, the case of the United States against William Pitt Kellogg was called. Mr. Kellogg is charged with having received money while a United States Senator for services rendered in relation to a contract with the United States in violation of section 1,782, Revised Statutes.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 29.--The Board of Supervisors of Erie County met and organized to-day by electing George Nichols Chairman. The attention of the Board was occupied with the report of Surrogate Stern, which caused a good deal of comment.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 29.--The interState convention of representative colored men of the country, called to discuss the interests of their race, now in session here, is as fine looking a body of men as was ever assembled in this city. Boardman, W.H. Pendleton, William Krebs, T.E. Leeds, J.K. Martin, J. Gowan, H. Holton Wood, and William Kentgen. Work on the extension of the road toward "the Point" is being steadily made.

TORONTO, Ontario, April 29.--Messrs. Bunting, Wilkinson, Meek, and Kirkland, defendants in the conspiracy case, were arraigned in the Criminal Assizes to-day, before Chief-Justice Hagarty.

There was a meeting yesterday in the Mayor's office of the committee appointed at the Chickering Hall meeting in reference to the preservation of the Adirondack forests. L.M. Bates was chosen Chairman and Henry Heiser Secretary.

At the meeting of the stockholders of the Academy of Music on Monday evening some very hard words were said against Col. Mapleson. It became apparent that if he gives opera in the house next season he will have to do it without any guarantee by the stockholders, unless a great chance of sentiment is effected between now and then.

While Archibald Campbell, a laborer, living at King's Bridge, was passing through a Clump of cedar trees at Twelfth-avenue and One Hundred and Ninetieth-street, yesterday, he was startled at seeing the body of a man hanging from a limb of one of the trees. The body was cold and stiff, and it was evident that life had been extinct for several hours.

Mr. Lester Wallack will revive "She Stoops to Conquer" on Saturday evening. A company of amateur players, who call themselves the New-York Amateur League, will undertake an ambitious work this evening at the Metropolitan Opera-house by presenting "Richard III."

The sympathies of a generous public are invoked in behalf of Mr. ABRAM S. HEWITT, who is engaged in the labor of accumulating political capital for the approaching campaign. Mr. HEWITT, unfortunately for himself, is burdened with the belief that the fortunes of his party largely rest upon his shoulders.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29.--Commissioner Evans and Congressman Culbertson have arrived from Washington to attend the Republican State Convention Thursday. John D. White will arrive to-night.

Owens Mercer, the stock brokers, of No. 7 Exchange-court, whose suspension was announced on Monday, have made an assignment to Mr. Freling H. Smith. The members of the firm were unable yesterday to give a definite statement of their liabilities or assets.

Referee R.F. Farrell took testimony yesterday in the case of Charles Hee Sing, a Chinese boarding-house keeper, of No. 383 Waterstreet, who is suing for a divorce from his wife Emma, nee Piper. The hearing was private.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 29.--Dr. Turner, City Physician of Newport, visited the United States steamer Portsmouth this morning and obtained the details of the sickness on the vessel. Capt. Wise and two others--a boy and a bugler-- have the yellow fever unmistakably. There is no other serious case, and all are doing well. There is no danger of contagion.

MADISON, Wis., April 29.--The city is already full of delegates and hangers-on to the Republican State Convention, which meets in the State-house at noon to-morrow. The convention will be remarkable for an unusual number of the real leaders of the party being delegates.

LONDON, April 29.--The officials of the Paddington Railway station have received threats that the station is to be blown up.

HAVANA, April 29.--About 1 o'clock this afternoon the whole city was shaken by two terrible concussions in succession. The streets were immediately filled with frightened people, who believed that the city had been shaken by an earthquake.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., April 29.--The principal question to come before the convention tomorrow is whether or not Nevada shall be represented at Chicago by a delegation pledged to support Mr. Blaine. At all the primaries in the State, except those held in Virginia City, the voters recorded their preferences for him, but the general sentiment of Nevada Republicans here, as well as in other parts of Nevada, is in sympathy with the "Plumed Knight."

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 29.--Levi D. Jarrard, ex-County Collector, was sentenced to-day to 10 years hard labor in State prison and to pay a fine of $1,000 for forgery. He will not be tried on the seven other indictments.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 29.--Friends of Dr. Walter Kempster, whose wife is now suing for a divorce at Oshkosh, allege there is no truth in the report that charges of adultery will figure in the bill of complaint.
Parson Berkemeier married another pair at Castle Garden yesterday. The contracting parties were Henry J. Schlitter, aged 23, and Maria Roob, aged 20.

NEW-HAVEN, April 29.--Major Thomas L. Watson, of the firm of Watson Gibson, bankers and brokers at No. 49 Broadway, New-York, has loomed up as the principal actor in the latest Connecticut sensation. Major Watson lives in Bridgeport when he is in Connecticut. When in New-York he lives at the Union League Club, of which he is a member.

Jay Gould owns the houses at Nos. 310 and 312 West Twenty-fourth-street. Between the houses is an alley running to the rear entrance of the Grand Opera-house, also the property of Mr. Gould. BUFFALO, N.Y., April 29.--The examination of Lorenzo Dimick, who is charged with improperly using the funds of three insurance companies for which he was agent, was began before the Police Justice here yesterday and continued to-day.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 29.--Judge Foraker, of Ohio, telegraphs that he is in the field as a candidate for the Alumni Trusteeship of Cornell University, and will accept and serve if elected. He did not desire the nomination, but, having been nominated, he has not and will not withdraw.

QUEBEC, April 29.--The confession made by Richardson, one of the Montreal safe burglars just sentenced to seven years in the penitentiary for the robery of $5,000 from a city broker's office, has created a great sensation throughout the city.

Some strange developments were made in the trial of Carrie Plunkitt, in the First Precint Police Court, Newark, N.J., yesterday afternoon. She was arraigned on a charge made by the wife of the Rev. S.T. Graham.

A dispatch received yesterday from Glasgow announced that the State Line steamship State of Florida, which left this port on April 12, had not yet arrived out. At the State Line offices in this city it was stated yesterday that no anxiety was felt about the overdue vessel. Some accident might have happened to her machinery, but it was too early to assume that anything more serious had occurred.

At his own request Chief Eli Bates, of the Fire Department, who has been a fireman in this city for 38 years, was yesterday retired from active service by the Fire Commissioners. His name was placed on the pension roll of the department, and he will hereafter receive a pension of $2,350 per annum, one-half the pay of the Chief in active service.

WASHINGTON, Penn., April 30.--State veterinary Surgeon Bridge, who was sent by Gov. Pattison to examine the cattle said to be attacked with pleuro-pneumonia, says the-disease is a catarrhal affection and not pleuro pneumonia. KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 30.--The Times's courier of Harper, Kan., this evening brings news of a daring attempt to rob the Medicine ...

VIRGINIA, April 30.--Blaine secured a substantial victory in the Nevada Republican Convention to-day, from the fact that though the delegates go unpledged, the resolution indorsing him was drawn so strongly as to leave them no alternative but to vote for him, so long as he has any chance of winning the nomination.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 1.--The Republican Territorial Convention passed rosolu tions for the separation of church and State, favoring a protective tariff indorsing the administrations of President Ar thur and Gov. Murray, and favoring a legislative commission for Utah, and vigorous ...

The eight men who kept up their ceaseless tramp around the saw-dust track in Madison-Square Garden yesterday looked as wilted and as wretched as the faded Spring flowers which for four days have hung over the doors of their wooden huts.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 1.--The Republican Convention adjourned at 1 P.M. Senator J.N. Dolph, J.T. Apperson, O.N. Denny, J.M. Swift, A.G. Hovey, and J.W. McConnell were selected as delegates to the Chicago Convention and were instructed for Blaine.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 1.--This morning, at Carroll, William Moran was met by two women, one of whom threw cayenne pepper in his eyes and the other began to ply a horse-whip with intense effect. Two men came up and interfered, and the row ended with one of the women firing a revolver at Moran, missing him, however.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., May 1.--The Republican State Convention, to-day, during a session lasting from noon until 7 o'clock, passed resolutions declaring that Mr. Blaine was the choice of the State for President, and elected four delegates at large who are favorable to Blaine.

CHICAGO, May 1.--The leading produce markets were active and generally stronger today. Perhaps the report of heavy rains in Kansas and the sight of falling rain here has something to do with the strength. Certainly the news from other markets, either home or foreign, was not conducive thereto, unless on the pig-head ...
ATLANTA, Ga., May 1.--The Whig Republican Convention met at noon, about 14 delegates being present. Gen. James Longstreet called the body to order.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1.--Another immense prohibition mass-meeting was held in the First Presbyterian Church to-night. Addresses were delivered by the Rev. Drs., Hodge, McCosh, Worden and Janvier, Prof. Johnson, and Mr. Baldwin. Several hundred voters have signed the no-license petition, which will be laid next week before the now Republican Common Council.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--The General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began its sessions this morning in Association Hall.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 1.--Eleven months ago the social sensation of this city was the brilliant wedding at the cathedral of the beautiful daughter of Chief-Justice Edward Bermudez, ...
WASHINGTON, May 1.--The EdmundsPhelps correspondence continues to be talked about here with interest, the opinion being among men not thick and thin admirers and ...
ATHENS, Ga., May 1.--The nuptials of J. L. Christian and Miss S.A. Lochlin, of Madison County, were to have taken place Sunday. The two had been engaged for some time.

Timothy Foley, the 13-year-old boy who was struck on the head with a hay-stick in the yard of the premises No. 200 Newark-street, Ho boken, by Jack Keilly, on Tuesday, died on Wednesday night of his wounds.

BOSTON, May 1.--The House to-day substituted for an adverse committee report a bill in aid of building associations and authorizing a loan of $3,000,000 from the State Treasury to provide homes for the people, the same to be paid back in fixed charges.
WASHINGTON, May 1.--As was intimated in a dispatch to THE TIMES last night the Kellogg case was to-day thrown out of court. No one is much surprised.

BEEMERVILLE, N.J., May 1.--The people here to-day were greatly excited over the elopement of a white schoolgirl, Miss Amanda Ayers, a daughter of C.D. Ayers, with a negro named Henry Adams. The girl was about 14 years of age, rather pretty, and attended the village school.

There is an unusual degree of excitement in the Clarksville Grammar School. The base-ball season is at hand, and the school "nine" is about to elect a new Captain. Hitherto the Clarksville "nine" has been very successful, and it is naturally anxious to maintain its reputation.

Policeman James Ryan, of the Eighteenth Precinct, arraigned Mr. Jacob Anhalt, a furniture-dealer of No. 529 Sixth-avenue, who has been in business in this city 40 years, before Justice White yesterday, and charged him with ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 1.--The Republican State Convention to-day was a less exciting affair than had been anticipated, though there were occasional ripples of excitement and outcroppings of factional jealousies.

Superintendent Hankinson and seven officers of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, under the instructions of Henry Bergh, made a descent on the saloon of James Kearney, at Dutch Kills, Long Island, about 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning, and interrupted a cock-fight which was in progress. When the officers entered the room they found 200 men watching a fight between two birds.

The police force were paid their salaries for the month of April yesterday, and a great deal of dissatisfaction was expressed by many patrolmen who were asked to contribute toward a fund which was being collected, ostensibly to ...

A letter, dated April 24, from Chesterfield Court-house, S.C., to the Charleston News says: "The story about Boggan Cash being in Canada is not believed here. I have yet to find one man that believes it.

PITTSBURG, May 1.--The discovery was made to-day that the reports which have been circulated for a year past of movements on the part of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad to obtain control of their road have ...

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 1.--The Democratic State Executive Committee met in this city to-day and selected Pensacola as the place and June 25 as the day of holding the State Convention for the nomination of State officers and the election of delegates to the National Convention. The convention of the First Congressional District will be held at the same time and place.
AUGUSTA, Me, May 1.--The State Prohibitory Convention was held in this city to-day. Seventeen delegates were present, representing nine counties.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1.--Owing to interruption in telegraphic communication north, the result of the Washington Territory Republican Convention has not been received.

The opening League game of base-ball was played on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon between the New-York and Chicago Clubs. Great preparations were made for this game, and a large number of invitations were issued.

DOVER, N.H., May 1.--A temporary bridge over the Cocheco River, on the Boston and Maine Railroad, was destroyed to-day, and the tracks were carried away by a heavy landslide, with trees and weighty rocks, and 1,000 square yards of solid clay were deposited in the river, forming a complete dam.
FORT WORTH, Texas, May 1.--The session of the Republican Convention to-day was almost entirely consumed in the promulgation of a platform and the election of delegates at large.

Denis T. Caddigan, the oldest hotel clerk, it is said, in America, died yesterday of apoplexy at the Sturtevant House, where he had been staying for the last five months. Mr. Caddigan had passed more than 50 years of his life in the principal hotels of the country.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 1.--The resident Alumni of Cornell University held a meeting last night and decided to give a banquet soon at which the Alumni Association of Central NewYork will be reorganized. The question of indorsing a candidnte for Alumnus Trustee was deferred to the evening of the banquet.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 1.--Last Fall, in Jefferson County, the canvass showed a tie for Sheriff between Bowen Harrison, Republican, and McGow, Democrat McGow did not attend the meeting of the board to draw lots and Harrison drew the lucky straw and in January assumed the office.
CHICAGO, May 1.--To-day was the last day of grace for the renewal of last year's saloon licenses.

To many people corpulence is so serious an inconvenience that the appearance in an English dress of Dr. Ebstein's much talked-of treatise on the cause and cure of obesity may revive hopes which the practical failure of other systems had almost quenched.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--At a sale of imported cattle to-day, the prices ranged from $100 to $500. Mrs. Wheeler, of this city, paid $500 for a cow called Good Fellow, and R.M. Fairchild, of Holyoke, Mass., paid $420 for a heifer.
There has been more or less discussion about what was to happen to the Aldermen after the power of extorting patronage from the Mayor was withdrawn from them.

The West Side Club and Institute, which has been recently organized under the Presidency of the Rev. R. Heber Newton, held a meeting last evening in Manhattan Hall, at Fifty-fourth, street and Eighth-avenue.

BALTIMORE, May 1.--Louis Bach, 26 years old, while handling a pistol this evening in the store of his father, in Calvert-street, accidentally shot himself. The ball entered his right temple and passed out two inches higher, penetrating the brain. He is in a dying condition. He was for several years a resident of Newark, N.J.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 1.--To-day, in Charlotte, N.C., Harvey McSmith, for many years manager of the branch music house of Ludden Bates, of Savannah, Ga., left his store about 9 o'clock.

EVANSTON, Wyoming, May 1.--The Republican Territorial Convention here to-day, after a somewhat stormy session, chose J.W. Meldrum and James France as delegates to the National Convention. The delegates favor Arthur.

The Chamber of Commerce held its first meeting in its new rooms in the Mutual Life Insurance Building, Nassau and Cedar streets, yesterday afternoon, and it called out a larger number of prominent merchants than has gathered together in the Chamber for a long time.

Capt. Charles H. Davis, of the schooner Florance Rogers, from Vivorilla Cay, arrived on Wednesday night. On his way to Baltimore he stopped at Swan Island, in the Carribean Sea, and was so attracted by its loveliness and abundance of fruit, game, and tropical riches that he remained several days. Swan Island is the most isolated island in the Carribean.

Special interest was given to the proceedings yesterday in the trial, before Judge Van Brunt and a jury, in the Supreme Court, of the suit of John F. Betz against William C. Baur, Henry Daily, Jr., George W. Moore, and John M. Littell for conspiring to defraud him, ...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 1.--The fight between the American and the Union Base-ball Association is fairly on. The Union Association, for the purpose of replenishing their treasury and advertising their grounds, arranged for an exhibition by the Sullivan combination on Sunday afternoon.

Miss Louise K. Taylor, daughter of the late George B. Taylor, who not long since took monastic vows into the Order of St. Francis de Sales, appears to have tired of a recluse's life and come into the world again.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1.--The notable feature of the State Republican Convention to day was the enthusiasm manifested for Blaine whenever his name was mentioned.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 1.--S.E. Melin, merchant tailor of this place, assigned to-day to John Peters. The assets and liabiiities are unknown. The failure is due to the inattention of Melin, who says there is enough property to pay all creditors, who are mainly in New-York and Jamestown.
KANSAS CITY, May 1.--A special to the Journal, from Harper, Kan., says: "Swift retribution has overtaken the Medicine Lodge murderers and robbers.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 1.--The annual meeting of the Buffalo Civil Service Association was held this evening. Mr. Jewett M. Richmond, Vice-President, presided.
The political emergencies in Georgia appear to have been desperate recently. In order to get the small Republican machine in that State in motion, it has been necessary to evade the civil ...
At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company, in Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City, yesterday, Frederic A. Potts, Simon Borg, ...

BALTIMORE, May 1.--The championship season of the American Association was opened here to-day by a game between the Baltimore and Metropolitan Clubs, and resulted in a victory for the home club by a score of 5 to 3. The game was a well-fought one up to the eighth inning, when the visitors permitted the Baltimores to score 3 runs by errors.

A large crowd gathered in the City Hall Park at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon to see William M. Woodside and W.J. Morgan start on a bicycling journey across the continent. At 1:08 the men mounted their high wheels, waved their skull-caps in the air, and spun away toward the North River ferries.
When Miss Rebecca Jones came into the Surrogate's Court yesterday morning, in care of her counsel, she placed in a row upon a radiator four small packages and a hand sachel.

WASHINGTON, May 1, 1884. The House Committee on Rivers and Harbors expect to complete consideration of the River and Harbor Appropriation bill to-morrow or Saturday. The total amount appropriated will be between $12,000,000 and $13,000,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 1.--The announcement that Keene had failed was received here with regret. Mr. Keene purchased Nathan Matthews's villa, on Bellevue-avenue, bought land, and erected a large stable and private riding academy on Coggeshall-avenue.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 29.--Chief-Justice R.D. Woodward, of the Orphans' Court of Anne Arundel, is 79 years old, yet he performed a feat yesterday evening that would have done credit to the agility of a youth.

Venus will be the loveliest star in the Heavens through the month of May, as after elongation she turns her steps westward, moving rapidly toward us, and hastenine on to her period of greatest brilliancy.

The following remarks appeared in THE TIMES on April 22: "We congratulate the Hon. WILLIAM PITT KELLOGG upon the near approach of that opportunity for vindication for which he has so long ineffectually clamored.
Mr. ALBERT DAGGETT, of Brooklyn, while admitting that he has been forced by public opinion to support the city reform measures, loses no opportunity to sneer at the whole business, and to refer ...
LONDON, May 2.--The Allen Line steam-ship Scandinavian, Capt. Park, from Boston April 20, has arr. at Glasgow.

If Macaulay's New-Zealander had been sitting on the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday he would have thought that a pestilence was feared in this city, for truck-loads of household goods were seen all day rolling over toward the easterly shores of the East River.

The Board of Aldermen at a recent meeting decided that their resolutions granting privileges for stands, barber-poles, , should expire on May 1. Incidentally the Bureau of Permits was made the agency through which permits are to be granted hereafter for anything on the sidewalk.
PITTSBURGH, Penn., May 1.--A secret meeting of the Iron Manufacturers' Association of the West, which was organized during the strike of 1882, was held in this city today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 1.--The Spring meeting of the Nashville Blood Horse Association commenced to-day. The attendance was good, the weather warm, and the track in fair condition.
J.A. Peabody, while in the woods getting birch-bark 29 years ago, lost a nugget of gold which he wore in his shirt bosom upon a pin.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 1.--In the Ulster County Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning, Judge Ingalls presiding, District Attorney Clearwater moved sentence in the case of Jacob Lane, who, on the 15th of April, stole a bay mare belonging to Cornelius Beckwith, an Esopus farmer.

DES MOINES, Iowa, MAy 1.--The Interstate Oratorical Association convened at Iowa City for a business meeting this afternoon. It was decided to admit Walter McHenry, of Ames College, as the speaker from Iowa, and Carl Pomeroy, of the State University, as delegate and alternate, respectively.

Color was lent to the narrow little courtroom in which Chief-Justice Sedgwick, of the Superior Court, sat yesterday by a blush rose that nestled close to the well-reaped chin of Spruce Deacon Wright, one of the adherents and legal advisers of Dr. John P. Newman, of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 1.--The Republican State Convention reassembled this morning, but little work was accomplished.
GLASGOW, May 1.--The establishment of Barclay Curles, ship-builders, was burned this morning. The loss is placed at 20,000.
Messrs. Frye and Vest filled up the time of the Senate this afternoon in the debate on the shipping bill.

ALBANY, May 1.--In the Court of Appeals today, present the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates, arguments were heard in the following cases: No. 788--The People exrel. Joseph Bork, appellant, ...
James R. Keene went down town early yesterday morning and found the hall leading to his office occupied by a number of put and call brokers and others eager to question him about his suspension.

KINGSTON, Ontario, May 1.--Gold in large quantities has been discovered in the township of Kaladar 40 miles from this city. Much of the precious dust has been brought here.

Carl Marwig, the Swede, who has a dancing academy at No. 67 Madison-avenue, and manages children's carnivals, kirmesses, and juvenile opera troupes, was before Justice White yesterday on a charge of misdemeanor preferred by Mr. Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
GORDON is now completely surrounded at Khartoum, from which he cannot make his escape; and Berber is on the point of falling into the hands of the rebels.

The last regular meeting and dinner of the Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island was held last night, at Delmonico's. It was a "ladies' meeting "and the larger dining-room was resplendent with gorgeous dresses.
DENVER, May 1.--Delegates from every county in Colorndo gathered here to-day, and, in convention, selected delegates to represent the State at the National Convention at Chicago.

The Senate took up in the morning hour to-day a bill for the relief of the Trustees of Isaac R. Trimble, who was a Confederate General of some prominence, and who wants to be paid a royalty for the use by the Government of the Howe patent truss in the long bridge built over the Potomac, at this city, in 1860.

LONDON, May 1.--In consequence of documents found in the possession of James Eagan, who has been under arrest at Birmingham for the past three weeks, charged with complicity with Daly in a dynamite scheme, William MacDonnell, ...
ALBANY, May 1.--Without much difficulty Col. Tremper got the Assembly to-day to lay aside all bills down to the Harbor-masters' bill, and then to discuss and finally to pass that by a handsome vote.

A lady writer in an agricultural paper says: "A mother who allows her boys to grow up ignorant of wholesome cookery and the fine art of sewing fails in her duty." That is true. A knowledge of cookery and sewing will come very handy if the boy happens to marry a Vassar College girl.
The reivsed schedule of message rates issued by the Western Union Telegraph Company went into effect yesterday. This new schedule embraces many radical reductions.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 1.--A Havana dispatch, dated yesterday, says the Liberal Conservatives triumphed through the undue influence of the authorities and despicable tricks, the election laws being construed against the votes of the Cubans.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Mr. Henry Wilson resumed his testimony before the Jeannette Investigating Committee this morning. During the retreat, he said, Capt. De Long often gave orders that were unreasonable; on one occasion, ...
Levin Benson, of the Pitts Creek neighborhood, while out fishing on Monday succeeded in capturing what he considered a very singular kind of fish.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 1.--Prices for Cattle were without noticeable change. There was decidedly a firmer demand than on Wednesday, but the increase in the supply of nearly 2,000 head effectually prevented any advnace that otherwise might have resulted. More buyers were present than on any of the preceding ...
OMAHA, Neb., May 1.--Considerable more trouble than was anticipated has been developed to-day concerning the reduction of wages of the Union Pacific employes going into effect to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1.--The Republican State Convention to elect delegates to Chicago was held here to-day. The tone of the convention was mainly Blaine, but with a moderate sprinkling of Arthur. There was one contest, that of the delegation from Warwick. The contestants were in favor of the present Administration; the delegates already on the floor were Blaine men from Blaineville, and were allowed to retain their seats.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 1.--Great excitement prevails at Medford, Wis. Two children of Anton Schleist, aged 5 and 7 years, respectively, disappeared nine days ago, and no trace of them can be found. Men are searching the woods, but the general belief is that the children were eaten by bears.
The arctic steam-ship Thetis, the flagship of the Greely relief expedition, sailed from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, May 1.--The Egyptian correspondence shows that the Government refused to allow Indian troops to relieve Gen. Gordon on the ground that India has no direct interest in the Soudan.

Great activity prevailed in both of the Oil Exchanges in this city yesterday. The market opened a little above the closing prices of Wednesday, and the quotations went up rapidly from 96 7/8 cents to 99 1/8. The closing figures were 96 .

TORONTO, Ontario, May 1.--Now that the excitement as to the dynamite scare is somewhat abated it is the prevailing opinion that the affair is either the result of a practical joke or the cartridges were placed in the House of Parliament by some one anxious for a position as watchman.
Yesterday's papers contained an announcement offering a reward of $250 for information as to the whereabouts of Louis Bermes, of Union Hill, N.J.

Herman Lepeter, a young German, was arrested yesterday by Detectives Hey and Mallon, of the steam-boat squad, on board the steamship Colon, of the Pacific Mail Steam-ship Company, charged with the attempted abduction of a young girl for improper purposes.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1.--The announcement is made this evening that at the close of the present theatrical season, namely on the 17th of May, S.L. Hanna will be retired from the management of the Euclid-Avenue Opera-house and Gus Hartz placed in charge. It is rumored in theatrical circles that the change was occasioned by Hanna's neglecting the business interests of the house.

It is interesting to see how Italy under a new King is taking hints from the surrounding European capitals. The Roman Salon, opened last year and again held this year, may now be regarded as an established institution; but this ...

RALEIGH, N.C., May 1.--The Republican State Convention met at 3 P.M. to-day and elected L.W. Humphrey, of Wayne County, permanent President. A committee of 15 was appointed to confer with the Liberal Convention to suggest a State ticket and a platform.
A meeting of the Directors of the Academy of Music for the purpose of organizing was held yesterday afternoon in the office of Mr. Clarence A. Seward, No. 31 Nassau-street.

A vagrant cow stood placidly upon the steps of the Queens County Court-house yesterday morning when the 12 intelligent jurors in the Hinsdale divorce suit filed in to listen to more testimony concerning William R. Hinsdale's neglect of his family and his attentions to Mrs. Maud Carll.

Hermann Schaeff, while using some varnish at Hill's Brewery, Newark, yesterday, was fatally burned, it taking fire from a candle. The material was in a can strapped to his waist, and could not be removed in time to save him.

The Washington Post promises the great mass of Democrats throughout the country that the Morrison Tariff bill will speedily pass the House of Representatives. There have been a great many promises made on behalf of the present Congress.
Vice-President Cleveland presided last evening at the quarterly meeting of the American Institute, and the first person whom he called to order was J. Sutton, who insisted that ...
The new Cunard steam-ship Aurania, which sailed for Liverpool on Wednesday on her first regular eastward passage, promises to prove a very fast vessel.

Mr. Christian Fritsch, tenor and musician, well known to local audiences, gave a concert at Steinway Hall last evening. He was heard in songs by Lessman, Rubinstein, and Liszt, all of which he interpreted with expression and finish, and with a voice of excellent quality.

OAKLAND, Cal., May 1.--The Republican State Convention has elected T.T. Bard, W.W. Morrow, George A. Knight, and Horace Davis delegates at large to Chicago. They are regarded as Blaine men. A resolution was introduced by the delegates of the First District naming Mr. Lincoln as Vice-President and was lost. The Sixth District, representing the entire southern section of the State, introduced resolutions instructing the delegates to support Lincoln for President, but it was defeated.

In a little room in Smith McNells's Hotel, No.199 Washington-street, W.J. Budington, of New-Haven, Conn., was found hanging by the neck at 7:30 o'clock last evening. He had been dead several hours. On an oil-cloth covered washstand was a slip of paper bearing these words:

Benjamin Wallace, a well-to-do soap manufacturer, doing business at No. 134 Janestreet and No. 403 West Seventeenth-street, and living at No. 91 Horatio-street, was reported to the police yesterday as missing. Mr. Wallace, who is 50 years of age, left, his home on Tuesday afternoon to go to one of his places of business and has not since been seen by his friends.

A number of witnesses have left here for Ottawa to testify in the suit of Rogers against Hoffman. A year ago last February Mr. John Hoffman, a wealthy farmer, celebrated his golden wedding at the Passenger House, this city.

"Capt." C.C. Duncan, Shipping Commissioner of New-York, was charged by THE TIMES with corruption in office and with dishonestly appropriating to his own use and to the use of members of his family money that should have been paid into the public treasury. Duncan sued THE TIMES for $100,000 and received 12 cents damages.
Patrick Magin, an elevator boy, 19 years old, was arrested in the United States Hotel on Wednesday night by Chief Grane, of Paterson, N.J., and Officer Morris Murphy, of the Fourteenth Precinct.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--Capt. Goodwin, of the brig Josefa, from Matanzas, Cuba, said to a Philadelphia reporter to-day: "Very little can be learned by foreigners of the progress of the rebellion on the island. Flying rumors of Aguero's presence are heard from time to time.

The amounts invested in buildings, according to the building permits issued last year and this, compare as follows: From Jan. 1, 1883, to May 1 the sum total was $926,865; from Jan. 1, 1884, to the present time, $1,240,070, showing an excess this year during the months stated of $313,705.

The prices of ice, according to the statement of the Knickerbocker Company, will be about the same this year as last--50 cents per week for 12 to 15 pounds daily, 70 cents for 18 to 20 pounds daily, and 40 cents per hundred weight for 25 pounds daily and upward.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 1.--T.A. Edison, the inventor, was the guest of the Mechanics' Association and the Natural History Society at a reception and collation at the Bay State House this evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1.--A special to the Chronicle from Vistoria, British Colombia, says: "The astounding discovery has been made that the mails which left Victoria March 21 and 24, for East Europe, never reached their destination.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 1.--Miss Elia Wheeler, the "Passion Poetess" of the Northwest, was married to-day to Robert M. Wilcox, of Meriden, Conn. Mr. Wilcox with his prize departed for the East to-night. The couple will reside in Meriden, where Mr. Wilcox is engaged in business.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--The publication of a dispatch from this city outlining AttorneyGeneral Brewster's views in opposition to the adoption of Blaine's South Amercian policy by the present Administration, has given rise to ...
The New-York Civil Service Reform Association met last evening in their rooms on Twenty-fourth-street, and listened to the reading of the annual report.
Of late years people in the country and in neighboring cities have found it convenient to do much of their shopping in this city by mail.

LONDON, May 1.--In the House of Commons, to-day, Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice, Under Foreign Secretary, stated that the treaty with Portugal regarding the Congo would supersedo all former engagements with the native chiefs who had not been consulted.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--A telegram was received at the Signal Office to-day from Colorado Springs, stating that another expedition had started to rescue the observer who is snowed in on Pike's Peak, and that redoubled efforts will be made to reach him.

United States District Attorney Tenney, after a careful search, has declared the title to the property sold to the Government as a site for the proposed Federal Building in Brooklyn absolutely clear. The property is bounded by Washington, Johnson, and Pearl streets, and some of the deeds examined are dated from 1646 A.D.

KINGSTON, N. Y., May 2.--In the Ulster County Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning District Attorney Clearwater had the Sheriff bring to the bar Thaddeus Avery, who on the 15th of February murdered his wife at Chichesterville, in the Catskills. Avery was indicted for murder in the first degree, and on being arraigned this morning pleaded not guilty. He was represent

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 2.--On Tuesday, near Harrison County, Della and Anna Janes, aged 16 and 18 years, respectively, were fatally poisoned by some unknown enemy. Della in the morning received an envelope by mail which, on being opened, was found to contain some brown sugar, accompanied by a note, purporting to be from a cousin, requesting her to eat the sugar and burn the note and envelope.

PEKIN, May 2.--An Imperial decree of April 28 appoints Shut-Sing-Chen Minister to France in place of the Marquis Tseng. Li-FongPas, Minister to Germany, will act temporarily at Paris.

The Bureau of Permits yesterday issued 291 permits and received $344 therefor. There were 400 applications sent out to be signed by Aldermen. GREENSBURG, Penn., May 2.--This afternoon the Pennsylvania Railroad, the North Central Company and the Philadelphia and Erie Company, through their Attorneys Logan and MacVeagh, went into the Court of Common

HAVANA, May 2.--Yesterday's edition of the Republican newspaper, El Palenque, was seized and the director of the paper was denounced. The director was sentenced, for a previous offense, to be imprisoned for six months, to be deprived of the right to vote, and to pay the costs of the trial.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 2.--Amanda Ayres and "Black Hank" Adams, the white girland negro who eloped from Beemerville, Sussex County, passed through Port Jervis last evening. They were captured near Lackawaxen at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon on a canal-boat on the Delaware and Hudson Canal. They were brought here and taken to Beemerville by New-Jersey officers.

Otto Meyer, liquor dealer, corner of Broadway and Thirty-sixth-street, is endeavoring to effect a compromise with his creditors at 10 cents on the dollar. His liabilities are about $6,000. It is said he paid $8,000 for the place.

NORWICH, N. Y., May 2.--The New-Enland Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Boston, Mass., has paid the policy of $10,000 which it issued upon the life of the late Col. Walton Dwight, of Binghamton. The policy was made payable to the estate of Dwight. Thie company has thus followed the example of the AEtna Life Insurance

TORONTO, Ontario, May 2.--There are no new developments in connection with the dynamite plot. The Government held a Cabinet council yesterday afternoon, talked the matter over, and decided to offer a reward of $1,000 for the arrest and conviction of the persons who put the cartridges where they were found.

Samuel J. Tilden has purchased for $42,000 a house and lot on the south side of Thirtyeighth-street, west of Fifth-avenue.

CAIRO, May 2.--Advices from Aden state that Admiral Hewitt has sent back his escort of 200 Bashi-Bazouks, as King John of Abyssinia refused to allow them to cross the frontier.

OMAHA, Neb., May 2.--The order of the Union Pacific Directors reducing the wages of all employes 10 per cent. was followed to-day by a general walk out along the main line from Council Bluffs to Ogden, and also on leased lines and branches. Fully 12,000 men quit work,

WASHINGTON, May 2.--The returns from all the States and Territories are in, and the friends of the candidates for President are amusing themselves with making canvasses which vary a good deal, according to the preferences, rather than the knowledge of the partisans who make them.

DAYTON, Washington Territory, May 2.-- The Republican Territorial Convention met here yesterday, and G.D. Hill and John L. Wilson were elected delegates to the National Convention. They are instructed for Blaine.

Thirteen hundred children from the various industrial schools of the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless went yesterday afternoon to the large hall in the Cooper Institute to rehearse for the golden jubilee of the society, that is to take place in Madison-Square Garden on Tuesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--Mr. Belmont, in the debate in the House to-day upon the Tariff bill, spoke briefly in an attempt to show that the State Department is undertaking to do by diplomacy precisely what the Democratic House ought to do by legislation, remove restrictions upon our foreien trade. JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 2.--News has been received of the death by accidental drowning, near Spokane Falls, Washington Territory, of Capt. H. Ward Dart, formerly of Jamestown. The young man's sister was drowned in Chautauqua Lake outlet 18 months ago. Capt. Dart and his father were agents in Washington Territory for the Westinghouse Manufacturing Company, of Schenectady.
Ex-State Senator Thomas I. Chatfield is seriously ill at his home in Owego, Tioga County.

DALTON, Ga., May 2.--William Stafford, 15 years old, living three miles from the city, was accidentally shot and instantly killed by a gun in the hands of a negro boy. Stafford was sitting on the side of the bed and the negro was in the doorway carelessly handling the gun, when its contents were discharged, the load passing through Stafford's heart and producing death in a few seconds.
LONDON, May 2.--George Augustus Sala writes that Lawrence Barrett's "Richelieu" is a most meritorious performance.

Woodside, a suburb of Newark, N. J., is excited over the killing of Parson Brodhead's dog. It had wandered to the barn of Robert Leslie, who lives half a mile away, and Leslie shot it. He says he has been much annoyed by the animal, and shot him only when he showed his teeth in answer to an order to leave. Mr. Brodhead was greatly excited when he heard of the animal's death.

A dispatch from President Scrymser, of the Mexican Telegraph Company, who is now in the city of Mexico, says the dispatches by way of Laredo, indicating that there is probability of a revolution in Mexico, are gross exaggerations, and that there is no sign of a revolution in the city of Mexico.

The Rev. Dr. Edward P. Terhune, of Springfield, Mass., has accepted a call to the First Reformed Church of Brooklyn, Eastern District. His connection with the First Church in Springfield will cease after Sunday, May 11. In a recent letter to his Springfield congregation Dr. Terhune says the first announcement of the call was made a fortnight ago. The invitation had been in his hands several weeks before it was announced.

LONDON, May 2.--At a meeting of the Jockey Club to-day, Sir George Chetwynd asked concerning the truth of the alleged conspiracy among the jockeys and book-makers to sell races. Contracts were executed yesterday between the Pullman Palace Car and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Companies for the operation of Pullman parlor and sleeping cars on all the lines of the railroad company for the term of 15 years from May 1, 1884. A superior equipment of Pullman cars is now being manufactured at the works of the company for immediate use upon the lines of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road.

CINCINNATI, May 2.--Notice was to-day served upon Hiram D. Peck, lately declared elected to the Superior Court Bench, that the question of the legality of his election would be appealed to the State Senate.

PORT JARVIS, N.Y., May 2.--Conductor Harry Terwilliger, while coming west on the Erie Railroad at about 5 o'clock last evening, saw three suspicious looking men walking along the track pursued by two other men heavily armed. When a curve hid the two parties from sight of each other one of the party ahead took out a roll of bills and buried it alongside the track.

The agents of the overdue steam-ship State of Florida, which left this port for Glasgow on Aprll 12, said yesterday that, although they had received no tidings, they felt no anxiety about her. Her machinery, they thought, might have become disabled, but as there had been no had weather of late it was hardly probable that anything serious had happened to the vessel.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington Territory, May 2.--Last night, at Thompson Falls, an Indian with some whites was engaged at a gambling table. The Indian was charged with unfair dealing, and a fight ensued. The Indian started to run, and was fatally shot in the back by one of the gamblers. As the news spread the Indians began to collect and to show signs of a general uprising.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 3.--The ice has not yet disappeared from the Buffalo harbor, but vessels now get through it with comparatively little difficulty. WASHINGTON, Penn., May 2.--The store of Mr. McElhany, Bentleysville, was broken into last night, the safe forced open, and $600 stolen therefrom. A horse belonging to Dr. Scott was also taken it is thought by the same parties.

ST. PAUL, May 2.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Winnipeg, says that a massmeeting was held there by the squatters at Regina, North-west Territory, to-night, to protest against the action of the Dominion Land Board in regard to squatter claims. The Government agent is now there trying to sell their claims, but he has been boycotted and can get no bids.

WORCHESTER, Mass., May 2.-- Burglars visited the town of Oxford, 12 miles south of here, last night, and broke into a bank, the Post Office, a jewelry store, and the ticket office at the station. Nothing of much value was secured, and at the bank they were unable to open the vault, although drills, powder and other explosives were used.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 2.--The examination in the case of John Randall and Burt Manchester, charged with assault on the old woman Mary Tranz, whose dead body was found by the roadside at West Falls, this county, last Saturday, was concluded to-day. Both men were held on a charge of assault in the first degree.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 2.--It is rumored to-night that an explosion of fire-damp occurred this afternoon in the Allegheny Valley coal mines, nine miles from Parker, and that a number of miners were killed.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 2.--The ship Alantine, of Drammen, Norway, was wrecked in the north-east gale, five miles east of Wolf Island station, Magdalen Islands, on the 30th of April. Nineteen lives were lost. The second mate is the only survivor.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 3.--A lady is lying at the point of death here from a singular cause. She is a citizen of Savannah, and, being afflicted with dyspepsia, came here to secure the benefit of the water-cure establishment in Atlanta. Inside of three hours she drank 11 gallons of tepid water, which has thrown her into convulsions, and her death is more than probable.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 3.--John L. Sullivan has telegraphed to Mr. Smith, his manager, that he will pitch in a game of base-ball for the Cincinnati Unions at Cincinnatti next Sunday, instead of having a slugging match, as previously arranged, and prohibited by Mayor Stephens.

Louis Blumenschweig, a German glazier, of No. 238 West Thirty-second-street, who is 74 years old, has been very much troubled with asthma for a long time. Last week he applied for admission to the Mount Sinai Hospital, but was unsuccessful.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 3.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Miles City, Montana, says the trial of the Cheyennes who burned the ranch of Fouk and Alderson, on Lame Deer Creek, in March last, was concluded to-day. Black Wolf was first found not guilty.
A prize of $2,000 has been offered by the Italian Government for the most practical process for the transmission of electrical energy.

About 20 years ago, a young doctor who had been established three years in London without making an income, lost heart, and determined to emigrate to Australia. He sold his small house and furniture, paid his passage money.

LONDON, May 3.--The Captain of the Devon reports that on Sunday evening last, in latitude 47 25 longitude 34 10 he picked up two life-boats of the State Line steam-ship State of Florida, which sailed from New-York for Glasgow on April 12.

Mr. Dobson quotes "by Jingo" from a book which was published some 30 years before "The Vicar of Wakefield," but he can throw no light on the origin of the quaint ejaculation. It seems likely enough that the word is pure Basque. "Jinco" is the Basque for "Dieu;" "jinco-houna!" for "bon Dieu!"

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 3.--The entire village of Gilman's Depot, on the Port Jervis and Monticello Railroad, 15 miles from here, was swept away by fire yesterday afternoon and last night. The fire started about 2 o'clock one mile from the depot. The wind was blowing a gale.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 3.--A freight car in a west-bound train on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad caught fire from a locomotive spark to-day, and was burned, together with its contents, consisting of a large amount of cloths, potatoes, and barrels. The contents were shipped from New-York and billed to Cleveland. The estimated lose is $2,000, which the railway company will have to pay.

PARIS, April 16.--Municipal elections are to be held throughout France on May 4. In all the communes the method of voting will be according to the provisions of the new law which has just been voted, after a year's intermittent debate, by the two houses of Parliament.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 3.--William Astor's new steel yacht Nourmahal was launched by the Harlan Hollingsworth Company at 6:46 A.M. Her dimensions are: Length, 232 feet 8 inches; extreme breadth, 30 feet; extreme depth, 20 feet.

The Hotel Kaaterskill, in the Catskill Mountains, will open on June 24 for the Summer season, which will continue until Oct. 1. This hotel, which has accommodations for 1,200 guests, is situated 3,000 feet above the sea level, upon a summit which commands an unobstructed view in every direction, embracing 90 miles in length of the Hudson River, the celebrated Kaaterskill Clove, Kaaterskill Lake, and Hunter Valley.

The resignation of the Rev. D.H. Miller, Pastor of the Noble-Street Baptist Church, Greenpoint, has been accepted, and the year's back salary due him paid. Mr. Miller's resignation has been ready for presentation several months, but his supporters in the church refused to let him resign until his back salary had been paid. The resignation will probably lead to a permanent division in the congregation, and perhaps to the establishment of a new church.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 4.--Scott E. Smith, who one year ago shot and killed a desperado named Reynolds, shot himself through the head just before 6 o'clock this evening. Smith had been drinking pretty heavily of late. He was under indictment for manslaughter, and was to be tried this month. He had lived in Des Moines many years, served in the volunteer service, and leaves a wife and three children.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 4.--Later reports from North-eastern Texas indicate considerable damage by floods.
