A paper calling a meeting of citizens to indorse the Administration of President Arthur was placed upon one of the tables in the UnionLeague Club-house yesterday and received a number of signatures.

At a meeting of the Democratic General Committee of Kings County, last evening, in Music Hall, at Flatbush and Fulton avenues, Brooklyn, resolutions in reference to free trade, which have been in the hands of a special committee for several weeks, were adopted.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Although Mr. Morrison is careful not to express too much confidence in the strength of his adherents in to-morrow's contest, the rank and file of the tariff reformers will be greatly disappointed if the motion to strike out the enacting clause of the Tariff Reduction bill is carried.

Miss Hattie Louise Simms, who is about to depart for Europe, where she intends completing her musical studies, gave a concert at Steinway Hall last evening. A programme including 13 or 14 numbers was interpreted to the evident gratification of a large audience.

Some weeks ago John Dunlap, the superintendent of the Atlantic and Pacific tea store, on Court-street, Brooklyn, was taken by the police to the bedside of his dying wife, on the top floor of No. 80 Bergen-street.

RED BANK, N.J., May 5.--The election to-day was a Waterloo for the saloon party. The entire temperance ticket was elected by a large majorlty. The temperance people had wagons and stages out to gather in the voters. Five hundred and fifty-seven votes were cast, 60 more than at any previous election.

The long-discussed plan for the financial relief of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad has been finally agreed upon by the persons in control of the property. According to the plan the coupons on the first mortgage bonds will be funded for three years.

The Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad Company has applied to the Stock Exchange to have the balance of its general mortgage bonds placed on the regular list. This will make a total of $3,700,000, a portion of which was listed on April 12.

BOSTON, May 5.--The Presidents of the National and other banks of Boston held their monthly banquet at Young's Hotel this evening, having as their guest ex-Controller of the Currency Knox. Only brief speeches were made.

TROY, N.Y., May 5.--At West Troy tonight all is bustle and excitement among the canal men. This is really the starting point of the Erie and Champlain Canal, and boats from NewYork and down the river are brought to this place. One hundred and fifty loaded canal-boats bound North and West are ready for locking through at midnight.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 5.--Christian Hamaker was found dead in a stable of the Black Horse Hotel, Elizabethtown, this morning. He was about 45 years of age and unmarried.

BALTIMORE, May 5.--The General Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of the United States, including delegates from Africa and Hayti, assembled in this city today. The body comprises nearly 300 members, representing 41 annual Conferences.

BANGOR, Me., May 5.--A communication has been published from William King, City Liquor Agent, in regard to the workings of the prohibitory law, which will only help to increase the opposition to the proposed constitutional amendment.

One of the most exciting and interesting races this season between eight-oared shells took place yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River. Two crews composed of members of the Freshman class of Columbia College, one from the mines and the other from the arts, competed for the honors.
Justice Cullen, sitting in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday handed down a decision dissolving the injunction obtained by Charles H. Martin, the proprietor of a "bucket shop," ...

RICHMOND, Va., May 5.--Carter W. Loutham, one of Mahone's Presidential Electors, was indicted by the Grand Jury of the Criminal Court here, to-day, for a violation of the State civil service law, passed by the last Democratic Legislature.

In September, 1883, Mr. James Hann was the possessor of a fine blonde beard of which he was very proud. One evening in that month he entered the saloon of Henry Holmes, at No. 404 Van Brunt-street, Brooklyn, with some friends.

VICKSBURG, Miss., May 5.--On Saturday night a difficulty occurred at Davenport's store, at Prairie Mer Rouge, La., in which Manuel Jennings was killed and several others were wounded. Pistols only were used in the fight, which was a drunken row.

ANNISTON, Ala., May 5.--Miss Lula Eggleston passed through here to-day in charge of Detective Fleischman, of Atlanta, on her way home to Washington City. She left home several weeks ago on account of some domestic disagreement, and was followed by the detective to ...

Aldermen Wendel, Sheils, Finck, Grant, and Farley were yesterday appointed a committee of the Board of Aldermen to extend "the courtesies of the board," whatever that may mean, to the siamese Embassy. "I regret extremely," said Alderman Farley, when his name ...

The will of the late William H. Fogg was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office on Saturday. Mr. Fogg gives to his wife, Elizabeth, $1,000,000, upon condition that she accept the money in lieu of dower in all real estate possessed by him at the time of his death, the house ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 5.--The differences between the iron manufacturers and the Amalgamated Association have assumed such a phase that a strike seems almost inevitable after the 1st of June.
WASHINGTON, May 5, 1884. Representative Stewart, of Texas, has prepared a bill providing for the appointment of three ...
ALBANY, N.Y., May 5.--The Assembly Ways and Means Committee submitted to-night an important resolution regarding taxation, which was adopted. It reads as follows:

The demand for gold for shipment abroad has been rather light during the past eight or ten days. The active demand for standard silver dollars, which promised at one time to be very large, has almost ceased.

CINCINNATI, May 5.--The College Hill Railway Company have made a large purchase of steel rails, deliverable in September, and its officers announce their intention of changing the gauge of the road from the narrow to the standard and extending it either to Richmond or Carmel.

While President Arthur's personal judgment, as expressed last September after his return from the West, would lead him to appoint officers for the Territories from residents of the Territories in which the appointments are to be made, and the House Committee on Territories reported a bill to limit the President's choice, ...

Mrs. Lydia C. Cocks fanned herself and Miss Ella Totten for six hours yesterday while the hearing in her suit against Mr. Cassius H. Read and Dr. Sussdorf dragged wearily along before Referee Dunning. The Referee was very anxious that the case should proceed as quickly as possible.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5.--A human head was found today in the Wissahickon Creek, hear the place where the trunk of a body, supposed to be that of Frederick Stahl, was picked up last March.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5.--The Rev. C.H. Harris, of Belmont, Allegany County, in this State who was brought to the State Insane Asylum; in this city, a few days ago, died to-day.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 5.--The contents of one of the cartridges found last week beneath the Provincial Parliament Buildings have been analyzed and proved to be dualin, a stronger explosive than dynamite.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 5.--The clergy and many residents of this city are greatly exercised by the exposure to-day of fraud practiced upon them by an alleged ex-Catholic priest. A man representing himself as Dr. F. Von Badenfeld, an ex-Catholic priest, born and educated in Austira, came to this city several weeks since, and registered at the Hotel Brunswick.

The firm of Henry I. Hart Co., upholsterers, at No. 39 Union-square, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to Ellis S. Yates, a lawyer, at No. 4 Warren-street. Of the preferred creditors the following are secured:

ASSOUAN, May 5.--Two thousand refugees have reached this place from Korosko and more are coming in daily. The evacuation is proceeding quietly at that place, Col. Duncan having charge of the troops. Refugees who left Khartoum before it was invested by the Mahdi are expected here within a few days.

CINCINNATI, May 5.--A special to the Commercial Gazette from Youngstown, Ohio, says: "John Good, a farmer living near Morgantown, was mortally wounded last night by an unknown assassin who came on horseback to his house and shot him through his bedroom window while he was asleep beside his wife. No clue to the assassin has been found."

BOSTON, May 5.--The suit of Marie Booth, daughter of the late Junius Brutus Booth, against Agnes Booth, to recover part of the property left by her father, has been compromised. The terms have not been made public.

The annual report of the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern Railroad just issued makes the following showing for 1883: Gross earnings, $2,863,555 37; expenses, $1,968,177; net earnings, $895,378 37.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 5.--Dr. Edward Seigle, of Newton, N.C., committed suicide at Lowesville, near this city, yesterday, by taking laudanum.
The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution limiting the height of dwelling-houses in streets and avenues, 60 feet wide or ...

When the Asbury-Methodist Episcopal Church was in Greene-street, almost 10 years ago, it was the custom of the members to live up to the old practices of Methodism, and to shout responses to those parts of the service which appealed the more strongly to their feelings or judgment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5.--James P. Scott, Anna D. Scott, and Miriam D. Bickley, Executors of the will of the late Thomas A. Scott, formerly President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, to-day filed a bill in equity against the Union Contract Company, of this State, of which Gen. William J. Palmer was a Director.

The excitement caused by the elopement of Miss Fanny Swallenberg and Mr. Walter Burden, of Dutch Kills, Long Island City, had scarcely subsided when yesterday afternoon it was announced that Mrs. Antonio Jackoman, a married lady, residing in Third-street, Hunter's Point, had left for parts unknown with a young man who occupied a furnished room in her house.

A meeting of the American Agricultural Association was held yesterday at Cooper Institute to discuss the most fitting place for a great national yearly fair, under the auspices of the association. The attendance was not large. M. Fulford, of Maryland, was elected Chairman.
UKIAH, Cal., May 5.--Two masked highwaymen Stopped the Cloverdale stage to-day and took the mail and the Wells, Fargo Co. treasure-box. The value of the contents is unknown.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 5.--The Spring race meeting of the Nashville Blood Horse Association was continued to-day. The weather was warm and the attendance very good. The track was heavy.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5.--At about 10 o'clock this morning Martin Mahon, one of the oldest and best known expressmen in the city, fell through a hatchway at the warerooms of ...

The Third Army Corps had a reunion at Sieghortner's, No. 32 Lafayette-place, last evening, to commemorate its twenty-first anniversary. Covers were laid for 50. Major Barclay Fassett presided, and among those present were Gen. J. Watts De Peyster, Gen. C.K. Graham, Major John M. Cooney, Gen. Gershom Mott, and Col. E.H. Ropes.

NORFOLK, Va., May 5.--This afternoon the First Regiment, colored volunteers, celebrated the anniversary of its organization by a parade, in which visiting colored companies from Petersburg joined. When preparing for dress parade, Major Palmer, commanding, ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 5.--The Marine Department has sent an officer to St. John, Newfoundland, to procure a suitable vessel for Hudson Bay service. It is probable that the expedition will reach the straits about the beginning ...

The visiting Siamese royalty saw nothing of New-York yesterday but the budding foliage in Madison-square from the windows of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and a hurried view they got of Broadway from a carriage as they were whirled off to the Pennsylvania Railroad station after dinner.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, May 5.--An unusually heavy thunder-storm, accompanied by much wind and lightning, struck the city at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Two black clouds united over the river, about a mile below the bridge, and dropped to the earth in Keator's lumber-yard, utterly demolishing a shed 150 by 50 feet long.

The vastness and importance of the annexed district weighs heavily upon the mind of Alderman Fullgraff, who represents that territory in the Board of Aldermen, and he believes that his colleagues do not appreciate his domain.

The New-Yorks, for the fourth time in succession, were the victors yesterday, winning their second game with the Detroits. They were puzzled somewhat by the deceptive curves of Shaw, the left-handed pitcher of the visiting team, but what they lacked in strength at the ...

Wall-street men are looking forward with some interest to the outcome of the meetings to be held to-day of the stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company and the New-York Elevated Railroad Company.
BOSTON, Mass., May 5.--Henry S. Hovey was to-night elected Commodore of the Eastern Yacht Club in place of Commodore Pickman resigned.

UTICA, N.Y., May 6.--Charles Lepper and William Dietz, of Herkimer, 12 and 14 years old, respectively, left their homes yesterday for a fishing trip along the Mohawk. At 4 P.M. Dietz was found in convulsions.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 5.--Commodore Steere, of Cornell University Navy, announced to-day the 'Varsity four-oared crew, and the selection of the oarsmen has met with general approval by the students and friends of the university.

There was a lively time in one of the saloons of Mount Vernon, Westchester County, on Saturday night. The announcement that there would be a raffle for a horse, at $1 a chance, drew quite a room full.

Petitions to Congress are circulating in that portion of the city lying between Seventieth-street and the Harlem River praying for an appropriation sufficient to cover the cost of such addition to the carrier force employed at Stations K and L as will secure a more prompt and speedy delivery of letters.

The Field Civil Code comes up for consideration in the Senate to-day, but is likely to get very little consideration on its merits. Most of the Senators have been asked their opinion as to the advisability of adopting this codification of the civil law of the State, but few of them ...

CITY OF MEXICO, May 5, via Galveston.-- The twenty-second anniversary of the defeat of the French army at Puebla was celebrated here to-day with much display. Five thousand soldiers, with department clerks, Government officials, and scbools marched in procession throughout the city. Fire-works are abundant to-night. Many strangers are in the city.

One by one the walkers who are entitled to a share of the gate money in the recent contest at Madison-Square Garden dropped into the building yesterday in search of the gentlemen who have charge of the proceeds. They were unable to gain any information. All of them, however, were satisfied that the money was in responsible hands, and said that they had no cause for alarm.
MOBILE, Ala., May 5.--The malady of Joseph E. Murrell, Jr., who was buried here this afternoon, was one of the strangest known to science. He was subject to terrible convulsions when asleep only.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Court of Claims today decided that Gen. M.C. Meigs is entitled to compensation at the rate of $10 a day as Superintendent of the new Pension Building in addition to his regular salary as an officer on the retired list of the army.

BOSTON, May 5.--In the matter of the failure of the Shaw Brothers to-day Judge Field made an interlocutory order that the report of the Assignee be filed on or before June 24. This was the disposition that a majority of the creditors desired.

Shipping Commissioner Charles C. Duncan, whose extortions have been called to public attention by THE TIMES, was yesterdar made the subject of a thorough castigation, administered in an opinion by Judge Wallace in the United States Circuit Court. Duncan recently presented one of his peculiarly fashioned bills for audit.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in the important case of The Pacific Railroad Company of Missouri, appellant, vs. The Missouri Pacific Railway Company, C.K. Garrison, Jay Gould, et al.--

LONDON, May 5.--The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "There are prospects of a good wheat crop. The trade in foreign wheat off stands is dull. There is but little business in off-coast cargoes.

The discovery recently made by the Board of Health that coffee-dealers in this city and Brooklyn are supplying the market with unground and unroasted coffee colored by the use of arsenic, lead, Prussian blue, lampblack, soapstone, and charcoal, has been followed by the publication of interesting admissions made by men engaged in the trade.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 5.--Thomas Simmons, a coal miner, living at Turtle Creek, 15 miles east of this city, was lodged in jail to-day, charged with having murdered his mother-inlaw, a Mrs. Dexter, who lived with him.

The Grand Jury for the May term was sworn in yesterday by Chief Clerk Sparks, in the Court of General Sessions, and the charge was delivered by Recorder Smyth. The jury is composed as follows: Abram M. Kirby, Secretary of the Continental Fire Insurance Company, No. 102 Broadway, ...

RALEIGH, N.C., May 5.--In the municipal elections to-day in Raleigh, Newbern, Asheville, Greensborough, Tarborough, Durham, Goldsborough, Greenville, and other towns in the State the Democrats were successful in all, in some instances making large gains.

When the steam-ship England, of the National Line, arrived at her dock yesterday morning an officer of the steam-boat squad was directed to summon a Bellevue Hospiral ambulance, as a cabin passenger was insane. He was taken to the Pavilion for the Insane.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--The first annual session of the American Climatological Association, which was begun in this city on Saturday, was continued to-day at the Georgetown Medical College building. About 20 physicians, members of the association, were present, and the session was presided over by Dr. F.I. Knight, of Boston.

Although the too easily depressed Mr. DINGELY, of Maine, declared that the free ships amendment to the Shipping bill "sounded the death knell" of that interesting measure, it is quite probable that some bill of moderate practical benefit to the shipping trade may yet be passed by the present Congress.

CHICAGO, May 5.--The Cattle received during Sunday and to-day numbered 6,000 head; same time last week 4,954 head. To-day was a fairly satisfactory market day. A healthy, strong demand existed, and with a very moderate run of stock the prevalent feeling was firm, despite the rather unfavorable tone of dispatches from the East.

The Assembly special committee continued its investigation of the Police Department yesterday, the session being devoted almost entirely to the defense offered by the police. Col. Bliss sat with ex-Judge Horace Russell watching the interests of his clients, but he took little active part in conducting the examination. Chairman Roosevelt and Assemblymen Erwin and ...

BOSTON, May 5.--It is reported from Nantucket that the Hon. Charles O'Conor is quite ill.

A dispatch from St. Paul, published yesterday, said that George B. Hulme, recently appointed Receiver of the Yellowstone National Park Improvement Company by a Wyoming court, did not believe that the appointment of a Receiver in New-Jersey, secured by Rufus ...

The General Term of the Superior Court, in an opinion written by Judge Freedman and concurred in by Judge O'Gorman, has reversed the judgment of Dr. C. Fayette Taylor and another against the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company and the Manhattan Railway Company.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the American Copyright League will be held this week to discuss the advisability of urging prompt action on the bill for international copyright now pending before Congress. It is expected that an active movement of this kind will ...
LONDON, May 5.--The Ceylon Company, (limited,) No. 27 Clements-lane, Lombard-street, of this city, has failed. It owed the Oriental Bank, which failed on Saturday, $2,000,000.

John A. Connolly, of Illinois, who was nominated last week for Solicitor of the Treasury, will decline the office. His name was used without his knowledge, Senators Cullom and Logan being chiefly instrumental in inducing the President to nominate him.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5.--Sunday afternoon dredge No. 2, belonging to Patrick Smith, and in charge of Thomas Murphy, left this port for the Black River in tow of the tugs Charles Henry and N.P. Sprague.
In the Court of General sessions, yesterday, Eliza Porret, of No. 54 West Thirty-firststreet, who was convicted of violation of the excise law, was arraigned for sentence, before Judge Gildersleeve.

According to the last financial statement of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company the earnings of that corporation are decreasing. The net earnings for March, l884, were $67,700 less than the net earnings for March,1883. From July 1, last year, to April 1, the gross earnings were $4,156,000, an increase of $336,200 over the gross earnings of the corresponding period of the previous year. POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 5.--This was a red letter day for the Salvation Army of this city. It included a reception of Major Moore and staff, of Brooklyn, a "tea fight" in the Young Men's Christian Association Building, a parade, a presentation of colors, and a hallelujah wedding, also "dare devil meetings," participated in by "Devil Teasers."

NYACK, N.Y., May 5.--To-day the Commissioners of Excise for the town of Orangetown met in this village. ROCHESTER, May 5.--Information was received in this city this morning of a rumored, and, if true, most important, change in the management of the Ontario Southern Railroad, in which a number of Rochester men have been prominently interested.

Mallory Co. state that their steam-ship the Lampasas, which left Pier No. 2o East River at 4 P.M. on April 26, arrived off the Galveston bar at 1:45 Saturday morning. Her actual time was 6 days, 9 hours, and 45 minutes, including a delay of 4 hours and 30 minutes at Key West. This is the fastest time on record between Galveston and New-York.

Although some of the watchers for the transatlantic steam-ship State of Florida cheerfully hold to the opinion that the vessel is all right and that she will eventually come into port, bringing her passengers with her, there is good reason to believe that she has met with serious disaster, if not wreck.

Notice was sent to the Stock Exchange yesterday of the proposed increase of the capital stock of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company from $20,000,000 to $23,500,000, by the issue, on June 10, of 35,000 new shares of $100 each.

LONDON, May 5.--The Observer expresses astonishment that the steam-ship City of Rome did not follow up the information which it received from the sailing vessel that reported having some of the crew of the State of Florida on board and attempt to elicit further facts. It says the importance of the matter would justify even a little delay in the passage.
LONDON, May 6.--Official advices tend to confirm reports that the garrison and inhabitants of Berber have accepted favorable conditions offered by El Mahdi.

A crude burlesque of that bright, spirited trifle, "Barbe-Bleue," was given last night at the Bijou Opera-house. The French piece, done here several years ago by Irma, Aujac, and a clever company, is perhaps almost forgotten now.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 6.--Last Winter a law was passed authorizing the location of a new insane asylum, and south-west Iowa towns, by pooling, had a provision in the bill locating it in that part of the State. Atlantic Clarinda, and Red Oak were the contestants.
Mr. R. G. Morris's new melodrama, "The Pulse of New-York," will be presented at the Star Theatre on Saturday night.

BOSTON, May 6.--The Boston correspondent of the Marine Bank is the Everett National, to which it owes less than $125,000. The Atlantic National Bank of this city, having funds of the Marine Bank, the Everett attached them this afternoon and brought suit in the United States Circuit Court for $200,000.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 6.--The fifth day of the Spring meeting of the Nashville Blood Horse Association was favored with good weather, a stiff track and a very good attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 6, 1884. At the meeting of the Senate Committee on Finance this morning an agreement was reached that the Trade-dollar bill should be reported adversely, but not until after another meeting of the committee. In the meantime Senator Sherman will draw up an adverse report, which will be passed upon by the committee next week.
The merchants of the United States would be very glad to increase their trade with the merchants of the Spanish-American Republics.

Mr. Thomas White, member of the Parliament, of Canada, who came to this city as a delegate from the Montreal Board of Trade to the opening exercises of the new Produce Exchange building, speaking to a TIMES reporter last evening, in reference to Canadian affairs, said:
Neptune will be a pleasant planet to dwell in, on some accounts, when in the progress of ages he becomes fit for the abode of animate life.

The annual Spring reception of the American Museum of Natural History was held yesterday. A very large number of invitations were sent out, but on account of the rainy weather the attendance was only fair.

Holders of Anglo-Americans who have not recovered from the scare of the threatened competition of the Bennett-Mackay cable will be grieved to hear that a scheme for crossing the Atlantic by another telegraph line is exciting...

Alice Gertrude Crawford, a pretty little brunette, about 17 years old, was taken into Inspector Byrnes's room at Police Head-quarters yesterday by Detectives Ruland and Frink and handed over to her mother, Mrs. J. W. Crawford, of Chelsea, Mass.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 6.--The School Directors of Lancaster County met in convention in this city to-day, and elected Milton J. Brecht County Superintendent. The Directors of Lancaster City District met this evening and elected Prof. R.K. Buehrle City Superintendent.

The facts published in THE TIMES on Saturday in regard to dangerous adulteration of coffee were emphasized yesterday in reports made to the sanitary authorities. Dr. Cyrus Edson, Chief of the Secret Sanitary Division, estimates from analyses of samples of the doctored...

GALVESTON, Texas, May 6.--Capt. Du Jay, of the American schooner Rebecca, of Galveston, in a communication to the News, relates a story of outrage and imprisonment at the hands of the Mexican authorities at the port of Tampico on Feb. 17 last.
Startling rumors swept through Wall-street at noon yesterday, and for an hour messengers from banking houses and broker's offices were kept flying hither and thither in quest of accurate information.

The Senate Committee on Cities seems to be unable to agree upon a report, and there is likelihood that its protracted investigation of the Department of Public Works may prove fruitless so far as legislative action is concerned.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--A general court-martial has been appointed to meet at David's Island, NewYork Harbor, on May 31, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the trial of such prisoners as may be brought before it.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 6.--In March last Book-keeper Crocker, of the Commercial Bank, was robbed of $2,700 while making his exchanges. Later in the day C. H. Simmons and George Watson were arrested on the railroad cars at a...

Since Jan. 1, 1880, Mr. Fish has purchased real estate at a cost of about $2,500,000. This sum inlcudes a half-interest in the Booth's Theatre property and real estate in Madison-avenue, in the neighborhood of One Hundred and Twentieth and One Hundred and Twentyfirst streets, which was bought jointly with Ferdinand Ward at a cost of $912,500.
Rain prevented the New-York-Chicago and Brooklyn-Washington games of base-ball yesterday. Should the weather prove favorable these clubs will play to-day.

DETROIT, Mich., May 6.--The elopement of Miss Lillian Whitney, a young lady of 20, daughter of C. J. Whitney, proprietor of one of the opera-houses in this city, a large music-dealer, and a wealthy citizen, with her father's coachman, is the sensation of the hour.

It is painful to remark that fears have been expressed in the Methodist Conference now sitting at Philadelphia that elections to the Episcopate may be managed in the manner familiar to us all in secular politics.

CHICAGO, May 6.--"Ben Butler for President" is inscribed on the banner of the National Anti-Monopolists, who have opened headquarters at the Briggs House, and are getting ready for the National Convention, which is to meet in Chicago on May 14.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 6.--A second contested election suit was brought to-day, the appeal in this case being to the Court of Common Pleas.

LONDON, April 19.--"You may say what you like about our English weather," said Charles Reade to a friend during his last days at Cannes, "but I prefer it to the cruel, treacherous climate of this place.

The six successful pedestrians in the recent six-day race assembled in the Ashland House yesterday at noon and received their winnings. Fitzgerald got $8,438 15 as his share of the gate money and $980 of the stakes.

LONDON, May 6.--The African International Association has given Capt. Stephens, an Irishman, who was expelled from the British Army, a commission to enlist 2,000 hussars for service in the Congo Country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 6.--Generally better feeling prevailed along the docks to-day, no outbreaks of any kind occuring. Police and specials are still keeping guard to prevent any possible trouble, and all gatherings of men along the wharves are speedily broken up.

TUBBERCURRY, May 6.--In the hearing to-day of the Invincible case Thomas Moran testified that he and two other members of the Invincibles had been promised 10 apiece if they would murder a parish official.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6.--When the limited express east reached Enon Station, 40 miles west of this city, this morning, a young man, who said his name was George Baker, was discovered lying on the truck of the second car, between the wheels and the floor of the car.

BOSTON, Mass., May 6.--The largest gun over constructed in this country was cast to-day at the South Boston Iron Works in fulfilment of a contract with the Government.
The steam-ship Elbe, which was due last Saturday, but did not arrive until Monday night, met with an accident to her machinery, which delayed her considerably.

Mr. W. W. MacFarland, a lawyer of this city, has sued the Banque Franco-Egyptienne and the Quintera Mining Company in the Supreme Court on a claim for $500,000. SCRANTON, Penn., May 6.--Jown W. Atken, a young druggist of Carbondale, this county, was married six years ago to Miss Morss, the daughter of G. L. Morss, a wealthy tanner, who did business in the same city.

After listening to speeches from Messrs. Vance, Voorhees, Call, Plumb, and Bayard, the Senate to-day defeated the amendment to the Shipping bill offered by Mr. Vest, providing for free ships and free material for the construction of ships.

CHICAGO, May. 6.--A dispatch to the Times from Springfield, Mo., says: "The calaboose at North Springfield was burned early yesterday morning. The occupants, Clem Cecil, (white,) and Green Johnson, (colored,) were taken out alive, but Cecil was so badly burned that he died during the afternoon.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., May 6.--W. H. Meyer, of this city, who several years ago was convicted of embezzling a large amount from the Niagara County National Bank, of this city, and who has served a term in prison at Auburn on a charge of forgery, was to-day sued in the Supreme Court for the amount of the deficiency by the bank, and a judgment was obtained against him for $15,600.

Emil Unger, a commission dealer, of No. 237 East Tenth-street, accused Alfred S. Armuth, a young Hungarian, of No. 19 Chrystie-street, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, of at tempting to extort money by written threats.

Congress has been asked to loan $1,000,000 to the managers of the New-Orleans Exposition. It has been discovered that the money subscribed by stockholders and contributed by the city--which will probably amount in all to $1,100,000--will not be sufficient to provide accommodations for the exhibitors who have already applied for space.

At a meeting of the passenger agents yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office it was resolved to adhere to the present contract respecting the emigrant business, and Commissioner Pierson was authorized to prepare and forward the necessary notice to the various steamship companies.

The second edition of Mr. S. E. Dawson's "Study of the Lord Tennyson's Poem, the Princess," just issued in Montreal, Canada, contains the following letter from Lord Tennyson regarding the views and interpretations advanced:

The Hudson County Board of Freeholders held their organization meeting yesterday. The board is in the control of the Republicans, and the majority members had decided to displace County Counsel Lippincott with Counselor Cornelius S. See and County Superintendent Ed Burns with Architect L. H. Broome.

Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday directed the jury in the trial of the suit brought by the Merchants' National Bank against the Leather Manufacturers' National Bank to find a verdict for the plaintiff. The suit grew out of one of the forgeries committed by William C. Barrett.

The eighth annual bench show of dogs, under the auspices of the Westminster Kennel Club, was opened in the Madison-Square Garden yesterday morning. The pouring rain and chilly atmosphere had a serious effect upon the attendance, but, nevertheless, a goodly number of people were present in the course of the day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6.--The large grain and flour firm of Ballard Ballard, the largest and best known in the city, failed to-day, with liabilities placed at $160,000, only nominal assets, and uncertain security of the liabilities.

The sale of Jersey cattle belonging to Mr. Theodore A. Havemeyer, which took place yesterday at Mr. Havemeyer's stables in West Seventy-second-street, was very well attended, although very few animals brought fancy prices.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 6.--Secretary Vrooman, of the State Committee, is preparing for distribution among the four delegates at large to Chicago and their alternates complete lists of all the national delegates from this State and their alternates.

Up to 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon 22 of the 101 pawnbrokers in this city had paid to the Mayor's Marshal their annual license fee of $500 each. All of the licenses expire during this or next week, as do those of second-hand dealers, intelligence...

LOCKPORT, N. Y., May 6.--The Excise Board of Lockport, for the first time in three years, favors the issuing of licenses, and has set the following rates for the coming year: Hotel license, $75; ale and beer, $75; storekeepers', $50;...

The New-York Produce Exchange Glee Club celebrated the opening day of the new Exchange building by a dinner at Clark's, on Twenty-third-street, last evening. Covers were laid for 40, and an elaborate menu was served. After the dinner speech-making and singing were ...
LONDON, May 6.--The Hamburg-American Line steam-ship Westphalla, Capt. Frauzen, from New-York April 20, for Hamburg, has passed the Lizard.

Miss Ella G. Campbell, 16 years old, the only daughter of Capt. Campbell, of the First Precinct, Brooklyn, died suddenly a few minutes after 12 o'clock yesterday morning, while attending a party at the house of Mrs. George C. Jacobs, No. 22 Lee-avenue.
ST. LOUIS, May 6.--Charlie Ford, who committed suicide this morning at Richmond, Mo., was suffering from consumption and had been taking morphine for a long time to allay the pain of another disease.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 6.--Frank Page, a veteran railroad contractor, died suddenly here, this morning, of heart disease. Mr. Page was one of the best-known and most popular men in this part of the State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6.--Pittsburg Democrats are happy over the defeat of the Morrison Tariff bill in the House to-day, and are talking of nobody but Randall for the first place on the national ticket. A Randall Club will be organized to-night and others later on. For second place the names of Voorhees and Rosecrans are most frequently mentioned. Everybody gives Randall the lion's share of the credit for defeating the Morrison scheme.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6.--Eugene G. Woodward, Treasurer of the Presbyterian Board of Publication, has left the city, it is reported, leaving a shortage in his accounts of $10,000. About eight days ago he left home ostensibly to go to New-York.

The finger-bowl is tabooed, according to a society journal. Many years ago a distinguished French gourmet declared that the use of this appliance indicated ignorance of the art of eating, since an accomplished master of the knife and fork would never soil his fingers at the table.

In adjoining rooms on the second floor of No. 71 Broadway, yesterday noon, a score of stockholders of the Manhattan and New-York Elevated Railway Companies met to vote upon a proposition to cancel the merger agreements between the two roads.

ALBANY, May 6.--The Senate Committee on Cities is having a hard time over its report of the investigation into the Department of Public Works.

The details of the plan for the financial relief of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway are now being communicated to the persons interested with a view to getting a legal expression for or against the propositions.

Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, ordered a decree yesterday sustaining the right of the Atlantic Milling Company, of St. Louis, to the exclusive use of the word "Champion" as a trade-mark for its flour against George B. Robinson and Rowland Co.
KINGSTON, N. Y., May 6.--The Sons of Veterans, Department of New-York, at their division encampment this afternoon, elected the following officers: Colonel--J. B. Stanton, of...
GLASGOW, May 6.--Dunlop Twaddell, jute spinners, have suspended. Liabilities, $450,000.

WHEELING, West Va., May 6.--It appears that the conference of Republicans and Greenbackers, at Grafton, Saturday last, failed to bring about a satisfactory agreement, and the formal amalgamation of the two parties is yet to be accomplished.
The Academy of Music Directors held a meeting at the office of Mr. William B. Dinsmore yesterday afternoon to consider the subject of a consolidation of interests with the Metropolitan Opera-house.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 6.--The steamer Faraday, with the Bennett-Mackay cable on board, has arrived in Dover Bay. A telegram from Torbay reports the sea smooth and the weather fine, with a north-west breeze.

After enjoying a tumultuous frolic in heir old building, the members of the Produce Exchange assembled in the main room of their new structure yesterday and listened with attentive interest to the opening exercises. Before leaving the old home brief addresses were made by President Herrick and James McGee, and a parting song was sung by the glee club.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 6.--A criminal prosecution was commenced here to-day before Justice Gleason, which will probably lead to a long and important law suit, and eventually to the division of that branch of the Methodist Church known as the African Methodist Episcopal...

WASHINGTON, May 6.--The Swaim court of inquiry met this morning and organized. Gen. Swaim was present with his counsel, Representative Calkins and Judge Johnston, and Mr. Bateman, who made the charges against Gen. Swaim, also appeared accompanied by his attorney, Mr. Jeff Chandler.

MOBILE, Ala., May 6.--The revenue officers have had a close watch upon the steamer Dictator, which sailed this afternoon for Tampa. They state that a revenue cutter is cruising to overhaul the steamer.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--Morrison's Tariff Reduction bill is dead--killed by a DemocraticRepublican alliance--and the result is already selfishly and ungracefully pronounced by the minority party in the House to be a Republican victory.

Gen. N. N. Halsted was accidentally killed at the Market-street station of the Penn sylvania Railroad between 4 and 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had been in this city on business, and took the 4 o'clock "fast line" for Newark.

Shortly before her death Mrs. Yancey had set apart an adequate sum to erect a monument over the grave of her husband, and at her death Mr. Goodloe Yancey took charge of the work, selected the design for the monument, and contributed most liberally to its erection.

BOSTON, Mass., May 6.--Statements are made here in contradiction of the reports current in Wall-street regarding Union Pacific. It is denied that Mr. Fred L. Ames has sold his stock, but on the contrary it is declared positively ...
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 6.--It is reported that Sid Higgins, Postmaster at Baxter, has absconded with $3,000 belonging to his partner.

ALBANY, May 6.--In the Court of Appeals today the following decisions were handed down: In reapplication of Eureka Basin Warehouse, of General and Special Terms reversed and proceedings dismissed, with costs.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 6.--There was a good attendance at the Assignee's sale of blood stock belonging to James A. Grinstead, at Lexington...

SPRING PLACE, Ga., May 6.--Andrew Roland was under sentence of death on April 25 for a murder committed three years ago, but sentence was suspended awaiting action by the Supreme Court. On the night of April 30 all the prisoners in Murray Jail escaped, including the sentenced murderer.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 6.--Rosa St. Clair Leland, manager of the Leland Opera-house and a well-known actress, has been granted a divorce from her husband, Charles E. Leland the wellknown hotel man. The case was tried before a Referee in private.

ALBANY, May 6.--The Court of Appeals this morning denied the motion for a reargument in the case of James Irving, the well-known politician of New-York, who has been convicted of an aggravated assault and sentenced to a long term of imprisonment.

California cannot be said to have occupied any distinctive place in national politics till the Chinese question developed itself. Previous to that date we rather accepted the political law from the East. We did not hurrah very loudly till we got the cue. We always became enthusiastic at the right time, but usually a little behind.

ROME, May 6.--The Grand Orient of Italy publishes an ironical reply to the encyclical letter of the Pope with regard to Freemasonry. It says that the Vatican is free to lament that it is deprived of the temporal power to oppose the Divine Providence which has decreed its downfall, and that it may rave with respect to what it considers the abasement of human dignity.

The only important business on which the Democrats in the House of Representatives have been engaged for the past five months came to naught yesterday through the defection of 41 men of their own party.
FULTON, Mo., May 6.--Advices from Hatton Post Office, a small village in the northwestern part of this (Callaway) county, state that Ham Patterson, a negro, was taken from his bed...

BALTIMORE, May 6.--Woodside and Morgan, the bicycle riders, who left New-York on Thursday for the Pacific coast, arrived here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. They left Lancaster yesterday at 9:32 A.M., arrived at Hellam, Penn., at 1:20 P. M., where they stopped an hour for...

As so much has been printed and said about Senator Plumb's alleged connection with a cattle syndicate in the Indian Territory, we feel it but proper to publish herewith the following letter, which, it will be observed, was written only a few days since:

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 6.--Sir Charles Tupper has resigned his position in the Cabinet and his seat in Parliament owing to ill-health, but has retained the post of High Commissioner. He will start for England on May 24.
The Stock Exchange Committee on Stock List has been asked to investigate certain matters relative to the bonds of the Denver and Western Railroad Company.
ALBANY, May 6.--A move was made on the Bureau of Elections bill to-day which took the John J. O'Brien Republicans and Democrats completely by surprise.
Mr. J. S. Moore was gazing somewhat ruefully at a telegram that he had received when a TIMES reporter dropped into his office on Broadstreet at 5 o'clock last evening.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, May 6.--The Guion Line steamer Nevada, Capt. Bremner, from New-York April 29, for Liverpool, came in collision on May 3 with the steamer Romano, Capt. Mitchell, from Hull, bound for Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6.--The General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church reassembled this morning, Bishop Henry W. Warren in the chair. The report of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society stated that the past four years had been the most successful period in its history. Missionary leaflets have been distributed among women of the church and in auxiliary societies.

ALBANY, May 6.--The lobbies of the Senate were thronged during the evening by agents of Jacob Sharpe and of the cable company, who were anxious to find out what the Governor was going to do with the Surface Railroad bill.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6.--The annual meeting of the Pittsburg, Virginia and Charleston Railroad Company was held in this city today and the following officers elected: President --J. N. Dubarry, of Philadelphia; Secretary and...

COLUMBUS, Ga., May 6.--John B. Franklin, a white man, in Russe County, Ala., not satisfied with his wife's cooking, took a red-hot iron and branded her. He has been given a year in the penitentiary, and a fine of $1,000.

The Executive Committee of the Independent Republican Conference Committee met yesterday afternoon at No. 160 Broadway. There were present Carl Schurz, George Walton Green, A. T. White, Ethan Allen Doty, Frederick W. Holls, D. H. Chamberlain, of South Carolina, and David Allerton.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--The report of the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections in relation to the Copiah branch of the investigations which that committee has been making, bearing the signatures of the five Republican members of the committee, was laid before the Senate this afternoon.

The annual Spring show of the NewYork Horticultural Society was opened yesterday morning at Nos. 26 and 28 West Twentyeighth-street. In spite of the disagreeable state of the weather there was a steady flow of visitors...
Capt. John R. Atkinson, who is well known in shipping circles in this city, left his residence, No. 48 Douglass-street, Brooklyn, early Sunday evening and has not been heard of since.

ALBANY, Ga., May 7.--Mrs. Missouri Wright, wife of Richard Wright, went to the office of Dr. Osborn, dentist, to have some teeth extracted. Fearing that the operation would be painful, she asked for chloroform. Dr. Osborn called in Dr. Hillsman to administer the drug.

QUEBEC, May 7.--The steamer Titania, having on board 24 of the passengers and crew of the lost steamer State of Florida, passed here at 9 o'clock this evening. The third officer, Mr. Allan, of the State of Florida, was on board and gave a full account of the accident.
LONDON, May 7.--Two English railway companies discharged 2,500 of their employes and reduced the salaries of their clerks 10 per cent, owing to the depression of trade.

The Secretary of the Treasury has issued a circular to customs officers modifying the regulations of the department governing the transportation of Canadian merchandise through the United States under the treaty of Washington, so as to accord with the regulations of the Canadian Government on the same subject.

ASHLAND, Penn., May 7.--The number of cases of small-pox is still increasing, and fears are entertained that it will become epidemic. James Mulhern, at whose house an Italian girl was found suffering from the disease, was arrested to-day. Mulhern and his wife resisted the officers, assaulted Father Patterson, and threw an axe at Dr. Carr. Mulhern was held in $3,000 bail. There is great excitement in the town.

Because of the failure of the New-York firm of which ex-President Grant is a member, the Senators listened with interest to-day to a bill which was introduced by Mr. Edmunds authorizing the President to place Gen. Grant upon the retired list of the army.
The Commandery of the State of NewYork of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States held a meeting last evening at Delmonico's, Gen. Alexander Shaler, Commander, presiding.

FLORENCE, S.C., May 7.--Another abortive attempt was made last night to arrest Boggan Cash, the Chesterfield outlaw and murderer, who has recently tried to create the impression that he had escaped into Canada, but who has really been quartered at his father's house.
A judgment debtor in the City Court was to have been examined on Monday in supplementary proceedings, with a view to ascertaining ...

More than a thousand canine voices wailed aloud in Madison-Square Garden yesterday morning, when the canines found that the weather, instead of being composed of the traditional sunshine and balm of May, was still a howling blast of driven rain and north-east wind.
The Union Home and School for the Education of Children of Volunteers was organized in 1862 for the benefit of destitute children of volunteer soldiers.

The close of the drill season was marked by the Twenty-second Regiment last evening with special ceremonies. The command was formed with 10 companies, of 16 files front, leaving plenty of men for guard duty.

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 7.--The American squadron in the Mediterranean has arrived at Tenedos. From there Rear Admiral Baldwin, the commEnder, telegraphed to Gen. Wallace, American Minister to Turkey, that it was his intention to come to Constantinople.

COVINGTON, Ky., May 7.--The funeral of Bishop Toebbe took place to-day from St. Mary's Cathedral. Archbishop Elder was the celebrant of the solemn pontifical mass, and Bishop Dwenger, of Fort Wayne, preached the funeral sermon. There were present also Bishops Chatard, of Vincennes; Watterson, of Columbus; McCloskey, of Louisville; Richter, of Grand Rapids; Gilmour, of Cleveland; Rademacher, of Nashville, and Borgess, of Detroit.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 7.--Telegrams received here say that dispatches have been sent over the wires announcing the safe arrival of the special train bearing railroad officers and others at the city of Mexico.

BERLIN, May 7.--The proposed bill in regard to explosives, which has been submitted to a committee of the Bundesrath, makes it necessary to obtain police authority in order to make, sell, import, or possess explosives.

ST. LOUIS, May 7.--The Cotton-seed Crushers' Convention to-day discussed insurance methods only, and elected officers for the ensuing year as follows: J.W. Allison, Jackson, Tenn., President; E. Urquhard, Pine Bluffs, VicePresident, and Joseph H. Dugg, New-Orleans, La., Secretary and Treasurer.
Mrs. Arnold Weichert, of No.101 Wallstreet, hired one of the cheap cabs yesterday morning to take her from the corner of Cortlandt-street and Broadway to the Barclay-street ferry.

The Democrats are not happy over the results of yesterday's session on the Tariff bill. Even Mr. Randall's retainers are doubtful about the wisdom of having sacrificed themselves to gratify the Pennsylvania leader.
The Joint Executive Committee of the Passenger Department met yesterday to talk over the proposed new contract. Twenty-five railroads were represented.

Mr. GLADSTONE is much indebted to the tactical mistake committed by the Conservative leaders in Parliament in not making the cause of GORDON that of their party and fixing upon the Government the odium of failing to relieve him.
A verdict for $10,000 damages was rendered yesterday by a jury in the Supreme Court, in favor of Charles S. Hine and against the NewYork Elevated Railroad Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 7.--At the meeting of the Common Council last night Princeton's most eminent divines and prominent citizens were present with petitions for the abolition of the liquor traffic.

LYONS, N.Y., May 7.--For years the assessed valuation of railroad property in Wayn County has been discussed and disputed upon by every Board of Supervisors and the assessments in the different towns have been so widely apart as to attract wide attention.
MONROE, Ga., May 7.--Henry Walton's wife paid such attention to Nathan Baily as to arouse the jealousy of her husband. The latter attacked Baily, and was so badly cut up that death is inevitable.

CHICAGO, May 7.--Prices for Cattle were quite as satisfactory to salesmen as the day before. The receipts were again light--surprisingly so--but because of a lack of encouragement in Eastern advices the demand was smaller than usual, so that despite the limited proportions of the supply no important advance resulted.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 7.--The Alice Oates Opera Company arrived in this city from Braddocks, Penn., to-day without funds. The company is stranded here, and Mrs. Oates and her husband, Manager Watkins, have gone east.

WASHINGTON, May 7.--The Committed of the American Medical Association appointed to report upon the resolution for securing more competent medical and sanitary service on transoceanic passenger vessels, through the Chairman, Dr. A.N. Bell, made a report at this morning's session of the association.
The second series of "Wagner concerts" at the Metropolitan Opera-house was inaugurated last evening by a performance of fragments of "Tannhauser."

HAZLEHURST, Miss., May 7.--E.B. Wheeler, who was indicted on May 2 by the Grand Jury of Copiah County for the murder of Print Matthews, at the election polls, last November, was arraigned for trial this morning, before Judge T.J. Wharton, of the Circuit Court.

To-night and to-morrow evening there will be a sale at the Leavitt Art Galleries, 817 Broadway, of more than 100 pictures by modern European and American artists, belonging to Mr. H.L. Dousman, of St. Louis.
It now appears that the steam-ship State of Florida was not sunk by a dynamite explosion, contrived or accidental. Nor was she run down by an iceberg prematurely, as was suspected by some persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 7.--It has been learned to-day that the Marine Bank, of New York, about three weeks ago tried to negotiate a loan of $500,000 from the Nevada Bank, of this city. The managers declined to make the loan.

MITCHELL, Dakota, May 7.--John Schmidt, a wealthy farmer, living a few miles from here, has been murdered, the supposed object being robbery. The murderers tried to destroy all traces of the crime by burning the body, but the bloody bedding caused suspicion, and finally the half-burned bones and flesh were found.
WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., May 7.--The members of the City Council of Williamsport were to-day indicted by the Grand Jury for maintaining a nuisance in failing to keep up the streets of the city.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 7.--There was a very good attendance at the races to-day. The weather was cool and the track in fair condition.
Among the many rumors which were current yesterday was one that Albert Fink, the Trunk Line Commissioner, had resigned.

CLEVELAND, May 7--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lake Shore Road was held in the Lake Shore Building, closing at 12:30 o'clock to-day. Mr. Chauncey M. Depew was made Chairman, C.P. Leland Secretary, and Messrs. Daniel P. Eells, E.B. Hale, and S. T. Everett Supervisors of Election.

WASHINGTON, May 7.--Fitz John Porter's crse was discussed in the House to-day, the relief bill being taken from the Speaker's table as it passed the Senate. Whatever hope there might have remained in the breasts of its opponents that it would be beaten was dispelled when Keifer took the floor to lead the opposition.

RICHMOND, Va., May 7.--The trial of School Superintendent Carter M. Louthan, one of Mahone's national delegates, indicted for engaging in politics, in violation of the law recently passed, took place in the Hustings Court today. Louthan was found guilty and fined $50, in addition to the forfeiture of his office. He will appeal from the decision and test the constitutionality of the statute.

For the past three days Edward Keeler, who is reputed to be one of the most skillful and desperate burglars in the country, has been on trial in the Kings County Court of Sessions for the robbery of Eldin B. Hayden's jewelry store, on Fulton-street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, May 7.--The Prohibitory State Convention held here to-day was of about the usual character of such gatherings. The leading spirits were those who have figured in prohibitory conventions for the past 10 years, and there was the usual violent abuse of the Republican Party and vigorous declamation in favor of "constitutional prohibition."

HAVANA, May 7.--The civil guard having jurisdiction at Cienfuegos recently made a raid on a small band of bandits, and succeeded in dispersing them. The guard captured much booty, including documents addressed to Aguero.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7.--Capt. H.N. Adams, Assistant Superintendent of the Government canal-works here, was instantly killed this afternoon. His steam yacht got caught between a wharf-boat and the steamer Guthrie, and Adams's head became fastened between the roof of the boat and the wharf, and his neck was broken.
Roswell A. Parmenter, of Troy, is at the St. Denis Hotel. Gov. Eli H. Murray, of Utah, is at the St. James Hotel.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 7.--A special to the Times-Democrat from St. Joseph says that backwater continues to rise slowly. Hopes of planting this year are abandoned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7.--When the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church reassembled this morning, Bishop Cyrus D. Foss was in the chair.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 7.--John Bokody, Jr., last night robbed his employer, L.W. Cline, jeweler, of over $1,000 worth of jewelry and $70 in money. Bokody is 19 years old, dark complexion, and 5 feet 11 inches in height.

ATLANTA, May 7.--Decatur is a quaint old town which 40 years ago refused to allow a railroad station to be built there, and thus made way for Atlanta, six miles further up. The Town Council, passed two ordinances last night, one forbidding children to play marbles on the streets and the other allowing to run at large.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7.--The Allentown Iron-works were sold here to-day for $50,000, and were bought in for the bondholders, who will proceed to reorganize the company and put the works in operation again. The mortgage under which the sale was ordered amounts to $500,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 7.--The little hamlet of Otisco ranks third among the higest inhabited points in New-York State and is said to be equally high in its standard of morality.
The rain yesterday again postponed the games of base-ball that were to have been played in this city.
The breach of promise suit of Mary Sullivan against William Hayes was tried in the Richmond County Circuit Court on Tuesday, before Judge Pratt, and resulted in a verdict of $500 for the woman.

Another afternoon was spent by the senate to-day in discussing the Shipping bill without reaching a decision, but before adjourning the Senators agreed that the measure should be put upon its passage at 5 o'clock to-morrow.
DES MOINES, Iowa., May 7.--J.J. Smart has filed his answer to the application of his wife for divorce on the ground of cruelty.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 9.--James Seymour Coleman was hanged at 11:30 o'clock this morning. His neck was broken, the snap being distinctly heard. He died without a struggle, and met his fate without the slightest agitation. When the noose was being adjusted he said to the Sheriff, "Don't fix it too tight; it will be tight enough directly." In 20 minutes he was cut down and his body taken to the Potter's Field by his brother.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--John A. Walsh was before Mr. Springer's committee again to-day. He referred to alleged libelous articles in various newspapers against him and said: "The National Republican, of Washington, that published a libel, was owned by Bliss, Chandler, and other friends. The spectacle was presented of an Administration organ attacking a Government witness. Bliss, with 29 other friends of Arthur, put up $1,000 each, in the interest of the paper."

DUBLIN, May 13.--The authorities have received anonymous threats that attempts would be made to destroy the Nelson column. In consequence of this the column is constantly guarded by the police.

Walter S. Johnston, of Philadelphia, was yesterday appointed Receiver of the Marine National Bank, Controller of the Currency Cannon having become satisfied from reports of Examiner Scriba that the institution was insolvent. The Controller stated that the appointment was made after careful consideration and with full appreciation of the intricate questions involved in the failure of the bank.

The woman whom Dr. Isaac D. Edrehi shot in the dining-room of her house in East Seventy-first-street. Monday night, was able to sit up in bed yesterday, and Dr. Morris had no doubt that she would recover. The bullet struck her in the back, inflicting a not very serious wound.

NANTUCKET, Mass., May 13.--Charles O'Conor died at his residence in Nantucket yesterday at 3:25 P.M. On his return from NewYork about three weeks ago he contracted a severe cold, from which it was evident he could not recover. On the following Wednesday he called Dr. Edward Roth, a graduate of Bellevue College, whom he informed he did not care to live.

ALBANY, N. Y., May 13.--The veto of the Arcade Railroad bill, which the Governor sent to the Senate at the evening session, was the greatest surprise that this or any Legislature has been treated to in many years. No one anticipated a veto of this bill, which passed both houses almost unanimously.

HAVANA, May 12.--The British mail steamer from St. Thomas May 5 brings San Domingo dispatches to May 1. According to these a bill establishing free trade with the United States has been passed by the Dominican Congress. It is again asserted that negotiations are proceeding with Washington for the lease of Samana Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--No one seems to be greatly concerned about the tariff bill introduced by Mr. Hewitt. Wells, who first testified on behalf of Miss Hill in the Sharon divorce case, and when called by the defense later swore that their first testimony was false, were arrested last evening for perjury, with the bail in each case fixed at $20,000.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--A fire broke out in Willard's Hotel this morning at 10:30 o'clock. It started in the lower part of the building, ran up the coal elevator, and spread out under the tin roof.

OMAHA, May 13.--As a number of men were returning on the cars this morning from a prize-fight, which occurred near Clear Creek, Neb., a fight took place, during which revolvers were discharged. CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 14.--Michael Far rey, his wife, and Mrs. Gorman, Farrey's sister, were fatally poisoned yesterday by drinking a medicine prepared by an old woman for rheumatism. They died to-day in great agony.

WHEELING, West Va., May 14.--The south eastern portion of Jackson County was visited by a severe tornado and rain-storm yesterday which inflicted heavy damage to the property of the farmers living along the creek bottoms. Several dwellings and bridges and numerous barns are reported washed away, and considerable injury has been done to orchards and newly planted fields. The house of a farmer named Frankland was carried off and Charles Frankland was drowned.

ALBANY, May 14.--The Journal Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $140,000. The Directors are Joseph W. Drexel, formerly of Drexel, Morgan Co.; Senator James Arkell, W.J. Arkell, Vice-President of the Mount McGregor Railroad, and John A. Sleicher. W. J. Arkell is President of the company and Mr. Sleicher Secretary and Treasurer.

BRADFORD, Penn., May 14.--The financial crash in Wall-street had a most demoralizing effect upon the petroleum market, which fell off nearly 10 cents below the opening price. From the opening the market was weak and panicky.
CAIRO, May 14.--The rebellion is rapidly approaching Dongola. The telegraph line is cut beyond Debbah, a short distance south of Dongola.

DANIELSVILLE, Ga., May 14.--While Mrs. Nelms, a 16-year-old wife, was sitting to-day upon the river bank fishing, with a 2-months old baby in her lap, she suddenly exclaimed, "I've caught a perch!" and fell over dead.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 14.--The suspen sion of the North-western Manufacturing and Car Company caused the failure to-day of Rice Whiting, bankers and brokers, who have been in business in this city for many years.

ST. LOUIS, May 14.--St. Louis bankers claim that unless a general panic should result, the New-York disasters will not have any effect here. The failure of Donnell, Lawson Simpson, however, will, it is feared, cause considerable inconvenience in Western Missouri, Kansas, Iowa, Nebraska, and all the new West, as fully 20 percent. of the banking institutions there banked with the suspended house. It is not believed, however, that they will suffer serious loss.

BLOSSBURG, Penn., May 14.--T.C. Her bert, of Covington, Ky., failed to appear at the championship ten-mile running race, for $1,000, between him and William Steele, the champion. The latter ran alone against the record, beating the best American three-mile time. Time--15:11.

CHICAGO, May 14.--At 10:30 o'clock last night Alderman Michael Gaynor was shot, probably fatally, by James Dacey, an emplouye in the County Agent's office. The shooting took place in the saloon at No. 87 South Halsted-street. Dacey greeted Gaynor with the remark: "Won't you shake hands," and then came forward and extended his hand toward Gaynor, but the latter, without accepting it said: "Come, take a drink, Dacey."

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., May 14.--The city election held to-day resulted in a clean Republican sweep. William L. Proctor is elected Mayor by 203 majority over the present Mayor, William J. Averell, who was elected last year by 30 majority. The Supervisors, Alderman, and Recorder are all Republicans.

The ominous clatter of the Chairman's gavel brought business to a stand-still in the Stock Exchange at 10:16 o'clock yesterday morning. Members pushed their way eagerly up to the rostrum. Exciting rumors had been afloat in the Street for fully half an hour before the opening of the Exchange, and most of the brokers felt that disaster was impending. None, however, anticipated the wild and demoralizing panic that stirred Wall-street within the next two hours.

Fish's Assignee, against the firm of Grant Ward. Several creditors and attorneys interested in the settlement of affairs listened to what he had to say.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 14.--A west bound freight train came in collision with a gravel train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, one mile east of Cornellsville, between 9 and 10 o'clock this morning, and a number of laborers, variously estimated at from 12 to 20, were killed and many injured. The scene of the disaster is on a sharp curve just west of the Speer sand-works.

HAVERHILL, Mass., May 14.--A pretended blind man, calling himself Charles Adams, a discharged soldier, came here yesterday as a pencil peddler and engaged Adolphus Brecite, 10 years old, to lead him about the city, and then kidnaped the boy, taking him away on the 4 o'clock train in the afternoon.
A number of prominent insurance men arrived yesterday to attend the annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, to be held in the Boreel Building to-day.

Andrews, of Sumter, S.C., who will be 93 years of age on the 4th of next July, has entered upon a foot journey to Boston, but a few other facts in connection with the Captain and his remarkable undertaking have not been made public.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 15.--The Picayune was this morning printed on paper made of bagasse, the refuse of the sugar-cane fibre.

SLIGO, May 15.--The hearing in the case of Fitzgerald and others, charged with being Invincibles and with having conspired to murder landlords, was resumed at Tubbercurry to-day.

Chief-Justice Sedgwick, of the Superior Court, has decided that the Rev. Dr. John P. Newman is only the acting Pastor of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church, and as such is not entitled to participate in the business meetings of the members of the church.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 15.--This was the last day of the Spring meeting of the Kentucky Association. There was a very good attendance. The weather was fine and cool, but the track was a little stiff.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 15.--The anniversary exercises of Yale Theological Seminary were held in Battell Chapel this morning. Twenty-six theologians passed successful examinations and received diplomas.

DETROIT, Mich., May 15.--Representatives of Scottish capitalists are now in Detroit trying to ascertain about how much will be saved from the financial wreck of the extensive lumber companies. The Michigan pine is largely involved in the muddle.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--A Deputy Sheriff to-day attached a property at Tenth and Prior streets, this city, that belongs to Mrs. Della I. Parnell, the mother of the Irish leader. The writ was issued by Mrs. Mary R. Stewart, Mrs. Parnell's sister-in-law, in a suit to recover $6,000 for alleged breach of covenant in connection with a stock transaction. Both ladies live at Bordentown, N.J.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 15.--The Mississippi River Commission reached this city yesterday by steam-boat from St. Louis, and, after comparing notes and agreeing upon the features of their report, have disbanded and started for their homes.
